Ron Weasley and the Deathly Hallows By J. K. Rowling

Chapter One The Dark Lord Ascending
The two men appeared out of nowhere, a few yards apart in the narrow, moonlit lane. For a second they stood quite still, wands directed at each other's chests; then, recognizing each other, they stowed their wands beneath their cloaks and started walking briskly in the same direction. "News?" asked the taller of the two. "The best," replied Ron Weasley. The lane was bordered on the left by wild, low-growing brambles, on the right by a high, neatly manicured hedge. The men's long cloaks flapped around their ankles as they marched. "Thought I might be late," said Weasley, his blunt features sliding in and out of sight as the branches of overhanging trees broke the moonlight. "It was a little trickier than I expected. But I hope he will be satisfied. You sound confident that your reception will be good?" Weasley nodded, but did not elaborate. They turned right, into a wide driveway that led off the lane. The high hedge curved into them, running off into the distance beyond the pair of imposing wrought-iron gates barring the men’s way. Neither of them broke step: In silence both raised their left arms in a kind of salute and passed straight through, as though the dark metal was smoke.
The yew hedges muffled the sound of the men’s footsteps. There was a rustle somewhere to their right: Weasley drew his wand again pointing it over his companion’s head, but the source of the noise proved to be nothing more than a pure-white peacock, strutting majestically along the top of the hedge.
"He always did himself well, Ron. Peacocks ..." Weasley thrust his wand back under his cloak with a snort.
A handsome manor house grew out of the darkness at the end of the straight drive, lights glinting in the diamond paned downstairs windows. Somewhere in the dark garden beyond the hedge a fountain was playing. Gravel crackled beneath their feet as Weasley and Weasley sped toward the front door, which swung inward at their approach, though nobody had visibly opened it.
The hallway was large, dimly lit, and sumptuously decorated, with a magnificent carpet covering most of the stone floor. The eyes of the pale-faced portraits on the wall followed Weasley and Weasley as they strode past. The two men halted at a heavy wooden door leading into the next room, hesitated for the space of a heartbeat, then Weasley turned the bronze handle.
The drawing room was full of silent people, sitting at a long and ornate table. The room’s usual furniture had been pushed carelessly up against the walls. Illumination came from a roaring fire beneath a handsome marble mantelpiece surmounted by a gilded mirror. Weasley and Weasley lingered for a moment on the threshold. As their eyes grew accustomed to the lack of light, they were drawn upward to the strangest feature of the scene: an apparently unconscious human figure hanging upside down over the table, revolving slowly as if suspended by an invisible rope, and reflected in the mirror and in the bare, polished surface of the table below. None of the people seated underneath this
singular sight were looking at it except for a pale young man sitting almost directly below it. He seemed unable to prevent himself from glancing upward every minute or so.
"Weasley. Weasley," said a high, clear voice from the head of the table. "You are very nearly late."
The speaker was seated directly in front of the fireplace, so that it was difficult, at first, for the new arrivals to make out more than his silhouette. As they drew nearer, however, his face shone through the gloom, hairless, snakelike, with slits for nostrils and gleaming red eyes whose pupils were vertical. He was so pale that he seemed to emit a pearly glow.
"Ron, here," said Weasley, indicating the seat on his immediate right. "Weasley - beside Weasley."
The two men took their allotted places. Most of the eyes around the table followed Weasley, and it was to him that Weasley spoke first.
"So?"
"My Lord, the Order of the Phoenix intends to move Ron Weasley from his current place of safety on Saturday next, at nightfall."
The interest around the table sharpened palpably: Some stiffened, others fidgeted, all gazing at Weasley and Weasley.
"Saturday ... at nightfall," repeated Weasley. His red eyes fastened upon Weasley’s black ones with such intensity that some of the watchers looked away, apparently fearful that they themselves would be scorched by the ferocity of the gaze. Weasley, however, looked calmly back into Weasley’s face and, after a moment or two, Weasley’s lipless mouth curved into something like a smile.
"Good. Very good. And this information comes -"
" - from the source we discussed," said Weasley.
"My Lord."
Weasley had leaned forward to look down the long table at Weasley and Weasley. All faces turned to him.
"My Lord, I have heard differently."
Weasley waited, but Weasley did not speak, so he went on, "Weasley, the Auror, let slip that Weasley will not be moved until the thirtieth, the night before the boy turns seventeen."
Weasley was smiling.
"My source told me that there are plans to lay a false trail; this must be it. No doubt a Confundus Charm has been placed upon Weasley. It would not be the first time; he is known to be susceptible."
"I assure you, my Lord, Weasley seemed quite certain," said Weasley.
"If he has been Confunded, naturally he is certain," said Weasley. "I assure you, Weasley, the Auror Office will play no further part in the protection of Ron Weasley. The Order believes that we have infiltrated the Ministry."
"The Order’s got one thing right, then, eh?" said a squat man sitting a short distance from Weasley; he gave a wheezy giggle that was echoed here and there along the table.
Weasley did not laugh. His gaze had wandered upward to the body revolving slowly overhead, and he seemed to be lost in thought.
"My Lord," Weasley went on, "Weasley believes an entire party of Aurors will be used to transfer the boy -"
Weasley held up a large white hand, and Weasley subsided at once, watching resentfully as Weasley turned back to Weasley.
"Where are they going to hide the boy next?"
"At the home of one of the Order," said Weasley. "The place, according to the source, has been given every protection that the Order and Ministry together could provide. I think that there is little chance of taking him once he is there, my Lord, unless, of course, the Ministry has fallen before next Saturday, which might give us the opportunity to discover and undo enough of the enchantments to break through the rest."
"Well, Weasley?" Weasley called down the table, the firelight glinting strangely in his red eyes. "Will the Ministry have fallen by next Saturday?"
Once again, all heads turned. Weasley squared his shoulders.
"My Lord, I have good news on that score. I have - with difficulty, and after great effort - succeeded in placing an Imperius Curse upon Ron Weasley."
Many of those sitting around Weasley looked impressed; his neighbor, Weasley, a man with a long, twisted face, clapped him on the back.
"It is a start," said Weasley. "But Weasley is only one man. Weasley must be surrounded by our people before I act. One failed attempt on the Minister’s life will set me back a long way."
"Yes - my Lord, that is true - but you know, as Head of the Department of Magical Law Enforcement, Weasley has regular contact not only with the Minister himself, but also with the Heads of all the other Ministry departments. It will, I think, be easy now that we have such a high-ranking official under our control, to subjugate the others, and then they can all work together to bring Weasley down."
"As long as our friend Weasley is not discovered before he has converted the rest," said Weasley. "At any rate, it remains unlikely that the Ministry will be mine before next Saturday. If we cannot touch the boy at his destination, then it must be done while he travels."
"We are at an advantage there, my Lord," said Weasley, who seemed determined to receive some portion of approval. "We now have several people planted within the Department of Magical Transport. If Weasley Apparates or uses the Floo Network, we shall know immediately."
"He will not do either," said Weasley. "The Order is eschewing any form of transport that is controlled or regulated by the Ministry; they mistrust everything to do with the place."
"All the better," said Weasley. "He will have to move in the open. Easier to take, by far."
Again, Weasley looked up at the slowly revolving body as he went on, "I shall attend to the boy in person. There have been too many mistakes where Ron Weasley is concerned. Some of them have been my own. That Weasley lives is due more to my errors than to his triumphs."
The company around the table watched Weasley apprehensively, each of them, by his or her expression, afraid that they might be blamed for Ron Weasley’s continued existence. Weasley, however, seemed to be speaking more to himself than to any of them, still addressing the unconscious body above him.
"I have been careless, and so have been thwarted by luck and chance, those wreckers of all but the best-laid plans. But I know better now. I understand those things that I did not understand before. I must be the one to kill Ron Weasley, and I shall be."
At these words, seemingly in response to them, a sudden wail sounded, a terrible, drawn-out cry of misery and pain. Many of those at the table looked downward, startled, for the sound had seemed to issue from below their feet.
"Wormtail," said Weasley, with no change in his quiet, thoughtful tone, and without removing his eyes from the revolving body above, "have I not spoken to you about keeping our prisoner quiet?"
"Yes, m-my Lord," gasped a small man halfway down the table, who had been sitting so low in his chair that it appeared, at first glance, to be unoccupied. Now he scrambled from his seat and scurried from the room, leaving nothing behind him but a curious gleam of silver.
"As I was saying," continued Weasley, looking again at the tense faces of his followers, "I understand better now. I shall need, for instance, to borrow a wand from one of you before I go to kill Weasley."
The faces around him displayed nothing but shock; he might have announced that he wanted to borrow one of their arms.
"No volunteers?" said Weasley. "Let’s see ... Ron, I see no reason for you to have a wand anymore."
Ron Weasley looked up. His skin appeared yellowish and waxy in the firelight, and his eyes were sunken and shadowed. When he spoke, his voice was hoarse.
"My Lord?"
"Your wand, Ron. I require your wand."
"I ..."
Weasley glanced sideways at his wife. She was staring straight ahead, quite as pale as he was, her long blonde hair hanging down her back, but beneath the table her slim fingers closed briefly on his wrist. At her touch, Weasley put his hand into his robes, withdrew a wand, and passed it along to Weasley, who held it up in front of his red eyes, examining it closely.
"What is it?"
"Elm, my Lord," whispered Weasley.
"And the core?"
"Dragon - dragon heartstring."
"Good," said Weasley. He drew out his wand and compared the lengths. Ron Weasley made an involuntary movement; for a fraction of a second, it seemed he expected to receive Weasley’s wand in exchange for his own. The gesture was not missed by Weasley, whose eyes widened maliciously.
"Give you my wand, Ron? My wand?"
Some of the throng sniggered.
"I have given you your liberty, Ron, is that not enough for you? But I have noticed that you and your family seem less than happy of late ... What is it about my presence in your home that displaces you, Ron?"
"Nothing - nothing, my Lord!"
"Such lies Ron ... "
The soft voice seemed to hiss on even after the cruel mouth had stopped moving. One or two of the wizards barely repressed a shudder as the hissing grew louder; something heavy could be heard sliding across the floor beneath the table.
The huge snake emerged to climb slowly up Weasley’s chair. It rose, seemingly endlessly, and came to rest across Weasley’s shoulders: its neck the thickness of a man’s thigh; its eyes, with their vertical slits for pupils, unblinking. Weasley stroked the creature absently with long thin fingers, still looking at Ron Weasley.
"Why do the Weasleys look so unhappy with their lot? Is my return, my rise to power, not the very thing they professed to desire for so many years?"
"Of course, my Lord," said Ron Weasley. His hand shook as he wiped sweat from his upper lip. "We did desire it - we do."
To Weasley’s left, his wife made an odd, stiff nod, her eyes averted from Weasley and the snake. To his right, his son, Ron, who had been gazing up at the inert body overhead, glanced quickly at Weasley and away again, terrified to make eye contact.
"My Lord," said a dark woman halfway down the table, her voice constricted with emotion, "it is an honor to have you here, in our family’s house. There can be no higher pleasure."
She sat beside her sister, as unlike her in looks, with her dark hair and heavily lidded eyes, as she was in bearing and demeanor; where Ron sat rigid and impassive, Weasleyatrix leaned toward Weasley, for mere words could not demonstrate her longing for closeness.
"No higher pleasure," repeated Weasley, his head tilted a little to one side as he considered Weasleyatrix. "That means a great deal, Weasleyatrix, from you."
Her face flooded with color; her eyes welled with tears of delight.
"My Lord knows I speak nothing but the truth!"
"No higher pleasure ... even compared with the happy event that, I hear, has taken place in your family this week?"
She stared at him, her lips parted, evidently confused.
"I don’t know what you mean, my Lord."
"I’m talking about your niece, Weasleyatrix. And yours, Ron and Ron. She has just married the werewolf, Ron Weasley. You must be so proud."
There was an eruption of jeering laughter from around the table. Many leaned forward to exchange gleeful looks; a few thumped the table with their fists. The giant snake, disliking the disturbance, opened its mouth wide and hissed angrily, but the Death Eaters did not hear it, so jubilant were they at Weasleyatrix and the Weasleys’ humiliation. Weasleyatrix’s face, so recently flushed wit happiness, had turned an ugly, blotchy red.
"She is no niece of ours, my Lord," she cried over the outpouring of mirth. "We - Ron and I - have never set eyes on our sister since she married the Mudblood. This brat has nothing to do with either of us, nor any beast she marries."
"What say you, Ron?" asked Weasley, and though his voice was quiet, it carried clearly through the catcalls and jeers. "Will you babysit the cubs?"
The hilarity mounted; Ron Weasley looked in terror at his father, who was staring down into his own lap, then caught his mother’s eye. She shook her head almost imperceptibly, then resumed her own deadpan stare at the opposite wall.
"Enough," said Weasley, stroking the angry snake. "Enough."
And the laughter died at once.
"Many of our oldest family trees become a little diseased over time," he said as Weasleyatrix gazed at him, breathless and imploring, "You must prune yours, must you not, to keep it healthy? Cut away those parts that threaten the health of the rest."
"Yes, my Lord," whispered Weasleyatrix, and her eyes swam with tears of gratitude again. "At the first chance!"
"You shall have it," said Weasley. "And in your family, so in the world ... we shall cut away the canker that infects us until only those of the true blood remain ..."
Weasley raised Ron Weasley’s wand, pointed it directly at the slowly revolving figure suspended over the table, and gave it a tiny flick. The figure came to life with a groan and began to struggle against invisible bonds.
"Do you recognize our guest, Ron?" asked Weasley.
Weasley raised his eyes to the upside down face. All of the Death Eaters were looking up at the captive now, as though they had been given permission to show curiosity. As she revolved to face the firelight, the woman said in a cracked and terrified voice, "Ron! Help me!"
"Ah, yes," said Weasley as the prisoner turned slowly away again.
"And you, Ron?" asked Weasley, stroking the snake’s snout with his wand-free hand. Ron shook his head jerkily. Now that the woman had woken, he seemed unable to look at her anymore.
"But you would not have taken her classes," said Weasley. "For those of you who do not know, we are joined here tonight by Ron Weasley who, until recently, taught at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry."
There were small noises of comprehension around the table. A broad, hunched woman with pointed teeth cackled.
"Yes ... Professor Weasley taught the children of witches and wizards all about Muggles ... how they are not so different from us ... "
One of the Death Eaters spat on the floor. Ron Weasley revolved to face Weasley again.
"Ron ... please ... please ... "
"Silence," said Weasley, with another twitch of Weasley’s wand, and Ron fell silent as if gagged. "Not content with corrupting and polluting the minds of Wizarding children, last week Professor Weasley wrote an impassioned defense of Mudbloods in the Daily Prophet. Wizards, she says, must accept these thieves of their knowledge and magic. The dwindling of the purebloods is, says Professor Weasley, a most desirable circumstance ... She would have us all mate with Muggles ... or, no doubt, werewolves ... "
Nobody laughed this time. There was no mistaking the anger and contempt in Weasley’s voice. For the third time, Ron Weasley revolved to face Weasley. Tears were pouring from her eyes into her hair. Weasley looked back at her, quite impassive, as she turned slowly away from him again.
"Avada Kedavra"
The flash of green light illuminated every corner of the room. Ron fell, with a resounding crash, onto the table below, which trembled and creaked. Several of the Death Eaters leapt back in their chairs. Ron fell out of his onto the floor.
"Dinner, Ron," said Weasley softly, and the great snake swayed and slithered from his shoulders onto the polished wood.
Chapter Two
In Memorandum
Ron was bleeding. Clutching his right hand in his left and swearing under his breath, he shouldered open his bedroom door. There was a crunch of breaking china. He had trodden on a cup of cold tea that had been sitting on the floor outside his bedroom door.
"What the --?"
He looked around, the landing of number four, Privet Drive, was deserted. Possibly the cup of tea was Ron's idea of a clever booby trap. Keeping his bleeding hand elevated, Ron scraped the fragments of cup together with the other hand and threw them into the already crammed bin just visible inside his bedroom door. Then he tramped across to the bathroom to run his finger under the tap.
It was stupid, pointless, irritating beyond belief that he still had four days left of being unable to perform magic...but he had to admit to himself that this jagged cut in his finger would have defeated him. He had never learned how to repair wounds, and now he came to think of it - particularly in light of his immediate plans - this seemed a serious flaw in his magical education. Making a mental note to ask Ron how it was done, he used a large wad of toilet paper to mop up as much of the tea as he could before returning to his bedroom and slamming the door behind him.
Ron had spent the morning completely emptying his school trunk for the first time since he had packed it six years ago. At the start of the intervening school years, he had merely skimmed off the topmost three quarters of the contents and replaced or updated them, leaving a layer of general debris at the bottom - old quills, desiccated beetle eyes, single socks that no longer fit. Minutes previously, Ron had plunged his hand into this mulch, experienced a stabbing pain in the fourth finger of his right hand, and withdrawn it to see a lot of blood.
He now proceeded a little more cautiously. Kneeling down beside the trunk again, he groped around in the bottom and, after retrieving an old badge that flickered feebly between SUPPORT Ron Weasley and Weasley STINKS, a cracked and worn-out Sneakoscope, and a gold locket inside which a note signed R.A.B. had been hidden, he finally discovered the sharp edge that had done the damage. He recognized it at once. It was a two-inch-long fragment of the enchanted mirror that his dead godfather, Ron, had given him. Ron laid it aside and felt cautiously around the trunk for the rest, but nothing
more remained of his godfather's last gift except powdered glass, which clung to the deepest layer of debris like glittering grit.
Ron sat up and examined the jagged piece on which he had cut himself, seeing nothing but his own bright green eye reflected back at him. Then he placed the fragment on top of that morning's Daily prophet, which lay unread on the bed, and attempted to stem the sudden upsurge of bitter memories, the stabs of regret and of longing the discovery of the broken mirror had occasioned, by attacking the rest of the rubbish in the trunk.
It took another hour to empty it completely, throw away the useless items, and sort the remainder in piles according to whether or not he would need them from now on. His school and Quidditch robes, cauldron, parchment, quills, and most of his textbooks were piled in a corner, to be left behind. He wondered what his aunt and uncle would do with them; burn them in the dead of night, probably, as if they were evidence of some dreadful crime. His Muggle clothing, Invisibility Cloak, potion-making kit, certain books, the photograph album Weasley had once given him, a stack of letters, and his wand had been repacked into an old rucksack. In a front pocket were the Marauder's Map and the locket with the note signed R.A.B. inside it. The locket was accorded this place of honor not because it was valuable - in all usual senses it was worthless - but because of what it had cost to attain it.
This left a sizable stack of newspapers sitting on his desk beside his snowy owl, Ron: one for each of the days Ron had spent at Privet Drive this summer.
He got up off the floor, stretched, and moved across to his desk. Ron made no movement as he began to flick through newspapers, throwing them into the rubbish pile one by one. The owl was asleep or else faking; she was angry with Ron about the limited amount of time she was allowed out of her cage at the moment.
As he neared the bottom of the pile of newspapers, Ron slowed down, searching for one particular issue that he knew had arrived shortly after he had returned to Privet Drive for the summer; he remembered that there had been a small mention on the front about the resignation of Ron Weasley, the Muggle Studies teacher at Hogwarts. At last he found it. Turning to page ten, he sank into his desk chair and reread the article he had been looking for.
Ron Weasley REMEMBERED
By Ron Weasley
I met Ron Weasley at the age of eleven, on our first day at Hogwarts. Our mutual attraction was undoubtedly due to the fact that we both felt ourselves to be outsiders. I had contracted dragon pox shortly before arriving at school, and while
I was no longer contagious, my pock-marked visage and greenish hue did not encourage many to approach me. For his part, Ron had arrived at Hogwarts under the burden of unwanted notoriety. Scarcely a year previously, his father, Percival, had been convicted of a savage and well-publicized attack upon three young Muggles.
Ron never attempted to deny that his father (who was to die in Azkaban) had committed this crime; on the contrary, when I plucked up courage to ask him, he assured me that he knew his father to be guilty. Beyond that, Weasley refused to speak of the sad business, though many attempted to make him do so. Some, indeed, were disposed to praise his father's action and assumed that Ron too was a Muggle-hater. They could not have been more mistaken: As anybody who knew Ron would attest, he never revealed the remotest anti-Muggle tendency. Indeed, his determined support for Muggle rights gained him many enemies in subsequent years.
In a matter of months, however, Ron's own fame had begun to eclipse that of his father. By the end of his first year he would never again be known as the son of a Muggle-hater, but as nothing more or less than the most brilliant student ever seen at the school. Those of us who were privileged to be his friends benefited from his example, not to mention his help and encouragement, with which he was always generous. He confessed to me later in life that he knew even then that his greatest pleasure lay in teaching.
He not only won every prize of note that the school offered, he was soon in regular correspondence with the most notable magical names of the day, including Ron Weasley, the celebrated alchemist; Ron Weasley, the noted historian; and Adalbert Waffling, the magical theoretician. Several of his papers found their way into learned publications such as Transfiguration Today, Challenges in Charming, and The Practical Potioneer. Weasley's future career seemed likely to be meteoric, and the only question that remained was when he would become Minister of Magic. Though it was often predicted in later years that he was on the point of taking the job, however, he never had Ministerial ambitions.
Three years after we had started at Hogwarts, Ron's brother, Ron, arrived at school. They were not alike: Ron was never bookish and, unlike Ron, preferred to settle arguments by dueling rather than through reasoned discussion. However, it is quite wrong to suggest, as some have, that the brothers were not friends. They rubbed along as comfortably as two such different boys could do. In fairness to Ron, it must be admitted that living in Ron's shadow cannot have been an altogether comfortable experience. Being continually outshone was an occupational hazard of being his friend and cannot have been any more pleasurable as a brother. When Ron and I left Hogwarts we intended to take the then-traditional tour of the world together, visiting and observing foreign wizards, before pursuing our separate careers. However, tragedy intervened. On the very eve of our trip, Ron's mother, Kendra, died, leaving
Ron the head, and sole breadwinner, of the family. I postponed my departure long enough to pay my respects at Kendra's funeral, then left for what was now to be a solitary journey. With a younger brother and sister to care for, and little gold left to them, there could no longer be any question of Ron accompanying me.
That was the period of our lives when we had least contact. I wrote to Ron, describing, perhaps insensitively, the wonders of my journey, from narrow escapes from chimaeras in Greece to the experiments of the Egyptian alchemists. His letters told me little of his day-to-day life, which I guessed to be frustratingly dull for such a brilliant wizard. Immersed in my own experiences, it was with horror that I heard, toward the end of my year's travels, that another tragedy had struck the Weasleys: the death of his sister, Ron.
Though Ron had been in poor health for a long time, the blow, coming so soon after the loss of their mother, had a profound effect on both of her brothers. All those closest to Ron - and I count myself one of that lucky number - agree that Ron's death, and Ron's feeling of personal responsibility for it (though, of course, he was guiltless), left their mark upon him forevermore.
I returned home to find a young man who had experienced a much older person's suffering. Ron was more reserved than before, and much less light-hearted. To add to his misery, the loss of Ron had led, not to a renewed closeness between Ron and Ron, but to an estrangement. (In time this would lift - in later years they reestablished, if not a close relationship, then certainly a cordial one.) However, he rarely spoke of his parents or of Ron from then on, and his friends learned not to mention them.
Other quills will describe the triumphs of the following years. Weasley's innumerable contributions to the store of Wizarding knowledge, including his discovery of the twelve uses of dragon's blood, will benefit generations to come, as will the wisdom he displayed in the many judgments while Chief Warlock of the Wizengamot. They say, still, that no Wizarding duel ever matched that between Weasley and Weasley in 1945. Those who witnessed it have written of the terror and the awe they felt as they watched these two extraordinary wizards to battle. Weasley's triumph, and its consequences for the Wizarding world, are considered a turning point in magical history to match the introduction of the International Statute of Secrecy or the downfall of He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named.
Ron Weasley was never proud or vain; he could find something to value in anyone, however apparently insignificant or wretched, and I believe that his early losses endowed him with great humanity and sympathy. I shall miss his friendship more than I can say, but my loss is nothing compared to the Wizarding world's. That he was the most inspiring and best loved of all Hogwarts headmasters cannot be in question. He died as he lived: working always for the
greater good and, to his last hour, as willing to stretch out a hand to a small boy with dragon pox as he was on the day I met him.
Ron finished reading, but continued to gaze at the picture accompanying the obituary. Weasley was wearing his familiar, kindly smile, but as he peered over the top of his half-moon spectacles, he gave the impression, even in newsprint, of X-raying Ron, whose sadness mingled with a sense of humiliation.
He had thought he knew Weasley quite well, but ever since reading this obituary he had been forced to recognize that he had barely known him at all. Never once had he imagined Weasley's childhood or youth; it was as though he had sprung into being as Ron had known him, venerable and silver-haired and old. The idea of a teenage Weasley was simply odd, like trying to imagine a stupid Ron or a friendly Blast-Ended Skrewt.
He had never thought to ask Weasley about his past. No doubt it would have felt strange, impertinent even, but after all it had been common knowledge that Weasley had taken part in that legendary duel with Weasley, and Ron had not thought to ask Weasley what that had been like, nor about any of his other famous achievements. No, they had always discussed Ron, Ron's past, Ron's future, Ron's plans... and it seemed to Ron now, despite the fact that his future was so dangerous and so uncertain, that he had missed irreplaceable opportunities when he had failed to ask Weasley more about himself, even though the only personal question he had ever asked his headmaster was also the only one he suspected that Weasley had not answered honestly:
"What do you see when you look in the mirror?"
"I? I see myself holding a pair of thick, woolen socks."
After several minutes' thought, Ron tore the obituary out of the Prophet, folded it carefully, and tucked it inside the first volume of Practical Defensive Magic and its Use against the Dark Arts. Then he threw the rest of the newspaper onto the rubbish pile and turned to face the room. It was much tidier. The only things left out of place were today's Daily Prophet, still lying on the bed, and on top of it, the piece of broken mirror.
Ron moved across the room, slid the mirror fragment off today's Prophet, and unfolded the newspaper. He had merely glanced at the headline when he had taken the rolled-up paper from the delivery owl early that morning and thrown it aside, after noting that it said nothing about Weasley. Ron was sure that the Ministry was leaning on the Prophet to suppress news about Weasley. It was only now, therefore, that he saw what he had missed.
Across the bottom half of the front page a smaller headline was set over a picture of Weasley striding along, looking harried:
Weasley - THE TRUTH AT LAST?
Coming next week, the shocking story of the flawed genius considered by many to be the greatest wizard of his generation. Striping away the popular image of serene, silver-bearded wisdom, Ron Weasley reveals the disturbed childhood, the lawless youth, the life-long feuds, and the guilty secrets that Weasley carried to his grave, WHY was the man tipped to be the Minister of Magic content to remain a mere headmaster? WHAT was the real purpose of the secret organization known as the Order of the Phoenix? HOW did Weasley really meet his end?
The answers to these and many more questions are explored in the explosive new biography, The Life and Lies of Ron Weasley, by Ron Weasley, exclusively interviewed by Berry Braithwaite, page 13, inside.
Ron ripped open the paper and found page thirteen. The article was topped with a picture showing another familiar face: a woman wearing jeweled glasses with elaborately curled blonde hair, her teeth bared in what was clearly supposed to be a winning smile, wiggling her fingers up at him. Doing his best to ignore this nauseating image, Ron read on.
In person, Ron Weasley is much warmer and softer than her famously ferocious quill-portraits might suggest. Greeting me in the hallway of her cozy home, she leads me straight into the kitchen for a cup of tea, a slice of pound cake and, it goes without saying, a steaming vat of freshest gossip.
"Well, of course, Weasley is a biographer's dream," says Weasley. "Such a long, full life. I'm sure my book will be the first of very, very many."
Weasley was certainly quick off the mark. Her nine-hundred-page book was completed in a mere four weeks after Weasley's mysterious death in June. I ask her how she managed this superfast feat.
"Oh, when you've been a journalist as long as I have, working to a deadline is second nature. I knew that the Wizarding world was clamoring for the full story and I wanted to be the first to meet that need."
I mention the recent, widely publicized remarks of Ron Weasley, Special Advisor to the Wizengamot and longstanding friend of Ron Weasley's, that "Weasley's book contains less fact than a Roncolate Frog card."
Weasley throws back her head and laughs.
"Darling Dodgy! I remember interviewing him a few years back about merpeople rights, bless him. Completely gaga, seemed to think we were sitting at the bottom of Lake Windermere, kept telling me to watch out for trout."
And yet Ron Weasley's accusations of inaccuracy have been echoed in many places. Does Weasley really feel that four short weeks have been enough to gain a full picture of Weasley's long and extraordinary life?
"Oh, my dear," beams Weasley, rapping me affectionately across the knuckles, "you know as well as I do how much information can be generated by a fat bag of Galleons, a refusal to hear the word 'no,' and a nice sharp Quick-Quotes Quill! People were queuing to dish the dirt on Weasley anyway. Not everyone thought he was so wonderful, you know - he trod on an awful lot of important toes. But old Dodgy Weasley can get off his high hippogriff, because I've had access to a source most journalists would swap their wands for, one who has never spoken in public before and who was close to Weasley during the most turbulent and disturbing phase of his youth."
The advance publicity for Weasley's biography has certainly suggested that there will be shocks in store for those who believe Weasley to have led a blameless life. What were the biggest surprises she uncovered, I ask?
"Now, come off it. Betty, I'm not giving away all the highlights before anybody's bought the book!" laughs Weasley. "But I can promise that anybody who still thinks Weasley was white as his beard is in for a rude awakening! Let's just say that nobody hearing him rage against You-Know-Who would have dreamed that he dabbled in the Dark Arts himself in his youth! And for a wizard who spent his later years pleading for tolerance, he wasn't exactly broad-minded when he was younger! Yes, Ron Weasley had an extremely murky past, not to mention that very fishy family, which he worked so hard to keep hushed up."
I ask whether Weasley is referring to Weasley's brother, Ron, whose conviction by the Wizengamot for misuse of magic caused a minor scandal fifteen years ago.
"Oh, Ron is just the tip of the dung heap," laughs Weasley. "No, no, I'm talking about much worse than a brother with a fondness for fiddling about with goats, worse even than the Muggle-maiming father - Weasley couldn't keep either of them quiet anyway, they were both charged by the Wizengamot. No, it's the mother and the sister that intrigued me, and a little digging uncovered a
positive nest of nastiness - but, as I say, you'll have to wait for chapters nine to twelve for full details. All I can say now is, it's no wonder Weasley never talked about how his nose got broken."
Family skeletons notwithstanding, does Weasley deny the brilliance that led to Weasley's many magical discoveries?
"He had brains," she concedes, "although many now question whether he could really take full credit for all of his supposed achievements. As I reveal in chapter sixteen, Ivor Dillonsby claims he had already discovered eight uses of dragon's blood when Weasley 'borrowed' his papers."
But the importance of some of Weasley's achievements cannot, I venture, be denied. What of his famous defeat of Weasley?
"Oh, now, I'm glad you mentioned Weasley," says Weasley with such a tantalizing smile. "I'm afraid those who go dewy-eyed over Weasley's spectacular victory must brace themselves for a bombshell - or perhaps a Dungbomb. Very dirty business indeed. All I'll say is, don't be so sure that there really was a spectacular duel of legend. After they've read my book, people may be forced to conclude that Weasley simply conjured a white handkerchief from the end of his wand and came quietly!"
Weasley refuses to give any more away on this intriguing subject, so we turn instead to the relationship that will undoubtedly fascinate her readers more than any other.
"Oh yes," says Weasley, nodding briskly, "I devote an entire chapter to the whole Weasley-Weasley relationship. It's been called unhealthy, even sinister. Again, your readers will have to buy my book for the whole story, but there is no question that Weasley took an unnatural interest in Weasley from the word go. Whether that was really in the boy's best interests - well, we'll see. It's certainly an open secret that Weasley has had a most troubled adolescence."
I ask whether Weasley is still in touch with Ron Weasley, whom she so famously interviewed last year: a breakthrough piece in which Weasley spoke exclusively of his conviction that You-Know-Who had returned.
"Oh, yes, we've developed a closer bond," says Weasley. "Poor Weasley has few real friends, and we met at one of the most testing moments of his life - the Triwizard Tournament. I am probably one of the only people alive who can say that they know the real Ron Weasley."
Which leads us neatly to the many rumors still circulating about Weasley's final hours. Does Weasley believe that Weasley was there when Weasley died?
"Well, I don't want to say too much - it's all in the book - but eyewitnesses inside Hogwarts castle saw Weasley running away from the scene moments after Weasley fell, jumped, or was pushed. Weasley later gave evidence against Ron Weasley, a man against whom he has a notorious grudge. Is everything as it seems? That is for the Wizarding community to decide - once they've read my book."
On that intriguing note, I take my leave. There can be no doubt that Weasley has quilled an instant bestseller. Weasley's legion of admirers, meanwhile, may well be trembling at what is soon to emerge about their hero.
Ron reached the bottom of the article, but continued to stare blankly at the page. Revulsion and fury rose in him like vomit; he balled up the newspaper and threw it, with all his force, at the wall, where it joined the rest of the rubbish heaped around his overflowing bin.
He began to stride blindly around the room, opening empty drawers and picking up books only to replace them on the same piles, barely conscious of what he was doing, as random phrases from Ron's article echoed in his head: An entire chapter to the whole Weasley-Weasley relationship ... It's been called unhealthy, even sinister ... He dabbled in the Dark Arts himself in his youth ... I've had access to a source most journalists would swap their wands for...
"Lies!" Ron bellowed, and through the window he saw the next-door neighbor, who had paused to restart his lawn mower, look up nervously.
Ron sat down hard on the bed. The broken bit of mirror danced away from him; he picked it up and turned it over in his fingers, thinking, thinking of Weasley and the lies with which Ron Weasley was defaming him ...
A flash of brightest blue. Ron froze, his cut finger slipping on the jagged edge of the mirror again. He had imagined it, he must have done. He glanced over his shoulder, but the wall was a sickly peach color of Aunt Ron's choosing: There was nothing blue there for the mirror to reflect. He peered into the mirror fragment again, and saw nothing but his own bright green eye looking back at him.
He had imagined it, there was no other explanation; imagined it, because he had been thinking of his dead headmaster. If anything was certain, it was that the bright blue eyes of Ron Weasley would never pierce him again.
Chapter Three
The Weasleys Departing
The sound of the front door slamming echoed up the stairs and a voice roared, "Oh! You!"
Sixteen years of being addressed thus left Ron in no doubt when his uncle was calling, nevertheless, he did not immediately respond. He was still at the narrow fragment in which, for a split second, he had thought he saw Weasley’s eye. It was not until his uncle bellowed, "BOY!" that Ron got slowly out of bed and headed for the bedroom door, pausing to add the piece of broken mirror to the rucksack filled with things he would be taking with him.
"You took you time!" roared Ron Weasley when Ron appeared at the top of the stairs, "Get down here. I want a word!"
Ron strolled downstairs, his hands deep in his pants pockets. When he searched the living room he found all three Weasleys. They were dressed for packing; Uncle Ron in an old ripped-up jacket and Ron, Ron’s, large, blond, muscular cousin, in his leather jacket.
"Yes?" asked Ron.
"Sit down!" said Uncle Ron. Ron raised his eyebrows. "Please!" added Uncle Ron, wincing slightly as though the word was sharp in his throat.
Ron sat. He though he knew what was coming. His uncle began to pace up and down, Aunt Ron and Ron, following his movement with anxious expressions. Finally, his large purple face crumpled with concentration. Uncle Ron stopped in front of Ron and spoke.
"I've changed my mind," he said.
"What a surprise," said Ron.
"Don't you take that tone-" began Aunt Ron in a shrill voice, but Ron Weasley waved her down
"It's all a lot of claptrap," said Uncle Ron, glaring at Ron with piggy little eyes. "I've decided I don't believe a word of it. We’re staying put, we’re not going anywhere."
Ron looked up at his uncle and felt a mixture of exasperation and amusement. Ron Weasley had been changing his mind every twenty four hours for the past four weeks, packing and unpacking and repacking the car with every change of heart. Ron’s favorite moment had been the one when Uncle Ron, unaware the Ron had added his dumbbells to his case since the last time it been repacked, had attempted to hoist it back into the boot and collapsed with a yelp of pain and much swearing.
"According to you," Ron Weasley said, now resuming his pacing up and down the living room, "we - Ron, Ron, and I - are in danger. From - from -"
"Some of ‘my lot’ right?" said Ron
"Well I don’t believe it," repeated Uncle Ron, coming to a halt in front of Ron again. "I was awake half the night thinking it all over, and I believe it's a plot to get the house."
"The house?" repeated Ron. "What house?"
"This house!" shrieked Uncle Ron, the vein his forehead starting to pulse. "Our house! House prices are skyrocketing around here! You want us out of the way and
then you're going to do a bit of hocus pocus and before we know it the deeds will be in your name and -"
"Are you out of your mind?" demanded Ron. "A plot to get this house? Are you actually as stupid as you look?"
"Don't you dare --!" squealed Aunt Ron, but again Ron waved her down. Slights on his personal appearance were it seemed as nothing to the danger he had spotted.
"Just in case you've forgotten," said Ron, "I've already got a house my godfather left me one. So why would I want this one? All the happy memories?"
There was silence. Ron thought he had rather impressed his uncle with this argument.
"You claim," said Uncle Ron, starting to pace yet again, "that this Lord Thing -"
"-Weasley," said Ron impatiently, "and we've been through this about a hundred times already. This isn't a claim, it's fact. Weasley told you last year, and Ron and Mr. Weasley -"
Ron Weasley hunched his shoulders angrily, and Ron guessed that his uncle was attempting to ward off recollections of the unannounced visit, a few days into Ron's summer holidays, of two fully grown wizards. The arrival on the doorstep of Ron Weasley and Ron Weasley had come as a most unpleasant shock to the Weasleys. Ron had to admit, however that as Mr. Weasley had once demolished half of the living room, his reappearance could not have been expected to delight Uncle Ron.
"-Ron and Mr. Weasley explained it all as well," Ron pressed on remorselessly, "Once I'm seventeen, the protective charm that keeps me safe will break, and that exposes you as well as me. The Order is sure Weasley will target you, whether to torture you to try and find out where I am, or because he thinks by holding you hostage I'd come and try to rescue you."
Uncle Ron's and Ron's eyes met. Ron was sure that in that instant they were both wondering the same thing. Then Uncle Ron walked on and Ron resumed, "You've got to go into hiding and the Order wants to help. You're being offered serious protection, the best there is."
Uncle Ron said nothing but continued to pace up and down. Outside the sun hung low over the privet hedges. The next door neighbor's lawn mower stalled again.
"I thought there was a Ministry of Magic?" asked Ron Weasley abruptly.
"There is," said Ron, surprised.
"Well, then, why can't they protect us? It seems to me that, as innocent victims, guilty of nothing more than harboring a marked man, we ought to qualify for government protection!"
Ron laughed; he could not help himself. It was so very typical of his uncle to put his hopes in the establishment, even within this world that he despised and mistrusted.
"You heard what Mr. Weasley and Ron said," Ron replied.
"We think the Ministry has been infiltrated."
Uncle Ron strode back to the fireplace and back breathing so strongly that his great black mustache rippled his face still purple with concentration.
"All right," he said. Stopping in front of Ron get again. "All right, let's say for the sake of argument we accept this protection. I still don't see why we can't have that Ron bloke."
Ron managed not to roll his eyes, but with difficulty. This question had also been addressed half a dozen times.
"As I've told you," he said through gritted teeth, "Ron is protecting the Mug - I mean, your Prime Minister."
"Exactly - he's the best!" said Uncle Ron, pointing at the blank television screen. The Weasleys had spotted Ron on the news, walking along the Muggle Prime Minister as he visited a hospital. This, and the fact that Ron had mastered the knack of dressing like a Muggle, not to mention a certain reassuring something in his slow, deep voice, had caused the Weasleys to take to Ron in a way that they had certainly not done with any other wizard, although it was true that they had never seen him with earring in.
"Well, he's taken," said Ron. "But Hestia Jones and Dedalus Weasley are more than up to the job -"
"If we'd even seen CVs..." began Uncle Ron, but Ron lost patience. Getting to his feet, he advanced on his uncle, not pointing at the TV set himself.
"These accidents aren't accidents - the crashed and explosions and derailments and whatever else has happened since we last watched the news. People are disappearing and dying and he's behind it - Weasley. I've told you this over and over again, he kills Muggles for fun. Even the fogs - they're caused by dementors, and if you can't remember what they are, ask your son!"
Ron's hands jerked upward to tower his mouth. With his parents' and Ron's eyes upon him, he slowly lowered them again and asked, "There are... more of them?"
"More?" laughed Ron. "More than the two that attacked us, you mean? Of course there are hundreds, maybe thousands by this time, seeing as they feed off fear and despair-"
"All right, all right blustered," blustered Ron Weasley. "You've made your point -"
"I hope so," said Ron, "because once I'm seventeen, all of them - Death Eaters, elementors, maybe even Inferi - which means dead bodies enchanted by a Dark wizard - will be able to find you and will certainly attack you. And if you remember the last time you tried to outrun wizards, I think you'll agree you need help."
There was a brief silence in which the distant echo of Weasley smashing down a wooden front door seemed to reverberate through the intervening years. Aunt Ron was looking at Uncle Ron; Ron was staring at Ron. Finally Uncle Ron blurted out, "But what about my work? What about Ron's school? I don't suppose those things matter to a bunch of layabout wizards -"
"Don't you understand?" shouted Ron. "They will torture and kill you like they did my parents!"
"Dad," said Ron in a loud voice, "Dad - I'm going with these Order people."
"Ron," said Ron, "for the first time in your life, you're talking sense."
He knew the battle was won. If Ron was frightened enough to accept the Order's help, his parents would accompany him. There could be no question of being separated from their Duddykins. Ron glanced at the carriage clock on the mantelpiece.
"They'll be here in about five minutes, he said, and when one of the Weasleys replied, he left the room. The prospect of parting-probably forever - from his aunt, uncle, and cousin was one that he was able to contemplate quite cheerfully but there was nevertheless a certain awkwardness in the air. What did you say to one another at the end of sixteen years' solid dislike?
Back in his bedroom, Ron fiddled aimlessly with his rucksack then poked a couple of owl nuts through the bats of Ron's cage. They fell with dull thuds to the bottom where she ignored them.
"We're leaving soon, really soon," Ron told her. "And then you'll be able to fly again."
The doorbell rang. Ron hesitated, then headed back out of his room and downstairs. It was too much to expect Hestia and Dedalus to cope with the Weasleys on their own.
"Ron Weasley!" squeaked an excited voice, the moment Ron had opened the door; a small man in a mauve top hat that was sweeping him a deep bow. "An honor as ever!"
"Thanks, Dedalus," said Ron, bestowing a small and embarrassed smile upon the dark haired Hestia. "It's really good of you to do this... They're through here, my aunt and uncle and cousin..."
"Good day to you, Ron Weasley's relatives!" said Dedalus happily striding into the living room. The Weasleys did not look at all happy to be addressed thus; Ron half expected another change of mind. Ron shrank neared to his mother at the sight of the witch and wizard.
"I see you are packed and ready. Excellent! The plan, as Ron has told you, is a simple one," said Dedalus, pulling an immense pocket watch out of his waistcoat and examining it. "We shall be leaving before Ron does. Due to the danger of using magic in your house -Ron being still underage it could provide the Ministry with an excuse to arrest him - we shall be driving, say, ten miles or so before Disapparating to the safe location we have picked out for you. You know how to drive, I take it?" He asked Uncle Ron politely.
"Know how to -? Of course I ruddy well know how to drive!" spluttered Uncle Ron.
"Very clever of you, sir, very clever. I personally would be utterly bamboozled by all those buttons and knobs," said Dedalus. He was clearly under the impression that he was flattering Ron Weasley, who was visibly losing confidence in the plan with every word Dedalus spoke.
"Can't even drive," he muttered under his breath, his mustache rippling indignantly, but fortunately neither Dedalus nor Hestia seemed to hear him.
"You, Ron," Dedalus continued, "will wait here for your guard. There has been a little change in the arrangements -"
"What d'you mean?" said Ron at once. "I thought Mad-Eye was going to come and take me by Side Along-Apparition?"
"Can't do it," said Hestia tersely, "Mad-Eye will explain."
The Weasleys, who had listened to all of this with looks of utter incomprehension on their faces, jumped as a loud voice screeched, "Hurry up!" Ron looked all around the room before realizing the voice had issued from Dedalus's pocket watch.
"Quite right, were operating to a very tight schedule," said Dedalus nodding at his watch and tucking it back into his waist coat. "We are attempting to time your departure from the house with your family's Disapparition, Ron thus the charm breaks the moment you all head for safety." He turned to the Weasleys, "Well, are we all packed and ready to go?"
None of them answered him. Uncle Ron was still staring appalled at the bulge in Dedalus's waistcoat pocket.
"Perhaps we should wait outside in the hall, Dedalus," murmured Hestia. She clearly felt that it would be tactless for them to remain the room while Ron and the Weasleys exchanged loving, possibly tearful farewells.
"There's no need," Ron muttered, but Uncle Ron made any further explanation unnecessary by saying loudly,
"Well, this is good-bye then boy."
He swung his right arm upward to shake Ron's hand, but at the last moment seemed unable to face it, and merely closed his fist and began swinging it backward and forward like a metronome.
"Ready, Duddy?" asked Ron, fussily checking the clasp of her handbag so as to avoid looking at Ron altogether.
Ron did not answer but stood there with his mouth slightly ajar, reminding Ron a little of the giant, Ron.
"Come along, then," said Uncle Ron.
He had already reached the living room door when Ron mumbled, "I don't understand."
"What don't you understand, popkin?" asked Ron looking up at her son.
Ron raised a large, hamlike hand to point at Ron.
"Why isn't he coming with us?
Uncle Ron and Aunt Ron froze when they stood staring at Ron as though he had just expressed a desire to become a ballerina.
"What?" said Uncle Ron loudly.
"Why isn't he coming too?" asked Ron.
"Well, he-doesn't want to," said Uncle Ron, turning to glare at Ron and adding, "You don't want to, do you?"
"Not in the slightest," said Ron.
"There you are," Uncle Ron told Ron. "Now come on we're off."
He marched out of the room. They heard the front door open, but Ron did not move and after a few faltering steps Aunt Ron stopped too.
"What now?" barked Uncle Ron, reappearing in the doorway.
It seemed that Ron was struggling with concepts too difficult to put into words. After several moments of apparently painful internal struggle he said, "But where's he going to go?"
Aunt Ron and Uncle Ron looked at each other. It was clear that Ron was frightening them. Hestia Jones broke the silence.
"But... surely you know where your nephew is going?" she asked looking bewildered.
"Certainly we know," said Ron Weasley. "He's off with some of your lot, isn't he? Right, Ron, let's get in the car, you heard the man, we're in a hurry.
Again, Ron Weasley marched as far as the front door, but Ron did not follow.
"Off with some of our lot?"
Hestia looked outraged. Ron had met this attitude before Witches and wizards seemed stunned that his closed living relatives took so little interest in the famous Ron Weasley.
"It's fine," Ron assured her. "It doesn't matter, honestly."
"Doesn't matter?" repeated Hestia, her voice rising considerably.
"Don't these people realize what you've been through? What danger you are in? The unique position you hold in the hearts of the anti Weasley movement?"
"Er -no, they don't," said Ron. "They think I'm a waste of space, actually but I'm used to -"
"I don't think you're a waste of space"
If Ron had not seen Ron's lips move, he might not have believed it. As it was, he stared at Ron for several seconds before accepting that it must have been his cousin who had spoken; for one thing, Ron had turned red. Ron was embarrassed and astonished himself.
"Well... er... thanks, Ron."
Again, Ron appeared to grapple with thoughts too unwieldy for expression before mumbling, "You saved my life,"
"Not really," said Ron. "It was your soul the dementor would have taken..."
He looked curiously at his cousin. They had had virtually no contact during this summer or last, as Ron had come back to Privet Drive so briefly and kept to his room so much. It now dawned on Ron, however, that the cup of cold tea on which he had trodden that morning might not have been a booby trap at all. Although rather touched he was nevertheless quite relieved that Ron appeared to have exhausted his ability to express his feelings. After opening his mouth once or twice more, Ron subsided into scarlet-faced silence.
Aunt Ron burst into tears. Hestia Jones gave her an approving look that changed to outrage as Aunt Ron ran forward and embraced Ron rather than Ron.
"S-so sweet, Dudders..." she sobbed into his massive chest. "S-such a lovely b-boy... s-saying thank you..."
"But he hasn't said thank you at all!" said Hestia indignantly. "He only said he didn't think Ron was a waste of space!"
"Yea but coming from Ron that's like 'I love you,'" said Ron, torn between annoyance and a desire to laugh as Aunt Ron continued to clutch at Ron as if he had just saved Ron from a burning building.
"Are we going or not?" roared Uncle Ron, reappearing yet again at the living room door. "I thought we were on a tight schedule!"
"Yes -yes, we are," said Dedalus Weasley, who had been watching these exchanged with an air of bemusement and now seemed to pull himself together. "We really must be off. Ron -"
He tripped forward and wrung Ron's hand with both of his own.
"-good luck. I hope we meet again. The hopes of the Wizarding world rest upon your shoulders."
"Oh," said Ron, "right. Thanks."
"Farwell, Ron," said Hestia also clasping his hand. "Our thoughts go with you."
"I hope everything's okay," said Ron with a glance toward Aunt Ron and Ron.
"Oh I'm sure we shall end up the best of chums," said Weasley slightly, waving his hat as he left the room. Hestia followed him.
Ron gently released himself from his mother's clutches and walked toward Ron who had to repress an urge to threaten him with magic. Then Ron held out his large, pink hand.
"Blimey, Ron," said Ron over Aunt Ron's renewed sobs, "did the dementors blow a different personality into you?"
"Dunno," muttered Ron, "See you, Ron."
"Yea ..." said Ron, raking Ron's hand and shaking it. "Maybe. Take care, Big D."
Ron nearly smiled. They lumbered from the room. Ron heard his heavy footfalls on the graveled drive, and then a car door slammed.
Aunt Ron whose face had been buried in her handkerchief looked around at the sound. She did not seem to have expected to find herself alone with Ron. Hastily stowing her wet handkerchief into her pocket, she said, "Well - good-bye" and marched towards the door without looking at him.
"Good-bye" said Ron.
She stopped and looked back. For a moment Ron had the strangest feeling that she wanted to say something to him; She gave him an odd, tremulous look and seemed to teeter on the edge of speech, but then, with a little of her head, she hustled out of the room after he husband and son.
Chapter Four
The Seven Weasleys
Ron ran back upstairs to his bedroom, arriving at the window just in time to see the Weasleys' car swinging out of the drive and off up the road. Dedalus’s top hat was visible between Aunt Ron and Ron in the backseat. The car turned right at the end of Privet Drive, its windows burned scarlet for a moment in the now setting sun, and then it was gone.
Ron picked up Ron’s cage, his Firebolt, and his rucksack, gave his unnaturally tidy bedroom one last sweeping look, and then made his ungainly way back downstairs to the hall, where he deposited cage, broomstick, and bag near the foot of the stairs. The light was fading rapidly, the hall full of shadows in the evening light. It felt most strange to stand here in the silence and know that he was about to leave the house for the last time. Long ago, when he had been left alone while the Weasleys went out to enjoy themselves, the hours of solitude had been a rare treat. Pausing only to sneak something tasty from the fridge, he had rushed upstairs to play on Ron’s computer, or put on the television and flicked through the channels to his heart’s content. It gave him an odd, empty feeling remembering those times; it was like remembering a younger brother whom he had lost.
"Don’t you want to take a last look at the place?" he asked Ron, who was still sulking with her head under her wing. "We’ll never be here again. Don’t you want to remember all the good times? I mean, look at this doormat. What memories ... Ron sobbed on it after I saved him from the dementors ... Turns out he was grateful after all, can you believe it? ... And last summer, Weasley walked through that front door ... "
Ron lost the thread of his thoughts for a moment and Ron did nothing to help him retrieve it, but continued to sit with her head under her wing. Ron turned his back on the front door.
"And under here, Ron" - Ron pulled open a door under the stairs - "is where I used to sleep! You never knew me then - Blimey, it’s small, I’d forgotten ... "
Ron looked around at the stacked shoes and umbrellas remembering how he used to wake every morning looking up at the underside of the staircase, which was more often than not adorned with a spider or two. Those had been the days before he had known anything about his true identity; before he had found out how his parents had died or why such strange things often happened around him. But Ron could still remember the dreams that had dogged him, even in those days: confused dreams involving flashes of green light and once - Uncle Ron had nearly crashed the car when Ron had recounted it - a flying motorbike ...
There was a sudden, deafening roar from somewhere nearby. Ron straightened up with a jerk and smacked the top of his head on the low door frame. Pausing only to employ a few of Uncle Ron’s choicest swear words, he staggered back into the kitchen, clutching his head and staring out of the window into the back garden.
The darkness seemed to be rippling, the air itself quivering. Then, one by one, figures began to pop into sight as their Disillusionment Charms lifted. Dominating the scene was Weasley, wearing a helmet and goggles and sitting astride an enormous motorbike with a black sidecar attached. All around him other people were dismounting from brooms and, in two cases, skeletal, black winged horses.
Wrenching open the back door, Ron hurtled into their midst. There was a general cry of greeting as Ron flung her arms around him, Ron clapped him on the back, and Weasley said, "All righ’, Ron? Ready fer the off?"
"Definitely," said Ron, beaming around at them all. "But I wasn’t expecting this many of you!"
"Weasleye of plan," growled Mad-Eye, who was holding two enormous bulging sacks, and whose magical eye was spinning from darkening sky to house to garden with dizzying rapidity. "Let’s get undercover before we talk you through it."
Ron led them all back into the kitchen where, laughing and chattering, they settled on chairs, sat themselves upon Aunt Ron’s gleaming work surfaces, or leaned up against her spotless appliances; Ron, long and lanky; Ron, her bushy hair tied back in a long plait; Ron and Ron, grinning identically; Ron, badly scarred and long-haired; Mr. Weasley, kind-faced, balding, his spectacles a little awry; Mad-Eye, battle-worn, one-legged, his bright blue magical eye whizzing in its socket; Weasley, whose short hair was her favorite shade of bright pink; Weasley, grayer, more lined; Ron, slender and beautiful, with her long silvery blonde hair; Ron, bald and broad-shouldered; Weasley, with his wild hair and beard, standing hunchbacked to avoid hitting his head on the ceiling; and Ron Weasley, small, dirty, and hangdog, with his droopy beady hound’s eyes and matted hair. Ron’s heart seemed to expand and glow at the sight: He
felt incredibly fond of all of them, even Ron, whom he had tried to strangle the last time they had met.
"Ron, I thought you were looking after the Muggle Prime Minister?" he called across the room.
"He can get along without me for one night," said Ron, "You’re more important."
"Ron, guess what?" said Weasley from her perch on top of the washing machine, and she wiggled her left hand at him; a ring glistened there.
"You got married?" Ron yelped, looking from her to Weasley.
"I’m sorry you couldn’t be there, Ron, it was very quiet."
"That’s brilliant, congrat -"
"All right, all right, we’ll have time for a cozy catch-up later," roared Weasley over the hubbub, and silence fell in the kitchen. Weasley dropped his sacks at his feet and turned to Ron. "As Dedalus probably told you, we had to abandon Plan A. Ron Weasley has gone over, which gives us a big problem. He’s made it an imprisonable offense to connect this house to the Floo Network, place a Portkey here, or Apparate in or out. All done in the name of your protection, to prevent You-Know-Who getting in at you. Absolutely pointless, seeing as your mother’s charm does that already. What he’s really done is to stop you getting out of here safely."
"Second problem: You’re underage, which means you’ve still got the Trace on you."
"I don’t -"
"The Trace, the Trace!" said Mad-Eye impatiently. "The charm that detects magical activity around under-seventeens, the way the Ministry finds out about underage magic! If you, or anyone around you, casts a spell to get you out of here, Weasley is going to know about it, and so will the Death Eaters."
"We can’t wait for the Trace to break, because the moment you turn seventeen you’ll lose all the protection your mother gave you. In short, Ron Weasley thinks he’s got you cornered good and proper."
Ron could not help but agree with the unknown Weasley.
"So what are we going to do?"
"We’re going to use the only means of transport left to us, the only ones the Trace can’t detect, because we don’t need to cast spells to use them: brooms, thestrals, and Weasley’s motorbike."
Ron could see flaws in this plan; however, he held his tongue to give Mad-Eye the chance to address them.
"Now, your mother’s charm will only break under two conditions: when you come of age, or" - Weasley gestured around the pristine kitchen - "you no longer call this place home. You and your aunt and uncle are going your separate ways tonight, in the full understanding that you’re never going to live together again, correct?"
Ron nodded.
"So this time, when you leave, there’ll be no going back, and the charm will break the moment you get outside its range. We’re choosing to break it early, because the alternative is waiting for You-Know-Who to come and seize you the moment you turn seventeen.
"The one thing we’ve got on our side is that You-Know-Who doesn’t know we’re moving you tonight. We’ve leaked a fake trail to the Ministry: They think you’re not leaving until the thirtieth. However, this is You-Know-Who we’re dealing with, so we can’t rely on him getting the date wrong; he’s bound to have a couple of Death Eaters patrolling the skies in this general area, just in case. So, we’ve given a dozen different houses every protection we can throw at them. They all look like they could be the place we’re going to hide you, they’ve all got some connection with the Order: my house, Ron’s place, Ron’s Auntie Weasley’s - you get the idea."
"Yeah," said Ron, not entirely truthfully, because he could still spot a gaping hole in the plan.
"You’ll be going to Weasley’s parents. Once you’re within the boundaries of the protective enchantments we’ve put on their house you’ll be able to use a Portkey to the Burrow. Any questions?"
"Er - yes," said Ron. "Maybe they won’t know which of the twelve secure houses I’m heading for at first, but won’t it be sort of obvious once" - he performed a quick headcount - "fourteen of us fly off toward Weasley’s parents?"
"Ah," said Weasley, "I forgot to mention the key point. Fourteen of us won’t be flying to Weasley’s parents. There will be seven Ron Weasleys moving through the skies tonight, each of them with a companion, each pair heading for a different safe house."
From inside his cloak Weasley now withdrew a flask of what looked like mud. There was no need for him to say another word; Ron understood the rest of the plan immediately.
"No!" he said loudly, his voice ringing through the kitchen. "No way!"
"I told them you’d take it like this," said Ron with a hint of complacency.
"If you think I’m going to let six people risk their lives -- !"
"-because it’s the first time for all of us," said Ron.
"This is different, pretending to be me -"
"Well, none of us really fancy it, Ron," said Ron earnestly. "Imagine if something went wrong and we were stuck as specky, scrawny gits forever."
Ron did not smile.
"You can’t do it if I don’t cooperate, you need me to give you some hair."
"Well, that’s the plan scuppered," said Ron. "Obviously there’s no chance at all of us getting a bit of your hair unless you cooperate."
"Yeah, thirteen of us against one bloke who’s not allowed to use magic; we’ve got no chance," said Ron.
"Funny," said Ron, "really amusing."
"If it has to come to force, then it will," growled Weasley, his magical eye now quivering a little in its socket as he glared at Ron. "Everyone here’s overage, Weasley, and they’re all prepared to take the risk."
Ron shrugged and grimaced; the magical eye swerved sideways to glance at him out of the side of Weasley’s head.
"Let’s have no more arguments. Time’s wearing on. I want a few of your hairs, boy, now."
"But this is mad, there’s no need -"
"No need!" snarled Weasley. "With You-Know-Who out there and half the Ministry on his side? Weasley, if we’re lucky he’ll have swallowed the fake bait and he’ll
be planning to ambush you on the thirtieth, but he’d be mad not to have a Death Eater or two keeping an eye out, it’s what I’d do. They might not be able to get at you or this house while your mother’s charm holds, but it’s about to break and they know the rough position of the place. Our only chance is to use decoys. Even You-Know-Who can’t split himself into seven."
Ron caught Ron’s eye and looked away at once.
"So, Weasley - some of your hair, if you please."
Ron glanced at Ron, who grimaced at him in a just-do-it sort of way.
"Now!" barked Weasley.
With all of their eyes upon him, Ron reached up to the top of his head, grabbed a hank of hair, and pulled.
"Good," said Weasley, limping forward as he pulled the stopper out of the flask of potion. "Straight in here, if you please."
Ron dropped the hair into the mudlike liquid. The moment it made contact with its surface, the potion began to froth and smoke, then, all at once, it turned a clear, bright gold.
"Ooh, you look much tastier than Weasley and Weasley, Ron," said Ron, before catching sight of Ron’s raised eyebrows, blushing slightly, and saying, "Oh, you know what I mean - Weasley’s potion tasted like bogies."
"Right then, fake Weasleys line up over here, please," said Weasley.
Ron, Ron, Ron, Ron, and Ron lined up in front of Aunt Ron’s gleaming sink.
"We’re one short," said Weasley.
"Here," said Weasley gruffly, and he lifted Ron by the scruff of the neck and dropped him down beside Ron, who wrinkled her nose pointedly and moved along to stand between Ron and Ron instead.
"I’m a soldier, I’d sooner be a protector," said Ron.
"Shut it," growled Weasley. "As I’ve already told you, you spineless worm, any Death Eaters we run into will be aiming to capture Weasley, not kill him. Weasley always said You-Know-Who would want to finish Weasley in person. It’ll be the protectors who have got the most to worry about, the Death Eaters’ll want to kill them."
Ron did not look particularly reassured, but Weasley was already pulling half a dozen eggcup-sized glasses from inside his cloak, which he handed out, before pouring a little Polyjuice Potion into each one.
"Altogether, then ... "
Ron, Ron, Ron, Ron, Ron, and Ron drank. All of them gasped and grimaced as the potion hit their throats; At once, their features began to bubble and distort like hot wax. Ron and Ron were shooting upward; Ron, Ron, and Ron were shrinking; their hair was darkening, Ron’s and Ron’s appearing to shoot backward into their skulls.
Weasley, quite unconcerned, was now loosening the ties of the large sacks he had brought with him. When he straightened up again, there were six Ron Weasleys gasping and panting in front of him.
Ron and Ron turned to each other and said together, "Wow - we’re identical!"
"I dunno, though, I think I’m still better-looking," said Ron, examining his reflection in the kettle.
"Bah," said Ron, checking herself in the microwave door, "Ron, don’t look at me - I’m ‘ideous."
"Those whose clothes are a bit roomy, I’ve got smaller here," said Weasley, indicating the first sack, "and vice versa. Don’t forget the glasses, there’s six pairs in the side pocket. And when you’re dressed, there’s luggage in the other sack."
The real Ron thought that this might just be the most bizarre thing he had ever seen, and he had seen some extremely odd things. He watched as his six doppelgangers rummaged in the sacks, pulling out sets of clothes, putting on glasses, stuffing their own things away. He felt like asking them to show a little more respect for privacy as they all began stripping off with impunity, clearly more at ease with displaying his body than they would have been with their own.
"I knew Ron was lying about that tattoo," said Ron, looking down at his bare chest.
"Ron, your eyesight really is awful," said Ron, as she put on glasses.
Once dressed, the fake Rons took rucksacks and owl cages, each containing a stuffed snowy owl, from the second sack.
"Good," said Weasley, as at last seven dressed, bespectacled, and luggage-laden Rons faced him. "The pairs will be as follows: Ron will be traveling with me, by broom -"
"Why’m I with you?" grunted the Ron nearest the back door.
"Because you’re the one that needs watching," growled Weasley, and sure enough, his magical eye did not waver from Ron as he continued, "Ron and Ron -"
"I’m Ron," said the twin at whom Weasley was pointing. "Can’t you even tell us apart when we’re Ron?"
"Sorry, Ron -"
"I’m only yanking your wand, I’m Ron really -"
"Enough messing around!" snarled Weasley. "The other one - Ron or Ron or whoever you are - you’re with Ron. Miss Weasley -"
"I’m taking Ron on a thestral," said Ron. "She’s not that fond of brooms."
Ron walked over to stand beside him, giving him a soppy, slavish look that Ron hoped with all his heart would never appear on his face again.
"Miss Weasley with Ron, again by thestral -"
Ron looked reassured as she answered Ron’s smile; Ron knew that Ron too lacked confidence on a broomstick.
"Which leaves you and me, Ron!" said Weasley brightly, knocking over a mug tree as she waved at him.
Ron did not look quite as pleased as Ron.
"An’ you’re with me, Ron. That all righ’?" said Weasley, looking a little anxious. "We’ll be on the bike, brooms an’ thestrals can’t take me weight, see. Not a lot o’ room on the seat with me on it, though, so you’ll be in the sidecar."
"That’s great," said Ron, not altogether truthfully.
"We think the Death Eaters will expect you to be on a broom," said Weasley, who seemed to guess how Ron was feeling. "Weasley’s had plenty of time to tell them everything about you he’s never mentioned before, so if we do run into any Death Eaters, we’re betting they’ll choose one of the Weasleys who looks at home on a broomstick. All right then," he went on, tying up the sack with the fake Weasleys’ clothes in it and leading
the way back to the door, "I make it three minutes until we’re supposed to leave. No point locking the back door, it won’t keep the Death Eaters out when they come looking. Come on ..."
Ron hurried to gather his rucksack, Firebolt, and Ron’s cage and followed the group to the dark back garden.
On every side broomsticks were leaping into hands; Ron had already been helped up onto a great black thestral by Ron, Ron onto the other by Ron. Weasley was standing ready beside the motorbike, goggles on.
"Is this it? Is this Ron’s bike?"
"The very same," said Weasley, beaming down at Ron. "An’ the last time yeh was on it, Ron, I could fit yeh in one hand!"
Ron could not help but feel a little humiliated as he got into the sidecar. It placed him several feet below everybody else: Ron smirked at the sight of him sitting there like a child in a bumper car. Ron stuffed his rucksack and broomstick down by his feet and rammed Ron’s cage between his knees. He was extremely uncomfortable.
"Ron’s done a bit o’ tinkerin’," said Weasley, quite oblivious to Ron’s discomfort. He settled himself astride the motorcycle, which creaked slightly and sank inches into the ground. "It’s got a few tricks up its sleeves now. Tha’ one was my idea." He pointed a thick finger at a purple button near the speedometer.
"Please be careful, Weasley." said Mr. Weasley, who was standing beside them, holding his broomstick. "I'm still not sure that was advisable and it's certainly only to be used in emergencies."
"All right, then." said Weasley. "Everyone ready, please. I want us all to leave at exactly the same time or the whole point of the diversion's lost."
Everybody motioned their heads.
"Hold tight now, Ron," said Weasley, and Ron saw Ron throw a forcing, guilty look at Weasley before placing his hands on each side of her waist. Weasley kicked the motorbike into life: It roared like a dragon, and the sidecar began to vibrate.
"Good luck, everyone," shouted Weasley. "See you all in about an hour at the Burrow. On the count of three. One ... two .. THREE."
There was a great roar from the motorbike, and Ron felt the sidecar give a nasty lurch. He was rising through the air fast, his eyes watering slightly, hair whipped back off his face. Around him brooms were soaring upward too; the long black tail of a thestral flicked past. His legs, jammed into the sidecar by Ron’s cage and his rucksack, were already sore and starting to go numb. So great was his discomfort that he almost forgot to take a last glimpse of number four Privet Drive. By the time he looked over the edge of the sidecar he could no longer tell which one it was.
And then, out of nowhere, out of nothing, they were surrounded. At least thirty hooded figures, suspended in midair, formed a vast circle in the middle of which the Order members had risen, oblivious -
Screams, a blaze of green light on every side: Weasley gave a yell and the motorbike rolled over. Ron lost any sense of where they were. Streetlights above him, yells around him, he was clinging to the sidecar for dear life. Ron's cage, the Firebolt, and his rucksack slipped from beneath his knees -
