"No - HELP!"
The broomstick spun too, but he just managed to seize the strap of his rucksack and the top of the cage as the motorbike swung the right way up again. A second's relief, and then another burst of green light. The owl screeched and fell to the floor of the cage.
"No - NO!"
The motorbike zoomed forward; Ron glimpsed hooded Death Eaters scattering as Weasley blasted through their circle.
"Ron - Ron -"
But the owl lay motionless and pathetic as a toy on the floor of her cage. He could not take it in, and his terror for the others was paramount. He glanced over his shoulder and saw a mass of people moving, flares of green light, two pairs of people on brooms soaring off into the distance, but he could not tell who they were -
"Weasley, we've got to go back, we've got to go back!" he yelled over the thunderous roar of the engine, pulling out his wand, ramming Ron's cage into the floor, refusing to believe that she was dead. "Weasley, TURN AROUND!"
"My job's ter get you there safe, Ron!" bellow Weasley, and he opened the throttle.
"Stop - STOP!" Ron shouted, but as he looked back again two jets of green light flew past his left ear: Four Death Eaters had broken away from the circle and were pursuing them, aiming for Weasley's broad back. Weasley swerved, but the Death Eaters were keeping up with the bike; more curses shot after them, and Ron had to sink low into the sidecar to avoid them. Wriggling around he cried, "Stupefy!" and a red bolt of light shot from his own wand, cleaving a gap between the four pursuing Death Eaters as they scattered to avoid it.
"Hold on, Ron, this'll do for 'em!" roared Weasley, and Ron looked up just in time to see Weasley slamming a thick finger into a green button near the fuel gauge.
A wall, a solid black wall, erupted out of the exhaust pipe. Craning his neck, Ron saw it expand into being in midair. Three of the Death Eaters swerved and avoided it, but the fourth was not so lucky; He vanished from view and then dropped like a boulder from behind it, his broomstick broken into pieces. One of his fellows slowed up to save him, but they and the airborne wall were swallowed by darkness as Weasley leaned low over the handlebars and sped up.
More Killing Curses flew past Ron's head from the two remaining Death Eaters' wands; they were aiming for Weasley. Ron responded with further Stunning Spells: Red and green collided in midair in a shower of multicolored sparks, and Ron thought wildly of fireworks, and the Muggles below who would have no idea what was happening -
"Here we go again, Ron, hold on!" yelled Weasley, and he jabbed at a second button. This time a great net burst from the bike's exhaust, but the Death Eaters were ready for it. Not only did they swerve to avoid it, but the companion who had slowed to save their unconscious friend had caught up. He bloomed suddenly out of the darkness and now three of them were pursuing the motorbike, all shooting curses after it.
"This'll do it, Ron, hold on tight!" yelled Weasley, and Ron saw him slam his whole hand onto the purple button beside the speedometer.
With an unmistakable bellowing roar, dragon fire burst from the exhaust, white-hot and blue, and the motorbike shot forward like a bullet with a sound of wrenching metal. Ron saw the Death Eaters swerve out of sight to avoid the deadly trail of flame,
and at the same time felt the sidecar sway ominously: Its metal connections to the bike had splintered with the force of acceleration.
"It's all righ', Ron!" bellowed Weasley, now thrown flat onto the back by the surge of speed; nobody was steering now, and the sidecar was starting to twist violently in the bike's slipstream.
"I'm on it, Ron, don' worry!" Weasley yelled, and from inside his jacket pocket he pulled his flowery pink umbrella.
"Weasley! No! Let me!"
"REPARO!"
There was a deafening bang and the sidecar broke away from the bike completely. Ron sped forward, propelled by the impetus of the bike's flight, then the sidecar began to lose height -
In desperation Ron pointed his wand at the sidecar and shouted, "Wingardium Leviosa!"
The sidecar rose like a cork, unsteerable but at least still airborne. He had but a split second's relief, however, as more curses streaked past him: The three Death Eaters were closing in.
"I'm comin', Ron!" Weasley yelled from out of the darkness, but Ron could feel the sidecar beginning to sink again: Weasleying as low as he could, he pointed at the middle of the oncoming figures and yelled, "Impedimenta!"
The jinx hit the middle Death Eater in the chest; For a moment the man was absurdly spread-eagled in midair as though he had hit an invisible barrier: One of his fellows almost collided with him -
Then the sidecar began to fall in earnest, and the remaining Death Eater shot a curse so close to Ron that he had to duck below the rim of the car, knocking out a tooth on the edge of his seat -
"I'm comin', Ron, I'm comin'!"
A huge hand seized the back of Ron's robes and hoisted him out of the plummeting sidecar; Ron pulled his rucksack with him as he dragged himself onto the motorbike's seat and found himself back-to-back with Weasley. As they soared upward, away from the two remaining Death Eaters, Ron spat blood out of his mouth, pointed his wand at the falling sidecar, and yelled, "Confringo!"
He knew a dreadful, gut-wrenching pang for Ron as it exploded; the Death Eater nearest it was blasted off his broom and fell from sight; his companion fell back and vanished.
"Ron, I'm sorry, I'm sorry," moaned Weasley, "I shouldn'ta tried ter repair it meself - yeh've got no room -"
"It's not a problem, just keep flying!" Ron shouted back, as two more Death Eaters emerged out of the darkness, drawing closer.
As the curses came shooting across the intervening space again, Weasley swerved and zigzagged: Ron knew that Weasley did not dare use the dragon-fire button again, with Ron seated so insecurely. Ron sent Stunning Spell after Stunning Spell back at their pursuers, barely holding them off. He shot another blocking jinx at them: The closest Death Eater swerved to avoid it and his hood slipped, and by the red light of his next Stunning Spell, Ron saw the strangely blank face of Ronley Weasley - Ron -
"Expelliarmus!" Ron yelled.
"That's him, it's him, it's the real one!"
The hooded Death Eater's shout reached Ron even above the thunder of the motorbike's engine: Next moment, both pursuers had fallen back and disappeared from view.
"Ron, what's happened?" bellowed Weasley. "Where've they gone?"
"I don't know!"
But Ron was afraid: The hooded Death Eater had shouted, "It's the real one!"; how had he known? He gazed around at the apparently empty darkness and felt its menace. Where were they?
He clambered around on the seat to face forward and seized hold of the back of Weasley's jacket.
"Weasley, do the dragon-fire thing again, let's get out of here!"
"Hold on tight, then, Ron!"
There was a deafening, screeching roar again and the white-blue fire shot from the exhaust: Ron felt himself slipping backwards off what little of the seat he had. Weasley flung backward upon him, barely maintaining his grip on the handlebars -
"I think we've lost 'em Ron, I think we've done it!" yelled Weasley.
But Ron was not convinced; Fear lapped at him as he looked left and right for pursuers he was sure would come. . . . Why had they fallen back? One of them had still had a wand. . . . It's him. . . it's the real one. . . . They had said it right after he had tried to Disarm Ron. . . .
"We're nearly there, Ron, we've nearly made it!" shouted Weasley.
Ron felt the bike drop a little, though the lights down on the ground still seemed remote as stars.
Then the scar on his forehead burned like fire: as a Death Eater appeared on either side of the bike, two Killing Curses missed Ron by millimeters, cast from behind -
And then Ron saw him. Weasley was flying like smoke on the wind, without broomstick or thestral to hold him, his snake-like face gleaming out of the blackness, his white fingers raising his wand again -
Weasley let out a bellow of fear and steered the motorbike into a vertical dive. Clinging on for dear life, Ron sent Stunning Spells flying at random into the whirling night. He saw a body fly past him and knew he had hit one of them, but then he heard a bang and saw sparks from the engine; the motorbike spiraled through the air, completely out of control -
Green jets of light shot past them again. Ron had no idea which way was up, which down: His scar was still burning; he expected to die at any second. A hooded figure on a broomstick was feet from him, he saw it raise its arm -
"NO!"
With a shout of fury Weasley launched himself off the bike at the Death Eater; to his horror, Ron saw both Weasley and the Death Eater, falling out of sight, their combined weight too much for the broomstick -
Barely gripping the plummeting bike with his knees, Ron heard Weasley scream, "Mine!"
It was over: He could not see or hear where Weasley was; he glimpsed another Death Eater swooping out of the way and heard, "Avada -"
As the pain from Ron's scar forced his eyes shut, his wand acted of its own accord. He felt it drag his hand around like some great magnet, saw a spurt of golden fire through his half-closed eyelids, heard a crack and a scream of fury. The remaining Death Eater yelled; Weasley screamed, "NO!" Somehow, Ron found his nose an inch from the dragon-fire button. He punched it with his wand-free hand and the bike shot more flames into the air, hurtling straight toward the ground.
"Weasley!" Ron called, holding on to the bike for dear life. "Weasley - Accio Weasley!"
The motorbike sped up, sucked towards the earth. Face level with the handlebars, Ron could see nothing but distant lights growing nearer and nearer: He was going to crash and there was nothing he could do about it. Behind him came another scream, "Your wand, Selwyn, give me your wand!"
He felt Weasley before he saw him. Looking sideways, he stared into the red eyes and was sure they would be the last thing he ever saw: Weasley preparing to curse him once more -
And then Weasley vanished. Ron looked down and saw Weasley spread-eagled on the ground below him. He pulled hard at the handlebars to avoid hitting him, groped for the brake, but with an earsplitting, ground trembling crash, he smashed into a muddy pond.
Chapter Five
Fallen Warrior
"Weasley?"
Ron struggled to raise himself out of the debris of metal and leather that surrounded him; his hands sank into inches of muddy water as he tried to stand. He could not understand where Weasley had gone and expected him to swoop out of the darkness at any moment. Something hot and wet was trickling down his chin and from his forehead. He crawled out of the pond and stumbled toward the great dark mass on the ground that was Weasley.
"Weasley? Weasley, talk to me -"
But the dark mass did not stir.
"Who's there? Is it Weasley? Are you Ron Weasley?"
Ron did not recognize the man's voice. Then a woman shouted. "They've crashed. Ron! Crashed in the garden!"
Ron's head was swimming.
"Weasley," he repeated stupidly, and his knees buckled.
The next thing he knew, he was lying on his back on what felt like cushions, with a burning sensation in his ribs and right arm. His missing tooth had been regrown. The scar on his forehead was still throbbing.
"Weasley?"
He opened his eyes and saw that he was lying on a sofa in an unfamiliar, lamplit sitting room. His rucksack lay on the floor a short distance away, wet and muddy. A fair-haired, big-bellied man was watching Ron anxiously.
"Weasley's fine, son," said the man, "the wife's seeing to him now. How are you feeling? Anything else broken? I've fixed your ribs, your tooth, and your arm. I'm Ron, by the way, Ron Weasley - Dora's father."
Ron sat up too quickly. Lights popped in front of his eyes and he felt sick and giddy.
"Weasley -"
"Easy, now," said Ron Weasley, placing a hand on Ron's shoulder and pushing him back against the cushions. "That was a nasty crash you just had. What happened, anyway? Something go wrong with the bike? Ron Weasley overstretch himself again, him and his Muggle contraptions?"
"No," said Ron, as his scar pulsed like an open wound. "Death Eaters, loads of them - we were chased -"
"Death Eaters?" said Ron sharply. "What d'you mean, Death Eaters? I thought they didn't know you were being moved tonight, I thought -"
"They knew," said Ron.
Ron Weasley looked up at the ceiling as though he could see through it to the sky above.
"Well, we know our protective charms hold, then, don't we? They shouldn't be able to get within a hundred yards of the place in any direction."
Now Ron understood why Weasley had vanished; it had been at the point when the motorbike crossed the barrier of the Order's charms. He only hoped they would continue to work: He imagined Weasley, a hundred yards above them as they spoke, looking for a way to penetrate what Ron visualized as a great transparent bubble.
He swung his legs off the sofa; he needed to see Weasley with his own eyes before he would believe that he was alive. He had barely stood up, however, when a door opened and Weasley squeezed through it, his face covered in mud and blood, limping a little but miraculously alive.
"Ron!"
Knocking over two delicate tables and an aspidistra, he covered the floor between them in two strides and pulled Ron into a hug that nearly cracked his newly repaired ribs. "Blimey, Ron, how did yeh get out o' that? I thought we were both goners."
"Yeah, me too. I can't believe -"
Ron broke off. He had just noticed the woman who had entered the room behind Weasley.
"You!" he shouted, and he thrust his hand into his pocket, but it was empty.
"Your wand's here, son," said Ron, tapping it on Ron's arm. "It fell right beside you, I picked it up...And that's my wife you're shouting at."
"Oh, I'm - I'm sorry."
As she moved forward into the room, Mrs. Weasley's resemblance to her sister Weasleyatrix became much less pronounced: Her hair was a light’s oft brown and her eyes were wider and kinder. Nevertheless, she looked a little haughty after Ron's exclamation.
"What happened to our daughter?" she asked. "Weasley said you were ambushed; where is Ron?"
"I don't know," said Ron. "We don't know what happened to anyone else."
She and Ron exchanged looks. A mixture of fear and guilt gripped Ron at the sight of their expressions, if any of the others had died, it was his fault, all his fault. He had consented to the plan, given them his hair . . .
"The Portkey," he said, remembering all of a sudden. "We've got to get back to the Burrow and find out - then we'll be able to send you word, or - or Weasley will, once she's -"
"Dora'll be ok, 'Dromeda," said Ron. "She knows her stuff, she's been in plenty of tight spots with the Aurors. The Portkey's through here," he added to Ron. "It's supposed to leave in three minutes, if you want to take it."
"Yeah, we do," said Ron. He seized his rucksack, swung it onto his shoulders. "I -"
He looked at Mrs. Weasley, wanting to apologize for the state of fear in which he left her and for which he felt so terribly responsible, but no words occurred to him that he did not seem hollow and insincere.
"I'll tell Weasley - Dora - to send word, when she . . . Thanks for patching us up, thanks for everything, I -"
He was glad to leave the room and follow Ron Weasley along a short hallway and into a bedroom. Weasley came after them, bending low to avoid hitting his head on the door lintel.
"There you go, son. That's the Portkey."
Mr. Weasley was pointing to a small, silver-backed hairbrush lying on the dressing table.
"Thanks," said Ron, reaching out to place a finger on it, ready to leave.
"Wait a moment," said Weasley, looking around. "Ron, where's Ron?"
"She . . . she got hit," said Ron.
The realization crashed over him: He felt ashamed of himself as the tears stung his eyes. The owl had been his companion, his one great link with the magical world whenever he had been forced to return to the Weasleys.
Weasley reached out a great hand and patted him painfully on the shoulder.
"Never mind," he said gruffly, "Never mind. She had a great old life -"
"Weasley!" said Ron Weasley warningly, as the hairbrush glowed bright blue, and Weasley only just got his forefinger to it in time.
With a jerk behind the navel as though an invisible hook and line had dragged him forward, Ron was pulled into nothingness, spinning uncontrollably, his finger glued to the Portkey as he and Weasley hurtled away from Mr. Weasley. Second later, Ron's feet slammed onto hard ground and he fell onto his hands and knees in the yard of the Burrow. He heard screams. Throwing aside the no longer glowing hairbrush, Ron stood up, swaying slightly, and saw Mrs. Weasley and Ron running down the steps by the back door as Weasley, who had also collapsed on landing, clambered laboriously to his feet.
"Ron? You are the real Ron? What happened? Where are the others?" cried Mrs. Weasley.
"What d'you mean? Isn't anyone else back?" Ron panted.
The answer was clearly etched in Mrs. Weasley's pale face.
"The Death Eaters were waiting for us," Ron told her, "We were surrounded the moment we took off - they knew it was tonight - I don't know what happened to anyone
else, four of them chased us, it was all we could do to get away, and then Weasley caught up with us -"
He could hear the self-justifying note in his voice, the plea for her to understand why he did not know what had happened to her sons, but -
"Thank goodness you're all right," she said, pulling him into a hug he did not feel he deserved.
"Haven't go' any brandy, have yeh, Ron?" asked Weasley a little shakily, "Fer medicinal purposes?"
She could have summoned it by magic, but as she hurried back toward the crooked house, Ron knew that she wanted to hide her face. He turned to Ron and she answered his unspoken plea for information at once.
"Ron and Weasley should have been back first, but they missed their Portkey, it came back without them," she said, pointing at a rusty oil can lying on the ground nearby. "And that one," she pointed at an ancient sneaker, "should have been Dad and Ron's, they were supposed to be second. You and Weasley were third and," she checked her watch, "if they made it, Ron and Weasley aught to be back in about a minute."
Mrs. Weasley reappeared carrying a bottle of brandy, which she handed to Weasley. He uncorked it and drank it straight down in one.
"Mum!" shouted Ron pointing to a spot several feet away.
A blue light had appeared in the darkness: It grew larger and brighter, and Weasley and Ron appeared, spinning and then falling. Ron knew immediately that there was something wrong: Weasley was supporting Ron, who was unconscious and whose face was covered in blood.
Ron ran forward and seized Ron's legs. Together, he and Weasley carried Ron into the house and through the kitchen to the living room, where they laid him on the sofa. As the lamplight fell across Ron's head, Ron gasped and Ron's stomach lurched: One of Ron's ears was missing. The side of his head and neck were drenched in wet, shockingly scarlet blood.
No sooner had Mrs. Weasley bent over her son that Weasley grabbed Ron by the upper arm and dragged him, none too gently, back into the kitchen, where Weasley was still attempting to ease his bulk through the back door.
"Oi!" said Weasley indignantly, "Le' go of him! Le' go of Ron!"
Weasley ignored him.
"What creature sat in the corner the first time that Ron Weasley visited my office at Hogwarts?" he said, giving Ron a small shake. "Answer me!"
"A - a grindylow in a tank, wasn't it?"
Weasley released Ron and fell back against a kitchen cupboard.
"Wha' was tha' about?" roared Weasley.
"I'm sorry, Ron, but I had to check," said Weasley tersely. "We've been betrayed. Weasley knew that you were being moved tonight and the only people who could have told him were directly involved in the plan. You might have been an impostor."
"So why aren' you checkin' me?" panted Weasley, still struggling with the door.
"You're half-giant," said Weasley, looking up at Weasley. "The Polyjuice Potion is designed for human use only."
"None of the Order would have told Weasley we were moving tonight," said Ron. The idea was dreadful to him, he could not believe it of any of them. "Weasley
only caught up with me toward the end, he didn't know which one I was in the beginning. If he'd been in on the plan he'd have known from the start I was the one with Weasley."
"Weasley caught up with you?" said Weasley sharply. "What happened? How did you escape?"
Ron explained how the Death Eaters pursuing them had seemed to recognize him as the true Ron, how they had abandoned the chase, how they must have summoned Weasley, who had appeared just before he and Weasley had reached the sanctuary of Weasley's parents.
"They recognized you? But how? What had you done?"
"I . . ." Ron tried to remember; the whole journey seemed like a blur of panic and confusion. "I saw Ron Weasley . . . . You know, the bloke who was the conductor on the Knight Bus? And I tried to Disarm him instead of - well, he doesn't know what he's doing, does he? He must be Imperiused!"
Weasley looked aghast.
"Ron, the time for Disarming is past! These people are trying to capture and kill you! At least Stun if you aren't prepared to kill!"
"We were hundreds of feet up! Ron's not himself, and if I Stunned him and he'd fallen, he'd have died the same as if I'd used Avada Kedavra! Expelliarmus saved me from Weasley two years ago," Ron added defiantly. Weasley was reminding him of the sneering Weasley Ron Weasley, who had jeered at Ron for wanting to teach Weasley's Army how to Disarm.
"Yes, Ron," said Weasley with painful restraint, "and a great number of Death Eaters witnessed that happening! Forgive me, but it was a very unusual move then, under the imminent threat of death. Repeating it tonight in front of Death Eaters who either witnessed or heard about the first occasion was close to suicidal!"
"So you think I should have killed Ron Weasley?" said Ron angrily.
"Of course not," said Weasley, "but the Death Eaters - frankly, most people! - would have expected you to attack back! Expelliarmus is a useful spell, Ron, but the Death Eaters seem to think it is your signature move, and I urge you not to let it become so!"
Weasley was making Ron feel idiotic, and yet there was still a grain of defiance inside him.
"I won't blast people out of my way just because they're there," said Ron, "That's Weasley's job."
Weasley's retort was lost: Finally succeeding in squeezing through the door, Weasley staggered to a chair and sat down; it collapsed beneath him. Ignoring his mingled oaths and apologies, Ron addressed Weasley again.
"Will Ron be okay?"
All Weasley's frustration with Ron seemed to drain away at the question.
"I think so, although there's no chance of replacing his ear, not when it's been cursed off -"
There was a scuffling from outside. Weasley dived for the back door; Ron leapt over Weasley's legs and sprinted into the yard.
Two figures had appeared in the yard, and as Ron ran toward them he realized they were Ron, now returning to her normal appearance, and Ron, both clutching a bent coat hanger, Ron flung herself into Ron's arms, but Ron
showed no pleasure at the sight of any of them. Over Ron's shoulder Ron saw him raise his wand and point it at Weasley's chest.
"The last words Ron Weasley spoke to the pair of us!"
"'Ron is the best hope we have. Trust him,'" said Weasley calmly.
Ron turned his wand on Ron, but Weasley said, "It's him, I've checked!"
"All right, all right!" said Ron, stowing his wand back beneath his cloak, "But somebody betrayed us! They knew, they knew it was tonight!"
"So it seems," replied Weasley, "but apparently they did not realize that there would be seven Rons."
"Small comfort!" snarled Ron. "Who else is back?"
"Only Ron, Weasley, Ron, and me."
Ron stifled a little moan behind her hand.
"What happened to you?" Weasley asked Ron.
"Followed by five, injured two, might've killed one," Ron reeled off, "and we saw You-Know-Who as well, he joined the chase halfway through but vanished pretty quickly. Ron, he can -"
"Fly," supplied Ron. "I saw him too, he came after Weasley and me."
"So that's why he left, to follow you!" said Ron, "I couldn't understand why he'd vanished. But what made him change targets?"
"Ron behaved a little too kindly to Ron Weasley," said Weasley.
"Ron?" repeated Ron. "But I thought he was in Azkaban?"
Ron let out a mirthless laugh.
"Ron, there's obviously been a mass breakout which the Ministry has hushed up. Ron's hood fell off when I cursed him, he's supposed to be inside too. But what happened to you, Ron? Where's Ron?"
"He lost an ear," said Weasley.
"lost an -- ?" repeated Ron in a high voice.
"Weasley's work," said Weasley.
"Weasley?" shouted Ron. "You didn't say -"
"He lost his hood during the chase. Sectumsempra was always a specialty of Weasley's. I wish I could say I'd paid him back in kind, but it was all I could do to keep Ron on the broom after he was injured, he was losing so much blood."
Silence fell between the four of them as they looked up at the sky. There was no sign of movement; the stars stared back, unblinking, indifferent, unobscured by flying friends. Where was Ron? Where were Ron and Mr. Weasley? Where were Ron, Ron, Weasley, Mad-Eye, and Ron?
"Ron, give us a hand!" called Weasley hoarsely from the door, in which he was stuck again. Glad of something to do, Ron pulled him free, the headed through the empty kitchen and back into the sitting room, where Mrs. Weasley and Ron were still tending to Ron. Mrs. Weasley had staunched his bleeding now, and by the lamplight Ron saw a clean gaping hole where Ron's ear had been.
"How is he?"
Mrs. Weasley looked around and said, "I can't make it grow back, not when it's been removed by Dark Magic. But it could've been so much worse . . . . He's alive."
"Yeah," said Ron. "Thank God."
"Did I hear someone else in the yard?" Ron asked.
"Ron and Ron," said Ron.
"Thank goodness," Ron whispered. They looked at each other; Ron wanted to hug her, hold on to her; he did not even care much that Mrs. Weasley was there, but before he could act on the impulse, there was a great crash from the kitchen.
"I'll prove who I am, Ron, after I've seen my son, now back off if you know what's good for you!"
Ron had never heard Mr. Weasley shout like that before. He burst into the living room, his bald patch gleaming with sweat, his spectacles askew, Ron right behind him, both pale but uninjured.
"Ron!" sobbed Mrs. Weasley. "Oh thank goodness!"
"How is he?"
Mr. Weasley dropped to his knees beside Ron. For the first time since Ron had known him, Ron seemed to be lost for words. He gaped over the back of the sofa at his twin's wound as if he could not believe what he was seeing.
Perhaps roused by the sound of Ron and their father's arrival, Ron stirred.
"How do you feel, Georgie?" whispered Mrs. Weasley.
Ron's fingers groped for the side of his head.
"Saintlike," he murmured.
"What's wrong with him?" croaked Ron, looking terrified. "Is his mind affected?"
"Saintlike," repeated Ron, opening his eyes and looking up at his brother. "You see. . . I'm holy. Holey, Ron, geddit?"
Mrs. Weasley sobbed harder than ever. Color flooded Ron's pale face.
"Pathetic," he told Ron. "Pathetic! With the whole wide world of ear-related humor before you, you go for holey?"
"Ah well," said Ron, grinning at his tear-soaked mother. "You'll be able to tell us apart now, anyway, Mum."
He looked around.
"Hi, Ron - you are Ron, right?"
"Yeah, I am," said Ron, moving closer to the sofa.
"Well, at least we got you back okay," said Ron. "Why aren't Ron and Ron huddled round my sickbed?"
"They're not back yet, Ron," said Mrs. Weasley. Ron's grin faded. Ron glanced at Ron and motioned to her to accompany him back outside. As they walked through the kitchen she said in a low voice.
"Ron and Weasley should be back by now. They didn't have a long journey; Auntie Weasley's not that far from here."
Ron said nothing. He had been trying to keep fear at bay ever since reaching the Burrow, but now it enveloped him, seeming to crawl over his skin, throbbing in his chest, clogging his throat. As they walked down the back steps into the dark yard, Ron took his hand.
Ron was striding backward and forward, glancing up at the sky every time he turned. Ron was reminded of Uncle Ron pacing the living room a million years ago. Weasley, Ron, and Weasley stood shoulder to shoulder, gazing upward in silence. None of them looked around when Ron and Ron joined their silent vigil.
The minutes stretched into what might as well have been years. The slightest breath of wind made them all jump and turn toward the whispering bush or tree in the hope that one of the missing Order members might leap unscathed from its leaves -
And then a broom materialized directly above them and streaked toward the ground -
"It's them!" screamed Ron.
Weasley landed in a long skid that sent earth and pebbles everywhere.
"Ron!" Weasley cried as she staggered off the broom into Weasley's arms. His face was set and white: He seemed unable to speak, Ron tripped dazedly toward Ron and Ron.
"You're okay," he mumbled, before Ron flew at him and hugged him tightly.
"I thought - I thought -"
"'M all right," said Ron, patting her on the back. "'M fine."
"Ron was great," said Weasley warmly, relinquishing her hold on Weasley. "Wonderful. Stunned one of the Death Eaters, straight to the head, and when you're aiming at a moving target from a flying broom -"
"You did?" said Ron, gazing up at Ron with her arms still around his neck.
"Always the tone of surprise," he said a little grumpily, breaking free. "Are we the last back?"
"No," said Ron, "we're still waiting for Ron and Ron and Mad-Eye and Ron. I'm going to tell Mum and Dad you're okay, Ron -"
She ran back inside.
"So what kept you? What happened?" Weasley sounded almost angry at Weasley.
"Weasleyatrix," said Weasley. "She wants me quite as much as she wants Ron, Ron, She tried very hard to kill me. I just wish I'd got her, I owe Weasleyatrix. But we definitely injured Ron . . . . Then we got to Ron's Auntie Weasley's and we missed our Portkey and she was fussing over us -"
A muscle was jumping in Weasley's jaw. He nodded, but seemed unable to say anything else.
"So what happened to you lot?" Weasley asked, turning to Ron, Ron, and Ron.
They recounted the stories of their own journeys, but all the time the continued absence of Ron, Ron, Mad-Eye, and Ron seemed to lie upon them like a frost, its icy bite harder and harder to ignore.
"I'm going to have to get back to Downing Street, I should have been there an hour ago," said Ron finally, after a last sweeping gaze at the sky. "Let me know when they're back,."
Weasley nodded. With a wave to the others, Ron walked away into the darkness toward the gate. Ron thought he heard the faintest pop as Ron Disapparated just beyond the Burrow's boundaries.
Mr. And Mrs. Weasley came racing down the back steps, Ron behind them. Both parents hugged Ron before turning to Weasley and Weasley.
"Thank you," said Mrs. Weasley, "for our sons."
"Don't be silly, Ron," said Weasley at once.
"How's Ron?" asked Weasley.
"What's wrong with him?" piped up Ron.
"He's lost -"
But the end of Mrs. Weasley's sentence was drowned in a general outcry. A thestral had just soared into sight and landed a few feet from them. Ron and Ron slid from its back, windswept but unhurt.
"Ron! Thank God, thank God -"
Mrs. Weasley ran forward, but the hug Ron bestowed upon her was perfunctory. Looking directly at his father, he said, "Mad-Eye's dead."
Nobody spoke, nobody moved. Ron felt as though something inside him was falling, falling through the earth, leaving him forever.
"We saw it," said Ron; Ron nodded, tear tracks glittering on her cheeks in the light from the kitchen window. "It happened just after we broke out of the circle: Mad-Eye and Dung were close by us, they were heading north too. Weasley - he can fly - went straight for them. Dung panicked, I heard him cry out, Mad-Eye tried to stop him, but he Disapparated. Weasley's curse hit Mad-Eye full in the face, he fell backward off his broom and - there was nothing we could do, nothing, we had half a dozen of them on our own tail -"
Ron's voice broke.
"Of course you couldn't have done anything," said Weasley.
They all stood looking at each other. Ron could not quite comprehend it. Mad-Eye dead; it could not be . . . . Mad-Eye, so tough, so brave, the consummate survivor . . .
At last it seemed to dawn on everyone, though nobody said it, that there was no point of waiting in the yard anymore, and in silence they followed Mr. And Mrs. Weasley back into the Burrow, and into the living room, where Ron and Ron were laughing together.
"What's wrong?" said Ron, scanning their faces as they entered, "What's happened? Who's --?"
"Mad-Eye," said Mr. Weasley, "Dead."
The twins' grins turned to grimaces of shock. Nobody seemed to know what to do. Weasley was crying silently into a handkerchief: She had been close to Mad-Eye, Ron knew, his favorite and his protégée at the Ministry of Magic. Weasley, who had sat down on the floor in the corner where he had most space, was dabbing at his eyes with his tablecloth-sized handkerchief.
Ron walked over to the sideboard and pulled out a bottle of fire-whisky and some glasses.
"Here," he said, and with a wave of his wand, eh sent twelve full glasses soaring through the room to each of them, holding the thirteenth aloft. "Mad-Eye."
"Mad-Eye," they all said, and drank.
"Mad-Eye," echoed Weasley, a little late, with a hiccup. The firewhisky seared Ron's throat. It seemed to burn feeling back into him, dispelling the numbness and sense of unreality firing him with something that was like courage.
"So Ron disappeared?" said Weasley, who had drained his own glass in one.
The atmosphere changed at once. Everybody looked tense, watching Weasley, both wanting him to go on, it seemed to Ron, and slightly afraid of what they might hear.
"I know what you're thinking," said Ron, "and I wondered that too, on the way back here, because they seemed to be expecting us, didn't they? But Ron can't have betrayed us. They didn't know there would be seven Rons, that confused them the
moment we appeared, and in case you've forgotten, it was Ron who suggested that little bit of skullduggery. Why wouldn't he have told them the essential point? I think Dung panicked, it's as simple as that. He didn't want to come in the first place, but Mad-Eye made him, and You-Know-Who went straight for them. It was enough to make anyone panic."
"You-Know-Who acted exactly as Mad-Eye expected him to," sniffed Weasley. "Mad-Eye said he'd expect the real Ron to be with the toughest, most skilled Aurors. He chased Mad-Eye first, and when Ron gave them away he switched to Ron. . . . "
"Yes, and zat eez all very good," snapped Ron, "but still eet does not explain 'ow zey know we were moving 'Arry tonight, does eet? Somebody must 'ave been careless. Somebody let slip ze date to an outsider. It is ze only explanation for zem knowing ze date but not ze 'ole plan."
She glared around at them all, tear tracks still etched on her beautiful face, silently daring any of them to contradict her. Nobody did. The only sound to break the silence was that of Weasley hiccupping from behind his handkerchief. Ron glanced at Weasley, who had just risked his own life to save Ron's - Weasley, whom he loved, whom he trusted, who had once been tricked into giving Weasley crucial information in exchange for a dragon's egg. . . .
"No," Ron said aloud, and they all looked at him, surprised: The firewhisky seemed to have amplified his voice. "I mean . . . if somebody made a mistake," Ron went on, "and let something slip, I know they didn't mean to do it. It's not their fault," he repeated, again a little louder than he would usually have spoken. "We've got to trust each other. I trust all of you, I don't think anyone in this room would ever sell me to Weasley."
More silence followed his words. They were all looking at him; Ron felt a little hot again, and drank some more firewhisky for something to do. As he drank, he thought of Mad-Eye. Mad-Eye had always been scathing about Weasley's willingness to trust people.
"Well said, Ron," said Ron unexpectedly.
"Year, 'ear, 'ear," said Ron, with half a glance at Ron, the corner of whose mouth twitched.
Weasley was wearing an odd expression as he looked at Ron. It was close to pitying.
"You think I'm a fool?" demanded Ron.
"No, I think you're like Ron," said Weasley, "who would have regarded it as the height of dishonor to mistrust his friends."
Ron knew what Weasley was getting at: that his father had been betrayed by his friend Ron Weasley. He felt irrationally angry. He wanted to argue, but Weasley had turned away from him, set down his glass upon a side table, and addressed Ron, "There's work to do. I can ask Ron whether -"
"No," said Ron at once, "I'll do it, I'll come."
"Where are you going?" said Weasley and Ron together.
"Mad-Eye's body," said Weasley. "We need to recover it."
"Can't it -- ?" began Mrs. Weasley with an appealing look at Ron.
"Wait?" said Ron, "Not unless you'd rather the Death Eaters took it?"
Nobody spoke. Weasley and Ron said good bye and left.
The rest of them now dropped into chairs, all except for Ron, who remained standing. The suddenness and completeness of death was with them like a presence.
"I've got to go too," said Ron.
Ten pairs of startled eyes looked at him.
"Don't be silly, Ron," said Mrs. Weasley, "What are you talking about?"
"I can't stay here."
He rubbed his forehead; it was prickling again, he had not hurt like this for more than a year.
"You're all in danger while I'm here. I don't want -"
"But don't be so silly!" said Mrs. Weasley. "The whole point of tonight was to get you here safely, and thank goodness it worked. And Ron's agreed to get married here rather than in France, we've arranged everything so that we can all stay together and look after you -"
She did not understand; she was making him feel worse, not better.
"If Weasley finds out I'm here -"
"But why should he?" asked Mrs. Weasley.
"There are a dozen places you might be now, Ron," said Mr. Weasley. "He's got no way of knowing which safe house you're in."
"It's not me I'm worried for!" said Ron.
"We know that," said Mr. Weasley quietly, but it would make our efforts tonight seem rather pointless if you left."
"Yer not goin' anywhere," growled Weasley. "Blimey, Ron, after all we wen' through ter get you here?"
"Yeah, what about my bleeding ear?" said Ron, hoisting himself up on his cushions.
"I know that -"
"Mad-Eye wouldn't want -"
"I KNOW!" Ron bellowed.
He felt beleaguered and blackmailed: Did they think he did not know what they had done for him, didn't they understand that it was for precisely that reason that he wanted to go now, before they had to suffer any more on his behalf? There was a long and awkward silence in which his scar continued to prickle and throb, and which was broken at last by Mrs. Weasley.
"Where's Ron, Ron?" she said coaxingly. "We can put her up with Pidwidgeon and give her something to eat."
His insides clenched like a fist. He could not tell her the truth. He drank the last of his firewhisky to avoid answering.
"Wait till it gets out yeh did it again, Ron," said Weasley. "Escaped him, fought him off when he was right on top of yeh!"
"It wasn't me," said Ron flatly. "It was my wand. My wand acted of its own accord."
After a few moments, Ron said gently, "But that's impossible, Ron. You mean that you did magic without meaning to; you reacted instinctively."
"No," said Ron. "The bike was falling, I couldn't have told you where Weasley was, but my wand spun in my hand and found him and shot a spell at him, and it wasn't even a spell I recognized. I've never made gold flames appear before."
"Often," said Mr. Weasley, "when you're in a pressured situation you can produce magic you never dreamed of. Small children often find, before they're trained -"
"It wasn't like that," said Ron through gritted teeth. His scar was burning. He felt angry and frustrated; he hated the idea that they were all imagining him to have power to match Weasley's.
No one said anything. He knew that they did not believe him. Now that he came to think of it, he had never heard of a wand performing magic on its own before.
His scar seared with pain, it was all he could do not to moan aloud. Muttering about fresh air, he set down his glass and left the room.
As he crossed the yard, the great skeletal thestral looked up - rustled its enormous batlike wings, then resumed its grazing. Ron stopped at the gate into the garden, staring out at its overgrown plants, rubbing his pounding forehead and thinking of Weasley.
Weasley would have believed him, he knew it. Weasley would have known how and why Ron's wand had acted independently, because Weasley always had the answers; he had known about wands, had explained to Ron the strange connection that existed between his wand and Weasley's . . . . But Weasley, like Mad-Eye, like Ron, like his parents, like his poor owl, all were gone where Ron could never talk to them again. He felt a burning in his throat that had nothing to do with firewhisky. . . .
And then, out of nowhere, the pain in his scar peaked. As he clutched his forehead and closed his eyes, a voice screamed inside his head.
"You told me the problem would be solved by using another's wand!"
And into his mind burst the vision of an emaciated old man lying in rags upon a stone floor, screaming, a horrible drawn-out scream, a scream of unendurable agony. . . .
"No! No! I beg you, I beg you. . . ."
"You lied to Lord Weasley, Weasley!"
"I did not. . . . I swear I did not. . . ."
"You sought to help Weasley, to help him escape me!"
"I swear I did not. . . . I believed a different wand would work. . . ."
"Explain, then, what happened. Ron's wand is destroyed!"
"I cannot understand. . . . The connection . . . exists only . . between your two wands. . . ."
"Lies!"
"Please . . . I beg you. . . ."
And Ron saw the white hand raise its wand and felt Weasley's surge of vicious anger, saw the frail old main on the floor writhe in agony -
"Ron?"
It was over as quickly as it had come: Ron stood shaking in the darkness, clutching the gate into the garden, his heart racing, his scar still tingling. It was several moments before he realized that Ron and Ron were at his side.
"Ron, come back in the house," Ron whispered, "You aren't still thinking of leaving?"
"Yeah, you've got to stay, mate," said Ron, thumping Ron on the back.
"Are you all right?" Ron asked, close enough now to look into Ron's face. "You look awful!"
"Well," said Ron shakily, "I probably look better than Weasley. . . ."
When he had finished telling them what he had seen, Ron looked appalled, but Ron downright terrified.
"But it was supposed to have stopped! Your scar - it wasn't supposed to do this anymore! You mustn't let that connection open up again - Weasley wanted you to close your mind!"
When he did not reply, she gripped his arm.
"Ron, he's taking over the Ministry and the newspapers and half the Wizarding world! Don't let him inside your head too!"
Chapter Six
The Ghoul in Pajamas
The shock of losing Mad-Eye hung over the house in the days that followed; Ron kept expecting to see him stumping in through the back door like the other Order members, who passed in and out to relay news. Ron felt that nothing but action would assuage his feelings of guilt and grief and that he ought to set out on his mission to find and destroy Horcruxes as soon as possible.
"Well, you can’t do anything about the" - Ron mouthed the word Horcruxes - "till you’re seventeen. You’ve still got the Trace on you. And we can plan here as well as anywhere, can’t we? Or," he dropped his voice to a whisper, "d’you reckon you already know where the You-Know-Whats are?"
"No," Ron admitted.
"I think Ron’s been doing a bit of research," said Ron. "She said she was saving it for when you got here."
They were sitting at the breakfast table; Mr. Weasley and Ron had just left for work. Mrs. Weasley had gone upstairs to wake Ron and Ron, while Ron had drifted off to take a bath.
"The Trace’ll break on the thirty-first," said Ron. "That means I only need to stay here four days. Then I can -"
"Five days," Ron corrected him firmly. "We’ve got to stay for the wedding. They’ll kill us if we miss it."
Ron understood "they" to mean Ron and Mrs. Weasley.
"It’s one extra day," said Ron, when Ron looked mutinous.
"Don’t they realize how important -?"
"’Course they don’t," said Ron. "They haven’t got a clue. And now you mention it, I wanted to talk to you about that."
Ron glanced toward the door into the hall to check that Mrs. Weasley was not returning yet, then leaned in closer to Ron.
"Mum’s been trying to get it out of Ron and me. What we’re off to do. She’ll try you next, so brace yourself. Dad and Weasley’ve both asked as well, but when we
said Weasley told you not to tell anyone except us, they dropped it. Not Mum, though. She’s determined."
Ron’s prediction came true within hours. Shortly before lunch, Mrs. Weasley detached Ron from the others by asking him to help identify a lone man’s sock that she thought might have come out of his rucksack. Once she had him cornered in the tiny scullery off the kitchen, she started.
"Ron and Ron seem to think that the three of you are dropping out of Hogwarts," she began in a light, casual tone.
"Oh," said Ron. "Well, yeah. We are."
The mangle turned of its own accord in a corner, wringing out what looked like one of Mr. Weasley’s vests.
"May I ask why you are abandoning your education?" said Mrs. Weasley.
"Well, Weasley left me . . . stuff to do," mumbled Ron. "Ron and Ron know about it, and they want to come too."
"What sort of ‘stuff’?"
"I’m sorry, I can’t -"
"Well, frankly, I think Ron and I have a right to know, and I’m sure Mr. And Mrs. Weasley would agree!" said Mrs. Weasley. Ron had been afraid of the "concerned parent" attack. He forced himself to look directly into her eyes, noticing as he did so that they were precisely the same shade of brown as Ron’s. This did not help.
"Weasley didn’t want anyone else to know, Mrs. Weasley. I’m sorry. Ron and Ron don’t have to come, it’s their choice -"
"I don’t see that you have to go either!" she snapped, dropping all pretense now. "You’re barely of age, any of you! It’s utter nonsense, if Weasley needed work doing, he had the whole Order at his command! Ron, you must have misunderstood him. Probably he was telling you something he wanted done, and you took it to mean that he wanted you-"
"I didn’t misunderstand," said Ron flatly. "It’s got to be me."
He handed her back the single sock he was supposed to be identifying, which was patterned with golden bulrushes.
"And that’s not mine. I don’t support Puddlemere United."
"Oh, of course not," said Mrs. Weasley with a sudden and rather unnerving return to her casual tone. "I should have realized. Well, Ron, while we’ve still got you here, you won’t mind helping with the preparations for Ron and Ron’s wedding, will you? There’s still so much to do."
"No - I - of course not," said Ron, disconcerted by this sudden change of subject.
"Sweet of you," she replied, and she smiled as she left the scullery.
From that moment on, Mrs. Weasley kept Ron, Ron and Ron so busy with preparations for the wedding that they hardly had any time to think. The kindest explanation of this behavior would have been that Mrs. Weasley wanted to distract them all from thoughts of Mad-Eye and the terrors of their recent journey. After two days of nonstop cutlery cleaning, of color-matching favors, ribbons, and flowers, of de-gnoming the garden and helping Mrs. Weasley cook vast batches of canapés, however, Ron started to suspect her of a different motive. All the jobs she handed out seemed to keep him, Ron, and Ron away from one another; he had not had a chance to speak to the
two of them alone since the first night, when he had told them about Weasley torturing Weasley.
"I think Mum thinks that if she can stop the three of you getting together and planning, she’ll be able to delay you leaving," Ron told Ron in an undertone, as they laid the table for dinner on the third night of his stay.
"And then what does she think’s going to happen?" Ron muttered. "Someone else might kill off Weasley while she’s holding us here making vol-au-vents?"
He had spoken without thinking, and saw Ron’s face whiten.
"So it’s true?" she said. "That’s what you’re trying to do?"
"I - not - I was joking," said Ron evasively.
They stared at each other, and there was something more than shock in Ron’s expression. Suddenly Ron became aware that this was the first time that he had been alone with her since those stolen hours in secluded corners of the Hogwarts grounds. He was sure she was remembering them too. Both of them jumped as the door opened, and Mr. Weasley, Ron, and Ron walked in.
They were often joined by other Order members for dinner now, because the Burrow had replaced number twelve, Grimmauld Place as the headquarters. Mr. Weasley had explained that after the death of Weasley, their Secret-Keeper, each of the people to whom Weasley had confided Grimmauld Place’s location had become a Secret-Keeper in turn.
"And as there are around twenty of us, that greatly dilutes the power of the Fidelius Charm. Twenty times as many opportunities for the Death Eaters to get the secret out of somebody. We can’t expect it to hold much longer."
"But surely Weasley will have told the Death Eaters the address by now?" asked Ron.
"Well, Mad-Eye set up a couple of curses against Weasley in case he turns up there again. We hope they’ll be strong enough both to keep him out and to bind his tongue if he tries to talk about the place, but we can’t be sure. It would have been insane to keep using the place as headquarters now that its protection has become so shaky."
The kitchen was so crowded that evening it was difficult to maneuver knives and forks. Ron found himself crammed beside Ron; the unsaid things that had just passed between them made him wish they had been separated by a few more people. He was trying so hard to avoid brushing her arm he could barely cut his chicken.
"No news about Mad-Eye?" Ron asked Ron.
"Nothing," replied Ron.
They had not been able to hold a funeral for Weasley, because Ron and Weasley had failed to recover his body. It had been difficult to know where he might have fallen, given the darkness and the confusion of the battle.
"The Daily Prophet hasn’t said a word about him dying or about finding the body," Ron went on. "But that doesn’t mean much. It’s keeping a lot quiet these days."
"And they still haven’t called a hearing about all the underage magic I used escaping the Death Eaters?" Ron called across the table to Mr. Weasley, who shook his head.
"Because they know I had no choice or because they don’t want me to tell the world Weasley attacked me?"
"The latter, I think. Weasley doesn’t want to admit that You-Know-Who is as powerful as he is, nor that Azkaban’s seen a mass breakout."
"Yeah, why tell the public the truth?" said Ron, clenching his knife so tightly that the faint scars on the back of his right hand stood out, white against his skin: I must not tell lies.
"Isn’t anyone at the Ministry prepared to stand up to him?" asked Ron angrily.
"Of course, Ron, but people are terrified," Mr. Weasley replied, "terrified that they will be next to disappear, their children the next to be attacked! There are nasty rumors going around; I for one don’t believe the Muggle Studies professor at Hogwarts resigned. She hasn’t been seen for weeks now. Meanwhile Weasley remains shut up in his office all day; I just hope he’s working on a plan."
There was a pause in which Mrs. Weasley magicked the empty plates onto the work surface and served apple tart.
"We must decide ‘ow you will be disguised, ‘Arry," said Ron, once everyone had pudding. "For ze wedding," she added, when he looked confused. "Of course, none of our guests are Death Eaters, but we cannot guarantee zat zey will not let something slip after zey ‘ave ‘ad champagne."
From this, Ron gathered that she still suspected Weasley.
"Yes, good point," said Mrs. Weasley from the top of the table where she sat, spectacles perched on the end of her nose, scanning an immense list of jobs that she had scribbled on a very long piece of parchment. "Now, Ron, have you cleaned out your room yet?"
"Why?" exclaimed Ron, slamming his spoon down and glaring at his mother. "Why does my room have to be cleaned out? Ron and I are fine with it the way it is!"
"We are holding your brother’s wedding here in a few days’ time, young man -"
"And are they getting married in my bedroom?" asked Ron furiously. "No! So why in the name of Merlin’s saggy left -"
"Don’t talk to your mother like that," said Mr. Weasley firmly. "And do as you’re told."
Ron scowled at both his parents, then picked up his spoon and attacked the last few mouthfuls of his apple tart.
"I can help, some of it’s my mess." Ron told Ron, but Mrs. Weasley cut across him.
"No, Ron, dear, I’d much rather you helped Ron much out the chickens, and Ron, I’d be ever so grateful if you’d change the sheets for Monsieur and Rone Weasley; you know they’re arriving at eleven tomorrow morning."
But as it turned out, there was very little to do for the chickens. "There’s no need to, er, mention it to Ron," Mr. Weasley told Ron, blocking his access to the coop, "but, er, Ron Weasley sent me most of what was left of Ron’s bike and, er, I’m hiding - that’s to say, keeping - it in here. Fantastic stuff: There’s an exhaust gaskin, as I believe it’s called, the most magnificent battery, and it’ll be a great opportunity to find out how brakes work. I’m going to try and put it all back together again when Ron’s not - I mean, when I’ve got time."
When they returned to the house, Mrs. Weasley was nowhere to be seen, so Ron slipped upstairs to Ron’s attic bedroom.
"I’m doing it, I’m doing - ! Oh, it’s you," said Ron in relief, as Ron entered the room. Ron lay back down on the bed, which he had evidently just vacated. The room was just as messy as it had been all week; the only chance was that Ron was now sitting in the far corner, her fluffy ginger cat, Ron, at her feet, sorting books, some of which Ron recognized as his own, into two enormous piles.
"Hi, Ron," she said, as he sat down on his camp bed.
"And how did you manage to get away?"
"Oh, Ron’s mum forgot that she asked Ron and me to change the sheets yesterday," said Ron. She threw Numerology and Grammatica onto one pile and The Rise and Fall of the Dark Arts onto the other.
"We were just talking about Mad-Eye," Ron told Ron. "I reckon he might have survived."
"But Ron saw him hit by the Killing Curse," said Ron.
"Yeah, but Ron was under attack too," said Ron. "How can he be sure what he saw?"
"Even if the Killing Curse missed, Mad-Eye still fell about a thousand feet," said Ron, now weight Quidditch Teams of Britain and Ireland in her hand.
"He could have used a Shield Charm -"
"Ron said his wand was blasted out of his hand," said Ron.
"Well, all right, if you want him to be dead," said Ron grumpily, punching his pillow into a more comfortable shape.
"Of course we don’t want him to be dead!" said Ron, looking shocked. "It’s dreadful that he’s dead! But we’re being realistic!"
For the first time, Ron imagined Mad-Eye’s body, broken as Weasley’s had been, yet with that one eye still whizzing in its socket. He felt a stab of revulsion mixed with a bizarre desire to laugh.
"The Death Eaters probably tidied up after themselves, that’s why no one’s found him," said Ron wisely.
"Yeah," said Ron. "Like Ron Weasley, turned into a bone and buried in Weasley’s front garden. They probably transfigured Weasley and stuffed him -"
"Don’t!" squealed Ron. Startled, Ron looked over just in time to see her burst into tears over her copy of Spellman’s Syllabary.
"Oh no," said Ron, struggling to get up from the old camp bed. "Ron, I wasn’t trying to upset -"
But with a great creaking of rusty bedsprings, Ron bounded off the bed and got there first. One arm around Ron, he fished in his jeans pocket and withdrew a revolting-looking handkerchief that he had used to clean out the oven earlier. Hastily pulling out his wand, he pointed it at the rag and said, "Tergeo."
The wand siphoned off most of the grease. Looking rather pleased with himself, Ron handed the slightly smoking handkerchief to Ron.
"Oh . . . thanks, Ron. . . . I’m sorry. . . ." She blew her nose and hiccupped. "It’s just so awf-ful, isn’t it? R-right after Weasley . . . I j-just n-never imagined Mad-Eye dying, somehow, he seemed so tough!"
"Yeah, I know," said Ron, giving her a squeeze. "But you know what he’d say to us if he was here?"
"’C-constant vigilance,’" said Ron, mopping her eyes.
"That’s right," said Ron, nodding. "He’d tell us to learn from what happened to him. And what I’ve learned is not to trust that cowardly little squit, Ron."
Ron gave a shaky laugh and leaned forward to pick up two more books. A second later, Ron had snatched his arm back from around her shoulders; she had dropped The Monster of Monsters on his foot. The book had broken free from its restraining belt and snapped viciously at Ron’s ankle.
"I’m sorry, I’m sorry!" Ron cried as Ron wrenched the book from Ron’s leg and retied it shit.
"What are you doing with all those books anyway?" Ron asked, limping back to his bed.
"Just trying to decide which ones to take with us," said Ron, "When we’re looking for the Horcruxes."
"Oh, of course," said Ron, clapping a hand to his forehead. "I forgot we’ll be hunting down Weasley in a mobile library."
"Ha ha," said Ron, looking down at Spellman’s Syllabary. "I wonder . . . will we need to translate runes? It’s possible. . . . I think we’d better take it, to be safe."
She dropped the syllabary onto the larger of the two piles and picked up Hogwarts, A History.
"Listen," said Ron.
He had sat up straight. Ron and Ron looked at him with similar mixtures of resignation and defiance.
"I know you said after Weasley’s funeral that you wanted to come with me," Ron began.
"Here he goes," Ron said to Ron, rolling his eyes.
"As we knew he would," he sighed, turning back to the books. "You know, I think I will take Hogwarts, A History. Even if we’re not going back there, I don’t think I’d feel right if I didn’t have it with -"
"Listen!" said Ron again.
"No, Ron, you listen," said Ron. "We’re coming with you. That was decided months ago - years, really."
"But -"
"Shut up," Ron advised him.
"- are you sure you’ve thought this through?" Ron persisted.
"Let’s see," said Ron, slamming Travels with Trolls onto the discarded pile with a rather fierce look. "I’ve been packing for days, so we’re ready to leave at a moment’s notice, which for your information has included doing some pretty difficult magic, not to mention smuggling Mad-Eye’s whole stock of Polyjuice Potion right under Ron’s mum’s nose.
"I’ve also modified my parents’ memories so that they’re convinced they’re really called Wendell and Monica Wilkins, and that their life’s ambition is to move to Australia, which they have now done. That’s to make it more difficult for Weasley to track them down and interrogate them about me - or you, because unfortunately, I’ve told them quite a bit about you.
"Assuming I survive our hunt for the Horcruxes, I’ll find Mum and Dad and lift the enchantment. If I don’t - well, I think I’ve cast a good enough charm to keep them
safe and happy. Wendell and Monica Wilkins don’t know that they’ve got a daughter, you see."
Ron’s eyes were swimming with tears again. Ron got back off the bed, put his arm around her once more, and frowned at Ron as though reproaching him for lack of tact. Ron could not think of anything to say, not least because it was highly unusual for Ron to be teaching anyone else tact.
"I - Ron, I’m sorry - I didn’t -"
"Didn’t realize that Ron and I know perfectly well what might happen if we come with you? Well, we do. Ron, show Ron what you’ve done."
"Nah, he’s just eaten," said Ron.
"Go on, he needs to know!"
"Oh, all right. Ron, come here."
For the second time Ron withdrew his arm from around Ron and stumped over to the door.
"C’mon."
"Why?" Ron asked, following Ron out of the room onto the tiny landing.
"Descendo," muttered Ron, pointing his wand at the low ceiling. A hatch opened right over their heads and a ladder slid down to their feet. A horrible, half-sucking, half-moaning sound came out of the square hole, along with an unpleasant smell like open drains.
"That’s your ghoul, isn’t it?" asked Ron, who had never actually met the creature that sometimes disrupted the nightly silence.
"Yeah, it is," said Ron, climbing the ladder. "Come and have a look at him."
Ron followed Ron up the few short steps into the tiny attic space. His head and shoulders were in the room before he caught sight of the creature curled up a few feet from him, fast asleep in the gloom with its large mouth wide open.
"But it . . . it looks . . . do ghouls normally wear pajamas?"
"No," said Ron. "Nor have they usually got red hair or that number of pustules."
Ron contemplated the thing, slightly revolted. It was human in shape and size, and was wearing what, now that Ron’s eyes became used to the darkness, was clearly an old pair of Ron’s pajamas. He was also sure that ghouls were generally rather slimy and bald, rather than distinctly hairy and covered in angry purple blisters.
"He’s me, see?" said Ron.
"No," said Ron. "I don’t."
"I’ll explain it back in my room, the smell’s getting to me," said Ron. They climbed back down the ladder, which Ron returned to the ceiling, and rejoined Ron, who was still sorting books.
"Once we’ve left, the ghoul’s going to come and live down here in my room," said Ron. "I think he’s really looking forward to it - well, it’s hard to tell, because all he can do is moan and drool - but he nods a lot when you mention it. Anyway, he’s going to be me with spattergroit. Good, eh?"
Ron merely looked his confusion.
"It is!" said Ron, clearly frustrated that Ron had not grasped the brilliance of the plan. "Look, when we three don’t turn up at Hogwarts again, everyone’s going to think Ron and I must be with you, right? Which means the Death Eaters will go straight for our families to see if they’ve got information on where you are."
"But hopefully it’ll look like I’ve gone away with Mum and Dad; a lot of Muggle-borns are talking about going into hiding at the moment," said Ron.
"We can’t hide my whole family, it’ll look too fishy and they can’t all leave their jobs," said Ron. "So we’re going to put out the story that I’m seriously ill with spattergroit, which is why I can’t go back to school. If anyone comes calling to investigate, Mum or Dad can show them the ghoul in my bed, covered in pustules. Spattergroit’s really contagious, so they’re not going to want to go near him. It won’t matter that he can’t say anything, either, because apparently you can’t once the fungus has spread to your uvula."
"And your mum and dad are in on this plan?" asked Ron.
"Dad is. He helped Ron and Ron transform the ghoul. Mum . . . well, you’ve seen what she’s like. She won’t accept we’re going till we’re gone."
There was silence in the room, broken only by gentle thuds as Ron continued to throw books onto one pile or the other. Ron sat watching her, and Ron looked from one to the other, unable to say anything. The measure they had taken to protect their families made him realize, more than anything else could have done, that they really were going to come with him and that they knew exactly how dangerous that would be. He wanted to tell them what that meant to him, but he simply could not find words important enough.
Through the silence came the muffled sounds of Mrs. Weasley shouting from four floors below.
"Ron’s probably left a speck of dust on a poxy napkin ring," said Ron. "I dunno why the Weasleys have got to come two days before the wedding."
"Ron’s sister’s a bridesmaid, she needs to be here for the rehearsal, and she’s too young to come on her own," said Ron, as she pored indecisively over Break with a Banshee.
"Well, guests aren’t going to help Mum’s stress levels," said Ron.
"What we really need to decide," said Ron, tossing Defensive Magical Theory into the bin without a second glance and picking up An Appraisal of Magical Education in Europe, "is where we’re going after we leave here. I know you said you wanted to go to Ron’s Hollow first, Ron, and I understand why, but . . . well . . . shouldn’t we make the Horcruxes our priority?"
"If we knew where any of the Horcruxes were, I’d agree with you," said Ron, who did not believe that Ron really understood his desire to return to Ron’s Hollow. His parents’ graves were only part of the attraction: He had a strong, though inexplicable, feeling that the place held answers for him. Perhaps it was simply because it was there that he had survived Weasley’s Killing Curse; now that he was facing the challenge of repeating the feat, Ron was drawn to the place where it had happened, wanting to understand.
"Don’t you think there’s a possibility that Weasley’s keeping a watch on Ron’s Hollow?" Ron asked. "He might expect you to go back and visit your parents’ graves once you’re free to go wherever you like?"
This had not occurred to Ron. While he struggled to find a counterargument, Ron spoke up, evidently following his own train of thought.
"This R.A.B. person," he said. "You know, the one who stole the real locket?"
Ron nodded.
"He said in his note he was going to destroy it, didn’t he?"
Ron dragged his rucksack toward him and pulled out the fake Horcrux in which R.A.B.’s note was still folded.
"’I have stolen the real Horcrux and intend to destroy it as soon as I can.’" Ron read out.
"Well, what if he did finish it off?" said Ron.
"Or she." Interposed Ron.
"Whichever," said Ron. "it’d be one less for us to do!"
"Yes, but we’re still going to have to try and trace the real locket, aren’t we?" said Ron, "to find out whether or not it’s destroyed."
"And once we get hold of it, how do you destroy a Horcrux?" asked Ron.
"Well," said Ron, "I’ve been researching that."
"How?" asked Ron. "I didn’t think there were any books on Horcruxes in the library?"
"There weren’t," said Ron, who had turned pink. "Weasley removed them all, but he - he didn’t destroy them." Ron sat up straight, wide-eyed.
"How in the name of Merlin’s pants have you managed to get your hands on those Horcrux books?"
"It - it wasn’t stealing!" said Ron, looking from Ron to Ron with a kind of desperation. "They were still library books, even if Weasley had taken them off the shelves. Anyway, if he really didn’t want anyone to get at them, I’m sure he would have made it much harder to -"
"Get to the point!" said Ron.
"Well . . . it was easy," said Ron in a small voice. "I just did a Summoning Charm. You know - Accio. And - they zoomed out of Weasley’s study window right into the girls’ dormitory."
"But when did you do this?" Ron asked, regarding Ron with a mixture of admiration and incredulity.
"Just after his - Weasley’s - funeral," said Ron in an even smaller voice. "Right after we agreed we’d leave school and go and look for the Horcruxes. When I went back upstairs to get my things it - it just occurred to me that the more we knew about them, the better it would be . . . and I was alone in there . . . so I tried . . . and it worked. They flew straight in through the open window and I - I packed them."
She swallowed and then said imploringly, "I can’t believe Weasley would have been angry, it’s not as though we’re going to use the information to make a Horcrux, is it?"
"Can you hear us complaining?" said Ron. "Where are these books anyway?"
Ron rummaged for a moment and then extracted from the pile a large volume, bound in faded black leather. She looked a little nauseated and held it as gingerly as if it were something recently dead.
"This is the one that gives explicit instructions on how to make a Horcrux. Secrets of the Darkest Art - it’s a horrible book, really awful, full of evil magic. I wonder when Weasley removed it from the library. . . . if he didn’t do it until he was headmaster, I bet Weasley got all the instruction he needed from here."
"Why did he have to ask Weasley how to make a Horcrux, then, if he’d already read that?" asked Ron.
"He only approached Weasley to find out what would happen if you split your soul into seven," said Ron. "Weasley was sure Weasley already knew how to make a Horcrux by the time he asked Weasley about them. I think you’re right, Ron, that could easily have been where he got the information."
"And the more I’ve read about them," said Ron, "the more horrible they seem, and the less I can believe that he actually made six. It warns in this book how unstable you make the rest of your soul by ripping it, and that’s just by making one Horcrux!"
Ron remembered what Weasley had said about Weasley moving beyond "usual evil."
"Isn’t there any way of putting yourself back together?" Ron asked.
"Yes," said Ron with a hollow smile, "but it would be excruciatingly painful."
"Why? How do you do it?" asked Ron.
"Remorse," said Ron. "You’ve got to really feel what you’ve done. There’s a footnote. Apparently the pain of it can destroy you. I can’t see Weasley attempting it somehow, can you?"
"No," said Ron, before Ron could answer. "So does it say how to destroy Horcruxes in that book?"
"Yes," said Ron, now turning the fragile pages as if examining rotting entrails, "because it warns Dark wizards how strong they have to make the enchantments on them. From all that I’ve read, what Ron did to Weasley’s diary was one of the few really foolproof ways of destroying a Horcrux."
"What, stabbing it with a basilisk fang?" asked Ron.
"Oh well, lucky we’ve got such a large supply of basilisk fangs, then," said Ron. "I was wondering what we were going to do with them."
"It doesn’t have to be a basilisk fang," said Ron patiently. "It has to be something so destructive that the Horcrux can’t repair itself. Basilisk venom only has one antidote, and it’s incredibly rare -"
"- phoenix tears," said Ron, nodding.
"Exactly," said Ron. "Our problem is that there are very few substances as destructive as basilisk venom, and they’re all dangerous to carry around with you. That’s a problem we’re going to have to solve, though, because ripping, smashing, or crushing a Horcrux won’t do the trick. You’ve got to put it beyond magical repair."
"But even if we wreck the thing it lives in," said Ron, "why can’t the bit of soul in it just go and live in something else?"
"Because a Horcrux is the complete opposite of a human being."
Seeing that Ron and Ron looked thoroughly confused, Ron hurried on. "Look, if I picked up a sword right now, Ron, and ran you through with it, I wouldn’t damage your soul at all."
"Which would be a real comfort to me, I’m sure," said Ron. Ron laughed.
"It should be, actually! But my point is that whatever happens to your body, your soul will survive, untouched," said Ron. "But it’s the other way round with a
Horcrux. The fragment of soul inside it depends on its container, its enchanted body, for survival. It can’t exist without it."
"That diary sort of died when I stabbed it," said Ron, remembering ink pouring like blood from the punctured pages, and the screams of the piece of Weasley’s soul as it vanished.
"And once the diary was properly destroyed, the bit of soul trapped in it could no longer exist. Ron tried to get rid of the diary before you did, flushing it away, but obviously it came back good as new."
"Hang on," said Ron, frowning. "The bit of soul in that diary was possessing Ron, wasn’t it? How does that work, then?"
"While the magical container is still intact, the bit of soul inside it can flit in and out of someone if they get too close to the object. I don’t mean holding it for too long, it’s nothing to do with touching it," she added before Ron could speak. "I mean close emotionally. Ron poured her heart out into that diary, she made herself incredibly vulnerable. You’re in trouble if you get too fond of or dependent on the Horcrux."
"I wonder how Weasley destroyed the ring?" said Ron. "Why didn’t I ask him? I never really . . ."
His voice trailed away: He was thinking of all the things he should have asked Weasley, and of how, since the headmaster had died, it seemed to Ron that he had wasted so many opportunities when Weasley had been alive, to find out more . . . to find out everything. . . .
The silence was shattered as the bedroom door flew open with a wall-shaking crash. Ron shrieked and dropped Secrets of the Darkest Art; Ron streaked under the bed, hissing indignantly; Ron jumped off the bed, skidded on a discarded Roncolate Frog wrapper, and smacked his head on the opposite wall; and Ron instinctively dived for his wand before realizing that he was looking up at Mrs. Weasley, whose hair was disheveled and whose face was contorted with rage.
"I’m so sorry to break up this cozy little gathering," she said, her voice trembling. "I’m sure you all need your rest . . . but there are wedding presents stacked in my room that need sorting out and I was under the impression that you had agreed to help."
"Oh yes," said Ron, looking terrified as she leapt to her feet, sending books flying in every direction. "we will . . . we’re sorry . . ."
With an anguished look at Ron and Ron, Ron hurried out of the room after Mrs. Weasley.
"it’s like being a house-elf," complained Ron in an undertone, still massaging his head as he and Ron followed. "Except without the job satisfaction. The sooner this wedding’s over, the happier, I’ll be."
"Yeah," said Ron, "then we’ll have nothing to do except find Horcruxes. . . . It’ll be like a holiday, won’t it?"
Ron started to laugh, but at the sight of the enormous pile of wedding presents waiting for them in Mrs. Weasley’s room, stopped quite abruptly.
The Weasleys arrived the following morning at eleven o’ clock. Ron, Ron, Ron and Ron were feeling quite resentful toward Ron’s family by this time; and it was with ill grace that Ron stumped back upstairs to put on matching socks, and Ron attempted to flatten his hair. Once they had all been deemed smart enough, they trooped out into the sunny backyard to await the visitors.
Ron had never seen the place looking so tidy. The rusty cauldrons and old Wellington boots that usually littered the steps by the back door were gone, replaced by two new Flutterby bushes standing either side of the door in large pots; though there was no breeze, the leaves waved lazily, giving an attractive rippling effect. The chickens had been shut away, the yard had been swept, and the nearby garden had been pruned, plucked, and generally spruced up, although Ron, who liked it in its overgrown state, thought that it looked rather forlorn without its usual contingent of capering gnomes.
He had lost track of how many security enchantments had been placed upon the Burrow by both the Order and the Ministry; all he knew was that it was no longer possible for anybody to travel by magic directly into the place. Mr. Weasley had therefore gone to meet the Weasleys on top of a nearby hill, where they were to arrive by Portkey. The first sound of their approach was an unusually high-pitched laugh, which turned out to be coming from Mr. Weasley, who appeared at the gate moments later, laden with luggage and leading a beautiful blonde woman in long, leaf green robes, who could be Ron’s mother.
"Maman!" cried Ron, rushing forward to embrace her. "Papa!"
Monsieur Weasley was nowhere near as attractive as his wife; he was a head shorter and extremely plumb, with a little, pointed black beard. However, he looked good-natured. Bouncing towards Mrs. Weasley on high-heeled boots, he kissed her twice on each cheek, leaving her flustered.
"You ‘ave been so much trouble," he said in a deep voice. "Ron tells us you ‘ave been working very ‘ard."
"Oh, it’s been nothing, nothing!" trilled Mrs. Weasley. "No trouble at all!"
Ron relieved his feelings by aiming a kick at a gnome who was peering out from behind one of the new Flutterby bushes.
"Dear lady!" said Monsieur Weasley, still holding Mrs. Weasley’s hand between his own two plump ones and beaming. "We are most honored at the approaching union of our two families! Let me present my wife, Apolline."
Rone Weasley glided forward and stooped to kiss Mrs. Weasley too.
"Enchantée," she said. "Your ‘usband ‘as been telling us such amusing stories!"
Mr. Weasley gave a maniacal laugh; Mrs. Weasley threw him a look, upon which he became immediately silent and assumed an expression appropriate to the sickbed of a close friend.
"And, of course, you ‘ave met my leetle daughter, Ron!" said Monsieur Weasley. Ron was Ron in miniature; eleven years old, with waist-length hair of pure, silvery blonde, she gave Mrs. Weasley a dazzling smile and hugged her, then threw Ron a glowing look, batting her eyelashes. Ron cleared her throat loudly.
"Well, come in, do!" said Mrs. Weasley brightly, and she ushered the Weasleys into the house, with many "No, please!"s and "After you!"s and "Not at all!"s.
The Weasleys, it soon transpired, were helpful, pleasant guests. They were pleased with everything and keen to assist with the preparations for the wedding. Monsieur Weasley pronounced everything from the seating plan to the bridesmaids’ shoes "Charmant!" Rone Weasley was most accomplished at household spells and had the oven properly cleaned in a trice; Ron followed her elder sister around, trying to assist in any way she could and jabbering away in rapid French.
On the downside, the Burrow was not built to accommodate so many people. Mr. and Mrs. Weasley were now sleeping in the sitting room, having shouted down Monsieur and Rone Weasley’s protests and insisted they take their bedroom. Ron was sleeping with Ron in Ron’s old room, and Ron would be sharing with Ron, his best man, once Ron arrived from Romania. Opportunities to make plans together became virtually nonexistent, and it was in desperation that Ron, Ron and Ron took to volunteering to feed the chickens just to escape the overcrowded house.
"But she still won’t leave us alone!" snarled Ron, and their second attempt at a meeting in the yard was foiled by the appearance of Mrs. Weasley carrying a large basket of laundry in her arms.
"Oh, good, you’ve fed the chickens," she called as she approached them. "We’d better shut them away again before the men arrive tomorrow . . . to put up the tent for the wedding," she explained, pausing to lean against the henhouse. She looked exhausted. "Millamant’s Magic Marquees . . . they’re very good. Ron’s escorting them. . . . You’d better stay inside while they’re here, Ron. I must say it does complicate organizing a wedding, having all these security spells around the place."
"I’m sorry," said Ron humbly.
