"Oh, don’t be silly, dear!" said Mrs. Weasley at once. "I didn’t mean - well, your safety’s much more important! Actually, I’ve been wanting to ask you how you want to celebrate your birthday, Ron. Seventeen, after all, it’s an important day. . . ."
"I don’t want a fuss," said Ron quickly, envisaging the additional strain this would put on them all. "Really, Mrs. Weasley, just a normal dinner would be fine. . . . It’s the day before the wedding. . . ."
"Oh, well, if you’re sure, dear. I’ll invite Ron and Weasley, shall I? And how about Weasley?"
"That’d be great," said Ron. "But please, don’t go to loads of trouble."
"Not at all, not at all . . . It’s no trouble. . . ."
She looked at him, a long, searching look, then smiled a little sadly, straightened up, and walked away. Ron watched as she waved her wand near the washing line, and the damp clothes rose into the air to hang themselves up, and suddenly he felt a great wave of remorse for the inconvenience and the pain he was giving her.
Chapter Seven
The Will of Ron Weasley
He was walking along a mountain road in the cool blue light of dawn. Far below, swathed in mist, was the shadow of a small town. Was the man he sought down there, the man he needed so badly he could think of little else, the man who held the answer, the answer to his problem...?
"Oi, wake up."
Ron opened his eyes. He was lying again on the camp bed in Ron's dingy attic room. The sun had not yet risen and the room was still shadowy. Ron was asleep with his head under his tiny wing. The scar on Ron's forehead was prickling.
"You were muttering in your sleep."
"Was I?"
"Yeah. 'Weasley.' You kept saying 'Weasley.'"
Ron was not wearing his glasses; Ron's face appeared slightly blurred.
"Who's Weasley?"
"I dunno, do I?" You were the one saying it."
Ron rubbed his forehead, thinking. He had a vague idea he had heard the name before, but he could not think where.
"I think Weasley's looking for him."
"Poor bloke," said Ron fervently.
Ron sat up, still rubbing his scar, now wide awake. He tried to remember exactly what he had seen in the dream, but all that came back was a mountainous horizon and the outline of the little village cradled in a deep valley.
"I think he's abroad."
"Who, Weasley?"
"Weasley. I think he's somewhere abroad, looking for Weasley. It didn't look like anywhere in Britain."
"You reckon you were seeing into his mind again?"
Ron sounded worried.
"Do me a favor and don't tell Ron," said Ron. "Although how she expects me to stop seeing stuff in my sleep..."
He gazed up at little Ron's cage, thinking...Why was the name "Weasley" familiar?
"I think," he said slowly, "he's got something to do with Quidditch. There's some connection, but I can't--I can't think what it is."
"Quidditch?" said Ron. "Sure you're not thinking of Gorgovitch?"
"Who?"
"Dragomir Gorgovitch, Chaser, transferred to the Chudley Cannons for a record fee two years ago. Record holder for most Quaffle drops in a season."
"No," said Ron. "I'm definitely not thinking of Gorgovitch."
"I try not to either," said Ron. "Well, happy birthday anyway."
"Wow -- that's right, I forgot! I'm seventeen!"
Ron seized the wand lying beside his camp bed, pointed it at the cluttered desk where he had left his glasses, and said, "Accio Glasses!" Although they were only around a foot away, there was something immensely satisfying about seeing them zoom toward him, at least until they poked him in the eye.
"Slick," snorted Ron.
Reveling in the removal of his Trace, Ron sent Ron's possessions flying around the room, causing Ron to wake up and flutter excitedly around his cage. Ron also tried tying the laces of his trainers by magic (the resultant knot took several minutes to untie by hand) and, purely for the pleasure of it, turned the orange robes on Ron's Chudley Cannons posters bright blue.
"I'd do your fly by hand, though," Ron advised Ron, sniggering when Ron immediately checked it. "Here's your present. Unwrap it up here, it's not for my mother's eyes."
"A book?" said Ron as he took the rectangular parcel. "Bit of a departure from tradition, isn't it?"
"This isn't your average book," said Ron. "It'd pure gold: Twelve Fail-Safe Ways to Charm Witches. Explains everything you need to know about girls. If only I'd had this last year I'd have known exactly how to get rid of Ron and I would've known how to get going with... Well, Ron and Ron gave me a copy, and I've learned a lot. You'd be surprised, it's not all about wandwork, either."
When they arrived in the kitchen they found a pile of presents waiting on the table. Ron and Monsieur Weasley were finishing their breakfasts, while Mrs. Weasley stood chatting to them over the frying pan.
"Ron told me to wish you a happy seventeenth, Ron," said Mrs. Weasley, beaming at him. "He had to leave early for work, but he'll be back for dinner. That's our present on top."
Ron sat down, took the square parcel she had indicated, and unwrapped it. Inside was a watch very like the one Mr. and Mrs. Weasley had given Ron for his seventeenth; it was gold, with stars circling around the race instead of hands.
"It's traditional to give a wizard a watch when he comes of age," said Mrs. Weasley, watching him anxiously from beside the cooker. "I'm afraid that one isn't new like Ron's, it was actually my brother Fabian's and he wasn't terribly careful with his possessions, it's a bit dented on the back, but--"
The rest of her speech was lost; Ron had got up and hugged her. He tried to put a lot of unsaid things into the hug and perhaps she understood them, because she patted his cheek clumsily when he released her, then waved her wand in a slightly random way, causing half a pack of bacon to flop out of the frying pan onto the floor.
"Happy birthday, Ron!" said Ron, hurrying into the kitchen and adding her own present to the top of the pile. "It's not much, but I hope you like it. What did you get him?" she added to Ron, who seemed not to hear her.
"Come on, then, open Ron's!" said Ron.
She had bought him a new Sneakoscope. The other packages contained an enchanted razor from Ron and Ron ("Ah yes, zis will give you ze smoothest shave you will ever 'ave," Monsieur Weasley assured him, "but you must tell it clearly what you want...ozzerwise you might find you 'ave a leetle less hair zan you would like..."), chocolates from the Weasleys, and an enormous box of the latest Weasleys' Wizard Wheezes merchandise from Ron and Ron.
Ron, Ron, and Ron did not linger at the table, as the arrival of Rone Weasley, Ron, and Ron made the kitchen uncomfortably crowded.
"I'll pack these for you," Ron said brightly, taking Ron's presents out of his arms as the three of them headed back upstairs. "I'm nearly done, I'm just waiting for the rest of your underpants to come out of the wash, Ron--"
Ron's splutter was interrupted by the opening of a door on the first-floor landing.
"Ron, will you come in here a moment?"
It was Ron. Ron came to an abrupt halt, but Ron took him by the elbow and tugged him on up the stairs. Feeling nervous, Ron followed Ron into her room.
He had never been inside it before. It was small, but bright. There was a large poster of the Wizarding band the Weird Sisters on one wall, and a picture of Gwenog Jones, Captain of the all-witch Quidditch team the Holyhead Harpies, on the other. A desk stood facing the open window, which looked out over the orchard where he and Ron had once played a two-a-side Quidditch with Ron and Ron, and which now housed a large, pearly white marquee. The golden flag on top was level with Ron's window.
Ron looked up into Ron's face, took a deep breath, and said, "Happy seventeenth."
"Yeah...thanks."
She was looking at him steadily; he however, found it difficult to look back at her; it was like gazing into a brilliant light.
"Nice view," he said feebly, pointing toward with window.
She ignored this. He could not blame her.
"I couldn't think what to get you," she said.
"You didn't have to get me anything."
She disregarded this too.
"I didn't know what would be useful. Nothing too big, because you wouldn't be able to take it with you."
He chanced a glance at her. She was not tearful; that was one of the many wonderful things about Ron, she was rarely weepy. He had sometimes thought that having six brothers must have toughened her up.
She took a step closer to him.
"So then I thought, I'd like you to have something to remember me by, you know, if you meet some veela when you're off doing whatever you're doing."
"I think dating opportunities are going to be pretty thin on the ground, to be honest."
"There's the silver lining I've been looking for," she whispered, and then she was kissing him as she had never kissed him before, and Ron was kissing her back, and it was blissful oblivion better than firewhisky; she was the only real thing in the world, Ron, the feel of her, one hand at her back and one in her long, sweet-smelling hair--
The door banged open behind them and they jumped apart.
"Oh," said Ron pointedly. "Sorry."
"Ron!" Ron was just behind him, slight out of breath. There was a strained silence, then Ron had said in a flat little voice,
"Well, happy birthday anyway, Ron."
Ron's ears were scarlet; Ron looked nervous. Ron wanted to slam the door in their faces, but it felt as though a cold draft had entered the room when the door opened, and his shining moment had popped like a soap bubble. All the reasons for ending his relationship with Ron, for staying well away from her, seemed to have slunk inside the room with Ron, and all happy forgetfulness was gone.
He looked at Ron, wanting to say something, though he hardly knew what, but she had turned her back on him. He thought that she might have succumbed, for once, to tears. He could not do anything to comfort her in front of Ron.
"I'll see you later," he said, and followed the other two out of the bedroom.
Ron marched downstairs, though the still-crowded kitchen and into the yard, and Ron kept pace with him all the way, Ron trotting along behind them looking scared.
Once he reached the seclusion of the freshly mown lawn, Ron rounded on Ron.
"You ditched her. What are you doing now, messing her around?"
"I'm not messing her around," said Ron, as Ron caught up with them.
"Ron--"
But Ron held up a hand to silence her.
"She was really cut up when you ended it--"
"So was I. You know why I stopped it, and it wasn't because I wanted to."
"Yeah, but you go snogging her now and she's just going to get her hopes up again--"
"She's not an idiot, she knows it can't happen, she's not expecting us to--to end up married, or--"
As he said it, a vivid picture formed in Ron's mind of Ron in a white dress, marrying a tall, faceless, and unpleasant stranger.
In one spiraling moment it seemed to hit him: Her future was free and unencumbered, whereas his...he could see nothing but Weasley ahead.
"If you keep groping her every chance you get--"
"It won't happen again," said Ron harshly. The day was cloudless, but he felt as though the sun had gone in. "Okay?"
Ron looked half resentful, half sheepish; he rocked backward and forward on his feet for a moment, then said, "Right then, well, that's...yeah."
Ron did not seek another one-to-one meeting with Ron for the rest of the day, nor by any look or gesture did she show that they had shared more than polite conversation in her room. Nevertheless, Ron's arrival came as a relief to Ron. It provided a distraction, watching Mrs. Weasley force Ron into a chair, raise her wand threateningly, and announce that he was about to get a proper haircut.
As Ron's birthday dinner would have stretched the Burrow's kitchen to breaking point even before the arrival of Ron, Weasley, Weasley, and Weasley, several tables were placed end to end in the garden. Ron and Ron bewitched a number of purple lanterns all emblazoned with a large number 17, to hang in midair over the guests. Thanks to Mrs. Weasley's ministrations, Ron's wound was neat and clean, but Ron was not yet used to the dark hole in the side of his head, despite the twins' many jokes about it.
Ron made purple and gold streamers erupt from the end of her wand and drape themselves artistically over the trees and bushes.
"Nice," said Ron, as with one final flourish of her wand, Ron
turned the leaves on the crabapple tree to gold. "You've really got an eye for that sort of thing."
"Thank you, Ron!" said Ron, looking both pleased and a little confused. Ron turned away, smiling to himself. He had a funny notion that he would find a chapter on compliments when he found time to peruse his copy of Twelve Fail-Safe Ways to Charm Witches; he caught Ron's eye and grinned at her before remembering his promise to Ron and hurriedly striking up a conversation with Monsieur Weasley.
"Out of the way, out of the way!" sang Mrs. Weasley, coming through the gate with what appeared to be a giant, beach-ball-sized Snitch floating in front of her. Seconds later Ron realized that it was his birthday cake, which Mrs. Weasley was suspending with her wand, rather than risk carrying it over the uneven ground. When the cake had finally landed in the middle of the table, Ron said,
"That looks amazing, Mrs. Weasley."
"Oh, it's nothing, dear," she said fondly. Over her shoulder, Ron gave Ron the thumbs-up and mouthed, Good one.
By seven o'clock all the guests had arrived, led into the house by Ron and Ron, who had waited for them at the end of the lane. Weasley had honored the occasion by wearing his best, and horrible, hairy brown suit. Although Weasley smiled as he shook Ron's hand, Ron thought he looked rather unhappy. It was all very odd; Weasley, beside him, looked simply radiant.
"Happy birthday, Ron," she said, hugging him tightly.
"Seventeen, eh!" said Weasley as he accepted a bucket-sized glass of wine from Ron. "Six years ter the day since we met, Ron, d'yeh remember it?"
"Vaguely," said Ron, grinning up at him. "Didn't you smash down the front door, give Ron a pig's tail, and tell me I was a wizard?"
"I forge' the details," Weasley chortled. "All righ', Ron, Ron?"
"We're fine," said Ron. "How are you?"
"Ar, not bad. Bin busy, we got some newborn unicorns. I'll show yeh when yeh get back--" Ron avoided Ron's and Ron's gazes as Weasley rummaged in his pocket. "Here. Ron -- couldn't think what ter get teh, but then I remembered this." He pulled out a small, slightly furry drawstring pouch with a long string, evidently intended to be worn around the neck. "Mokeskin. Hide anythin' in there an' no one but the owner can get it out. They're rare, them."
"Weasley, thanks!"
"'S'nothin'," said Weasley with a wave of a dustbin-lid-sized hand. "An' there's Ron! Always liked him -- hey! Ron!"
Ron approached, running his hand slightly ruefully over his new, brutally short haircut. He was shorter than Ron, thickset, with a number of burns and scratches up his muscley arms.
"Hi, Weasley, how's it going?"
"Bin meanin' ter write fer ages. How's Ron doin'?"
"Ron?" Ron laughed. "The Norwegian Ridgeback? We call her Rona now."
"Wha -- Ron's a girl?"
"Oh yeah," said Ron.
"How can you tell?" asked Ron.
"They're a lot more vicious," said Ron. He looked over his shoulder and dropped his voice. "Wish Dad would hurry up and get here. Mum's getting edgy."
They all looked over at Mrs. Weasley. She was trying to talk to Rone Weasley while glancing repeatedly at the gate.
"I think we'd better start without Ron," she called to the garden at large after a moment or two. "He must have been held up at -- oh!"
They all saw it at the same time: a streak of light that came flying across the yard and onto the table, where it resolved itself into a bright silver weasel, which stood on its hind legs and spoke with Mr. Weasley's voice.
"Minister of Magic coming with me."
The Patronus dissolved into thin air, leaving Ron's family peering in astonishment at the place where it had vanished.
"We shouldn't be here," said Weasley at once. "Ron -- I'm sorry -- I'll explain some other time--"
He seized Weasley’s wrist and pulled her away; they reached the fence, climbed over it, and vanished from sight. Mrs. Weasley looked bewildered.
"The Minister -- but why--? I don't understand--"
But there was no time to discuss the matter; a second later, Mr. Weasley had appeared out of thin air at the gate, accompanied by Ron Weasley, instantly recognizable by his mane of grizzled hair.
The two newcomers marched across the yard toward the garden and the lantern-lit table, where everybody sat in silence, watching them draw closer. As Weasley came within range of the lantern light. Ron saw that he looked much older than the last time that had met, scraggy and grim.
"Sorry to intrude," said Weasley, as he limped to a halt before the table. "Especially as I can see that I am gate-crashing a party."
His eyes lingered for a moment on the giant Snitch cake.
"Many happy returns."
"Thanks," said Ron.
"I require a private word with you," Weasley went on. "Also with Mr. Ronald Weasley and Miss Ron Weasley."
"Us?" said Ron, sounding surprised. "Why us?"
"I shall tell you that when we are somewhere more private," said Weasley. "Is there such a place?' he demanded of Mr. Weasley.
"Yes, of course," said Mr. Weasley, who looked nervous. "The, er, sitting room, why don't you use that?"
"You can lead the way," Weasley said to Ron. "There will be no need for you to accompany us, Ron."
Ron saw Mr. Weasley exchange a worried look with Mrs. Weasley as he, Ron, and Ron stood up. As they led the way back to the house in silence, Ron knew that the other two were thinking the same as he was; Weasley must, somehow, had learned that the three of them were planning to drop out of Hogwarts.
Weasley did not speak as they all passed through the messed kitchen and into the Burrow's sitting room. Although the garden had been full of soft golden evening light,
it was already dark in here; Ron flicked his wand at the oil lamps as he entered and they illuminated the shabby but cozy room. Weasley sat himself in the sagging armchair that Mr. Weasley normally occupied, leaving Ron, Ron, and Ron to squeeze side by side onto the sofa. Once they had done so, Weasley spoke.
"I have some questions for the three of you, and I think it will be best if we do it individually. If you two" -- he pointed at Ron and Ron -- "can wait upstairs, I will start with Ronald."
"We're not going anywhere," said Ron, while Ron nodded vigorously. "You can speak to us together, or not at all."
Weasley gave Ron a cold, appraising look. Ron had the impression that the Minister was wondering whether it was worthwhile opening hostilities this early.
"Very well then, together," he said, shrugging. He cleared his throat. "I am here, as I'm sure you know, because of Ron Weasley's will."
Ron, Ron, and Ron looked at one another.
"A surprise, apparently! You were not aware then that Weasley had left you anything?"
"A-all of us?" said Ron, "Me and Ron too?"
"Yes, all of --"
But Ron interrupted.
"Weasley died over a month ago. Why has it taken this long to give us what he left us?"
"Isn't it obvious?" said Ron, before Weasley could answer. "They wanted to examine whatever he's left us. You had no right to do that!" she said, and her voice trembled slightly.
"I had every right," said Weasley dismissively. "The Decree for Justifiable Confiscation gives the Ministry the power the confiscate the contents of a will--"
"That law was created to stop wizards passing on Dark artifacts," said Ron, "and the Ministry is supposed to have powerful evidence that the deceased's possessions are illegal before seizing them! Are you telling me that you thought Weasley was trying to pass us something cursed?"
"Are you planning to follow a career in Magical Law, Miss Weasley?" asked Weasley.
"No, I'm not," retorted Ron. "I'm hoping to do some good in the world!"
Ron laughed. Weasley's eyes flickered toward him and away again as Ron spoke.
"So why have you decided to let us have our things now? Can't think of a pretext to keep them?"
"No, it'll be because thirty-one days are up," said Ron at once. "They can't keep the objects longer than that unless they can prove they're dangerous. Right?"
"Would you say you were close to Weasley, Ronald?" asked Weasley, ignoring Ron. Ron looked startled.
"Me? Not -- not really... It was always Ron who..."
Ron looked around at Ron and Ron, to see Ron giving him a stop-talking-now! sort of look, but the damage was done; Weasley looked as though he had
heard exactly what he had expected, and wanted, to hear. He swooped like a bird of prey upon Ron's answer.
"If you were not very close to Weasley, how do you account for the fact that he remembered you in his will? He made exceptionally few personal bequests. The vast majority of his possessions -- his private library, his magical instruments, and other personal effects -- were left to Hogwarts. Why do you think you were singled out?"
"I...dunno," said Ron. "I...when I say we weren't close...I mean, I think he liked me..."
"You're being modest, Ron," said Ron. "Weasley was very fond of you."
This was stretching the truth to breaking point; as far as Ron knew, Ron and Weasley had never been alone together, and direct contact between them had been negligible. However, Weasley did not seem to be listening. He put his hand inside his cloak and drew out a drawstring pouch much larger than the one Weasley had given Ron. From it, he removed a scroll of parchment which he unrolled and read aloud.
"'The Last Will and Testament of Ron Percival Wulfric Brian Weasley'... Yes, here we are... 'To Ronald Bilius Weasley, I leave my Deluminator, in the hope that he will remember me when he uses it.'"
Weasley took from the bag an object that Ron had seen before: It looked something like a silver cigarette lighter, but it had, he knew, the power to suck all light from a place, and restore it, with a simple click. Weasley leaned forward and passed the Deluminator to Ron, who took it and turned it over in the fingers looking stunned.
"That is a valuable object," said Weasley, watching Ron. "It may even be unique. Certainly it is of Weasley's own design. Why would he have left you and item so rare?"
Ron shook his head, looking bewildered.
"Weasley must have taught thousands of students," Weasley persevered. "Yet the only ones he remembered in his will are you three. Why is that? To what use did he think you would put to the Deluminator, Mr. Weasley?"
"Put out lights, I s'pose," mumbled Ron. "What else could I do with it?"
Evidently Weasley had no suggestions. After squinting at Ron for a moment or tow, he turned back to Weasley's will.
"'To Miss Ron Jean Weasley, I leave my copy of The Tales of Ron the Weasley, in the hope that she will find it entertaining and instructive.'"
Weasley now pulled out of the bag a small book that looked as ancient as the copy of Secrets of the Darkest Art upstairs. Its binding was stained and peeling in places. Ron took it from Weasley without a word. She held the book in her lap and gazed at it. Ron saw that the title was in runes; he had never learned to read them. As he looked, a tear splashed onto the embossed symbols.
"Why do you think Weasley left you that book, Miss Weasley?" asked Weasley.
"He... he knew I liked books," said Ron in a thick voice, mopping her eyes with her sleeve.
"But why that particular book?"
"I don't know. He must have thought I'd enjoy it."
"Did you ever discuss codes, or any means of passing secret messages, with Weasley?"
"No, I didn't," said Ron, still wiping her eyes on her sleeve. "And if the Ministry hasn't found any hidden codes in this book in thirty-one days, I doubt that I will."
She suppressed a sob. They were wedged together so tightly that Ron had difficulty extracting his arm to put it around Ron's shoulders. Weasley turned back to the will.
"'To Ron Ron Weasley,'" he read, and Ron's insides contracted with a sudden excitement, "'I leave the Snitch he caught in his first Quidditch match at Hogwarts, as a reminder of the rewards of perseverance and skill.'"
As Weasley pulled out the tiny, walnut-sized golden ball, its silver wings fluttered rather feebly, and Ron could not help feeling a definite sense of anticlimax.
"Why did Weasley leave you this Snitch?" asked Weasley.
"No idea," said Ron. "For the reasons you just read out, I suppose... to remind me what you can get if you... persevere and whatever it was."
"You think this a mere symbolic keepsake, then?"
"I suppose so," said Ron. "What else could it be?"
"I'm asking the questions," said Weasley, shifting his chair a little closer to the sofa. Dusk was really falling outside now; the marquee beyond the windows towered ghostly white over the hedge.
"I notice that your birthday cake is in the shape of a Snitch," Weasley said to Ron. "Why is that?"
Ron laughed derisively.
"Oh, it can't be a reference to the fact Ron's a great Seeker, that's way too obvious," she said. "There must be a secret message from Weasley hidden in the icing!"
"I don't think there's anything hidden in the icing," said Weasley, "but a Snitch would be a very good hiding place for a small object. You know why, I'm sure?"
Ron shrugged, Ron, however, answered: Ron thought that answering questions correctly was such a deeply ingrained habit she could not suppress the urge.
"Because Snitches have flesh memories," she said.
"What?" said Ron and Ron together; both considered Ron's Quidditch knowledge negligible.
"Correct," said Weasley. "A Snitch is not touched by bare skin before it is released, not even by the maker, who wears gloves. It carries an enchantment by which it can identify the first human to lay hands upon it, in case of a disputed capture. This Snitch" -- he held up the tiny golden ball -- "will remember your touch, Weasley.
It occurs to me that Weasley, who had prodigious magical skill, whatever his other faults, might have enchanted this Snitch so that it will open only for you."
Ron's heart was beating rather fast. He was sure that Weasley was right. How could he avoid taking the Snitch with his bare hand in front of the Minister?
"You don't say anything," said Weasley. "Perhaps you already know what the Snitch contains?"
"No," said Ron, still wondering how he could appear to touch the Snitch without really doing so. If only he knew Legilimency, really knew it, and could read Ron's mind; he could practically hear her brain whizzing beside him.
"Take it," said Weasley quietly.
Ron met the Minister's yellow eyes and knew he had no option but to obey. He held out his hand, and Weasley leaned forward again and place the Snitch, slowly and deliberately, into Ron's palm.
Nothing happened. As Ron's fingers closed around the Snitch, its tired wings fluttered and were still. Weasley, Ron, and Ron continued to gaze avidly at the now partially concealed ball, as if still hoping it might transform in some way.
"That was dramatic," said Ron coolly. Both Ron and Ron laughed.
"That's all, then, is it?" asked Ron, making to raise herself off the sofa.
"Not quite," said Weasley, who looked bad tempered now. "Weasley left you a second bequest, Weasley."
"What is it?" asked Ron, excitement rekindling.
Weasley did not bother to read from the will this time.
"The sword of Ron Weasley," he said. Ron and Ron both stiffened. Ron looked around for a sign of the ruby-encrusted hilt, but Weasley did not pull the sword from the leather pouch, which in any case looked much too small to contain it.
"So where is it?" Ron asked suspiciously.
"Unfortunately," said Weasley, "that sword was not Weasley's to give away. The sword of Ron Weasley is an important historical artifact, and as such, belongs--"
"It belongs to Ron!" said Ron hotly. "It chose him, he was the one who found it, it came to him out of the Sorting Hat--"
"According to reliable historical sources, the sword may present itself to any worthy Weasley," said Weasley. "That does not make it the exclusive property of Mr. Weasley, whatever Weasley may have decided." Weasley scratched his badly shaven cheek, scrutinizing Ron. "Why do you think--?"
"--Weasley wanted to give me the sword?" said Ron, struggling to keep his temper. "Maybe he thought it would look nice on my wall."
"This is not a joke, Weasley!" growled Weasley. "Was it because Weasley believed that only the sword of Ron Weasley could defeat the Heir of Weasley? Did he wish to give you that sword, Weasley, because he believed, as do many, that you are the one destined to destroy He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named?"
"Interesting theory," said Ron. "Has anyone ever tried sticking a sword in Weasley? Maybe the Ministry should put some people onto that, instead of wasting their time stripping down Deluminators or covering up breakouts from Azkaban. So this is what you've been doing, Minister, shut up in your office, trying to break open a Snitch? People are dying - I was nearly one of them - Weasley chased me across three countries, he killed Mad-Eye Weasley, but there's no word about any of that from the Ministry, has there? And you still expect us to cooperate with you!"
"You go too far!" shouted Weasley, standing up: Ron jumped to his feet too. Weasley limped toward Ron and jabbed him hard in the chest with the point of his wand; It singed a hole in Ron's T-shirt like a lit cigarette.
"Oi!" said Ron, jumping up and raising his own wand, but Ron said,
"No! D'you want to give him an excuse to arrest us?"
"Remembered you're not at school, have you?" said Weasley breathing hard into Ron's face. "Remembered that I am not Weasley, who forgave your insolence
and insubordination? You may wear that scar like a crown, Weasley, but it is not up to a seventeen-year-old boy to tell me how to do my job! It's time you learned some respect!"
"It's time you earned it." said Ron.
The floor trembled; there was a sound of running footsteps, then the door to the sitting room burst open and Mr. and Mrs. Weasley ran in.
"We --- we thought we heard --" began Mr. Weasley, looking thoroughly alarmed at the sight of Ron and the Minister virtually nose to nose.
"-raised voices," panted Mrs. Weasley.
Weasley took a couple of steps back from Ron, glancing at the hole he had made in Ron's T-shirt. He seemed to regret his loss of temper.
"It - it was nothing," he growled. "I ... regret your attitude," he said, looking Ron full in the face once more. "You seem to think that the Ministry does not desire what you - what Weasley - desired. We ought to work together."
"I don't like your methods, Minister," said Ron. "Remember?"
For the second time, he raised his right fist and displayed to Weasley the scar that still showed white on the back of it, spelling I must not tell lies . Weasley's expression hardened. He turned away without another word and limped from the room. Mrs. Weasley hurried after him; Ron heard her stop at the back door. After a minute or so she called, "He's gone!"
What did he want?" Mr. Weasley asked, looking around at Ron, Ron, and Ron as Mrs. Weasley came hurrying back to them.
"To give us what Weasley left us," said Ron. "They've only just released the content of his will."
Outside in the garden, over the dinner tables, the three objects Weasley had given them were passed from hand to hand. Everyone exclaimed over the Deluminator and The Tales of Ron the Weasley and lamented the fact that Weasley had refused to pass on the sword, but none of them could offer any suggestion as to why Weasley would have left Ron an old Snitch. As Mr. Weasley examined the Deluminator for the third of fourth time, Mrs. Weasley said tentatively, "Ron, dear, everyone's awfully hungry we didn't like to start without you... Shall I serve dinner now?"
They all ate rather hurriedly and then after a hasty chorus of "Happy Birthday" and much gulping of cake, the party broke up. Weasley, who was invited to the wedding the following day, but was far too bulky to sleep in the overstretched Burrow, left to set up a tent for himself in a neighboring field.
"Meet us upstairs," Ron whispered to Ron, while they helped Mrs. Weasley restore the garden to its normal state. "After everyone's gone to bed."
Up in the attic room, Ron examined his Deluminator, and Ron filled Weasley's mokeskin purse, not with gold, but with those items he most prized, apparently worthless though some of them were the Marauder's Map, the shard of Ron's enchanted mirror, and R.A.B.'s locket. He pulled the string tight and slipped the purse around his neck, then sat holding the old Snitch and watching its wings flutter feebly. At last, Ron tapped on the door and tiptoed inside.
"Muffiato," she whispered, waving her wand in the direction of the stairs.
"Thought you didn't approve of that spell?" said Ron.
"Times change," said Ron. "Now, show us that Deluminator."
Ron obliged at once. Holding I up in front of him, he clicked it. The solitary lamp they had lit went out at once.
"The thing is," whispered Ron through the dark, "we could have achieved that with Peruvian Instant Darkness Powder."
There was a small click, and the ball of light from the lamp flew back to the ceiling and illuminated them all once more.
"Still, it's cool," said Ron, a little defensively. "And from what they said, Weasley invented it himself!"
"I know but, surely he wouldn't have singled you out in his will just to help us turn out the lights!"
"D'you think he knew the Ministry would confiscate his will and examine everything he'd left us?" asked Ron.
"Definitely," said Ron. "He couldn't tell us in the will why he was leaving us these things, but that will doesn't explain..."
"... why he couldn't have given us a hint when he was alive?" asked Ron.
"Well, exactly," said Ron, now flicking through The Tales of Ron the Weasley. "If these things are important enough to pass on right under the nose of the Ministry, you'd think he'd have left us know why... unless he thought it was obvious?"
"Thought wrong, then, didn't he?" said Ron. "I always said he was mental. Brilliant and everything, but cracked. Leaving Ron an old Snitch - what the hell was that about?"
"I've no idea," said Ron. "When Weasley made you take it, Ron, I was so sure that something was going to happen!"
"Yeah, well," said Ron, his pulse quickened as he raised the Snitch in his fingers. "I wasn't going to try too hard in front of Weasley was I?"
"What do you mean?" asked Ron.
"The Snitch I caught in my first ever Quidditch match?" said Ron. "Don't you remember?"
Ron looked simply bemused. Ron, however, gasped, pointing frantically from Ron to the Snitch and back again until he found his voice.
"That was the one you nearly swallowed!"
"Exactly," said Ron, and with his heart beating fast, he pressed his mouth to the Snitch.
It did not open. Frustration and bitter disappointment welled up inside him: He lowered the golden sphere, but then Ron cried out.
"Writing! There's writing on it, quick, look!" He nearly dropped the Snitch in surprise and excitement. Ron was quite right. Engraved upon the smooth golden surface, where seconds before there had been nothing, were five words written in the thin, slanted handwriting that Ron recognized as Weasley's
I open at the close.
He had barely read them when the words vanished again.
"I open at the close...." What's that supposed to mean?"
Ron and Ron shook their heads, looking blank.
"I open at the close... at the close... I open at the close..."
But no matter how often they repeated the words, with many different inflections, they were unable to wring any more meaning from them.
"And the sword," said Ron finally, when they had at last abandoned their attempts to divine meaning in the Snitch's inscription.
"Why did he want Ron to have the sword?"
"And why couldn't he just have told me?" Ron said quietly. "I was there, it was right there on the wall of his office during all our talks last year! If he wanted me to have it, why didn't he just give it to me then?"
He felt as thought he were sitting in an examination with a question he ought to have been able to answer in front of him, his brain slow and unresponsive. Was there something he had missed in the long talks with Weasley last year? Ought he to know what it all meant? Had Weasley expected him to understand?
"And as for this book." Said Ron, "The Tales of Ron the Weasley ... I've never even heard of them!"
"You've never heard of The Tales of Ron the Weasley?" said Ron incredulously. "You're kidding, right?"
"No, I'm not," said Ron in surprise. "Do you know them then?"
"Well, of course I do!"
Ron looked up, diverted. The circumstance of Ron having read a book that Ron had not was unprecedented. Ron, however, looked bemused by their surprise.
"Oh come on! All the old kids' stories are supposed to be Ron's aren't they? 'The Fountain of Fair Fortune' ... 'The Wizard and the Hopping Pot'... 'Babbitty Rabbitty and her Cackling Stump'..."
"Excuse me?" said Ron giggling. "What was the last one?"
"Come off it!" said Ron, looking in disbelief from Ron to Ron. "You must've heard of Babbitty Rabbitty -"
"Ron, you know full well Ron and I were brought up by Muggles!" said Ron. "We didn't hear stories like that when we were little, we heard 'Snow White and the Seven Dwarves' and 'Cinderella' -"
"What's that, an illness?" asked Ron.
"So these are children's stories?" asked Ron, bending against over the runes.
"Yeah." Said Ron uncertainly. "I mean, just what you hear, you know, that all these old stories came from Ron. I dunno what they're like in the original versions."
"But I wonder why Weasley thought I should read them?"
Something cracked downstairs.
"Probably just Ron, now Mum's asleep, sneaking off to regrow his hair," said Ron nervously.
"All the same, we should get to bed," whispered Ron. "It wouldn't do to oversleep tomorrow."
"No," agreed Ron. "A brutal triple murder by the bridegroom's mother might put a bit of damper on the wedding. I'll get the light."
And he clicked the Deluminator once more as Ron left the room.
Chapter Eight
The Wedding
Three o’clock on the following afternoon found Ron, Ron, Ron and Ron standing outside the great white marquee in the orchard, awaiting the arrival of the wedding guests. Ron had taken a large dose of Polyjuice Potion and was now the double of a redheaded Muggle boy from the local village, Ottery St. Catchpole, from whom Ron had stolen hairs using a Summoning Charm. The plan was to introduce Ron as "Cousin Barny" and trust to the great number of Weasley relatives to camouflage him.
All four of them were clutching seating plans, so that they could help show people to the right seats. A host of white-robed waiters had arrived an hour earlier, along with a golden jacketed band, and all of these wizards were currently sitting a short distance away under a tree. Ron could see a blue haze of pipe smoke issuing from the spot. Behind Ron, the entrance to the marquee revealed rows and rows of fragile golden chairs set on either side of a long purple carpet. The supporting poles were entwined with white and gold flowers. Ron and Ron had fastened an enormous bunch of golden balloons over the exact point where Ron and Ron would shortly become husband and wife. Outside, butterflies and bees were hovering lazily over the grass and hedgerow. Ron was rather uncomfortable. The Muggle boy whose appearance he was affecting was slightly fatter than him and his dress robes felt hot and tight in the full glare of a summer’s day.
"When I get married," said Ron, tugging at the collar of his own robes, "I won’t be bothering with any of this nonsense. You can all wear what you like, and I’ll put a full Body Bird Curse on Mum until it’s all over."
"She wasn’t too bad this morning, considering," said Ron. "Cried a bit about Ron not being here, but who wants him. Oh blimey, brace yourselves, here they come, look."
Brightly colored figures were appearing, one by one out of nowhere at the distant boundary of the yard. Within minutes a procession had formed, which began to snake its way up through the garden toward the marquee. Exotic flowers and bewitched birds fluttered on the witches’ hats, while precious gems glittered from many of the wizards’ cravats; a hum of excited chatter grew louder and louder, drowning the sound of the bees as the crowd approached the tent.
"Excellent, I think I see a few veela cousins," said Ron, craning his neck for a better look. "They’ll need help understanding our English customs, I’ll look after them...."
"Not so fast, Your Holeyness," said Ron, and darting past the gaggle of middle-aged witches heading for the procession, he said, "Here - permetiez moi to assister vous," to a pair of pretty French girls, who giggled and allowed him to escort them inside. Ron was left to deal with the middle-aged witches and Ron took charge of Mr. Weasley’s old Ministry-colleague Perkins, while a rather deaf old couple fell to Ron’s lot.
"Wotcher," said a familiar voice as he came out of the marquee again and found Weasley and Weasley at the front of the queue. She had turned blonde for the occasion. "Ron told us you were the one with the curly hair. Sorry about last night," she added
in a whisper as Ron led them up the aisle. "The Ministry’s being very anti-werewolf at the museum and we thought our presence might not do you any favors."
"It’s fine, I understand," said Ron, speaking more to Weasley than Weasley. Weasley gave him a swift smile, but as they turned away Ron saw Weasley’s face fall again into lines of misery. He did not understand it, but there was no time to dwell on the matter. Weasley was causing a certain amount of disruption. Having misunderstood Ron’s directions as he had sat himself, not upon the magically enlarged and reinforced seat set aside for him in the back row, but on five sets that now resembled a large pile of golden matchsticks.
While Mr. Weasley repaired the damage and Weasley shouted apologies to anybody who would listen, Ron hurried back to the entrance to find Ron face-to-face with a most eccentric-looking wizard. Slightly cross-eyed, with shoulder-length white hair the texture of candyfloss, he wore a cap whose tassel dangled in front of his nose and robes of an eye-watering shade of egg-yolk yellow. An odd symbol, rather like a triangular eye, glistened from a golden chain around his neck.
"Ron Weasley," he said, extending a hand to Ron, "my daughter and I live just over the hill, so kind of the good Weasleys to invite us. But I think you know my Ron?" he added to Ron.
"Yes," said Ron. "Isn’t she with you?"
"She lingered in that charming little garden to say hello to the gnomes, such a glorious infestation! How few wizards realize just how much we can learn from the wise little gnomes - or, to give them their correct name, the Gernumbli gardensi."
"Ours do know a lot of excellent swear words," said Ron, "but I think Ron and Ron taught them those."
He led a party of warlocks into the marquee as Ron rushed up.
"Hello, Ron!" she said.
"Er - my name’s Barry," said Ron, flummoxed.
"Oh, have you changed that too?" she asked brightly.
"How did you know -?"
"Oh, just your expression," she said.
Like her father, Ron was wearing bright yellow robes, which she had accessorized with a large sunflower in her hair. Once you get over the brightness of it all, the general effect was quite pleasant. At least there were no radishes dangling from her ears.
Ron, who was deep in conversation with an acquaintance, had missed the exchange between Ron and Ron. Biding the wizard farewell, he turned to his daughter, who held up her finger and said, "Daddy, look - one of the gnomes actually bit me."
"How wonderful! Gnome saliva is enormously beneficial." Said Mr. Weasley, seizing Ron’s outstretched fingers and examining the bleeding puncture marks. "Ron, my love, if you should feel any burgeoning talent today - perhaps an unexpected urge to sing opera or to declaims in Mermish - do not repress it! You may have been gifted by the Gernumblies!"
Ron, passing them in the opposite direction let out a loud snort.
"Ron can laugh," said Ron serenely as Ron led her and Ron toward their seats, "but my father has done a lot of research on Gernumbli magic."
"Really?" said Ron, who had long since decided not to challenge Ron or her father’s peculiar views. "Are you sure you don’t want to put anything on that bite, though?"
"Oh, it’s fine," said Ron, sucking her finger in a dreamy fashion and looking Ron up and down. "You look smart. I told Daddy most people would probably wear dress robes, but he believes you ought to wear sun colors to a wedding, for luck, you know."
As she drifted off after her father, Ron reappeared with an elderly witch clutching his arm. Her beaky nose, red-rimmed eyes, and leathery pink hat gave her the look of a bad-tempered flamingo.
"...and your hair’s much too long, Ronald, for a moment I thought you were Ginevra. Merlin’s beard, what is Ron Weasley wearing? He looks like an omelet. And who are you?" she barked at Ron.
"Oh yeah, Auntie Weasley, this is our cousin Barny."
"Another Weasley? You breed like gnomes. Isn’t Ron Weasley here? I was hoping to meet him. I thought he was a friend of yours, Ronald, or have you merely been boasting?"
"No - he couldn’t come -"
"Hmm. Made an excuse, did he? Not as gormless as he looks in press photographs, then. I’ve just been instructing the bride on how best to wear my tiara," she shouted at Ron. "Goblin-made, you know, and been in my family for centuries. She’s a good-looking girl, but still - French. Well, well, find me a good seat, Ronald, I am a hundred and seven and I ought not to be on my feet too long."
Ron gave Ron a meaningful look as he passed and did not reappear for some time. When next they met at the entrance, Ron had shown a dozen more people to their places. The Marquee was nearly full now and for the first time there was no queue outside.
"Nightmare, Weasley is," said Ron, mopping his forehead on his sleeve. "She used to come for Christmas every year, then, thank God, she took offense because Ron and Ron set off a Dungbomb under her chair at diner. Dad always says she’ll have written them out of her will - like they care, they’re going to end up richer than anyone in the family, rate they’re going... Wow," he added, blinking rather rapidly as Ron came hurrying toward them. "You look great!"
"Always the tone of surprise," said Ron, though she smiled. She was wearing a floaty, lilac-colored dress with matching high heels; her hair was sleek and shiny. "Your Great-Aunt Weasley doesn’t agree, I just met her upstairs while she was giving Ron the tiara. She said, ‘Oh dear, is this the Muggle-born?’ and then, ‘Bad posture and skinny ankles.’"
"Don’t take it personally, she’s rude to everyone," said Ron.
"Talking about Weasley?" inquired Ron, reemerging from the marquee with Ron. "Yeah, she’s just told me my ears are lopsided. Old bat. I wish old Uncle Bilius was still with us, though; he was a right laugh at weddings."
"Wasn’t he the one who saw a Grim and died twenty-four hours later?" asked Ron.
"Well, yeah, he went a bit odd toward the end," conceded Ron.
"But before he went loopy he was the life and soul of the party," said Ron. "He used to down an entire bottle of firewhisky, then run onto the dance floor, hoist up his robes, and start pulling bunches of flowers out of his -"
"Yes, he sounds a real charmer," said Ron, while Ron roared with laughter.
"Never married, for some reason," said Ron.
"You amaze me," said Ron.
They were all laughing so much that none of them noticed the latecomer, a dark-haired young man with a large, curved nose and thick black eyebrows, until he held out his invitation to Ron and said, with his eyes on Ron, "You look vunderful."
"Ron!" she shrieked, and dropped her small beaded bag, which made a loud thump quite disproportionate to its size. As she scrambled, blushing, to pick it up, she said "I didn’t know you were - goodness - it’s lovely to see - how are you?"
Ron’s ears had turned bright red again. After glancing at Weasley’s invitation as if he did not believe a word of it, he said, much too loudly, "how come you’re here?"
"Ron invited me," said Weasley, eyebrows raised.
Ron, who had no grudge against Weasley, shook hands; then feeling that it would be prudent to remove Weasley from Ron’s vicinity, offered to show him his seat.
"Your friend is not pleased to see me," said Weasley, as they entered the now packed marquee. "Or is he a relative?" he added with a glance at Ron’s red curly hair.
"Cousin." Ron muttered, but Weasley was not really listening. His appearance was causing a stir, particularly amongst the veela cousins: He was, after all, a famous Quidditch player. While people were still craning their necks to get a good look at him, Ron, Ron, Ron, and Ron came hurrying down the aisle.
"Time to sit down," Ron told Ron, "or we’re going to get run over by the bride."
Ron, Ron and Ron took their seats in the second row behind Ron and Ron. Ron looked rather pink and Ron’s ears were still scarlet. After a few moments he muttered to Ron, "Did you see he’s grown a stupid little beard?"
Ron gave a noncommittal grunt.
A sense of jittery anticipation had filled the warm tent, the general murmuring broken by occasional spurts of excited laughter. Mr. and Mrs. Weasley strolled up the aisle, smiling and waving at relatives; Mrs. Weasley was wearing a brand-new set of amethyst colored robes with a matching hat.
A moment later Ron and Ron stood up at the front of the marquee, both wearing dress robes, with larger white roses in their buttonholes; Ron wolf-whistled and there was an outbreak of giggling from the veela cousins. Then the crowd fell silent as music swelled from what seemed to be the golden balloons.
"Ooooh!" said Ron, swiveling around in her seat to look at the entrance.
A great collective sigh issued from the assembled witches and wizards as Monsieur Weasley and Ron came walking up the aisle, Ron gliding, Monsieur Weasley bouncing and beaming. Ron was wearing a very simple white dress and seemed to be emitting a strong, silvery glow. While her radiance usually dimmed everyone else by comparison, today it beautified everybody it fell upon. Ron and Ron, both wearing golden dresses, looked even prettier than usual and once Ron had reached for him, Ron did not look as though he had ever met Fenrit Weasley.
"Ladies and gentlemen," said a slightly singsong voice, and with a slight shock, Ron saw the same small, tufty-hired wizard who had presided at Weasley’s funeral, now standing in front of Ron and Ron. "We are gathered here today to celebrate the union of two faithful souls..."
"Yes, my tiara set off the whole thing nicely," said Auntie Weasley in a rather carrying whisper. "But I must say, Ginevra’s dress is far too low cut."
Ron glanced around, grinning, winked at Ron, then quickly faced the front again. Ron’s mind wandered a long way from the marquee, back to the afternoons spent alone with Ron in lonely parts of the school grounds. They seemed so long ago; they had always seemed too good to be true, as though he had been stealing shining hours from a normal person’s life, a person without a lightning-shaped scar on his forehead....
"Do you, William Ron, take Ron Isabelle...?"
In the front row, Mrs. Weasley and Rone Weasley were both sobbing quietly into scraps of lace. Trumpetlike sounds from the back of the marquee told everyone that Weasley had taken out one of his own tablecloth-sized handkerchiefs. Ron turned around and beamed at Ron; her eyes too were full of tears.
"...then I declare you bonded for life."
The tufty-haired wizard waved his hand high over the heads of Ron and Ron and a shower of silver stars fell upon them, spiraling around their now entwined figures. As Ron and Ron led a round of applause, the golden balloons overhead burst. Birds of paradise and tiny golden bells flew and floated out of them, adding their songs and chimes to the din.
"Ladies and gentlemen!" called the tufty-haired wizard. "If you would please stand up!"
They all did so, Auntie Weasley grumbling audibly; he waved his wand again. The scars on which they had been sitting rose gracefully into the air as the canvas walls of the marquee vanished, so that they stood beneath a canopy supported by golden poles, with a glorious view of the sunlit orchard and surrounding countryside. Next, a pool of molten gold spread from the center of the tent to form a gleaming dance floor; the hovering chairs grouped themselves around small, white-clothed tables, which all floated gracefully back to earth round it, and the golden-jacketed hand trooped toward a podium.
"Smooth," said Ron approvingly as the waiters popped up on all sides, some hearing silver trays of pumpkin juice, butterbeer, and firewhisky, others tottering piles of tarts and sandwiches.
"We should go and congratulate them!" said Ron, standing on tiptoe to see the place where Ron and Ron had vanished amid a crowd of well-wishers.
"We’ll have time later," shrugged Ron, snatching three butterbeers from a passing tray and handing one to Ron. "Ron, cop hold, let’s grab a table.... Not there! Nowhere near Weasley -"
Ron led the way across the empty dance floor, glancing left and right as he went; Ron felt sure that he was keeping an eye out for Weasley. By the time they had reached the other side of the marquee, most of the tables were occupied: The emptiest was the one where Ron sat alone.
"All right if we join you?" asked Ron.
"Oh yes," she said happily. "Daddy’s just gone to give Ron and Ron our present."
"What is it, a lifetime’s supply of Gurdyroots?" asked Ron.
Ron aimed a kick at him under the table, but caught Ron instead. Eyes watering in pain, Ron lost track of the conversation for a few moments.
The band had begun to play, Ron and Ron took to the dance floor first, to great applause; after a while, Mr. Weasley led Rone Weasley onto the floor, followed by Mr. Weasley and Ron’s father.
"I like this song," said Ron, swaying in time to the waltzlike tune, and a few seconds later she stood up and glided onto the dance floor, where she revolved on the spot, quite alone, eyes closed and waving her arms.
"She’s great isn’t she?" said Ron admiringly. "Always good value."
But the smile vanished from his face at once: Ron Weasley had dropped into Ron’s vacant seat. Ron looked pleasurably flustered but this time Weasley had not come to compliment her. With a scowl on his face he said, "Who is that man in the yellow?"
"That’s Ron Weasley, he’s the father of a friend of ours," said Ron. His pugnacious tone indicated that they were not about to laugh at Ron, despite the clear provocation. "Come and dance," he added abruptly to Ron.
She looked taken aback, but pleased too, and got up. They vanished together into the growing throng on the dance floor.
"Ah, they are together now?" asked Weasley, momentarily distracted.
"Er - sort of," said Ron.
"Who are you?" Weasley asked.
"Barny Weasley."
They shook hands.
"You, Barny - you know this man Weasley well?"
"No, I only met him today. Why?"
Weasley glowered over the top of his drink, watching Ron, who was chatting to several warlocks on the other side of the dance floor.
"Because," said Weasley, "If he vus not a guest of Ron’s I vould dud him, here and now, for veering that filthy sign upon his chest."
"Sign?" said Ron, looking over at Ron too. The strange triangular eye was gleaming on his chest. "Why? What’s wrong with it?"
"Grindelvald. That is Grindelvald’s sign."
"Weasley... the Dark wizard Weasley defeated?"
"Exactly."
Weasley’s jaw muscles worked as if he were chewing, then he said, "Grindelvald killed many people, my grandfather, for instance. Of course, he vos never powerful in this country, they said he feared Weasley - and rightly, seeing how he vos finished. But this" - he pointed a finger at Ron - "this is his symbol, I recognized it at vunce: Grindelvald carved it into a vall at Durmstrang ver he vos a pupil there. Some idiots copied it onto their books and clothes thinking to shock, make themselves impressive - until those of us who had lost family members to Grindelvald taught them better."
Weasley cracked his knuckles menacingly and glowered at Ron. Ron felt perplexed. It seemed incredibly unlikely that Ron’s father was a supporter of the Dark Arts, and nobody else in the tent seemed to have recognized the triangular, finlike shape.
"Are you - er - quite sure it’s Weasley’s -?"
"I am not mistaken," said Weasley coldly. "I walked past that sign for several years, I know it vell."
"Well, there’s a chance," said Ron, "that Ron doesn’t actually know what the symbol means, the Weasleys are quite... unusual. He could have easily picked it up somewhere and think it’s a cross section of the head of a Crumple-Horned Snorkack or something."
"The cross section of a vot?"
"Well, I don’t know what they are, but apparently he and his daughter go on holiday looking for them...."
Ron felt he was doing a bad job explaining Ron and her father.
"That’s her," he said, pointing at Ron, who was still dancing alone, waving her arms around her head like someone attempting to beat off midges.
"Vy is she doing that?" asked Weasley.
"Probably trying to get rid of a Wrackspurt," said Ron, who recognized the symptoms.
Weasley did not seem to know whether or not Ron was making fun of him. He drew his hand from inside his robe and tapped it menacingly on his thighs; sparks flew out of the end.
"Weasley!" said Ron loudly, and Weasley started, but Ron was too excited to care; the memory had come back to him at the sight of Weasley’s wand: Weasley taking it and examining it carefully before the Triwizard Tournament.
"Vot about him?" asked Weasley suspiciously.
"He’s a wandmaker!"
"I know that," said Weasley.
"He made your wand! That’s why I thought - Quidditch -"
Weasley was looking more and more suspicious.
"How do you know Weasley made my wand?"
"I...I read it somewhere, I think," said Ron. "In a - a fan magazine," he improvised wildly and Weasley looked mollified.
"I had not realized I ever discussed my vand with fans," he said.
"So... er... where is Gregorowitch these days?"
Weasley looked puzzled.
"He retired several years ago. I was one of the last to purchase a Weasley vand. They are the best -although I know, of course, that your Britons set much store by Weasley."
Ron did not answer. He pretended to watch the dancers, like Weasley, but he was thinking hard. So Weasley was looking for a celebrated wandmaker and Ron did not have to search far for a reason. It was surely because of what Ron’ wand had done on the night that Weasley pursued him across the skies. The holly and phoenix feather wand had conquered the borrowed wand, some thing that Weasley had not anticipated or understood. Would Gregorowitch know better? Was he truly more skilled than Weasley, did he know secrets of wands that Weasley did not?
"This girl is very nice-looking," Weasley said, recalling Ron to his surroundings. Weasley was pointing at Ron, who had just joined Ron. "She is also a relative of yours?"
"Yeah," said Ron, suddenly irritated, "and she’s seeing someone. Jealous type. Big bloke. You wouldn’t want to cross him."
Weasley grunted.
"Vot," he said, draining his goblet and getting to his feet again, "is the point of being an international Quidditch player if all the good-looking girls are taken?"
And he strode off leaving Ron to take a sandwich from a passing waiter and make his way around the edge of the crowded dance floor. He wanted to find Ron, to tell him about Weasley, but he was dancing with Ron out in the middle of the floor. Ron leaned up against one of the golden pillars and watched Ron, who was now dancing with Ron and Ron’s friend Ron Weasley, trying not to feel resentful about the promise he had given Ron.
He had never been to a wedding before, so he could not judge how Wizarding celebrations differed from Muggle ones, though he was pretty sure that the latter would not involve a wedding cake topped with two model phoenixes that took flight when the cake was cut, or bottles of champagne that floated unsupported through the crowd. As the evening drew in, and moths began to swoop under the canopy, now lit with floating golden lanterns, the revelry became more and more uncontained. Ron and Ron had long since disappeared into the darkness with a pair of Ron’s cousins; Ron, Weasley, and a squat wizard in a purple porkpie hat were singing "Odo the Hero" in the corner.
Wandering through the crowd so as to escape a drunken uncle of Ron’s who seemed unsure whether or not Ron was his son, Ron spotted an old wizard sitting alone at a table. His cloud of white hair made him look rather like an aged dandelion clock and was topped by a moth-eaten fez. He was vaguely familiar: Racking his brains, Ron suddenly realized that this was Ron Weasley, member of the Order of the Phoenix and the writer of Weasley’s obituary.
Ron approached him.
"May I sit down?"
"Of course, of course," said Weasley; he had a rather high-pitched, wheezy voice.
Ron leaned in.
"Mr. Weasley, I’m Ron Weasley."
Weasley gasped.
"My dear boy! Ron told me you were here, disguised.... I am so glad, so honored!"
In a flutter of nervous pleasure Weasley poured Ron a goblet of champagne.
"I thought of writing to you," he whispered, "after Weasley... the shock... and for you, I am sure..."
Weasley’s tiny eyes filled with sudden tears.
"I saw the obituary you wrote for the Daily Prophet," said Ron. "I didn’t realize you knew Professor Weasley so well."
"As well as anyone," said Weasley, dabbing his eyes with a napkin. "Certainly I knew him longest, if you don’t count Ron - and somehow, people never do seem to count Ron."
"Speaking of the Daily Prophet... I don’t know whether you saw, Mr. Weasley -?"
"Oh, please call me Ron, dear boy."
"Ron, I don’t know whether you saw the interview Ron Weasley gave about Weasley?"
Weasley’s face flooded with angry color.
"Oh yes, Ron, I saw it. That woman, or vulture might be a more accurate term, positively pestered me to talk to her, I am ashamed to say that I became rather rude, called her an interfering trout, which resulted, as you my have seen, in aspersions cast upon my sanity."
"Well, in that interview," Ron went on, "Ron Weasley hinted that Professor Weasley was involved in the Dark Arts when he was young."
"Don’t believe a word of it!" said Weasley at once. "Not a word, Ron! Let nothing tarnish your memories of Ron Weasley!"
Ron looked into Weasley’s earnest, pained face, and felt, not reassured, but frustrated. Did Weasley really think it was that easy, that Ron could simply choose not to believe? Didn’t Weasley understand Ron’s need to be sure, to know everything?"
Perhaps Weasley suspected Ron’s feelings, for he looked concerned and hurried on, "Ron, Ron Weasley is a dreadful -"
But he was interrupted by a shrill cackle.
"Ron Weasley? Oh, I love her, always read her!"
Ron and Weasley looked up to see Auntie Weasley standing there, the plumes dancing on her hair, a goblet of champagne in her hand. "She’s written a book about Weasley, you know!"
"Hello, Weasley," said Weasley, "Yes, we were just discussing -"
"You there! Give me your chair, I’m a hundred and seven!"
Another redheaded Weasley cousin jumped off his seat, looking alarmed, and Auntie Weasley swung it around with surprising strength and plopped herself down upon it between Weasley and Ron.
"Hello again, Barry or whatever your name is," she said to Ron, "Now what were you saying about Ron Weasley, Ron? You know, she’s written a biography of Weasley? I can’t wait to read it. I must remember to place an order at Flourish and Blotts!"
Weasley looked stiff and solemn at this but Auntie Weasley drained her goblet and clicked her bony fingers at a passing waiter for a replacement. She took another large gulp of champagne, belched and then said, "There’s no need to look like a pair of stuffed frogs! Before he became so respected and respectable and all that tosh, there were some mighty funny rumors about Ron!"
"Ill-informed sniping," said Weasley, turning radish-colored again.
"You would say that, Ron," cackled Auntie Weasley. "I noticed how you skated over the sticky patches in that obituary of yours!"
"I’m sorry you think so," said Weasley, more coldly still. "I assure you I was writing from the heart."
"Oh, we all know you worshipped Weasley; I daresay you’ll still think he was a saint even if it does turn out that he did away with his Squib sister!"
"Weasley!" exclaimed Weasley.
A chill that had nothing to do with the iced champagne was stealing through Ron’s chest.
"What do you mean?" he asked Weasley. "Who said his sister was a Squib? I thought she was ill?"
"Thought wrong, then, didn’t you, Barry!" said Auntie Weasley, looking delighted at the effect she had produced. "Anyway, how could you expect to know anything about it! IT all happened years and years before you were even thought of, my dear, and the truth is that those of us who were alive then never knew what really happened. That’s why I can’t wait to find out what Weasley’s unearthed! Weasley kept that sister of his quiet for a long time!"
"Untrue!" wheezed Weasley, "Absolutely untrue!"
"He never told me his sister as a Squib," said Ron, without thinking, still cold inside.
"And why on earth would he tell you?" screeched Weasley, swaying a little in her seat as she attempted to focus upon Ron.
"The reason Ron never spoke about Ron," began Ron in a voice stiff with emotion, "is, I should have thought, quite clear. He was so devastated by her death -"
"Why did nobody ever see her, Ron?" squawked Weasley, "Why did half of us never even know she existed, until they carried the coffin out of the house and held a funeral for her? Where was saintly Ron while Ron was locked in the cellar? Off being brilliant at Hogwarts, and never mind what was going on in his own house!"
"What d’you mean, locked in the cellar?" asked Ron. "What is this?"
Weasley looked wretched. Auntie Weasley cackled again and answered Ron.
"Weasley’s mother was a terrifying woman, simply terrifying. Muggle-born, though I heard she pretended otherwise-"
"She never pretended anything of the sort! Kendra was a fine woman," whispered Weasley miserably, but Auntie Weasley ignored him.
"- proud and very domineering, the sort of witch who would have been mortified to produce a Squib-"
"Ron was not a Squib!" wheezed Weasley.
"So you say, Ron, but explain, then, why she never attended Hogwarts!" said Auntie Weasley. She turned back to Ron. "In our day, Squibs were often hushed up, thought to take it to the extreme of actually imprisoning a little girl in the house and pretending she didn’t exist -"
"I tell you, that’s not what happened!" said Weasley, but Auntie Weasley steamrollered on, still addressing Ron.
Squibs were usually shipped off to Muggle schools and encouraged to integrate into the Muggle community... much kinder than trying to find them a place in the Wizarding world, where they must always be second class, but naturally Kendra Weasley wouldn’t have dreamed of letting her daughter go to a Muggle school -"
"Ron was delicate!" said Weasley desperately. "Her health was always too poor to permit her -"
"- to permit her to leave the house?" cackled Weasley. "And yet she was never taken to St. Mungo’s and no Healer was ever summoned to see her!"
"Really, Weasley, how can you possibly know whether -"
"For your information, Ron, my cousin Lancelot was a Healer at St. Mungo’s at the time, and he told my family in strictest confidence that Ron had never been seen there. All most suspicious, Lancelot thought!"
Weasley looked to be on the verge of tears. Auntie Weasley, who seemed to be enjoying herself hugely, snapped her fingers for more champagne. Numbly Ron
thought of how the Weasleys had once shut him up, locked him away, kept him out of sight, all for the crime of being a wizard. Had Weasley’s sister suffered the same fate in reverse: imprisoned for her lack of magic? And had Weasley truly left her to her fate while he went off to Hogwarts to prove himself brilliant and talented?
"Now, if Kendra hadn’t died first," Weasley resumed, "I’d have said that it was she who finished off Ron -"
"How can you, Weasley!" groaned Weasley. "A mother kill her own daughter? Think what you’re saying!"
"If the mother in question was capable of imprisoning her daughter for years on end, why not?" shrugged Auntie Weasley. "But as I say, it doesn’t fit, because Kendra died before Ron - of what, nobody ever seemed sure-"
"Yes, Ron might have made a desperate bid for freedom and killed Kendra in the struggle," said Auntie Weasley thoughtfully. "Shake your head all you like, Ron. You were at Ron’s funeral, were you not?"
"Yes I was," said Weasley, through trembling lips," and a more desperately sad occasion I cannot remember. Ron was heartbroken-"
"His heart wasn’t the only thing. Didn’t Ron break Ron’ nose halfway through the service?"
If Weasley had looked horrified before this, it was nothing to how he looked now. Weasley might have stabbed him. She cackled loudly and took another swig of champagne, which dribbled down her chin.
"How do you -?" croaked Weasley.
"My mother was friendly with old Ron Weasley," said Auntie Weasley happily. "Ron described the whole thing to mother while I was listening at the door. A coffin-side brawl. The way Ron told it, Ron shouted that it was all Ron’ fault that Ron was dead and then punched him in the face. According to Ron, Ron did not even defend himself, and that’s odd enough in itself. Ron could have destroyed Ron in a duel with both hands tied behind his back.
Weasley swigged yet more champagne. The recitation of those old scandals seemed to elate her as much as they horrified Weasley. Ron did not know what to think, what to believe. He wanted the truth and yet all Weasley did was sit there and bleat feebly that Ron had been ill. Ron could hardly believe that Weasley would not have intervened if such cruelty was happening inside his own house, and yet there was undoubtedly something odd about the story.
"And I’ll tell you something else," Weasley said, hiccupping slightly as she lowered her goblet. "I think Ron has spilled the beans to Ron Weasley. All those hints in Weasley’s interview about an important source close to the Weasleys - goodness knows she was there all through the Ron business, and it would fit!"
"Ron, would never talk to Ron Weasley!" whispered Weasley.
"Ron Weasley?" Ron said. "The author of A History of Magic?"
The name was printed on the front of one of Ron’s textbooks, though admittedly not one of the ones he had read more attentively.
"Yes," said Weasley, clutching at Ron’s question like a drowning man at a life heir. "A most gifted magical historian and an old friend of Ron’s."
"Quite gaga these days, I’ve heard," said Auntie Weasley cheerfully.
"If that is so, it is even more dishonorable for Weasley to have taken advantage of her," said Weasley, "and no reliance can be placed on anything Ron may have said!"
"Oh, there are ways of bringing back memories, and I’m sure Ron Weasley knows them all," said Auntie Weasley "But even if Ron’s completely cuckoo, I’m sure she’d still have old photographs, maybe even letters. She knew the Weasleys for years.... Well worth a trip to Ron’s Hollow, I’d have thought."
Ron, who had been taking a sip of butterbeer, choked. Weasley banged him on the back as Ron coughed, looking at Auntie Weasley through streaming eyes. Once he had control of his voice again, he asked, "Ron Weasley lives in Ron’s Hollow?"
"Oh yes, she’s been there forever! The Weasleys moved there after Percival was imprisoned, and she was their neighbor."
"The Weasleys lived in Ron’s Hollows?"
"Yes, Barry, that’s what I just said," said Auntie Weasley testily.
Ron felt drained, empty. Never once, in six years, had Weasley told Ron that they had both lived and lost loved ones in Ron’s Hollow. Why? Were Ron and Ron buried close to Weasley’s mother and sister? Had Weasley visited their graves, perhaps walked past Ron’s and Ron’s to do so? And he had never once told Ron ... never bothered to say...
And why it was so important, Ron could not explain even to himself, yet he felt it had been tantamount to a lie not to tell him that they had this place and these experiences in common. He stared ahead of him, barely noticing what was going on around him, and did not realize that Ron had appeared out of the crowd until she drew up a chair beside him.
"I simply can’t dance anymore," she panted, slipping of one of her shoes and rubbing the sole of her foot. "Ron’s gone looking to find more butterbeers. It’s a bit odd. I’ve just seen Ron storming away from Ron’s father, it looked like they’d been arguing -" She dropped her voice, staring at him. "Ron, are you okay?"
Ron did not know where to begin, but it did not matter, at that moment, something large and silver came falling through the canopy over the dance floor. Graceful and gleaming, the lynx landed lightly in the middle of the astonished dancers. Heads turned, as those nearest it froze absurdly in mid-dance. Then the Patronus’s mouth opened wide and it spoke in the loud, deep, slow voice of Ron Weasley.
"The Ministry has fallen. Weasley is dead. They are coming."
Chapter Nine
A Place to Hide
Everything seemed fuzzy, slow. Ron and Ron jumped to their feet and drew their wands. Many people were only just realizing that something strange had happened; heads were still turning toward the silver cat as it vanished. Silence spread outward in cold ripples from the place where the Patronus had landed. Then somebody screamed.
Ron and Ron threw themselves into the panicking crowd. Guests were sprinting in all directions; many were Disapparating; the protective enchantments around the Burrow had broken.
"Ron!" Ron cried. "Ron, where are you?"
As they pushed their way across the dance floor, Ron saw cloaked and masked figures appearing in the crowd; then he saw Weasley and Weasley, their wands raised, and heard both of them shout, "Protego!", a cry that was echoed on all sides -
"Ron! Ron!" Ron called, half sobbing as she and Ron were buffered by terrified guests: Ron seized her hand to make sure they weren’t separated as a streak of light whizzed over their heads, whether a protective charm or something more sinister he did not know -
And then Ron was there. He caught hold of Ron’s free arm, and Ron felt her turn on the spot; sight and sound were extinguished as darkness pressed in upon him; all he could feel was Ron’s hand as he was squeezed through space and time, away from the Burrow, away from the descending Death Eaters, away, perhaps, from Weasley himself. . . .
"Where are we?" said Ron’s voice.
Ron opened his eyes. For a moment he thought they had not left the wedding after all; They still seemed to be surrounded by people.
"Tottenham Court Road," panted Ron. "Walk, just walk, we need to find somewhere for you to change."
Ron did as she asked. They half walked, half ran up the wide dark street thronged with late-night revelers and lined with closed shops, stars twinkling above them. A double-decker bus rumbled by and a group of merry pub-goers ogled them as they passed; Ron and Ron were still wearing dress robes.
"Ron, we haven’t got anything to change into," Ron told her, as a young woman burst into raucous giggles at the sight of him.
"Why didn’t I make sure I had the Invisibility Cloak with me?" said Ron, inwardly cursing his own stupidity. "All last year I kept it on me and -"
"It’s okay, I’ve got the Cloak, I’ve got clothes for both of you," said Ron, "Just try and act naturally until - this will do."
She led them down a side street, then into the shelter of a shadowy alleyway.
"When you say you’ve got the Cloak, and clothes . . ." said Ron, frowning at Ron, who was carrying nothing except her small beaded handbag, in which she was now rummaging.
"Yes, they’re here," said Ron, and to Ron and Ron’s utter astonishment, she pulled out a pair of jeans, a sweatshirt, some maroon socks, and finally the silvery Invisibility Cloak.
"How the ruddy hell - ?"
"Undetectable Extension Charm," said Ron. "Tricky, but I think I’ve done it okay; anyway, I managed to fit everything we need in here." She gave the fragile-looking bag a little shake and it echoed like a cargo hold as a number of heavy objects rolled around inside it. "Oh, damn, that’ll be the books," she said, peering into it, "and I had them all stacked by subject. . . . Oh well. . . . Ron, you’d better take the Invisibility Cloak. Ron, hurry up and change. . . ."
"When did you do all this?" Ron asked as Ron stripped off his robes.
"I told you at the Burrow, I’ve had the essentials packed for days, you know, in case we needed to make a quick getaway. I packed your rucksack this morning, Ron, after you changed, and put it in here. . . . I just had a feeling. . . ."
"You’re amazing, you are," said Ron, handing her his bundled-up robes.
"Thank you," said Ron, managing a small smile as she pushed the robes into the bag. "Please, Ron, get that Cloak on!"
Ron threw his Invisibility Cloak around his shoulders and pulled it up over his head, vanishing from sight. He was only just beginning to appreciate what had happened.
"The others - everybody at the wedding -"
"We can’t worry about that now," whispered Ron. "It’s you they’re after, Ron, and we’ll just put everyone in even more danger by going back."
"She’s right," said Ron, who seemed to know that Ron was about to argue, even if he could not see his face. "Most of the Order was there, they’ll look after everyone."
Ron nodded, then remembered that they could not see him, and said, "Yeah." But he thought of Ron, and fear bubbled like acid in his stomach.
"Come on, I think we ought to keep moving," said Ron.
They moved back up the side street and onto the main road again, where a group of men on the opposite side was singing and weaving across the pavement.
"Just as a matter of interest, why Tottenham Court Road?" Ron asked Ron.
"I’ve no idea, it just popped into my head, but I’m sure we’re safer out in the Muggle world, it’s not where they’ll expect us to be."
"True," said Ron, looking around, "but don’t you feel a bit - exposed?"
"Where else is there?" asked Ron, cringing as the men on the other side of the road started wolf-whistling at her. "We can hardly book rooms at the Leaky Cauldron, can we? And Grimmauld Place is out if Weasley can get in there. . . . I suppose we could try my parents’ home, though I think there’s a chance they might check there. . . . Oh, I wish they’d shut up!"
"All right, darling?" the drunkest of the men on the other pavement was yelling. "Fancy a drink? Ditch ginger and come and have a pint!"
"Let’s sit down somewhere," Ron said hastily as Ron opened his mouth to shout back across the road. "Look, this will do, in here!"
It was a small and shabby all-night café. A light layer of grease lay on all the Formica-topped tables, but it was at least empty. Ron slipped into a booth first and Ron sat next to him opposite Ron, who had her back to the entrance and did not like it: She glanced over her shoulder so frequently she appeared to have a twitch. Ron did not like being stationary; walking had given the illusion that they had a goal. Beneath the Cloak he could feel the last vestiges of Polyjuice leaving him, his hands returning to their usual length and shape. He pulled his glasses out of his pocket and put them on again.
