After a minute or two, Ron said, "You know, we’re not far from the Leaky Cauldron here, it’s only in Charing Cross -"
"Ron, we can’t!" said Ron at once.
"Not to stay there, but to find out what’s going on!"
"We know what’s going on! Weasley’s taken over the Ministry, what else do we need to know?"
"Okay, okay, it was just an idea!" They relapsed into a prickly silence. The gum-chewing waitress shuffled over and Ron ordered two cappuccinos: As Ron was invisible, it would have looked odd to order him one. A pair of burly workmen entered the café and squeezed into the next booth. Ron dropped her voice to a whisper.
"I say we find a quiet place to Disapparate and head for the countryside. Once we’re there, we could send a message to the Order."
"Can you do that talking Patronus thing, then?" asked Ron.
"I’ve been practicing and I think so," said Ron.
"Well, as long as it doesn’t get them into trouble, though they might’ve been arrested already. God, that’s revolting," Ron added after one sip of the foamy, grayish coffee. The waitress had heard; she shot Ron a nasty look as she shuffled off to take the new customers’ orders. The larger of the two workmen, who was blond and quite huge, now that Ron came to look at him, waved her away. She stared, affronted.
"Let’s get going, then, I don’t want to drink this muck," said Ron. "Ron, have you got Muggle money to pay for this?"
"Yes, I took out all my Building Society savings before I came to the Burrow. I’ll bet all the change is at the bottom," sighed Ron, reaching for her beaded bag.
The two workmen made identical movements, and Ron mirrored them without conscious thought: All three of them drew their wands. Ron, a few seconds late in realizing what was going on, lunged across the table, pushing Ron sideways onto her bench. The force of the Death Eaters’ spells shattered the tiled wall where Ron’s head had just been, as Ron, still invisible, yelled, "Stupefy!"
The great blond Death Eater was hit in the face by a jet of red light: He slumped sideways, unconscious. His companion, unable to see who had cast the spell, fired another at Ron: Shining black ropes flew from his wand-tip and bound Ron head to foot - the waitress screamed and ran for the door - Ron sent another Stunning Spell at the Death Eater with the twisted face who had tied up Ron, but the spell missed, rebounded on the window, and hit the waitress, who collapsed in front of the door.
"Expulso!" bellowed the Death Eater, and the table behind which Ron was standing blew up: The force of the explosion slammed him into the wall and he felt his wand leave his hand as the Cloak slipped off him.
"Petrificus Totalus!" screamed Ron from out of sight, and the Death Eater fell forward like a statue to land with a crunching thud on the mess of broken china, table, and coffee. Ron crawled out from underneath the bench, shaking bits of glass ashtray out of her hair and trembling all over.
"D-diffindo," she said, pointing her wand at Ron, who roared in pain as she slashed open the knee of his jeans, leaving a deep cut. "Oh, I’m so sorry, Ron, my hand’s shaking! Diffindo!"
The severed ropes fell away. Ron got to his feet, shaking his arms to regain feeling in them. Ron picked up his wand and climbed over all the debris to where the large blond Death Eater was sprawled across the bench.
"I should’ve recognized him, he was there the night Weasley died," he said. He turned over the darker Death Eater with his foot; the man’s eyes moved rapidly between Ron, Ron and Ron.
"That’s Weasley," said Ron. "I recognize him from the old wanted posters. I think the big one’s Ron Weasley."
"Never mind what they’re called!" said Ron a little hysterically. "How did they find us? What are we going to do?"
Somehow her panic seemed to clear Ron’s head.
"Lock the door," he told her, "and Ron, turn out the lights."
He looked down at the paralyzed Weasley, thinking fast as the lock clicked and Ron used the Deluminator to plunge the café into darkness. Ron could hear the men who had jeered at Ron earlier, yelling at another girl in the distance.
"What are we going to do with them?" Ron whispered to Ron through the dark; then, even more quietly, "Kill them? They’d kill us. They had a good go just now."
Ron shuddered and took a step backward. Ron shook his head.
"We just need to wipe their memories," said Ron. "It’s better like that, it’ll throw them off the scent. If we killed them it’d be obvious we were here."
"You’re the boss," said Ron, sounding profoundly relieved. "But I’ve never down a Memory Charm."
"Nor have I," said Ron, "but I know the theory."
She took a deep, calming breath, then pointed her wand at Weasley’s forehead and said, "Obliviate."
At once, Weasley’s eyes became unfocused and dreamy.
"Brilliant!" said Ron, clapping her on the back. "Take care of the other one and the waitress while Ron and I clear up." "Clear up?" said Ron, looking around at the partly destroyed café. "Why?"
"Don’t you think they might wonder what’s happened if they wake up and find themselves in a place that looks like it’s just been bombed?"
"Oh right, yeah . . ."
Ron struggled for a moment before managing to extract his wand from his pocket.
"It’s no wonder I can’t get it out, Ron, you packed my old jeans, they’re tight."
"Oh, I’m so sorry," hissed Ron, and as she dragged the waitress out of sight of the windows, Ron heard her mutter a suggestion as to where Ron could stick his wand instead.
Once the café was restored to its previous condition, they heaved the Death Eaters back into their booth and propped them up facing each other. "But how did they find us?" Ron asked, looking from one inert man to the other. "How did they know where we were?"
She turned to Ron.
"You - you don’t think you’ve still got your Trace on you, do you, Ron?"
"He can’t have," said Ron. "The Trace breaks at seventeen, that’s Wizarding law, you can’t put it on an adult."
"As far as you know," said Ron. "What if the Death Eaters have found a way to put it on a seventeen-year-old?"
"But Ron hasn’t been near a Death Eater in the last twenty-four hours. Who’s supposed to have put a Trace back on him?"
Ron did not reply. Ron felt contaminated, tainted: Was that really how the Death Eaters had found them?
"If I can’t use magic, and you can’t use magic near me, without us giving away our position - " he began.
"We’re not splitting up!" said Ron firmly.
"We need a safe place to hide," said Ron. "Give us time to think things through."
"Grimmauld Place," said Ron.
The other two gaped.
"Don’t be silly, Ron, Weasley can get in there!"
"Ron’s dad said they’ve put up jinxes against him - and even if they haven’t worked," he pressed on as Ron began to argue "so what? I swear, I’d like nothing better than to meet Weasley!"
"But -"
"Ron, where else is there? It’s the best chance we’ve got. Weasley’s only one Death Eater. If I’ve still got the Trace on me, we’ll have whole crowds of them on us wherever else we go."
She could not argue, though she looked as if she would have liked to. While she unlocked the café door, Ron clicked the Deluminator to release the café’s light. Then, on Ron’s count of three, they reversed the spells upon their three victims, and before the waitress or either of the Death Eaters could do more than stir sleepily, Ron, Ron and Ron had turned on the spot and vanished into the compressing darkness once more.
Seconds later Ron’s lungs expanded gratefully and he opened his eyes: They were now standing in the middle of a familiar small and shabby square. Tall, dilapidated houses looked down on them from every side. Number twelve was visible to them, for they had been told of its existence by Weasley, its Secret-Keeper, and they rushed toward it, checking every few yards that they were not being followed or observed. They raced up the stone steps, and Ron tapped the front door once with his wand. They heard a series of metallic clicks and the clatter of a chain, then the door swung open with a creak and they hurried over the threshold.
As Ron closed the door behind them, the old-fashioned gas lamps sprang into life, casting flickering light along the length of the hallway. It looked just as Ron remembered it: eerie, cobwebbed, the outlines of the house-elf heads on the wall throwing odd shadows up the staircase. Long dark curtains concealed the portrait of Ron’s mother. The only thing that was out of place was the troll’s leg umbrella stand, which was lying on its side as if Weasley had just knocked it over again.
"I think somebody’s been in here," Ron whispered, pointing toward it.
"That could’ve happened as the Order left," Ron murmured back.
"So where are these jinxes they put up against Weasley?" Ron asked.
"Maybe they’re only activated if he shows up?" suggested Ron.
Yet they remained close together on the doormat, backs against the door, scared to move farther into the house.
"Well, we can’t stay here forever," said Ron, and he took a step forward.
"Ron Weasley?"
Mad-Eye Weasley’s voice whispered out of the darkness, making all three of them jump back in fright. "We’re not Weasley!" croaked Ron, before something whooshed over him like cold air and his tongue curled backward on itself, making it impossible to speak. Before he had time to feel inside his mouth, however, his tongue had unraveled again.
The other two seemed to have experienced the same unpleasant sensation. Ron was making retching noises; Ron stammered, "That m-must have b-been the T-Tongue-Tying Curse Mad-Eye set up for Weasley!"
Gingerly Ron took another step forward. Something shifted in the shadows at the end of the hall, and before any of them could say another word, a figure had risen up out of the carpet, tall, dust-colored, and terrible; Ron screamed and so did Mrs. Weasley, her curtains flying open; the gray figure was gliding toward them, faster and faster,
its waist-length hair and beard streaming behind it, its face sunken, fleshless, with empty eye sockets: Horribly familiar, dreadfully altered, it raised a wasted arm, pointing at Ron.
"No!" Ron shouted, and though he had raised his wand no spell occurred to him. "No! It wasn’t us! We didn’t kill you -"
On the word kill, the figure exploded in a great cloud of dust: Coughing, his eyes watering, Ron looked around to see Ron crouched on the floor by the door with her arms over her head, and Ron, who was shaking from head to foot, patting her clumsily on the shoulder and saying, "It’s all r-right. . . . It’s g-gone. . . ."
Dust swirled around Ron like mist, catching the blue gaslight, as Mrs. Weasley continued to scream.
"Mudbloods, filth, stains of dishonor, taint of shame on the house of my fathers -"
"SHUT UP!" Ron bellowed, directing his wand at her, and with a bang and a burst of red sparks, the curtains swung shut again, silencing her.
"That . . . that was . . . " Ron whimpered, as Ron helped her to her feet.
"Yeah," said Ron, "but it wasn’t really him, was it? Just something to scare Weasley." Had it worked, Ron wondered, or had Weasley already blasted the horror-figure aside as casually as he had killed the real Weasley? Nerves still tingling, he led the other two up the hall, half-expecting some new terror to reveal itself, but nothing moved except for a mouse skittering along the skirting board.
"Before we go any farther, I think we’d better check," whispered Ron, and she raised her wand and said, "Homenum revelio."
Nothing happened.
"Well, you’ve just had a big shock," said Ron kindly. "What was that supposed to do?"
"It did what I meant it to do!" said Ron rather crossly. "That was a spell to reveal human presence, and there’s nobody here except us!" "And old Dusty," said Ron, glancing at the patch of carpet from which the corpse-figure had risen.
"Let’s go up," said Ron with a frightened look at the same spot, and she led the way up the creaking stairs to the drawing room on the first floor.
Ron waved her wand to ignite the old gas lamps, then, shivering slightly in the drafty room, she perched on the sofa, her arms wrapped tightly around her. Ron crossed to the window and moved the heavy velvet curtains aside an inch.
"Can’t see anyone out there," he reported. "And you’d think, if Ron still had a Trace on him, they’d have followed us here. I know they can’t get in the house, but - what’s up, Ron?"
Ron had given a cry of pain: His scar had burned against as something flashed across his mind like a bright light on water. He saw a large shadow and felt a fury that was not his own pound through his body, violent and brief as an electric shock.
"What did you see?" Ron asked, advancing on Ron. "Did you see him at my place?"
"No, I just felt anger - he’s really angry -"
"But that could be at the Burrow," said Ron loudly. "What else? Didn’t you see anything? Was he cursing someone?"
"No, I just felt anger - I couldn’t tell -"
Ron felt badgered, confused, and Ron did not help as she said in a frightened voice, "Your scar, again? But what’s going on? I thought that connection had closed!"
"It did, for a while," muttered Ron; his scar was still painful, which made it hard to concentrate. "I - I think it’s started opening again whenever he loses control, that’s how it used to -"
"But then you’ve got to close your mind!" said Ron shrilly. "Ron, Weasley didn’t want you to use that connection, he wanted you to shut it down, that’s why you were supposed to use Occlumency! Otherwise Weasley can plant false images in your mind, remember -"
"Yeah, I do remember, thanks," said Ron through gritted teeth; he did not need Ron to tell him that Weasley had once used this selfsame connection between them to lead him into a trap, nor that it had resulted in Ron’s death. He wished that he had not told them what he had seen and felt; it made Weasley more threatening, as though he were pressing against the window of the room, and still the pain in his scar was building and he fought it: It was like resisting the urge to be sick.
He turned his back on Ron and Ron, pretending to examine the old tapestry of the Weasley family tree on the wall. Then Ron shrieked: Ron drew his wand again and spun around to see a silver Patronus soar through the drawing room window and land upon the floor in front of them, where it solidified into the weasel that spoke with the voice of Ron’s father.
"Family safe, do not reply, we are being watched."
The Patronus dissolved into nothingness. Ron let out a noise between a whimper and a groan and dropped onto the sofa: Ron joined him, gripping his arm.
"They’re all right, they’re all right!" she whispered, and Ron half laughed and hugged her.
"Ron," he said over Ron’s shoulder, "I -"
"It’s not a problem," said Ron, sickened by the pain in his head. "It’s your family, ‘course you were worried. I’d feel the same way." He thought of Ron. "I do feel the same way."
The pain in his scar was reaching a peak, burning as it had back in the garden of the Burrow. Faintly he heard Ron say "I don’t want to be on my own. Could we use the sleeping bags I’ve brought and camp in here tonight?"
He heard Ron agree. He could not fight the pain much longer. He had to succumb.
"Bathroom," he muttered, and he left the room as fast as he could without running.
He barely made it: Bolting the door behind him with trembling hands, he grasped his pounding head and fell to the floor, then in an explosion of agony, he felt the rage that did not belong to him possess his soul, saw a long room lit only by firelight, and the giant blond Death Eater on the floor, screaming and writhing, and a slighter figure standing over him, wand outstretched, while Ron spoke in a high, cold, merciless voice.
"More, Weasley, or shall we end it and feed you to Ron? Lord Weasley is not sure that he will forgive this time. . . . You called me back for this, to tell me that Ron Weasley has escaped again? Ron, give Weasley another taste of our displeasure. . . . Do it, or feel my wrath yourself!"
A log fell in the fire: Flames reared, their light darting across a terrified, pointed white face - with a sense of emerging from deep water, Ron drew heaving breaths and opened his eyes.
He was spread-eagled on the cold black marble floor, his nose inches from one of the silver serpent tails that supported the large bathtub. He sat up. Weasley’s gaunt, petrified face seemed burned on the inside of his eyes. Ron felt sickened by what he had seen, by the use to which Ron was now being put by Weasley.
There was a sharp rap on the door, and Ron jumped as Ron’s voice rang out.
"Ron, do you want your toothbrush? I’ve got it here."
"Yeah, great, thanks," he said, fighting to keep his voice casual as he stood up to let her in.
Chapter Ten
Ron’s Tale
Ron woke early next morning, wrapped in a sleeping bag on the drawing room floor. A chink of sky was visible between the heavy curtains. It was the cool, clear blue of watered ink, somewhere between night and dawn, and everything was quiet except for Ron and Ron’s slow, deep breathing. Ron glanced over at the dark shapes they made on the floor beside him. Ron had had a fit of gallantry and insisted that Ron sleep on the cushions from the sofa, so that her silhouette was raised above his. Her arm curved to the floor, her fingers inches from Ron’s. Ron wondered whether they had fallen asleep holding hands. The idea made him feel strangely lonely.
He looked up at the shadowy ceiling, the cobwebbed chandelier. Less than twenty-four house ago, he had been standing in the sunlight at the entrance to the marquee, waiting to show in wedding guests. It seemed a lifetime away. What was going to happen now? He lay on the floor and he thought of the Horcruxes, of the daunting complex mission Weasley had left him... Weasley...
The grief that had possessed him since Weasley’s death felt different now. The accusations he had heard from Weasley at the wedding seemed to have nested in his brain like diseased things, infecting his memories of the wizard he had idolized. Could Weasley have let such things happen? Had he been like Ron, content to watch neglect and abuse as long as it did not affect him? Could he have turned his back on a sister who was being imprisoned and hidden?
Ron thought of Ron’s Hollow, of graves Weasley had never mentioned there; he thought of mysterious objects left without explanation in Weasley’s will, and resentment swelled in the darkness. Why hadn’t Weasley told him? Why hadn’t he explained? Had Weasley actually cared about Ron at all? Or had Ron been nothing more than a tool to be polished and honed, but not trusted, never confided in?
Ron could not stand lying there with nothing but bitter thoughts for company. Desperate for something to do, for distraction, he slipped out of his sleeping bad, picked up his wand, and crept out of the room. On the landing he whispered, "Lumos," and started to climb the stairs by wandlight.
On the second landing was the bedroom in which he and Ron had slept last time they had been here; he glanced into it. The wardrobe doors stood open and the bedclothes had been ripped back. Ron remembered the overturned troll leg downstairs. Somebody had searched the house since the Order had left. Weasley? Or perhaps Ron, who had pilfered plenty from this house both before and after Ron died? Ron’s gaze wandered to the portrait that sometimes contained Phineas  Weasley, Ron’s great-great grandfather, but it was empty, showing nothing but a stretch of muddy backdrop. Phineas  was evidently spending the night in the headmaster’s study at Hogwarts.
Ron continued up the stairs until he reached the topmost landing where there were only two doors. The one facing him bore a nameplate reading Ron. Ron had never entered his godfather’s bedroom before. He pushed open the door, holding his wand high to cast light as widely as possible. The room was spacious and must once have been handsome. There was a large bed with a carved wooden headboard, a tall window obscured by long velvet curtains and a chandelier thickly coated in dust with candle scrubs still resting in its sockets, solid wax banging in frostlike drips. A fine film of dust covered the pictures on the walls and the bed’s headboard; a spiders web stretched between the chandelier and the top of the large wooden wardrobe, and as Ron moved deeper into the room, he head a scurrying of disturbed mice.
The teenage Ron had plastered the walls with so many posters and pictures that little of the wall’s silvery-gray silk was visible. Ron could only assume that Ron’s parents had been unable to remove the Permanent Sticking Charm that kept them on the wall because he was sure they would not have appreciated their eldest son’s taste in decoration. Ron seemed to have long gone out of his way to annoy his parents. There were several large Weasley banners, faded scarlet and gold just to underline his difference from all the rest of the Weasley family. There were many pictures of Muggle motorcycles, and also (Ron had to admire Ron’s nerve) several posters of bikini-clad Muggle girls. Ron could tell that they were Muggles because they remained quite stationary within their pictures, faded smiles and glazed eyes frozen on the paper. This was in contrast the only Wizarding photograph on the walls which was a picture of four Hogwarts students standing arm in arm, laughing at the camera.
With a leap of pleasure, Ron recognized his father, his untidy black hair stuck up at the back like Ron’s, and he too wore glasses. Beside him was Ron, carelessly handsome, his slightly arrogant face so much younger and happier than Ron had ever seen it alive. To Ron’s right stood Weasley, more than a head shorter, plump and watery-eyed, flushed with pleasure at his inclusion in this coolest of gangs, with the much-admired rebels that Ron and Ron had been. On Ron’s left was Weasley, even then a little shabby-looking, but he had the same air of delighted surprise at finding himself liked and included or was it simply because Ron knew how it had been, that he saw these things in the picture? He tried to take it from the wall; it was his now, after all, Ron had left him everything, but it would not budge. Ron had taken no chances in preventing his parents from redecorating his room.
Ron looked around at the floor. The sky outside was growing brightest. A shaft of light revealed bits of paper, books, and small objects scattered over the carpet. Evidently Ron’s bedroom had been reached too, although its contents seemed to have been judged mostly, if not entirely, worthless. A few of the books had been shaken roughly enough to part company with the covers and sundry pages littered the floor.
Ron bent down, picked up a few of the pieces of paper, and examined them. He recognized one as a part of an old edition of A History of Magic, by Ron Weasley, and another as belonging to a motorcycle maintenance manual. The third was handwritten and crumpled. He smoothed it out.
Dear Padfoot,
Thank you, thank you, for Ron’s birthday present! It was his favorite by far. One year old and already zooming along on a toy broomstick, he looked so pleased with himself. I’m enclosing a picture so you can see. You know it only rises about two feet off the ground but he nearly killed the cat and he smashed a horrible vase Ron sent me for Christmas (no complaints there). Of course Ron thought it was so funny, says he’s going to be a great Quidditch player but we’ve had to pack away all the ornaments and make sure we don’t take our eyes off him when he gets going.
We had a very quiet birthday tea, just us and old Ron who has always been sweet to us and who dotes on Garry. We were so sorry you couldn’t come, but the Order’s got to come first, and Ron’s not old enough to know it’s his birthday anyway! Ron is getting a bit frustrated shut up here, he tries not to show it but I can tell - also Weasley’s still got his Invisibility Cloak, so no chance of little excursions. If you could visit, it would cheer him up so much. Wormy was here last weekend. I thought he seemed down, but that was probably the next about the McKinnons; I cried all evening when I heard.
Ron drops in most days, she’s a fascinating old thing with the most amazing stories about Weasley. I’m not sure he’d be pleased if he knew! I don’t know how much to believe, actually because it seems incredible that Weasley
Ron’s extremities seemed to have gone numb. He stood quite still, holding the miraculous paper in his nerveless fingers while inside him a kind of quiet eruptions sent joy and grief thundering its equal measure through his veins. Lurching to the bed, he sat down.
He read the letter again, but could not take in any more meaning than he had done the first time, and was reduced to staring at the handwriting itself. She had made her "g"s the same way he did. He searched through the letter for every one of them, and each felt like a friendly little wave glimpsed from behind a veil. The letter was an incredible treasure, proof that Ron Weasley had lived, really lived, that her warm hand had once moved across this parchment, tracing ink into these letters, these words, words about him, Ron, her son.
Impatiently brushing away the wetness in his eyes, he reread the letter, this time concentrating on the meaning. It was like listening to a half-remembered voice.
They had a cat... perhaps it had perished, like his parents at Ron’s Hollow... or else fled when there was nobody left to feed it... Ron had bought him his first broomstick... His parents had known Ron Weasley; had Weasley introduced them? Weasley’s still got his Invisibility Cloak... there was something funny there...
Ron paused, pondering his mother’s words. Why had Weasley taken Ron’s Invisibility Cloak? Ron distinctly remembered his headmaster telling him years before, "I don’t need a cloak to become invisible" Perhaps some less gifted Order
member had needed its assistance, and Weasley had acted as a carrier? Ron passed on...
Wormy was here... Weasley, the traitor, had seemed "down" had he? Was he aware that he was seeing Ron and Ron alive for the last time?
And finally Ron again, who told incredible stories about Weasley. It seems incredible that Weasley ---
That Weasley what? But there were any number of things that would seem incredible about Weasley; that he had once received bottom marks in a Transfiguration test, for instance or had taken up goat charming like Ron...
Ron got to his feet and scanned the floor: Perhaps the rest of the letter was here somewhere. He seized papers, treating them in his eagerness, with as little consideration as the original searcher, he pulled open drawers, shook out books, stood on a chair to run his hand over the top of the wardrobe, and crawled under the bed and armchair.
At last, lying facedown on the floor, he spotted what looked like a torn piece of paper under the chest of drawers. When he pulled it out, it proved to be most of the photograph that Ron had described in her letter. A black-haired baby was zooming in and out of the picture on a tiny broom, roaring with laughter, and a pair of legs that must have belonged to Ron was chasing after him. Ron tucked the photograph into his pocket with Ron’s letter and continued to look for the second sheet.
After another quarter of an hour, however he was forced to conclude that the rest of his mother’s letter was gone. Had it simply been lost in the sixteen years that had elapsed since it had been written, or had it been taken by whoever had searched the room? Ron read the first sheet again, this time looking for clues as to what might have made the second sheet valuable. His toy broomstick could hardly be considered interesting to the Death Eaters... The only potentially useful thing he could see her was possible information on Weasley. It seems incredible that Weasley - what?
"Ron? Ron? Ron!"
"I’m here!" he called, "What’s happened?"
There was a clatter of footsteps outside the door, and Ron burst inside.
"We woke up and didn’t know where you were!" she said breathlessly. She turned and shouted over her shoulder, "Ron! I’ve found him"
Ron’s annoyed voice echoed distantly from several floors below.
"Good! Tell him from me he’s a git!"
"Ron don’t just disappear, please, we were terrified! Why did you come up here anyway?" She gazed around the ransacked room. "What have you been doing?"
"Look what I’ve just found"
He held out his mother’s letter. Ron took it out and read it while Ron watched her. When she reached the end of the page she looked up at him.
"Oh Ron..." "And there’s this too"
He handed her the torn photograph, and Ron smiled at the baby zooming in and out of sight on the toy broom.
"I’ve been looking for the rest of the letter," Ron said, "but it’s not here."
Ron glanced around.
"Did you make all this mess, or was some of it done when you got here?"
"Someone had searched before me," said Ron.
"I thought so. Every room I looked into on the way up had been disturbed. What were they after, do you think?"
"Information on the Order, if it was Weasley."
"But you’d think he’d already have all he needed. I mean was in the Order, wasn’t he?"
"Well then," said Ron, keen to discuss his theory, "what about information on Weasley? The second page of the letter, for instance. You know this Ron my mum mentions, you know who she is?"
"Who?"
"Ron Weasley, the author of -"
"A History of Magic," said Ron, looking interested. "So your parents knew her? She was an incredible magic historian."
"And she’s still alive," said Ron, "and she lives in Ron’s Hollow. Ron’s Auntie Weasley was talking about her at the wedding. She knew Weasley’s family too. Be pretty interesting to talk to, wouldn’t she?" There was a little too much understanding in the smile Ron gave him for Ron’s liking. He took back the letter and the photograph and tucked them inside the pouch around his neck, so as not to have to look at her and give himself away. "I understand why you’d love to talk to her about your mum and dad, and Weasley too," said Ron. "But that wouldn’t really help us in our search for the Horcruxes, would it?" Ron did not answer, and she rushed on, "Ron, I know you really want to go to Ron’s Hollow, but I’m scared. I’m scared at how easily those Death Eaters found us yesterday. It just makes me feel more than ever that we ought to avoid the place where your parents are buried, I’m sure they’d be expecting you to visit it."
"It’s not just that," Ron said, still avoiding looking at her, "Weasley said stuff about Weasley at the wedding. I want to know the truth..."
He told Ron everything that Weasley had told him. When he had finished, Ron said, "Of course, I can see why that’s upset you, Ron -"
"I’m not upset," he lied, "I’d just like to know whether or not it’s true or -"
"Ron do you really think you’ll get the truth from a malicious old woman like Weasley, or from Ron Weasley? How can you believe them? You knew Weasley!"
"I thought I did," he muttered.
"But you know how much truth there was in everything Ron wrote about you! Weasley is right, how can you let these people tarnish your memories of Weasley?"
He looked away, trying not to betray the resentment he felt. There it was again: Ronose what to believe. He wanted the truth. Why was everybody so determined that he should not get it?
"Shall we go down to the kitchen?" Ron suggested after a little pause. "Find something for breakfast?"
He agreed, but grudgingly, and followed her out onto the landing and past the second door that led off it. There were deep scratch marks in the paintwork below a small sign that he had not noticed in the dark. He passed at the top of the stairs to read it. It was a pompous little sign, neatly lettered by hand the sort of thing that Ron Weasley might have stuck on his bedroom door.
Do Not Enter
Without the Express Permission of
Ron Arcturus Weasley
Excitement trickled through Ron, but he was not immediately sure why. He read the sign again. Ron was already a flight of stairs below him.
"Ron," he said, and he was surprised that his voice was so calm. "Come back up here."
"What’s the matter?"
"R.A.B. I think I’ve found him."
There was a gasp, and then Ron ran back up the stairs.
"In your mum’s letter? But I didn’t see -"
Ron shook his head, pointing at Ron’s sign. She read it, then clutched Ron’s arm so tightly that he winced.
"Ron’s brother?" she whispered.
"He was a Death Eater," said Ron. "Ron told me about him, he joined up when he was really young and then got cold feet and tried to leave - so they killed him."
"That fits!" gasped Ron. "If he was a Death Eater he had access to Weasley, and if he became disenchanted, then he would have wanted to bring Weasley down!"
She released Ron, leaned over the banister, and screamed, "Ron! RON! Get up here, quick!"
Ron appeared, panting, a minute later, his wand ready in his hand.
"What’s up? If it’s massive spiders again I want breakfast before I -"
He frowned at the sign on Ron’s door, in which Ron was silently pointing.
"What? That was Ron’s brother, wasn’t it? Ron Arcturus ... Ron ... R.A.B.! The locket - you don’t reckon -- ?"
"Let’s find out," said Ron. He pushed the door: It was locked. Ron pointed her wand at the handle and said, "Alohamora." There was a click, and the door swung open.
They moved over the threshold together, gazing around. Ron’s bedroom was slightly smaller than Ron’s, though it had the same sense of former grandeur. Whereas Ron had sought to advertise his diffidence from the rest of the family, Ron had striven to emphasize the opposite. The Weasley colors of emerald and silver were everywhere, draping the bed, the walls, and the windows. The Weasley family crest was painstakingly painted over the bed, along with its motto, TOUJOURS PUR. Beneath this was a collection of yellow newspaper cuttings, all stuck together to make a ragged collage. Ron crossed the room to examine them.
"They’re all about Weasley," she said. "Ron seems to have been a fan for a few years before he joined the Death Eaters ..."
A little puff of dust rose from the bedcovers as she sat down to read the clippings. Ron, meanwhile, had noticed another photograph: a Hogwarts Quidditch team was smiling and waving out of the frame. He moved closer and saw the snakes emblazoned on their chests: Weasleys. Ron was instantly recognizable as the boy sitting in the middle of the front row: He had the same dark hair and slightly haughty look of his brother, though he was smaller, slighter, and rather less handsome than Ron had been.
"He played Seeker," said Ron.
"What?" said Ron vaguely; she was still immersed in Weasley’s press clippings.
"He’s sitting in the middle of the front row, that’s where the Seeker ... Never mind," said Ron, realizing that nobody was listening. Ron was on his hands and knees, searching under the wardrobe. Ron looked around the room for likely hiding places and approached the desk. Yet again, somebody had searched before them. The drawers’ contents had been turned over recently, the dust disturbed, but there was nothing of value there: old quills, out-of-date textbooks that bore evidence of being roughly handled, a recently smashed ink bottle, its sticky residue covering the contents of the drawer.
"There’s an easier way," said Ron, as Ron wiped his inky fingers on his jeans. She raised her wand and said, "Accio Locket!"
Nothing happened. Ron, who had been searching the folds of the faded curtains, looked disappointed.
"Is that it, then? It’s not here?"
"Oh, it could still be here, but under counter-enchantments," said Ron. "Charms to prevent it from being summoned magically, you know."
"Like Weasley put on the stone basin in the cave," said Ron, remembering how he had been unable to Summon the fake locket.
"How are we supposed to find it then?" asked Ron.
"We search manually," said Ron.
"That’s a good idea," said Ron, rolling his eyes, and he resumed his examination of the curtains.
They combed every inch of the room for more than an hour, but were forced, finally, to conclude that the locket was not there.
The sun had risen now; its light dazzled them even through the grimy landing windows.
"It could be somewhere else in the house, though," said Ron in a rallying tone as they walked back downstairs. As Ron and Ron had become more discouraged, she seemed to have become more determined. "Whether he’d manage to destroy it or not, he’d want to keep it hidden from Weasley, wouldn’t he? Remember all those awful things we had to get rid of when we were here last time? That clock that shot bolts at everyone and those old robes that tried to strangle Ron; Ron might have put them there to protect the locket’s hiding place, even though we didn’t realize it at ... at ... "
Ron and Ron looked at her. She was standing with one foot in midair, with the dumbstruck look of one who had just been Obliviated: her eyes had even drifted out of focus.
"... at the time," she finished in a whisper.
"Something wrong?" asked Ron.
"There was a locket."
"What?" said Ron and Ron together.
"In the cabinet in the drawing room. Nobody could open it. And we ... we ... "
Ron felt as though a brick had slid down through his chest into his stomach. He remembered. He had even handled the thing as they passed it around, each trying in turn to pry it open. It had been tossed into a sack of rubbish, along with the snuffbox of Wartcap powder and the music box that had made everyone sleepy ..."
"Ron nicked loads of things back from us," said Ron. It was the only chance, the only slender hope left to them, and he was going to cling to it until forced to let go. "He had a whole stash of stuff in his cupboard in the kitchen. C’mon."
He ran down the stairs taking two steps at a time, the other two thundering along in his wake. They made so much noise that they woke the portrait of Ron’s mother as they passed through the hall.
"Filth! Mudbloods! Scum!" she screamed after them as they dashed down into the basement kitchen and slammed the door behind them. Ron ran the length of the room, skidded to a halt at the door of Ron’s cupboard, and wrenched it open. There was the nest of dirty old blankets in which the house-elf had once slept, but they were not longer glittering with the trinkets Ron had salvaged. The only thing there was an old copy of Nature’s Nobility: A Wizarding Genealogy. Refusing to believe his eyes, Ron snatched up the blankets and shook them. A dead mouse fell out and rolled dismally across the floor. Ron groaned as he threw himself into a kitchen chair; Ron closed her eyes.
"It’s not over yet," said Ron, and he raised his voice and called, "Ron!"
There was a loud crack and the house elf that Ron had so reluctantly inherited from Ron appeared out of nowhere in front of the cold and empty fireplace: tiny, half human-sized, his pale skin hanging off him in folds, white hair sprouting copiously from his batlike ears. He was still wearing the filthy rag in which they had first met him, and the contemptuous look he bent upon Ron showed that his attitude to his change of ownership had altered no more than his outfit.
"Master," croaked Ron in his bullfrog’s voice, and he bowed low; muttering to his knees, "back in my Mistress’s old house with the blood-traitor Weasley and the Mudblood -"
"I forbid you to call anyone ‘blood traitor’ or ‘Mudblood,’" growled Ron. He would have found Ron, with his snoutlike nose and bloodshot eyes, a distinctively unlovable object even if the elf had not betrayed Ron to Weasley.
"I’ve got a question for you," said Ron, his heart beating rather fast as he looked down at the elf, "and I order you to answer it truthfully. Understand?"
"Yes, Master," said Ron, bowing low again. Ron saw his lips moving soundlessly, undoubtedly framing the insults he was now forbidden to utter.
"Two years ago," said Ron, his heart now hammering against his ribs, "there was a big gold locket in the drawing room upstairs. We threw it out. Did you steal it back?"
There was a moment’s silence, during which Ron straightened up to look Ron full in the face. Then he said, "Yes."
"Where is it now?" asked Ron jubilantly as Ron and Ron looked gleeful.
Ron closed his eyes as though he could not bear to see their reactions to his next word.
"Gone."
"Gone?" echoed Ron, elation floating out of him, "What do you mean, it’s gone?"
The elf shivered. He swayed.
"Ron," said Ron fiercely, "I order you -"
"Ron Weasley," croaked the elf, his eyes still tight shut. "Ron Weasley stole it all; Miss Weasleya’s and Miss Cissy’s pictures, my Mistress’s gloves, the Order of Merlin, First Class, the goblets with the family crest, and - and - "
Ron was gulping for air: His hollow chest was rising and falling rapidly, then his eyes flew open and he uttered a bloodcurdling scream.
"-and the locket, Master Ron’s locket. Ron did wrong, Ron failed in his orders!"
Ron reacted instinctively: As Ron lunged for the poker standing in the grate, he launched himself upon the elf, flattening him. Ron’s scream mingled with Ron’s but Ron bellowed louder than both of them: "Ron, I order you to stay still!"
He felt the elf freeze and released him. Ron lay flat on the cold stone floor, tears gushing from his sagging eyes.
"Ron, let him up!" Ron whispered.
"So he can beat himself up with the poker?" snorted Ron, kneeling beside the elf. "I don’t think so. Right. Ron, I want the truth: How do you know Ron Weasley stole the locket?"
"Ron saw him!" gasped the elf as tears poured over his snout and into his mouth full of graying teeth. "Ron saw him coming out of Ron’s cupboard with his hands full of Ron’s treasures. Ron told the sneak thief to stop, but Ron Weasley laughed and r-ran ... "
"You called the locket ‘Master Ron’s,’" said Ron. "Why? Where did it come from? What did Ron have to do with it? Ron, sit up and tell me everything you know about that locket, and everything Ron had to do with it!"
The elf sat up, curled into a ball, placed his wet face between his knees, and began to rock backward and forward. When he spoke, his voice was muffled but quite distinct in the silent, echoing kitchen.
"Master Ron ran away, good riddance, for he was a bad boy and broke my Mistress’s heart with his lawless ways. But Master Ron had proper order; he knew what was due to the name of Weasley and the dignity of his pure blood. For years he talked of the Dark Lord, who was going to bring the wizards out of hiding to rule the Muggles and the Muggle-borns ... and when he was sixteen years old, Master Ron joined the Dark Lord. So proud, so proud, so happy to serve ...
And one day, a year after he joined, Master Ron came down to the kitchen to see Ron. Master Ron always liked Ron. And Master Ron said ... he said ..."
The old elf rocked faster than ever.
"... he said that the Dark Lord required an elf."
"Weasley needed an elf?" Ron repeated, looking around at Ron and Ron, who looked just as puzzled as he did.
"Oh yes," moaned Ron. "And Master Ron had volunteered Ron. It was an honor, said Master Ron, an honor for him and for Ron, who must be sure to do whatever the Dark Lord ordered him to do ... and then to c-come home."
Ron rocked still faster, his breath coming in sobs.
"So Ron went to the Dark Lord. The Dark Lord did not tell Ron what they were to do, but took Ron with him to a cave beside the sea. And beyond the cave was a cavern, and in the cavern was a great black lake ... "
The hairs on the back of Ron’s neck stood up. Ron’s croaking voice seemed to come to him from across the dark water. He saw what had happened as clearly as though he had been present.
"... There was a boat ..."
Of course there had been a boat; Ron knew the boat, ghostly green and tiny, bewitched so as to carry one wizard and one victim toward the island in the center. This, then, was how Weasley had tested the defenses surrounding the Horcrux, by borrowing a disposable creature, a house-elf...
"There was a b-basin full of potion on the island. The D-Dark Lord made Ron drink it ..."
The elf quaked from head to foot.
"Ron drank, and as he drank he saw terrible thing ... Ron’s insides burned ... Ron cried for Master Ron to save him, he cried for his Mistress Weasley, but the Dark Lord only laughed ... He made Ron drink all the potion ... He dropped a locket into the empty basin ... He filled it with more potion."
"And then the Dark Lord sailed away, leaving Ron on the island ... "
Ron could see it happening. He watched Weasley’s white, snakelike face vanishing into darkness, those red eyes fixed pitilessly on the thrashing elf whose death would occur within minutes, whenever he succumbed to the desperate thirst that the burning poison caused its victim ... But here, Ron’s imagination could go no further, for he could not see how Ron had escaped.
"Ron needed water, he crawled to the island’s edge and he drank from the black lake ... and hands, dead hands, came out of the water and dragged Ron under the surface ... "
"How did you get away?" Ron asked, and he was not surprised to hear himself whispering.
Ron raised his ugly head and looked Ron with his great, bloodshot eyes.
"Master Ron told Ron to come back," he said.
"I know - but how did you escape the Inferi?"
Ron did not seem to understand.
"Master Ron told Ron to come back," he repeated.
"I know, but - "
"Well, it’s obvious, isn’t it, Ron?" said Ron. "He Disapparated!"
"But ... you couldn’t Apparate in and out of that cave," said Ron, "otherwise Weasley - "
"Elf magic isn’t like wizard’s magic, is it?" said Ron, "I mean, they can Apparate and Disapparate in and out of Hogwarts when we can’t."
There was a silence as Ron digested this. How could Weasley have made such a mistake? But even as he thought this, Ron spoke, and her voice was icy.
"Of course, Weasley would have considered the ways of house-elves far beneath his notice ... It would never have occurred to him that they might have magic that he didn’t."
"The house-elf’s highest law is his Master’s bidding," intoned Ron. "Ron was told to come home, so Ron came home ... "
"Well, then, you did what you were told, didn’t you?" said Ron kindly. "You didn’t disobey orders at all!"
Ron shook his head, rocking as fast as ever.
"So what happened when you got back?" Ron asked. "What did Ron say when you told him what happened?"
"Master Ron was very worried, very worried," croaked Ron. "Master Ron told Ron to stay hidden and not to leave the house. And then ... it was a little while later ... Master Ron came to find Ron in his cupboard one night, and Master Ron was strange, not as he usually was, disturbed in his mind, Ron could tell ... and he asked Ron to take him to the cave, the cave where Ron had gone with the Dark Lord ... "
And so they had set off. Ron could visualize them quite clearly, the frightened old elf and the thin, dark Seeker who had so resembled Ron ... Ron knew how to open the concealed entrance to the underground cavern, knew how to raise the tiny boat: this time it was his beloved Ron who sailed with him to the island with its basin of poison ...
"And he made you drink the poison?" said Ron, disgusted.
But Ron shook his head and wept. Ron’s hands leapt to her mouth: She seemed to have understood something.
"M-Master Ron took from his pocket a locket like the one the Dark Lord had," said Ron, tears pouring down either side of his snoutlike nose. "And he told Ron to take it and, when the basin was empty, to switch the lockets ..."
Ron’s sobs came in great rasps now; Ron had to concentrate hard to understand him.
"And he order - Ron to leave - without him. And he told Ron - to go home - and never to tell my Mistress - what he had done - but to destroy - the first locket. And he drank - all the potion - and Ron swapped the lockets - and watched ... as Master Ron ... was dragged beneath the water ... and ... "
"Oh, Ron!" wailed Ron, who was crying. She dropped to her knees beside the elf and tried to hug him. At once he was on his feet, cringing away from her, quite obviously repulsed.
"The Mudblood touched Ron, he will not allow it, what would his Mistress say?"
"I told you not to call her ‘Mudblood’!" snarled Ron, but the elf was already punishing himself. He fell to the ground and banged his forehead on the floor.
"Stop him - stop him!" Ron cried. "Oh, don’t you see now how sick it is, the way they’ve got to obey?"
"Ron - stop, stop!" shouted Ron.
The elf lay on the floor, panting and shivering, green mucus glistening around his snot, a bruise already blooming on his pallid forehead where he had struck himself, his eyes swollen and bloodshot and swimming in tears. Ron had never seen anything so pitiful.
"So you brought the locket home," he said relentlessly, for he was determined to know the full story. "And you tried to destroy it?"
"Nothing Ron did made any mark upon it," moaned the elf. "Ron tried everything, everything he knew, but nothing, nothing would work ... So many powerful spells upon the casing, Ron was sure the way to destroy it was to get inside it, but it would not open ... Ron punished himself, he tried again, he punished himself, he tried again. Ron failed to obey orders, Ron could not destroy the locket! And his mistress was mad with grief, because Master Ron had disappeared and Ron could not tell her what had happened, no, because Master Ron had f-f-forbidden him to tell any of the f-f-family what happened in the c-cave ..."
Ron began to sob so hard that there were no more coherent words. Tears flowed down Ron’s cheeks as she watched Ron, but she did not dare touch him again. Even Ron, who was no fan of Ron’s, looked troubled. Ron sat back on his heels and shook his head, trying to clear it.
"I don’t understand you, Ron," he said finally. "Weasley tried to kill you, Ron died to bring Weasley down, but you were still happy to betray Ron to Weasley? You were happy to go to Ron and Weasleyatrix, and pass information to Weasley through them ... "
"Ron, Ron doesn’t think like that," said Ron, wiping her eyes on the back of her hand. "He’s a slave; house-elves are used to bad, even brutal treatment; what Weasley did to Ron wasn’t that far out of the common way. What do wizard wars mean to an elf like Ron? He’s loyal to people who are kind to him, and Mrs. Weasley must have been, and Ron certainly was, so he served them willingly and parroted their beliefs. I know what you’re going to say," she went on as Ron began to protest, "that Ron changed his mind ... but he doesn’t seem to have explained that to Ron, does he?" And I think I know why. Ron and Ron’s family were all safest if they kept to the old pure-blood line. Ron was trying to protect them all."
"Ron - "
"Ron was horrible to Ron, Ron, and it’s no good looking like that, you know it’s true. Ron had been alone for such a long time when Ron came to live here, and he was probably starving for a bit of affection. I’m sure ‘Miss Cissy’ and ‘Miss Weasleya’ were perfectly lovely to Ron when he turned up, so he did them a favor and told them everything they wanted to know. I’ve said all along that wizards would pay for how they treat house-elves. Well, Weasley did ... and so did Ron."
Ron had no retort. As he watched Ron sobbing on the floor, he remembered what Weasley had said to him, mere hours after Ron’s death: I do not think Ron ever saw Ron as a being with feelings as acute as a human’s ...
"Ron," said Ron after a while, "when you feel up to it, er ... please sit up."
It was several minutes before Ron hiccupped himself into silence. Then he pushed himself into a sitting position again, rubbing his knuckles into his eyes like a small child.
"Ron, I am going to ask you to do something," said Ron. He glanced at Ron for assistance. He wanted to give the order kindly, but at the same time, he could not pretend that it was not an order. However, the change in his tone seemed to have gained her approval: She smiled encouragingly.
"Ron, I want you, please, to go and find Ron Weasley. We need to find out where the locket - where Master Ron’s locket it. It’s really important. We
want to finish the work Master Ron started, we want to - er - ensure that he didn’t die in vain."
Ron dropped his fists and looked up at Ron.
"Find Ron Weasley?" he croaked.
And bring him here, to Grimmauld Place," said Ron. "Do you think you could do that for us?"
As Ron nodded and got to his feet, Ron had a sudden inspiration. He pulled out Weasley’s purse and took out the fake Horcrux, the substitute locket in which Ron had placed the note to Weasley.
"Ron, I’d, er, like you to have this," he said, pressing the locket into the elf’s hand. "This belonged to Ron and I’m sure he’d want you to have it as a token of gratitude for what you-"
"Overkill, mate," said Ron as the elf took one look at the locket, let out a howl of shock and misery, and threw himself back onto the ground.
It took them nearly half an hour to calm down Ron, who was so overcome to be presented with a Weasley family heirloom for his very own that he was too weak at the knees to stand properly. When finally he was able to totter a few steps they all accompanied him to his cupboard, watched him tuck up the locket safely in his dirty blankets, and assured him that they would make its protection their first priority while he was away. He then made two low bows to Ron and Ron, and even gave a funny little spasm in Ron’s direction that might have been an attempt at a respectful salute, before Disapparating with the usual loud crack.
Chapter Eleven
The Bribe
If Ron could escape a lake full of Inferi, Ron was confident that the capture of Ron would take a few hours at most, and he prowled the house all morning in a state of high anticipation. However, Ron did not return that morning or even that afternoon. By nightfall, Ron felt discouraged and anxious, and a supper composed largely of moldy bread, upon which Ron had tried a variety of unsuccessful Transfigurations, did nothing to help.
Ron did not return the following day, nor the day after that. However, two cloaked men had appeared in the square outside number twelve, and they remained there into the night, gazing in the direction of the house that they could not see.
"Death Eaters, for sure," said Ron, as he, Ron, and Ron watched from the drawing room windows. "Reckon they know we’re in here?"
"I don’t think so," said Ron, though she looked frightened, "or they’d have sent Weasley in after us, wouldn’t they?"
"D’you reckon he’s been in here and has his tongue tied by Weasley’s curse?" asked Ron.
"Yes," said Ron, "otherwise he’d have been able to tell that lot how to get in, wouldn’t he? But they’re probably watching to see whether we turn up. They know that Ron owns the house, after all."
"How do they --?" began Ron.
"Wizarding wills are examined by the Ministry, remember? They’ll know Ron left you the place."
The presence of the Death Eaters outside increased the ominous mood inside number twelve. They had not heard a word form anyone beyond Grimmauld Place since Mr. Weasley’s Patronus, and the strain was starting to tell. Restless and irritable, Ron had developed an annoying habit of playing with the Deluminator in his pocket; This particularly infuriated Ron, who was whiling away the wait for Ron by studying The Tales of Ron the Weasley and did not appreciate the way the lights kept flashing on and off.
"Will you stop it!" she cried on the third evening of Ron’s absence, as all the light was sucked from the drawing room yet again.
"Sorry, sorry!" said Ron, clicking the Deluminator and restoring the lights. "I don’t know I’m doing it!"
"Well, can’t you find something useful to occupy yourself?"
"What, like reading kids’ stories?"
"Weasley left me this book, Ron -"
"-and he left me the Deluminator, maybe I’m supposed to use it!"
Unable to stand the bickering, Ron slipped out of the room unnoticed by either of them. He headed downstairs toward the kitchen, which he kept visiting because he was sure that was where Ron was most likely to reappear. Halfway down the flight of stairs into the hall, however, he heard a tap on the front door, then metallic clicks and the grinding of the chain.
Every nerve in his body seemed to tauten: He pulled out his wand, moved into the shadows beside the decapitated elf heads, and waited. The door opened: He saw a glimpse of the lamplit square outside, and a cloaked figure edged into the hall and closed the door behind it. The intruder took a step forward, and Weasley’s voice asked, "Ron Weasley?" Then the dust figure rose from the end of the hall and rushed him, raising its dead hand.
"It was not I who killed you, Ron," said a quiet voice.
The jinx broke: The dust-figure exploded again, and it was impossible to make out the newcomer through the dense gray cloud it left behind.
Ron pointed the wand into the middle of it.
"Don’t move!"
He had forgotten the portrait of Mrs. Weasley: At the sound of his yell, the curtains hiding her flew open and she began to scream, "Mudbloods and filth dishonoring my house -"
Ron and Ron came crashing down the stairs behind Ron, wands pointing, like his, at the unknown man now standing with his arms raised in the hall below.
"Hold your fire, it’s me, Ron!"
"Oh, thank goodness," said Ron weakly, pointing her wand at Mrs. Weasley instead; with a bang, the curtains swished shut again and silence fell. Ron too lowered his wand, but Ron did not.
"Show yourself!" he called back.
Weasley moved forward into the lamplight, hands still held high in a gesture of surrender.
"I am Ron Ron Weasley, werewolf, sometimes known as Moony, one of the four creators of the Marauder’s Map, married to Ron, usually known as Weasley, and I taught you how to produce a Patronus, Ron, which takes the form of a stag."
"Oh, all right," said Ron, lowering his wand, "but I had to check, didn’t I?"
"Speaking as your ex-Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher, I quite agree that you had to check. Ron, Ron, you shouldn’t be so quick to lower your defenses."
They ran down the stairs towards him. Wrapped in a thick black traveling cloak, he looked exhausted, but pleased to see them.
"No sign of Ron, then?" he asked.
"No," said Ron. "What’s going on? Is everyone okay?’
"Yes," said Weasley, "but we’re all being watched. There are a couple of Death Eaters in the square outside -"
"We know -"
"I had to Apparate very precisely onto the top step outside the front door to be sure that they would not see me. They can’t know you’re in here or I’m sure they’d have more people out there; they’re staking out everywhere that’s got any connection with you, Ron. Let’s go downstairs, there’s a lot to tell you, and I want to know what happened after you left the Burrow."
They descended into the kitchen, where Ron pointed her wand at the grate. A fire sprang up instantly: It gave the illusion of coziness to the stark stone walls and glistened off the long wooden table. Weasley pulled a few butterbeers from beneath his traveling cloak and they sat down.
"I’d have been here three days ago but I needed to shake off the Death Eater tailing me," said Weasley. "So, you came straight here after the wedding?"
"No," said Ron, "only after we ran into a couple of Death Eaters in a café on Tottenham Court Road."
Weasley slopped most of his butterbeer down his front.
"What?"
They explained what had happened; when they had finished, Weasley looked aghast.
"But how did they find you so quickly? It’s impossible to track anyone who Apparates, unless you grab hold of them as they disappear."
"And it doesn’t seem likely they were just strolling down Tottenham Court Road at the time, does it?" said Ron.
"We wondered," said Ron tentatively, "whether Ron could still have the Trace on him?"
"Impossible," said Weasley. Ron looked smug, and Ron felt hugely relieved. "Apart from anything else, they’d know for sure Ron was here if he still had the Trace on him, wouldn’t they? But I can’t see how they could have tracked you to Tottenham Court Road, that’s worrying, really worrying."
He looked disturbed, but as far as Ron was concerned, that question could wait.
"Tell us what happened after we left, we haven’t heard a thing since Ron’s dad told us the family was safe."
"Well, Ron saved us," said Weasley. "Thanks to his warning most of the wedding guests were able to Disapparate before they arrived."
"Were they Death Eaters or Ministry people?" interjected Ron.
"A mixture; but to all intents and purposes they’re the same thing now," said Weasley. "There were about a dozen of them, but they didn’t know you were there, Ron. Ron heard a rumor that they tried to torture your whereabouts out of Weasley before they killed him; if it’s true, he didn’t give you away."
Ron looked at Ron and Ron; their expressions reflected the mingled shock and gratitude he felt. He had never liked Weasley much, but if what Weasley said was true, the man’s final act had been to try to protect Ron.
"The Death Eaters searched the Burrow from top to bottom," Weasley went on. "They found the ghoul, but didn’t want to get too close - and then they interrogated those of us who remained for hours. They were trying to get information on you, Ron, but of course nobody apart from the Order knew that you had been there.
"At the same time that they were smashing up the wedding, more Death Eaters were forcing their way into every Order-connected house in the country. No deaths," he added quickly, forestalling the question, "but they were rough. They burned down Dedalus Weasley’s house, but as you know he wasn’t there, and they used the Cruciarus Curse on Weasley’s family. Again, trying to find out where you went after you visited them. They’re all right - shaken, obviously, but otherwise okay."
"The Death Eaters got through all those protective charms?"
Ron asked, remembering how effective these had been on the night he had crashed in Weasley’s parents’ garden.
"What you’ve got to realize, Ron, is that the Death Eaters have got the full might of the Ministry on their side now," said Weasley. "They’ve got the power to perform brutal spells without fear of identification or arrest. They managed to penetrate every defensive spell we’d cast against them, and once inside, they were completely open about why they’d come."
"And are they bothering to give an excuse for torturing Ron’s whereabouts out of people?" asked Ron, an edge to her voice.
"Well," Weasley said. He hesitated, then pulled out a folded copy of the Daily Prophet.
"Here," he said, pushing it across the table to Ron, "you’ll know sooner or later anyway. That’s their pretext for going after you."
Ron smoothed out the paper. A huge photograph of his own face filled the front page. He read the headline over it:
WANRon FOR QUESTIONING ABOUT
THE DEATH OF Ron Weasley
Ron and Ron gave roars of outrage, but Ron said nothing. He pushed the newspaper away; he did not want to read anymore: He knew what it would say. Nobody but those who had been on top of the tower when Weasley died knew who had really killed him and, as Ron Weasley had already told the Wizarding world, Ron had been seen running from the place moments after Weasley had fallen.
"I’m sorry, Ron," Weasley said.
"So Death Eaters have taken over the Daily Prophet too?" asked Ron furiously.
Weasley nodded.
"But surely people realize what’s going on?"
"The coup has been smooth and virtually silent," said Weasley.
"The official version of Weasley’s murder is that he resigned; he has been replaced by Ron Weasley, who is under the Imperius Curse."
"Why didn’t Weasley declare himself Minister of Magic?" asked Ron.
Weasley laughed.
"He doesn’t need to, Ron. Effectively, he is the Minister, but why should he sit behind a desk at the Ministry? His puppet, Weasley, is taking care of everyday business, leaving Weasley free to extend his power beyond the Ministry.
"Naturally many people have deduced what has happened: There has been such a dramatic change in Ministry policy in the last few days, and many are whispering that Weasley must be behind it. However, that is the point: They whisper. They daren’t confide in each other, not knowing whom to trust; they are scared to speak out, in case their suspicions are true and their families are targeted. Yes, Weasley is playing a very clever game. Declaring himself might have provoked open rebellion: Remaining masked has created confusion, uncertainty, and fear."
"And this dramatic change in Ministry policy," said Ron, "involves warning the Wizarding world against me instead of Weasley?"
"That’s certainly a part of it," said Weasley, "and it is a masterstroke. Now that Weasley is dead, you - the Boy Who Lived - were sure to be the symbol and rallying point for any resistance to Weasley. But by suggesting that you had a hand in the old hat’s death, Weasley has not only set a price upon your head, but sown doubt and fear amongst many who would have defended you.
"Meanwhile, the Ministry has started moving against Muggle-borns."
Weasley pointed at the Daily Prophet.
"Look at page two."
Ron turned the pages with much the same expression of distaste she had when handling Secrets of the Darkest Art.
"Muggle-born Register!" she read aloud. "‘The Ministry of Magic is undertaking a survey of so-called "Muggle-borns" the better to understand how they came to possess magical secrets.
"‘Recent research undertaken by the Department of Mysteries reveals that magic can only be passed from person to person when Wizards reproduce. Where no proven Wizarding ancestry exists, therefore, the so-called Muggle-born is likely to have obtained magical power by theft or force.
"‘The Ministry is determined to root out such usurpers of magical power, and to this end has issued an invitation to every so-called Muggle-born to present themselves for interview by the newly appointed Muggle-born Registration Commission.’"
"People won’t let this happen," said Ron.
"It is happening, Ron," said Weasley. "Muggle-borns are being rounded up as we speak."
"But how are they supposed to have ‘stolen’ magic?" said Ron. "It’s mental, if you could steal magic there wouldn’t be any Squibs, would there?"
"I know," said Weasley. "Nevertheless, unless you can prove that you have at least one close Wizarding relative, you are now deemed to have obtained your magical power illegally and must suffer the punishment."
Ron glanced at Ron, then said, "What if purebloods and halfbloods swear a Muggle-born’s part of their family? I’ll tell everyone Ron’s my cousin -"
Ron covered Ron’s hand with hers and squeezed it.
"Thank you, Ron, but I couldn’t let you -"
"You won’t have a choice," said Ron fiercely, gripping her hand back. "I’ll teach you my family tree so you can answer questions on it."
Ron gave a shaky laugh.
"Ron, as we’re on the run with Ron Weasley, the most wanted person in the country, I don’t think it matters. If I was going back to school it would be different. What’s Weasley planning for Hogwarts?" she asked Weasley.
"Attendance is now compulsory for every young witch and wizard," he replied. "That was announced yesterday. It’s a change, because it was never obligatory before. Of course, nearly every witch and wizard in Britain has been educated at Hogwarts, but their parents had the right to teach them at home or send them abroad if they preferred. This way, Weasley will have the whole Wizarding population under his eye from a young age. And it’s also another way of weeding out Muggle-borns, because students must be given Blood Status - meaning that they have proven to the Ministry that they are of Wizard descent - before they are allowed to attend."
Ron felt sickened and angry: At this moment, excited eleven-year-olds would be poring over stacks of newly purchased spell-books, unaware that they would never see Hogwarts, perhaps never see their families again either.
"It’s . . . it’s . . ." he muttered, struggling to find words that did justice to the horror of his thoughts, but Weasley said quietly,
"I know."
Weasley hesitated.
I’ll understand if you can’t confirm this, Ron, but the Order is under the impression that Weasley left you a mission."
"He did," Ron replied, "and Ron and Ron are in on it and they’re coming with me."
"Can you confide in me what the mission is?"
Ron looked into the prematurely lined face, framed in thick but graying hair, and wished that he could return a different answer.
"I can’t, Ron, I’m sorry. If Weasley didn’t tell you I don’t think I can."
"I thought you’d say that," said Weasley, looking disappointed. "But I might still be of some use to you. You know what I am and what I can do. I could come with you to provide protection. There would be no need to tell me exactly what you were up to."
Ron hesitated. It was a very tempting offer, though how they would be able to keep their mission secret from Weasley if he were with them all the time he could not imagine.
Ron, however, looked puzzled.
"But what about Weasley?" she asked.
"What about her?" said Weasley.
"Well," said Ron, frowning, "you’re married! How does she feel about you going away with us?"
"Weasley will be perfectly safe," said Weasley, "She’ll be at her parents’ house."
There was something strange in Weasley’s tone, it was almost cold. There was also something odd in the idea of Weasley remaining hidden at her parents’ house; she was, after all, a member of the Order and, as far as Ron knew, was likely to want to be in the thick of the action.
"Ron," said Ron tentatively, "is everything all right . . . you know . . . between you and - "
"Everything is fine, thank you," said Weasley pointedly.
Ron turned pink. There was another pause, an awkward and embarrassed one, and then Weasley said, with an air of forcing himself to admit something unpleasant, "Weasley is going to have a baby."
"Oh, how wonderful!" squealed Ron.
"Excellent!" said Ron enthusiastically.
"Congratulations," said Ron.
Weasley gave an artificial smile that was more like a grimace, then said, "So . . . do you accept my offer? Will three become four? I cannot believe that Weasley would have disapproved, he appointed me your Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher, after all. And I must tell you that I believe we are facing magic many of us have never encountered or imagined."
Ron and Ron both looked at Ron.
"Just - just to be clear," he said. "You want to leave Weasley at her parents’ house and come away with us?"
"She’ll be perfectly safe there, they’ll look after her," said Weasley. He spoke with a finality bordering on indifference: "Ron, I’m sure Ron would have wanted me to stick with you."
"Well," said Ron slowly, "I’m not. I’m pretty sure my father would have wanted to know why you aren’t sticking with your own kid, actually."
Weasley’s face drained of color. The temperature in the kitchen might have dropped ten degrees. Ron stared around the room as though he had been bidden to memorize it, while Ron’s eyes swiveled backward and forward from Ron to Weasley.
"You don’t understand," said Weasley at last.
"Explain, then," said Ron.
Weasley swallowed.
"I - I made a grave mistake in marrying Weasley. I did it against my better judgment and have regretted it very much every since."
"I see," said Ron, "so you’re just going to dump her and the kid and run off with us?"
Weasley sprang to his feet: His chair toppled over backward, and he glared at them so fiercely that Ron saw, for the first time ever, she shadow of the wolf upon his human face.
"Don’t you understand what I’ve done to my wife and my unborn child? I should never have married her, I’ve made her an outcast!"
Weasley kicked aside the chair he had overturned.
"You have only ever seen me amongst the Order, or under Weasley’s protection at Hogwarts! You don’t know how most of the Wizarding world sees creatures like me! When they know of my affliction, they can barely talk to me! Don’t you see what I’ve done?
Even her own family is disgusted by our marriage, what parents want their only daughter to marry a werewolf? And the child - the child - "
Weasley actually seized handfuls of his own hair; he looked quite deranged.
"My kind don’t usually breed! It will be like me, I am convinced of it - how can I forgive myself, when I knowingly risked passing on my own condition to an innocent child? And if, by some miracle, it is not like me, then it will be better off, a hundred times so, without a father of whom it must always be ashamed!"
"Ron!" whispered Ron, tears in her eyes. "Don’t say that - how could any child be ashamed of you?"
"Oh, I don’t know, Ron," said Ron. "I’d be pretty ashamed of him."
Ron did not know where his rage was coming from, but it had propelled him to his feet too. Weasley looked as though Ron had hit him.
"If the new regime thinks Muggle-borns are bad," Ron said, "what will they do to a half-werewolf whose father’s in the Order? My father died trying to protect my mother and me, and you reckon he’d tell you to abandon your kid to go on an adventure with us?"
"How - how dare you?" said Weasley. "This is not about a desire for - for danger or personal glory - how dare you suggest such a - "
"I think you’re feeling a bit of a daredevil," Ron said, "You fancy stepping into Ron’s shoes -"
"Ron, no!" Ron begged him, but he continued to glare into Weasley’s livid face.
"I’d never have believed this," Ron said. "The man who taught me to fight dementors - a coward."
Weasley drew his wand so fast that Ron had barely reached for his own; there was a loud bang and he felt himself flying backward as if punched; as he slammed into the kitchen wall and slid to the floor, he glimpsed the tail of Weasley’s cloak disappearing around the door.
"Ron, Ron, come back!" Ron cried, but Weasley did not respond. A moment later they heard the front door slam.
"Ron!" wailed Ron. "How could you?"
"It was easy," said Ron. He stood up, he could feel a lump swelling where his head had hit the wall. He was still so full of anger he was shaking.
"Don’t look at me like that!" he snapped at Ron.
"Don’t you start on her!" snarled Ron.
"No - no - we mustn’t fight!" said Ron, launching herself between them.
"You shouldn’t have said that stuff to Weasley," Ron told Ron.
"He had it coming to him," said Ron. Broken images were racing each other through his mind: Ron falling through the veil; Weasley suspended, broken, in midair; a flash of green light and his mother’s voice, begging for mercy . . .
"Parents," said Ron, "shouldn’t leave their kids unless - unless they’ve got to."
"Ron -" said Ron, stretching out a consoling hand, but he shrugged it off and walked away, his eyes on the fire Ron had conjured. He had once spoken to Weasley out of that fireplace, seeking reassurance about Ron, and Weasley had consoled him. Now Weasley’s tortured white face seemed to swim in the air before him. He felt a
sickening surge of remorse. Neither Ron nor Ron spoke, but Ron felt sure that they were looking at each other behind his back, communicating silently.
He turned around and caught them turning hurriedly away form each other.
"I know I shouldn’t have called him a coward."
"No, you shouldn’t," said Ron at once.
"But he’s acting like one."
"All the same . . ." said Ron.
"I know," said Ron. "But if it makes him go back to Weasley, it’ll be worth it, won’t it?"
He could not keep the plea out of his voice. Ron looked sympathetic, Ron uncertain. Ron looked down at his feet, thinking of his father. Would Ron have backed Ron in what he had said to Weasley, or would he have been angry at how his son had treated his old friend?
The silent kitchen seemed to hum with the shock of the recent scene and with Ron and Ron’s unspoken reproaches. The Daily Prophet Weasley had brought was still lying on the table, Ron’s own face staring up at the ceiling from the front page. He walked over to it and sat down, opened the paper at random, and pretended to read. He could not take in the words; his mind was still too full of the encounter with Weasley. He was sure that Ron and Ron had resumed their silent communications on the other side of the Prophet. He turned a page loudly, and Weasley’s name leapt out at him. It was a moment or two before he took in the meaning of the photograph, which showed a family group. Beneath the photograph were the words: The Weasley family, left to right: Ron; Percival, holding newborn Ron; Kendra, and Ron.
His attention caught, Ron examined the picture more carefully. Weasley’s father, Percival, was a good-looking man with eyes that seemed to twinkle even in this faded old photograph. The baby, Ron, was a little longer than a loaf of bread and no more distinctive-looking. The mother, Kendra, had jet black hair pulled into a high bun. Her face had a carved quality about it. Ron thought of photos of Native Americans he’d seen as he studied her dark eyes, high cheekbones, and straight nose, formally composed above a high-necked silk gown. Ron and Ron wore matching lacy collared jackets and had identical, shoulder-length hairstyles. Ron looked several years older, but otherwise the two boys looked very alike, for this was before Ron’s nose had been broken and before he started wearing glasses.
The family looked quite happy and normal, smiling serenely up out of the newspaper. Baby Ron’s arm waved vaguely out of her shawl. Ron looked above the picture and saw the headline:
EXCLUSIVE EXTRACT FROM UPCOMING
BIOGRAPHY OF Ron Weasley
by Ron Weasley
Thinking it could hardly make him feel any worse than he already did, Ron began to read:
Proud and haughty, Kendra Weasley could not bear to remain in Mould-on-the-Wold after her husband Percival’s well-publicized arrest and imprisonment in Azkaban. She therefore decided to uproot the family and relocate to Ron’s Hollow, the village that was later to gain fame as the scene of Ron Weasley’s strange escape from You-Know-Who.
Like Mould-on-the-Wold, Ron’s Hollow was home to a number of Wizarding families, but as Kendra knew none of them, she would be spared the curiosity about her husband’s crime she had faced in her former village. By repeatedly rebuffing the friendly advances of her new Wizarding neighbors, she soon ensured that her family was left well alone.
"Slammed the door in my face when I went around to welcome her with a batch of homemade Cauldron Cakes," says Ron Weasley. "The first year they were there I only ever saw the two boys. Wouldn’t have known there was a daughter if I hadn’t been picking Plangentines by moonlight the winter after they moved in, and saw Kendra leading Ron out into the back garden. Walked her round the lawn once, keeping a firm grip on her, then took her back inside. Didn’t know what to make of it."
It seems that Kendra thought the move to Ron’s Hollow was the perfect opportunity to hide Ron once and for all, something she had probably been planning for years. The timing was significant. Ron was barely seven years old when she vanished from sight, and seven is the age by which most experts agree that magic will have revealed itself, if present. Nobody now alive remembers Ron ever demonstrating even the slightest sign of magical ability. It seems clear, therefore, that Kendra made a decision to hide her daughter’s existence rather than suffer the shame of admitting that she had produced a Squib. Moving away from the friends and neighbors who knew Ron would, of course, make imprisoning her all the easier. The tiny number of people who henceforth knew of Ron’s existence could be counted upon to keep the secret, including her two brothers, who had deflected awkward questions with the answer their mother had taught them. "My sister is too frail for school."
Next week: Ron Weasley at Hogwarts - the Prizes and the Pretense.
