"Thanks, River," said another very familiar voice. Ron started to speak, but Ron forestalled him in a whisper.
"We know it’s Weasley!"
"Romulus, do you maintain, as you have every time you’ve appeared on our program, that Ron Weasley is still alive?"
"I do," said Weasley firmly. "There is no doubt at all in my mind that his death would be proclaimed as widely as possible by the Death Eaters if it had happened, because it would strike a deadly blow at the morale of those resisting the new regime. ‘The Boy Who Lived’ remains a symbol of everything for which we are fighting: the triumph of good, the power of innocence, the need to keep resisting."
A mixture of gratitude and shame welled up in Ron. Had Weasley forgiven him, then, for the terrible things he had said when they had last met?
"And what would you say to Ron if you knew he was listening, Romulus?"
"I’d tell him we’re all with him in spirit," said Weasley, then hesitated slightly, "And I’d tell him to follow his instincts, which are good and nearly always right."
Ron looked at Ron, whose eyes were full of tears.
"Nearly always right," she repeated.
"Oh, didn’t I tell you?" said Ron in surprise. "Ron told me Weasley’s living with Weasley again! And apparently she’s getting pretty big too..."
"...and our usual update on those friends of Ron Weasley’s who are suffering for their allegiance?" Ron was saying.
"Well, as regular listeners will know, several of the more outspoken supporters of Ron Weasley have now been imprisoned, including Ron Weasley, erstwhile editor of The Quibbler," said Weasley.
"At least he’s still alive!" muttered Ron.
"We have also heard within the last few hours that Ron Weasley" - all three of them gasped, and so nearly missed the rest of the sentence -- "well-known gamekeeper at Hogwarts School, has narrowly escaped arrest within the grounds of Hogwarts, where he is rumored to have hosted a ‘Support Ron Weasley’ party in his house. However, Weasley was not taken into custody, and is, we believe, on the run."
"I suppose it helps, when escaping from Death Eaters, if you’ve got a sixteen-foot-high half brother?" asked Ron.
"It would tend to give you an edge," agreed Weasley gravely. "May I just add that while we here at Weasleywatch applaud Weasley’s spirit, we would urge even the most devoted of Ron’s supporters against following Weasley’s lead. ‘Support Ron Weasley’ parties are unwise in the present climate."
"Indeed they are, Romulus," said Ron, "so we suggest that you continue to show your devotion to the man with the lightning scar by listening to Weasleywatch! And now let’s move to news concerning the wizard who is proving just as elusive as Ron Weasley. We like to refer to him as the Chief Death Eater, and here to give his views on some of the more insane rumors circulating about him, I’d like to introduce a new correspondent. Rodent?"
"’Rodent’?" said yet another familiar voice, and Ron, Ron, and Ron cried out together:
"Ron!"
"No - is it Ron?"
"It’s Ron, I think," said Ron, leaning in closer, as whichever twin it was said,
"I’m not being ‘Rodent,’ no way, I told you I wanted to be ‘Rapier’!"
"Oh, all right then, ‘Rapier,’ could you please give us your take on the various stories we’ve been hearing about the Chief Death Eater?"
"Yes, River, I can," said Ron. "As our listeners will know, unless they’ve taken refuge at the bottom of a garden pond or somewhere similar, You-Know-Who’s strategy of remaining in the shadows is creating a nice little climate of panic. Mind you, if all the alleged sightings of him are genuine, we must have a good nineteen You-Know-Whos running around the place."
"Which suits him, of course," said Ron. "The air of mystery is creating more terror than actually showing himself."
"Agreed," said Ron. "So, people, let’s try and calm down a bit. Things are bad enough without inventing stuff as well. For instance, this new idea that You-Know-Who can kill people with a single glance from his eyes. That’s a basilisk, listeners. One simple test: Check whether the thing that’s glaring at you has got legs. If it has, it’s safe to look into its eyes, although if it really is You-Know-Who, that’s still likely to be the last thing you ever do."
For the first time in weeks and weeks, Ron was laughing: He could feel the weight of tension leaving him.
"And the rumors that he keeps being sighted abroad?" asked Ron.
"Well, who wouldn’t want a nice little holiday after all the hard work he’s been putting in?" asked Ron. "Point is, people, don’t get lulled into a false sense of security, thinking he’s out of the country. Maybe he is, maybe he isn’t, but the fact remains he can move faster than Ron Weasley confronted with shampoo when he wants to, so don’t
count on him being a long way away if you’re planning to take any risks. I never thought I’d hear myself say it, but safety first!"
"Thank you very much for those wise words, Rapier," said Ron. "Listeners, that brings us to the end of another Weasleywatch. We don’t know when it will be possible to broadcast again, but you can be sure we shall be back. Keep twiddling those dials: The next password will be ‘Mad-Eye.’ Keep each other safe: Keep faith. Good night."
The radio’s dial twirled and the lights behind the tuning panel went out. Ron, Ron, and Ron were still beaming. Hearing familiar, friendly voices was an extraordinary tonic; Ron had become so used to their isolation he had nearly forgotten that other people were resisting Weasley. It was like waking from a long sleep.
"Good, eh?" said Ron happily.
"Brilliant," said Ron.
"It’s so brave of them," sighed Ron admiringly. "If they were found ..."
"Well, they keep on the move, don’t they?" said Ron. "Like us."
"But did you hear what Ron said?" asked Ron excitedly; now the broadcast was over, his thoughts turned around toward his all consuming obsession. "He’s abroad! He’s still looking for the Wand, I knew it!"
"Ron-"
"Come on, Ron, why are you so determined not to admit it? Vol -"
"Ron, NO!"
"-demort’s after the Elder Wand!"
"The name’s Taboo!" Ron bellowed, leaping to his feet as a loud crack sounded outside the tent. "I told you, Ron, I told you, we can’t say it anymore - we’ve got to put the protection back around us - quickly - it’s how they find -"
But Ron stopped talking, and Ron knew why. The Sneakoscope on the table had lit up and begun to spin; they could hear voices coming nearer and nearer: rough, excited voices. Ron pulled the Deluminator out of his pocket and clicked it: Their lamps went out.
"Come out of there with your hands up!" came a rasping voice through the darkness. "We know you’re in there! You’ve got half a dozen wands pointing at you and we don’t care who we curse!"
Chapter Twenty-Three
Weasley Manor
Ron looked around at the other two, now mere outlines in the darkness. He saw Ron point her wand, set toward the outside, but into his face; there was a bang, a burst of white light, and he buckled in agony, unable to see. He could feel his face swelling rapidly under his hands as heavy footfalls surrounded him.
"Get up, vermin."
Unknown hands dragged Ron roughly off the ground, before he could stop them, someone had rummaged through his pockets and removed the blackthorn wand. Ron clutched at his excruciatingly painful face, which felt unrecognizable beneath his fingers, tight, swollen, and puffy as though he had suffered some violent allergic reaction. His
eyes had been reduced to slits through which he could barely see; his glasses fell off as he was bundled out of the tent: all he could make out were the blurred shapes of four or five people wrestling Ron and Ron outside too.
"Get -- off - her!" Ron shouted. There was the unmistakable sound of knuckles hitting flesh: Ron grunted in pain and Ron screamed, "No! Leave him alone, leave him alone!"
"Your boyfriend's going to have worse than that done to him if he's on my list," said the horribly familiar, rasping voice. "Delicious girl... what a treat . . . I do enjoy the softness of the skin. . . ."
Ron's stomach turned over. He knew who this was, Fenrit Weasley, the werewolf who was permitted to wear Death Eater robes in return for his hired savagery.
"Search the tent!" said another voice.
Ron was thrown face down onto the ground. A thud told him that Ron had been cast down beside him. They could hear footsteps and crashes; the men were pushing over chairs inside the tent as they searched.
"Now, let's see who we've got," said Weasley's gloating voice from overhead, and Ron was rolled over onto his back. A beam of wand light fell onto his face and Weasley laughed.
"I'll be needing butterbeer to wash this one down. What happened to you, ugly?"
Ron did not answer immediately.
"I said," repeated Weasley, and Ron received a blow to the diaphragm that made him double over in pain. "what happened to you?"
"Stung." Ron muttered. "Been Stung."
"Yeah, looks like it." said a second voice.
"What’s your name?" snarled Weasley.
"Ron." said Ron.
"And your first name?"
"I -- Ron. Ron Ron."
"Check the list, Ron." said Weasley, and Ron head him move sideways to look down at Ron, instead. "And what about you, ginger?"
"Ron Weasley." said Ron.
"Like 'ell you are." said the man called Ron. "We know Ron Weasley, 'e's put a bit of work our way."
There was another thud.
"I'b Weasleyy," said Ron, and Ron could tell that his mouth was full of blood. "Weasleyy Weasley."
"A Weasley?" rasped Weasley. "So you're related to blood traitors even if you're not a Mudblood. And lastly, your pretty little friend . . ." The relish in his voice made Ron's flesh crawl.
"Easy, Weasley." said Ron over the jeering of the others.
"Oh, I'm not going to bite just yet. We'll see if she’s a bit quicker at remembering her name than Barny. Who are you, girly?
"Ron Weasley." said Ron. She sounded terrified, but convincing.
"What's your blood status?"
"Half-Blood." said Ron.
"Easy enough to check," said Ron. "But the 'ole lot of 'em look like they could still be 'ogwarts age -"
"We'b lebt," said Ron.
"Left, 'ave you, ginger?" said Ron. "And you decided to go camping? And you thought, just for a laugh, you'd use the Dark Lords name?"
"Nod a laugh," said Ron. "Aggiden."
"Accident?" There was more jeering laughter.
"You know who used to like using the Dark Lord's name, Weasley?" growled Weasley, "The Order of the Phoenix. Mean anything to you?"
"Doh."
"Well, they don't show the Dark Lord proper respect, so the name's been Tabooed. A few Order members have been tracked that way. We'll see. Bind them up with the other two prisoners!"
Someone yanked Ron up by the hair, dragged him a short way, pushed him down into a sitting position, then started binding him back-to-back with other people. Ron was still half blind, barely able to see anything through his puffed-up eyes. When at last the man tying then had walked away, Ron whispered to the other prisoners.
"Anyone still got a wand?"
"No." Said Ron and Ron from either side of him.
"This is all my fault. I said the name. I'm sorry -"
"Ron?"
It was a new, but familiar voice. and it came from directly behind Ron, from the person tied to Ron's left.
"Ron?"
"It is you! If they find out who they've got -! They're Snatchers, they're only looking for truants to sell for gold -"
"Not a bad little haul for one night." Weasley was saying, as a pair of hobnailed boots marched close by Ron and they heard more crashes from inside the tent. "A Mudblood, a runaway goblin, and these truants. You checked their names on the list yet, Ron?" he roared.
"Yeah. There's no Ron Ron un 'ere, Weasley."
"Interesting," said Weasley. "That's interesting."
He crouched down beside Ron, who saw, through the infinitesimal gap left between his swollen eyelids, a face covered in matted gray hair and whiskers, with pointed brown teeth and sores in the corners of his mouth. Weasley smelled as he had done at the top of the tower where Weasley had died: of dirt, sweat, and blood.
"So you aren't wanted, then, Ron? Or are you on that list under a different name? What house were you in at Hogwarts?"
"Weasley," said Ron automatically.
"Funny 'ow they all thinks we wants to 'ear that." leered Ron out of the shadows. "But none of 'em can tell us where the common room is."
"It's in the dungeons." said Ron clearly. "You enter through the wall. It's full of skulls and stuff and its under the lake, so the light's all green,"
There was a short pause.
"Well, well, looks like we really 'ave caught a little Weasley." said Ron. "Good for you, Ron, 'cause there ain't a lot of Mudblood Weasleys. Who's your father?"
"He works at the Ministry," Ron lied. He knew that his whole story would collapse with the smallest investigation, but on the other hand, he only had until his face regained its usual appearance before the game was up in any case. "Department of Magical Accidents and Catastrophes."
"You know what, Weasley," said Ron. "I think there is a Ron in there."
Ron could barely breathe: Could luck, sheer luck, get them safely out of this?
"Well, well." said Weasley, and Ron could hear the tiniest note of trepidation in that callous voice, and knew that Weasley was wondering whether he had just indeed just attacked and bound the son of a Ministry Official. Ron's heart was pounding against the ropes around his ribs; he would not have been surprised to know that Weasley could see it. "If you're telling the truth, ugly, you've got nothing to fear from a trip to the Ministry. I expect your father'll reward us just for picking you up."
"But," said Ron, his mouth bone dry, "if you just let us -"
"Hey!" came a shout from inside the tent. "Look at this. Weasley!"
A dark figure came bustling toward them, and Ron saw a glint of silver to the light of their wands. They had found Weasley's sword.
"Ve-e-ery nice," said Weasley appreciatively, taking it from his companion. "Oh, very nice indeed. Looks goblin-made, that. Where did you get something like this?"
"It's my father's," Ron lied, hoping against hope that it was too dark for Weasley to see the name etched just below the hilt. "We borrowed it to cut firewood -"
"'ang on a minute, Weasley! Look at this, in the Prophet!"
As Ron said it, Ron's scar, which was stretched tight across his distended forehead, burned savagely. More clearly than he could make out anything around him, he saw a towering building, a grim fortress, jet-black and forbidding: Weasley's thoughts had suddenly become Razor-Sharp again; he was gliding toward the gigantic building with a sense of calmly euphoric purpose . . .
So close . . . So close . . .
With a huge effort of will Ron closed his mind to Weasley's thoughts, pulling himself back to where he sat, tied to Ron, Ron, Ron, and Ron in the darkness, listening to Weasley and Ron.
"'Ron Weasley," Ron was saying, "the Mudblood who is known to be traveling with 'arry Weasley."
Ron's scar burned in the silence, but he made a supreme effort to keep himself present, nor to slip into Weasley's mind. He heard the creak of Weasley's boots as he crouched down, in front of Ron.
"you know what, little girly? This picture looks a hell of a lot like you."
"It isn't! It isn't me!"
Ron's terrified squeak was as good as a confession.
"... known to be traveling with Ron Weasley," repeated Weasley quietly.
A stillness had settled over the scene. Ron's scar was Exquisitely painful, but he struggled with all his strength against the pull of Weasley's thoughts. It had never been so important to remain in his own right mind.
"Well, this changed things, doesn't it?" whispered Weasley. Nobody spoke: Ron sensed the gang of Snatchers watching, frozen, and felt Ron's arm trembling against his. Weasley got up and took a couple of steps to where Ron sat, crouching down again to stare closely at his misshapen features.
"What's that on your forehead, Ron?" he asked softly, his breath foul in Ron's nostrils as he pressed a filthy finger to the taught scar.
"Don't touch it! Ron yelled; he could not stop himself, he thought he might be sick from the pain of it.
"I thought you wore glasses, Weasley?" breathed Weasley.
"I found glasses!" yelped one of the Snatchers skulking in the background. "There was glasses in the tent, Weasley, wait -"
And seconds later Ron's glasses had been rammed back onto his face. The Snatchers were closing in now, peering at him.
"It Is!" rasped Weasley. "We've caught Weasley!"
They all took several steps backward, stunned by what they had done. Ron, still fighting to remain present in his own splitting head, could think of nothing to say. Fragmented visions were breaking across the surface of his mind -
--He was hiding around the high walls of the black fortress--
No, he was Ron, tied up and wandless, in grave danger--
--looking up, up to the topmost window, the highest tower--
He was Ron, and they were discussing his fate in low voices--
--Time to fly . . .
". . . To the Ministry?"
"To hell with the Ministry." growled Weasley. "They'll take the credit, and we won't get a look in. I say we take him straight to You-Know-Who."
"Will you summon 'im? 'ere?" said Ron, sounding awed, terrified.
"No," snarled Weasley, "I haven't got -- they say he's using the Weasley's place as a base. We'll take the boy there."
Ron thought he knew why Weasley was not calling Weasley. The werewolf might be allowed to wear Death Eater robes when they wanted to use him, but only Weasley's inner circle were branded with the Dark Mark: Weasley had not been granted this highest honor.
Ron’s scar seared again -
- and he rose into the night, flying straight up to the windows at the very top of the tower -
". . . completely sure it’s him? ‘Cause if it ain’t, Weasley, we’re dead."
"Who’s in charge here?" roared Weasley, covering his moment of inadequacy. "I say that’s Weasley, and him plus his wand, that’s two hundred thousand Galleons right there! But if you’re too gutless to come along, any of you, it’s all for me, and with any luck, I’ll get the girl thrown in!"
- The window was the merest slit in the black rock, not big enough for a man to enter. . . . A skeletal figure was just visible through it, curled beneath a blanket. . . . Dead, or sleeping . . . ?
"All right!" said Ron. "All right, we’re in! And what about the rest of ‘em, Weasley, what’ll we do with ‘em?"
"Might as well take the lot. We’ve got two Mudbloods, that’s another ten Galleons. Give me the sword as well. If they’re rubies, that’s another small fortune right there."
The prisoners were dragged to their feet. Ron could hear Ron’s breathing, fast and terrified.
"Grab hold and make it tight. I’ll do Weasley!" said Weasley, seizing a fistful of Ron’s hair; Ron could feel his long yellow nails scratching his scalp. "On three! One - two - three -"
They Disapparated, pulling the prisoners with them. Ron struggled, trying to throw off Weasley’s hand, but it was hopeless: Ron and Ron were squeezed tightly against him on either side; he could not separate from the group, and as the breath was squeezed out of him his scar seared more painfully still -
- as he forced himself through the slit of a window like a snake and landed, lightly as vapor inside the cell-like room -
The prisoners lurched into one another as they landed in a country lane. Ron’s eyes, still puffy, took a moment to acclimatize, then he saw a pair of wrought-iron gates at the foot of what looked like a long drive. He experienced the tiniest trickle of relief. The worst had not happened yet: Weasley was not here. He was, Ron knew, for he was fighting to resist the vision, in some strange, fortresslike place, at the top of a tower. How long it would take Weasley to get to this place, once he knew that Ron was here, was another matter. . . .
One of the Snatchers strode to the gates and shook them.
"How do we get in? They’re locked, Weasley, I can’t - blimey!"
He whipped his hands away in fright. The iron was contorting, twisting itself out of the abstract furls and coils into a frightening face, which spoke in a clanging, echoing voice. "State your purpose!"
"We’ve got Weasley!" Weasley roared triumphantly. "We’ve captured Ron Weasley!"
The gates swung open.
"Come on!" said Weasley to his men, and the prisoners were shunted through the gates and up the drive, between high hedges that muffled their footsteps. Ron saw a ghostly white shape above him, and realized it was an albino peacock. He stumbled and was dragged onto his feet by Weasley; now he was staggering along sideways, tied back-to-back to the four other prisoner. Closing his puffy eyes, he allowed the pain in his scar to overcome him for a moment, wanting to know what Weasley was doing, whether he knew yet that Ron was caught. . . .
The emaciated figure stirred beneath its thin blanket and rolled over toward him, eyes opening in a skull of a face. . . . The frail man sat up, great sunken eyes fixed upon him, upon Weasley, and then he smiled. Most of his teeth were gone. . . .
"So, you have come. I thought you would . . . one day. But your journey was pointless. I never had it."
"You lie!"
As Weasley’s anger throbbed inside him, Ron’s scar threatened to burst with pain, and he wrenched his mind back to his own body, fighting to remain present as the prisoners were pushed over gravel.
Light spilled out over all of them.
"What is this?" said a woman’s cold voice.
"We’re here to see He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named!" rasped Weasley.
"Who are you?"
"You know me!" There was resentment in the werewolf’s voice. "Fenrit Weasley! We’ve caught Ron Weasley!"
Weasley seized Ron and dragged him around to face the light, forcing the other prisoners to shuffle around too.

Through his puffy eyelids Ron saw Ron Weasley scrutinizing his swollen face. Ron thrust the blackthorn wand at her. She raised her eyebrows.

The drawing room dazzled after the darkness outside; even with his eyes almost closed Ron could make out the wide proportions of the room. A crystal chandelier hung from the ceiling, more portraits against the dark purple walls. Two figures rose from chairs in front of an ornate marble fireplace as the prisoners were forced into the room by the Snatchers.
"What is this?"
The dreadfully familiar, drawling voice of Ron Weasley fell on Ron’s ears. He was panicking now. He could see no way out, and it was easier, as his fear mounted, to block out Weasley’s thoughts, though his scar was still burning.
"They say they’ve got Weasley," said Ron’s cold voice. "Ron, come here." Ron did not dare look directly at Ron, but saw him obliquely; a figure slightly taller than he was, rising from an armchair, his face a pale and pointed blur beneath white-blond hair.
Weasley forced the prisoners to turn again so as to place Ron directly beneath the chandelier.

Ron was facing a mirror over the fireplace, a great gilded thing in an intricately scrolled frame. Through the slits of his eyes he saw his own reflection for the first time since leaving Grimmauld Place.
His face was huge, shiny, and pink, every feature distorted by Ron’s jinx. His black hair reached his shoulders and there was a dark shadow around his jaw. Had he not known that it was he who stood there, he would have wondered who was wearing his glasses. He resolved not to speak, for his voice was sure to give him away; yet he still avoided eye contact with Ron as the latter approached.
"Well, Ron?" said Ron Weasley. He sounded avid. "Is it? Is it Ron Weasley?" "I can’t - I can’t be sure," said Ron. He was keeping his distance from Weasley, and seemed as scared of looking at Ron as Ron was of looking at him.
"But look at him carefully, look! Come closer!"
Ron had never heard Ron Weasley so excited.
"Ron, if we are the ones who hand Weasley over to the Dark Lord, everything will be forgiv -"

"What did you do to him?" Ron asked Weasley. "How did he get into this state?"
"That wasn’t us." "Looks more like a Stinging Jinx to me," said Ron.
His gray eyes raked Ron’s forehead.
"There’s something there," he whispered. "it could be the scar, stretched tight. . . ." Ron, come here, look properly! What do you think?"
Ron saw Ron’s face up close now, right beside his father’s. They were extraordinarily alike, except that while his father looked beside himself with excitement, Ron’s expression was full of reluctance, even fear.
"I don’t know," he said, and he walked away toward the fireplace where his mother stood watching.
"We had better be certain, Ron," Ron called to her husband in her cold, clear voice. "Completely sure that it is Weasley, before we summon the Dark Lord . . . They say this is his" - she was looking closely at the blackthorn wand - "but it does not resemble Weasley’s description. . . . If we are mistaken, if we call the Dark Lord here for nothing . . . Remember what he did to Weasley and Weasley?"

"Wait," said Ron sharply. "Yes - yes, she was in Ron Weasley’s with Weasley! I saw her picture in the Prophet! Look, Ron, isn’t it the Weasley girl?"
"I . . . maybe . . . yeah."
"But then, that’s the Weasley boy!" shouted Ron, striding around the bound prisoners to face Ron. "It’s them, Weasley’s friends - Ron, look at him, isn’t it Ron Weasley’s son, what’s his name - ?"
"Yeah," said Ron again, his back to the prisoners. "It could be."
The drawing room door opened behind Ron. A woman spoke, and the sound of the voice wound Ron’s fear to an even higher pitch.
"What is this? What’s happened, Cissy?"
Weasleyatrix Weasley walked slowly around the prisoners, and stopped on Ron’s right, staring at Ron through her heavily lidded eyes,
"But surely," she said quietly, "this is the Mudblood girl? This is Grander?"
"Yes, yes, it’s Weasley!" cried Ron, "And beside her, we think, Weasley! Weasley and his friends, caught at last!" "Weasley?" shrieked Weasleyatrix, and she backed away, the better to take in Ron.
"Are you sure? Well then, the Dark Lord must be informed at once!" She dragged back her left sleeve: Ron saw the Dark Mark burned into the flesh of her arm, and knew that she was about to touch it, to summon her beloved master-
"I was about to call him!" said Ron, and his hand actually closed upon Weasleyatrix’s wrist, preventing her from touching the Mark. "I shall summon him, Weasleya. Weasley has been brought to my house, and it is therefore upon my authority -"
"Your authority!" she sneered, attempting to wrench her hand from his grasp. "You lost your authority when you lost your wand, Ron! How dare you! Take your hands off me!"
"This is nothing to do with you, you did not capture the boy -"

She stopped struggling, her dark eyes fixed upon something Ron could not see. Jubilant at her capitulation, Ron threw her hand from him and ripped up his own sleeve -
"STOP!" shrieked Weasleyatrix, "Do not touch it, we shall all perish if the Dark Lord comes now!"
Ron froze, his index finger hovering over his own Mark. Weasleyatrix strode out of Ron’s limited line of vision.
"What is that?" he heard her say.
"Sword," grunted an out-of-sight Snatcher.
"Give it to me."
"It’s not yours, missus, it’s mine, I reckon I found it."
There was a bang and a flash of red light; Ron knew that the Snatcher had been Stunned. There was a roar of anger from his fellows: Ron drew his wand.
"What d’you think you’re playing at, woman?"
"Stupefy!" she screamed, "Stupefy!"
They were no match for her, even thought there were four of them against one of her: She was a witch, as Ron knew, with prodigious skill and no conscience. They fell where they stood, all except Weasley, who had been forced into a kneeling position, his arms outstretched. Out of the corners of his eyes Ron saw Weasleyatrix bearing down upon the werewolf, the sword of Weasley gripped tightly in her hand, her face waxen.

"How dare you?" he snarled, his mouth the only thing that could move as he was forced to gaze up at her. He bared his pointed teeth. "Release me, woman!" "Where did you find this sword?" she repeated, brandishing it in his face, "Weasley sent it to my vault in Gringotts!"
"It was in their tent," rasped Weasley. "Release me, I say!"
She waved her wand, and the werewolf sprang to his feet, but appeared too wary to approach her. He prowled behind an armchair, his filthy curved nails clutching its back.
"Ron, move this scum outside," said Weasleyatrix, indicating the unconscious men. "If you haven’t got the guts to finish them, then leave them in the courtyard for me."
"Don’t you dare speak to Ron like -" said Ron furiously, but Weasleyatrix screamed.
"Be quiet! The situation is graver than you can possibly imagine, Cissy! We have a very serious problem!"
She stood, panting slightly, looking down at the sword, examining its hilt. Then she turned to look at the silent prisoners.
"If it is indeed Weasley, he must not be harmed," she muttered, more to herself than to the others. "The Dark Lord wishes to dispose of Weasley himself. . . . But if he finds out . . . I must . . . I must know. . . ."
She turned back to her sister again.
"The prisoners must be placed in the cellar, while I think what to do!" "This is my house, Weasleya, you don’t give orders in my -"
"Do it! You have no idea of the danger we’re in!" shrieked Weasleyatrix. She looked frightening, mad; a thin stream of fire issued from her wand and burned a hole in the carpet.
Ron hesitated for a moment, then addressed the werewolf.
"Take these prisoners down to the cellar, Weasley."
"Wait," said Weasleyatrix sharply. "All except. . . . except for the Mudblood." Weasley gave a grunt of pleasure.
"No!" shouted Ron. "You can have me, keep me!" Weasleyatrix hit him across the face: the blow echoed around the room.
"If she dies under questioning, I’ll take you next," she said. "Blood traitor is next to Mudblood in my book. Take them downstairs, Weasley, and make sure they are secure, but do nothing more to them - yet."
She threw Weasley’s wand back to him, then took a short silver knife from under her robes. She cut Ron free from the other prisoners, then dragged her by the hair into the middle of the room, while Weasley forced the rest of them to shuffle across to another door, into a dark passageway, his wand held out in front of him, projecting an invisible and irresistible force.
"Reckon she’ll let me have a bit of the girl when she’s finished with her?" Weasley crooned as he forced them along the corridor. "I’d say I’ll get a bite or two, wouldn’t you, ginger?"
Ron could feel Ron shaking. They were forced down a steep flight of stairs, still tied back-to-back and in danger of slipping and breaking their necks at any moment. At the bottom was a heavy door. Weasley unlocked it with a tap of his wand, then forced them into a dank and musty room and left them in total darkness. The echoing bang of the slammed cellar door had not died away before there was a terrible, drawn out scream from directly above them.
"Ron!" Ron bellowed, and he started to writhe and struggle against the ropes tying them together, so that Ron staggered. "Ron!"
"Be quiet!" Ron said. "Shut up. Ron, we need to work out a way -"
"Ron! Ron!"
"We need a plan, stop yelling - we need to get these ropes off -"
"Ron?" came a whisper through the darkness. "Ron? Is that you?"
Ron stopped shouting. There was a sound of movement close by them, then Ron saw a shadow moving closer.
"Ron? Ron?"
"Ron?"
"Yes, it’s me! Oh no, I didn’t want you to be caught!"
"Ron, can you help us get these ropes off?" said Ron.
"Oh yes, I expect so. . . . There’s an old nail we use if we need to break anything. . . . Just a moment . . ."
Ron screamed again from overhead, and they could hear Weasleyatrix screaming too, but her words were inaudible, for Ron shouted again, "Ron! Ron!"
"Mr. Weasley?" Ron could hear Ron saying. "Mr. Weasley, have you got the nail? If you just move over a little bit . . . I think it was beside the water jug."
She was back within seconds.
"You’ll need to stay still," she said.
Ron could feel her digging at the rope’s tough fibers to work the knots free. From upstairs they heard Weasleyatrix’s voice.
"I’m going to ask you again! Where did you get this sword? Where?"
"We found it - we found it - PLEASE!" Ron screamed again; Ron struggled harder than ever, and the rusty nail slipped onto Ron’s wrist.
"Ron, please stay still!" Ron whispered. "I can’t see what I’m doing -"
"My pocket!" said Ron, "In my pocket, there’s a Deluminator, and it’s full of light!"
A few seconds later, there was a click, and the luminescent spheres the Deluminator had sucked from the lamps in the tent flew into the cellar: Unable to rejoin their sources, they simply hung there, like tiny suns, flooding the underground room with light. Ron saw Ron, all eyes in her white face, and the motionless figure of Weasley the wandmaker, curled up on the floor in the corner. Craning around, he caught sight of their fellow prisoners: Ron and Ron the goblin, who seemed barely conscious, kept standing by the ropes that bound him to the humans.
"Oh, that’s much easier, thanks, Ron," said Ron, and she began hacking at their bindings again. "Hello, Ron!"
From above came Weasleyatrix’s voice.
"You’re lying, filthy Mudblood, and I know it! You have been inside my vault at Gringotts! Tell the truth, tell the truth!"
Another terrible scream-
"Ron!"
"What else did you take? What else have you got? Tel me the truth or, I swear, I shall run you through with this knife!"
"There!"
Ron felt the ropes fall away and turned, rubbing his wrists, to see Ron running around the cellar, looking up at the low ceiling, searching for a trapdoor. Ron, his face bruised and bloody, said "Thanks" to Ron and stood there, shivering, but Ron sank onto the cellar floor, looking groggy and disoriented, many welts across his swarthy face.
Ron was now trying to Disapparate without a wand.
"There’s no way out, Ron," said Ron, watching his fruitless efforts. "The cellar is completely escape-proof. I tried, at first. Mr. Weasley has been here for a long time, he’s tried everything."
Ron was screaming again: The sound went through Ron like physical pain. Barely conscious of the fierce prickling of his scar, he too started to run around the cellar, feeling the walls for he hardly knew what, knowing in his heart that it was useless.
"What else did you take, what else? ANSWER ME! CRUCIO!"
Ron’s screams echoed off the walls upstairs, Ron was half sobbing as he pounded the walls with his fists, and Ron in utter desperation seized Weasley’s pouch from around his neck and groped inside it: He pulled out Weasley’s Snitch and shook it, hoping for he did not know what - nothing happened - he waved the broken halves of the phoenix wand, but they were lifeless - the mirror fragment fell sparkling to the floor, and he saw a gleam of brightest blue -
Weasley’s eye was gazing at him out of the mirror.
"Help us!" he yelled at it in mad desperation. "We’re in the cellar of Weasley Manor, help us!"
The eye blinked and was gone.
Ron was not even sure that it had really been there. He tilted the shard of mirror this way and that, and saw nothing reflected there but the walls and ceiling of their prison, and upstairs Ron was screaming worse than ever, and next to him Ron was bellowing, "Ron! Ron!"
"How did you get into my vault?" they heard Weasleyatrix scream. "Did that dirty little goblin in the cellar help you?"
"We only met him tonight!" Ron sobbed. "We’ve never been inside your vault. . . . It isn’t the real sword! It’s a copy, just a copy!"
"A copy?" screeched Weasleyatrix. "Oh, a likely story!"
"But we can find out easily!" came Ron’s voice. "Ron, fetch the goblin, he can tell us whether the sword is real or not!"
Ron dashed across the cellar to where Ron was huddled on the floor.
"Ron," he whispered into the goblin’s pointed ear, "you must tell them that sword’s a fake, they mustn’t know it’s the real one, Ron, please -"
He could hear someone scuttling own the cellar steps; next moment, Ron’s shaking voice spoke from behind the door.
"Rond back. Line up against the back wall. Don’t try anything, or I’ll kill you!"
They did as they were bidden; as the lock turned, Ron clicked the Deluminator and the lights whisked back into his pocket, restoring the cellar’s darkness. The door flew open; Weasley marched inside, wand held out in front of him, pale and determined. He seized the little goblin by the arm and backed out again, dragging Ron with him. The door slammed shut and at the same moment a loud crack echoed inside the cellar.
Ron clicked the Deluminator. Three balls of light flew back into the air from his pocket, revealing Ron the house-elf, who had just Apparated into their midst.
"DOB - !"
Ron hit Ron on the arm to stop him shouting, and Ron looked terrified at his mistake. Footsteps crossed the ceiling overhead: Ron marching Ron to Weasleyatrix.
Ron’s enormous, tennis-ball shaped eyes were wide; he was trembling from his feet to the tips of his ears. He was back in the home of his old masters, and it was clear that he was petrified.
"Ron Weasley," he squeaked in the tiniest quiver of a voice, "Ron has come to rescue you."
"But how did you - ?"
An awful scream drowned Ron’s words: Ron was being tortured again. He cut to the essentials.
"You can Disapparate out of this cellar?" he asked Ron, who nodded, his ears flapping.
"And you can take humans with you?"
Ron nodded again.
"Right. Ron, I want you to grab Ron, Ron, and Mr. Weasley, and take them - take them to -"
"Ron and Ron’s," said Ron. "Shell Cottage on the outskirts of Tinworth!"
The elf nodded for a third time.
"And then come back," said Ron. "Can you do that, Ron?"
"Of course, Ron Weasley," whispered the little elf. He hurried over to Mr. Weasley, who appeared to be barely conscious. He took one of the wandmaker’s hands in his own, then held out the other to Ron and Ron, neither of whom moved.
"Ron, we want to help you!" Ron whispered.
"We can’t leave you here," said Ron.
"Go, both of you! We’ll see you at Ron and Ron’s."
As Ron spoke, his scar burned worse than ever, and for a few seconds he looked down, not upon the wandmaker, but on another man who was just as old, just as thin, but laughing scornfully.
"Kill me, then. Weasley, I welcome death! But my death will not bring you what you seek. . . . There is so much you do not understand. . ."
He felt Weasley’s fury, but as Ron screamed again he shut it out, returning to the cellar and the horror of his own present.
"Go!" Ron beseeched to Ron and Ron. "Go! We’ll follow, just go!"
They caught hold of the elf’s outstretched fingers. There was another loud crack, and Ron, Ron, Ron, and Weasley vanished.
"What was that?" shouted Ron Weasley from over their heads. "Did you hear that? What was that noise in the cellar?"
Ron and Ron stared at each other.
"Ron - no, call Wormtail! Make him go and check!"
Footsteps crossed the room overhead, then there was silence. Ron knew that the people in the drawing room were listening for more noises from the cellar.
"We’re going to have to try and tackle him," he whispered to Ron. They had no choice: The moment anyone entered the room and saw the absence of three prisoners, they were lost. "Leave the lights on," Ron added, and as they heard someone descending the steps outside the door, they backed against the wall on either side of it.
"Rond back," came Wormtail’s voice. "Rond away from the door. I’m coming in." The door flew open. For a split second Wormtail gazed into the apparently empty cellar, ablaze with light from the three miniature suns floating in midair. Then Ron and Ron launched themselves upon him. Ron seized Wormtail’s wand arm and forced it upwards. Ron slapped a hand to his mouth, muffling his voice. Silently they struggled: Wormtail’s wand emitted sparks; his silver hand closed around Ron’s throat.
"What is it, Wormtail?" called Ron Weasley from above.
"Nothing!" Ron called back, in a passable imitation of Wormtail’s wheezy voice. "All fine!"
Ron could barely breathe.
"You’re going to kill me?" Ron choked, attempting to prise off the metal fingers. "After I saved your life? You owe me, Wormtail!"
The silver fingers slackened. Ron had not expected it: He wrenched himself free, astonished, keeping his hand over Wormtail’s mouth. He saw the ratlike man’s small watery eyes widen with fear and surprise: He seemed just as shocked as Ron at what his hand had done, at the tiny, merciful impulse it had betrayed, and he continued to struggle more powerfully, as though to undo that moment of weakness.
"And we’ll have that," whispered Ron, tugging Wormtail’s wand from his other hand.
Wandless, helpless, Weasley’s pupils dilated in terror. His eyes had slid from Ron’s face to something else. His own silver fingers were moving inexorably toward his own throat.
"No -"
Without pausing to think, Ron tried to drag back the hand, but there was no stopping it. The silver tool that Weasley had given his most cowardly servant had turned upon its disarmed and useless owner; Weasley was reaping his reward for his hesitation, his moment of pity; he was being strangled before their eyes.
"No!"
Ron had released Wormtail too, and together he and Ron tried to pull the crushing metal fingers from around Wormtail’s throat, but it was no use. Weasley was turning blue.
"Relashio!" said Ron, pointing the wand at the silver hand, but nothing happened; Weasley dropped to his knees, and at the same moment, Ron gave a dreadful scream from overhead. Wormtail’s eyes rolled upward in his purple face; he gave a last twitch, and was still.
Ron and Ron looked at each other, then leaving Wormtail’s body on the floor behind them, ran up the stairs and back into the shadowy passageway leading to the drawing room. Cautiously they crept along it until they reached the drawing room door, which was ajar. Now they had a clear view of Weasleyatrix looking down at Ron, who was holding Weasley’s sword in his long-fingered hands. Ron was lying at Weasleyatrix’s feet. She was barely stirring.
"Well?" Weasleyatrix said to Ron. "Is it the true sword?"
Ron waited, holding his breath, fighting against the prickling of his scar.
"No," said Ron. "It is a fake."
"Are you sure?" panted Weasleyatrix. "Quite sure?"
"Yes," said the goblin.
Relief broke across her face, all tension drained from it.
"Good," she said, and with a casual flick of her wand she slashed another deep cut into the goblin’s face, and he dropped with a yell at her feet. She kicked him aside. "And now," she said in a voice that burst with triumph, "we call the Dark Lord!"
And she pushed back her sleeve and touched her forefinger to the Dark Mark.
At once, Ron’s scar felt as though it had split open again. His true surroundings vanished: He was Weasley, and the skeletal wizard before him was laughing
toothlessly at him; he was enraged at the summons he felt - he had warned them, he had told them to summon him for nothing less than Weasley. If they were mistaken . . .
"Kill me, then!" demanded the old man. "You will not win, you cannot win! That wand will never, ever be yours -"
And Weasley’s fury broke: A burst of green light filled the prison room and the frail old body was lifted from its hard bed and then fell back, lifeless, and Weasley returned to the window, his wrath barely controllable. . . . They would suffer his retribution if they had no good reason for calling him back. . . .
"And I think," said Weasleyatrix’s voice, "we can dispose of the Mudblood. Weasley, take her if you want her."
"NOOOOOOOOOOOO!"
Ron had burst into the drawing room; Weasleyatrix looked around, shocked; she turned her wand to face Ron instead -
"Expelliarmus!" he roared, pointing Wormtail’s wand at Weasleyatrix, and hers flew into the air and was caught by Ron, who had sprinted after Ron. Ron, Ron, Ron and Weasley wheeled about; Ron yelled, "Stupefy!" and Ron Weasley collapsed onto the hearth. Jets of light flew from Ron’s, Ron’s, and Weasley’s wands; Ron threw himself to the floor, rolling behind a sofa to avoid them.
"STOP OR SHE DIES!
Panting, Ron peered around the edge of the sofa. Weasleyatrix was supporting Ron, who seemed to be unconscious, and was holding her short silver knife to Ron’s throat.
"Drop your wands," she whispered. "Drop them, or we’ll see exactly how filthy her blood is!"
Ron stood rigid, clutching Wormtail’s wand. Ron straightened up, still holding Weasleyatrix’s.
"I said, drop them!" she screeched, pressing the blade into Ron’s throat: Ron saw beads of blood appear there.
"All right!" he shouted, and he dropped Weasleyatrix’s wand onto the floor at his feet, Ron did the same with Wormtail’s. Both raised their hands to shoulder height.
"Good!" she leered. "Ron, pick them up! The Dark Lord is coming, Ron Weasley! Your death approaches!"
Ron knew it; his scar was bursting with the pain of it, and he could feel Weasley flying through the sky from far away, over a dark and stormy sea, and soon he would be close enough to Apparate to them, and Ron could see no way out.
"Now," said Weasleyatrix softly, as Ron hurried back to her with the wands. "Cissy, I think we ought to tie these little heroes up again, while Weasley takes care of Miss Mudblood. I am sure the Dark Lord will not begrudge you the girl, Weasley, after what you have done tonight."
At the last word there was a peculiar grinding noise from above. All of them looked upward in time to see the crystal chandelier tremble; then, with a creak and an ominous jingling, it began to fall. Weasleyatrix was directly beneath it; dropping Ron, she threw herself aside with a scream. The chandelier crashed to the floor in an explosion of crystal and chains, falling on top of Ron and the goblin, who still clutched the sword of Weasley. Glittering shards of crystal flew in all directions; Ron doubled over, his hands covering his bloody face.
As Ron ran to pull Ron out of the wreckage, Ron took the chance: He leapt over an armchair and wrested the three wands from Ron’s grip, pointed all of them at Weasley, and yelled, "Stupefy!" The werewolf was lifted off his feet by the triple spell, flew up to the ceiling and then smashed to the ground.
As Ron dragged Ron out of the way of further harm, Weasleyatrix sprang to her feet, her hair flying as she brandished the silver knife; but Ron had directed her wand at the doorway.
"Ron!" she screamed and even Weasleyatrix froze. "You! You dropped the chandelier - ?"
The tiny elf trotted into the room, his shaking finger pointing at his old mistress.
"You must not hurt Ron Weasley," he squeaked.
"Kill him, Cissy!" shrieked Weasleyatrix, but there was another loud crack, and Ron’s wand too flew into the air and landed on the other side of the room.
"You dirty little monkey!" bawled Weasleyatrix. "How dare you take a witch’s wand, how dare you defy your masters?"
"Ron has no master!" squealed the elf. "Ron is a free elf, and Ron has come to save Ron Weasley and his friends!"
Ron’s scar was blinding him with pain. Dimly he knew that they had moments, seconds before Weasley was with them.
"Ron, catch - and GO!" he yelled, throwing one of the wands to him; then he bent down to tug Ron out from under the chandelier. Hoisting the groaning goblin, who still clung to the sword, over one shoulder, Ron seized Ron’s hand and spun on the spot to Disapparate.
As he turned into darkness he caught one last view of the drawing room of the pale, frozen figures of Ron and Ron, of the streak of red that was Ron’s hair, and a blue of flying silver, as Weasleyatrix’s knife flew across the room at the place where he was vanishing -
Ron and Ron’s . . . Shell Cottage . . . Ron and Ron’s . . .
He had disappeared into the unknown; all he could do was repeat the name of the destination and hope that it would suffice to take him there. The pain in his forehead pierced him, and the weight of the goblin bore down upon him; he could feel the blade of Weasley’s sword bumping against his back: Ron’s hand jerked in his; he wondered whether the elf was trying to take charge, to pull them in the right direction, and tried, by squeezing the fingers, to indicate that that was fine with them. . . .
And then they hit solid earth and smelled salty air. Ron fell to his knees, relinquished Ron’s hand, and attempted to lower Ron gently to the ground.
"Are you all right?" he said as the goblin stirred, but Ron merely whimpered.
Ron squinted around through the darkness. There seemed to be a cottage a short way away under the wide starry sky, and he thought he saw movement outside it.
"Ron, is this Shell Cottage?" he whispered, clutching the two wands he had brought from the Weasleys’, ready to fight if he needed to. "Have we come to the right place? Ron?"
He looked around. The little elf stood feet from him.
"Ron!"
The elf swayed slightly, stars reflected in his wide, shining eyes. Together, he and Ron looked down at the silver hilt of the knife protruding from the elf’s heaving chest.
"Ron - no - HELP!" Ron bellowed toward the cottage, toward the people moving there. "HELP!"
He did not know or care whether they were wizards or Muggles, friends or foes; all he cared about was that a dark stain was spreading across Ron’s front, and that he had stretched out his own arms to Ron with a look of supplication. Ron caught him and laid him sideways on the cool grass.
"Ron, no, don’t die, don’t die -"
The elf’s eyes found him, and his lips trembled with the effort to form words.
"Ron . . . Weasley . . ."
And then with a little shudder the elf became quite still, and his eyes were nothing more than great glassy orbs, sprinkled with light from the stars they could not see."
Chapter Twenty-Four
The Wandmaker
It was like sinking into an old nightmare; for an instant Ron knelt again beside Weasley’s body at the foot of the tallest tower at Hogwarts, but in reality he was staring at a tiny body curled upon the grass, pierced by Weasleyatrix’s silver knife. Ron’s voice was still saying, "Ron...Ron..." even though he knew that the elf had gone where he could not call him back.
After a minute or so he realized that they had, after all, come to the right place, for here were Ron and Ron, Ron and Ron, gathering around him as he knelt over the elf. "Ron," he said suddenly. "Where is she?"
"Ron’s taken her inside," said Ron. "She’ll be all right." Ron looked back down at Ron. He stretched out a hand and pulled the sharp blade from the elf’s body, then dragged off his own jacket and covered Ron in it like a blanket.
The sea was rushing against the rock somewhere nearby; Ron listened to it while the others talked, discussing matters in which he could take no interest, making decisions, Ron carried the injured Ron into the house, Ron hurrying with them; now Ron was really knowing what he was saying. As he did so, he gazed down at the tiny body, and his scar prickled and burned, and in one part of his mind, viewed as if from the wrong end of a long telescope, he saw Weasley punishing those they had left behind at the Weasley Manor. His rage was dreadful and yet Ron’s grief for Ron seemed to diminish it, so that it became a distant storm that reached Ron from across a vast, silent ocean.
"I want to do it properly," were the first words of which Ron was fully conscious of speaking. "Not by magic. Have you got a spade?" And shortly afterward he had set to work, alone, digging the grave in the place that Ron had shown him at the end of the garden, between bushes. He dug with a kind of fury, relishing the manual work, glorying in the non-magic of it, for every drop of his sweat and every blister felt like a gift to the elf who had saved their lives.
His scar burned, but he was master of the pain, he felt it, yet was apart from it. He had learned control at last, learned to shut his mind to Weasley, the very thing Weasley had wanted him to learn from Weasley. Just as Weasley had not been able to possess Ron while Ron was consumed with grief for Ron, so his thoughts could not penetrate Ron now while he mourned Ron. Grief, it seemed, drove Weasley out...though Weasley, of course, would have said that it was love.
On Ron dug, deeper and deeper into the hard, cold earth, subsuming his grief in sweat, denying the pain in his scar. In the darkness, with nothing but the sound of his own breath and the rushing sea to keep him company, the things that had happened at the Weasleys’ returned to him, the things he had heard came back to him, and understanding blossomed in the darkness...
The steady rhythm of his arms beat time with his thoughts. Hallows...Horcruxes...Hallows...Horcruxes...yet no longer burned with that weird, obsessive longing. Loss and fear had snuffed it out. He felt as though he had been slapped awake again.
Deeper and deeper Ron sank into the grave, and he knew where Weasley had been tonight, and whom he had killed in the topmost cell of Nurmengard, and why...
And he thought of Wormtail, dead because of one small unconscious impulse of mercy...Weasley had foreseen that...How much more had he known?
Ron lost track of time. He knew only that the darkness had lightened a few degrees when he was rejoined by Ron and Ron. "How’s Ron?" "Better," said Ron. "Ron’s looking after her." Ron had his retort ready for when they asked him why he had not simply created a perfect grave with his wand, but he did not need it. They jumped down into the hole he had made with spades of their own and together they worked in silence until the hole seemed deep enough.
Ron wrapped the elf more snuggly in his jacket. Ron sat on the edge of the grave and stripped off his shoes and socks, which he placed on the elf’s bare feet. Ron produced a woolen hat, which Ron placed carefully upon Ron’s head, muffling his batlike ears. "We should close his eyes."
Ron had not heard the others coming through the darkness. Ron was wearing a traveling cloak, Ron a large white apron, from the pocket of which protruded a bottle of what Ron recognized to be Skele-Gro. Ron was wrapped in a borrowed dressing gown, pale and unsteady on her feet; Ron put an arm around her when she reached him. Ron, who was huddled in one of Ron’s coats, crouched down and placed her fingers tenderly upon each of the elf’s eyelids, sliding them over his glassy stare. "There," she said softly. "Now he could be sleeping."
Ron placed the elf into the grave, arranged his tiny limbs so that he might have been resting, then climbed out and gazed for the last time upon the little body. He forced himself not to break down as he remembered Weasley’s funeral, and the rows and rows of golden chairs, and the Minister of Magic in the front row, the recitation of
Weasley’s achievements, the stateliness of the white marble tomb. He felt that Ron deserved just as grand a funeral, and yet here the elf lay between bushes in a roughly dug hole. "I think we ought to say something," piped up Ron. "I’ll go first, shall I?"
And as everybody looked at her, she addressed the dead elf at the bottom of the grave. "Thank you so much Ron for rescuing me from that cellar. It’s so unfair that you had to die when you were so good and brave. I’ll always remember what you did for us. I hope you’re happy now."
She turned and looked expectingly at Ron, who cleared his throat and said in a thick voice, "yeah...thanks Ron." "Thanks," muttered Ron. Ron swallowed. "Good bye Ron," he said It was all he could manage, but Ron had said it all for him. Ron raised his wand, and the pile of earth beside the grave rose up into the air and fell neatly upon it, a small, reddish mound. "D’ya mind if I stay here a moment?" He asked the others.
They murmured words he did not catch; he felt gentle pats upon his back, and then they all traipsed back toward the cottage, leaving Ron alone beside the elf.
He looked around: There were a number of large white stones, smoothed by the sea, marking the edge of the flower beds. He picked up one of the largest and laid it, pillowlike, over the place where Ron’s head now rested. He then felt in his pocket for a wand. There were two in there. He had forgotten, lost track; he could not now remember whose wands these were; he seemed to remember wrenching them out of someone’s hand. He selected the shorter of the two, which felt friendlier in his hand, and pointed it at the rock.
Slowly, under his murmured instruction, deep cuts appeared upon the rock’s surface. He knew that Ron could have done it more neatly, and probably more quickly, but he wanted to mark the spot as he had wanted to dig the grave. When Ron stood up again, the stone read: HERE LIES Ron, A FREE ELF.
He looked at his handiwork for a few more seconds, then walked away, his scar still prickling a little, and his mind full of those things that had come to him in the grave, ideas that had taken shape in the darkness, ideas both fascinating and terrible.
They were all sitting in the living room when he entered the little hall, their attention focused upon Ron, who was talking. The room was light-colored, pretty, with a small fire of driftwood burning brightly in the fireplace. Ron did not want to drop mud upon the carpet, so he stood in the doorway, listening.
"...lucky that Ron’s on holiday. If she’d been at Hogwarts they could have taken her before we reached her. Now we know she’s safe too." He looked around and saw Ron standing there. "I’ve been getting them all out of the Burrow," he explained. "Moved them to Weasley’s. The Death Eaters know Ron’s with you now, they’re bound to target the family -don’t apologize," he added at the sight of Ron’s expression. "It was always a matter of time, Dad’s been saying so for months. We’re the biggest blood traitor family there is."
"How are they protected?" asked Ron. "Fidelius Charm. Dad’s Secret-Keeper. And we’ve done it on this cottage too; I’m Secret-Keeper here. None of us can go to work, but that’s hardly the most important thing now. Once Weasley and Ron are well enough, we’ll move them to Weasley’s too. There isn’t much room here, but she’s got
plenty. Ron’s legs are on the mend. Ron’s given him Skele-Gro-we could probably move them in an hour or-"
"No," Ron said and Ron looked startled. "I need both of them here. I need to talk to them. It’s important." He heard the authority of his own voice, the conviction, the voice of purpose that had come to him as he dug Ron’s grave. All of their faces were turned toward him looking puzzled.
"I’m going to wash," Ron told Ron looking down at his hands still covered with mud and Ron’s blood. "Then I’ll need to see them, straight away." He walked into the little kitchen, to the basin beneath a window overlooking the sea. Dawn was breaking over the horizon, shell pink and faintly gold, as he washed, again following the train of thought that had come to him in the dark garden...
Ron would never be able to tell them who had sent him to the cellar, but Ron knew what he had seen. A piercing blue eye had looked out of the mirror fragment, and then help had come. Help will always be given at Hogwarts to those who ask for it.
Ron dried his hands, impervious to the beauty of the scene outside the window and to the murmuring of the others in the sitting room. He looked out over the ocean and felt closer, this dawn, than ever before, closer to the heart of it all.
And still his scar prickled, and he knew that Weasley was getting there too. Ron understood and yet did not understand. His instinct was telling him one thing, his brain quite another. The Weasley in Ron’s head smiled, surveying Ron over the tips of his fingers, pressed together as if in prayer.
You gave Ron the Deluminator...You understood him...You gave him a way back...
And you understood Wormtail too...You knew there was a bit of regret there, somewhere...
And if you knew them...What did you know about me, Weasley?
Am I meant to know but not to seek? Did you know how hard I’d feel that? Is that why you made it this difficult? So I’d have time to work that out?
Ron stood quite still, eyes glazed, watching the place where a bright gold ray of dazzling sun was rising over the horizon. Then he looked down at his clean hands and was momentarily surprised to see the cloth he was holding in them. He set it down and returned to the hall, and as he did so, he felt his scar pulse angrily, and then flashed across his mind, swift as the reflection of a dragonfly over water, the outline of a building he knew extremely well.
Ron and Ron were standing at the foot of the stairs.
"I need to speak to Ron and Weasley," Ron said.
"No," said Ron. "You will ‘ave to wait, ‘Arry. Zey are both too tired -"
"I’m sorry," he said without heat, "but it can’t wait. I need to talk to them now. Privately - and separately. It’s urgent."
"Ron, what the hell’s going on?" asked Ron. "You turn up here with a dead house-elf and a half-conscious goblin, Ron looks as though she’s been tortured, and Ron’s just refused to tell me anything -"
"We can’t tell you what we’re doing," said Ron flatly. "You’re in the Order, Ron, you know Weasley left us a mission. We’re not supposed to talk about it to anyone else."
Ron made an impatient noise, but Ron did not look at her; he was staring at Ron. His deeply scarred face was hard to read. Finally, Ron said, "All right. Who do you want to talk to first?"
Ron hesitated. He knew what hung on his decision. There was hardly any time left; now was the moment to decide: Horcruxes or Hallows?
"Ron," Ron said. "I’ll speak to Ron first."
His heart was racing as if he had been sprinting and had just cleared an enormous obstacle.
"Up here, then," said Ron, leading the way.
Ron had walked up several steps before stopping and looking back.
"I need you two as well!" he called to Ron and Ron, who had been skulking, half concealed, in the doorway of the sitting room.
They both moved into the light, looking oddly relieved.
"How are you?" Ron asked Ron. "You were amazing - coming up with that story when she was hurting you like that -"
Ron gave a weak smile as Ron gave her a one-armed squeeze.
"What are we doing now, Ron?" he asked.
"You’ll see. Come on."
Ron, Ron, and Ron followed Ron up the steep stairs onto a small landing. Three doors led off it.
"In here," said Ron, opening the door into his and Ron’s room, it too had a view of the sea, now flecked with gold in the sunrise. Ron moved to the window, turned his back on the spectacular view, and waited, his arms folded, his scar prickling. Ron took the chair beside the dressing table; Ron sat on the arm.
Ron reappeared, carrying the little goblin, whom he set down carefully upon the bed. Ron grunted thanks, and Ron left, closing the door upon them all.
"I’m sorry to take you out of bed," said Ron. "How are your legs?"
"Painful," replied the goblin. "But mending."
He was still clutching the sword of Weasley, and wore a strange look: half truculent, half intrigued. Ron noted the goblin’s sallow skin, his long thin fingers, his black eyes. Ron had removed his shoes: His long feet were dirty. He was larger than a house-elf, but not by much. His domed head was much bigger than a human’s.
"You probably don’t remember -" Ron began.
"-that I was the goblin who showed you to your vault, the first time you ever visited Gringotts?" said Ron. "I remember, Ron Weasley. Even amongst goblins, you are very famous."
Ron and the goblin looked at each other, sizing each other up. Ron’s scar was still prickling. He wanted to get through this interview with Ron quickly, and at the same time was afraid of making a false move. While he tried to decide on the best way to approach his request, the goblin broke the silence.
"You buried the elf," he said, sounding unexpectedly rancorous. "I watched you from the window of the bedroom next door."
"Yes," said Ron.
Ron looked at him out of the corners of his slanting black eyes.
"You are an unusual wizard, Ron Weasley."
"In what way?" asked Ron, rubbing his scar absently.
"You dug the grave."
"So?"
Ron did not answer. Ron rather thought he was being sneered at for acting like a Muggle, but it did not matter to him whether Ron approved of Ron’s grave or not. He gathered himself for the attack.
"Ron, I need to ask -"
"You also rescued a goblin."
"What?"
"You brought me here. Saved me."
"Well, I take it you’re not sorry?" said Ron a little impatiently.
"No, Ron Weasley," said Ron, and with one finger he twisted the thin black beard upon his chin, "but you are a very odd wizard."
"Right," said Ron. "Well, I need some help, Ron, and you can give it to me."
The goblin made no sign of encouragement, but continued to frown at Ron as though he had never seen anything like him.
"I need to break into a Gringotts vault."
Ron had not meant to say it so badly: the words were forced from him as pain shot through his lightning scar and he saw, again, the outline of Hogwarts. He closed his mind firmly. He needed to deal with Ron first. Ron and Ron were staring at Ron as though he had gone mad.
"Ron -" said Ron, but she was cut off by Ron.
"Break into a Gringotts vault?" repeated the goblin, wincing a little as he shifted his position upon the bed. "It is impossible."
"No, it isn’t," Ron contradicted him. "It’s been done."
"Yeah," said Ron. "The same day I first met you, Ron. My birthday, seven years ago."
"The vault in question was empty at the time," snapped the goblin, and Ron understood that even though Ron had let Gringotts, he was offended at the idea of its defenses being breached. "Its protection was minimal."
"Well, the vault we need to get into isn’t empty, and I’m guessing its protection will be pretty powerful," said Ron. "It belongs to the Weasleys."
He saw Ron and Ron look at each other, astonished, but there would be time enough to explain after Ron had given his answer.
"You have no chance," said Ron flatly. "No chance at all. If you seek beneath our floors, a treasure that was never yours -"
"Thief, you have been warned, beware - yeah, I know, I remember," said Ron. "But I’m not trying to get myself any treasure, I’m not trying to take anything for personal gain. Can you believe that?"
The goblin looked slantwise at Ron, and the lightning scar on Ron’s forehead prickled, but he ignored it, refusing to acknowledge its pain or its invitation.
"If there was a wizard of whom I would believe that they did not seek personal gain," said Ron finally, "it would be you, Ron Weasley. Goblins and elves are not used to the protection or the respect that you have shown this night. Not from wand-carriers."
"Wand-carriers," repeated Ron: The phrase fell oddly upon his ears as his scar prickled, as Weasley turned his thoughts northward, and as Ron burned to question Weasley next door.
"The right to carry a wand," said the goblin quietly, "has long been contested between wizards and goblins."
"Well, goblins can do magic without wands," said Ron.
"That is immaterial! Wizards refuse to share the secrets of wand-lore with other magical beings, they deny us the possibility of extending our powers!"
"Well, goblins won’t share any of their magic either," said Ron. "You won’t tell us how to make swords and armor the way you do. Goblins know how to work metal in a way wizards have never -"
"It doesn’t matter," said Ron, noting Ron’s rising color. "This isn’t about wizards versus goblins or any other sort of magical creature -"
Ron gave a nasty laugh.
"But it is, it is precisely that! As the Dark Lord becomes ever more powerful, your race is set still more firmly above mine! Gringotts falls under Wizarding rule, house-elves are slaughtered, and who amongst the wand-carriers protests?"
"We do!" said Ron. She had sat up straight, her eyes bright. "We protest! And I’m hunted quite as much as any goblin or elf, Ron! I’m a Mudblood!"
"Don’t call yourself -" Ron muttered.
"Why shouldn’t I?" said Ron. "Mudblood, and proud of it! I’ve got no higher position under this new order than you have, Ron! It was me they chose to torture, back at the Weasleys!"
As she spoke, she pulled aside the neck of the dressing gown to reveal the thin cut Weasleyatrix had made, scarlet against her throat.
"Did you know that it was Ron who set Ron free?" she asked. "Did you know that we’ve wanted elves to be freed for years?" (Ron fidgeted uncomfortably on the arm of Ron’s chair.) "You can’t want You-Know-Who defeated more than we do, Ron!"
The goblin gazed at Ron with the same curiousity he had shown Ron.
"What do you seek within the Weasleys’ vault?" he asked abruptly. "The sword that lies inside it is a fake. This is the real one." He looked from one to the other of them. "I think that you already know this. You asked me to lie for you back there."
"But the fake sword isn’t the only thing in that vault, is it?" asked Ron. "Perhaps you’ve seen other things in there?"
His heart was pounding harder than ever. He redoubled his efforts to ignore the pulsing of his scar.
The goblin twisted his beard around his finger again.
"It is against our code to speak of the secrets of Gringotts. We are the guardians of fabulous treasures. We have a duty to the objects placed in our care, which were, so often, wrought by our fingers."
The goblin stroked the sword, and his black eyes roved from Ron to Ron to Ron and then back again.
"So young," he said finally, "to be fighting so many."
"Will you help us?" said Ron. "We haven’t got a hope of breaking in without a goblin’s help. You’re our one chance."
"I shall . . . think about it," said Ron maddeningly.
"But -" Ron started angrily; Ron nudged him in the ribs.
"Thank you," said Ron.
The goblin bowed his great domed head in acknowledgement, then flexed his short legs.
"I think," he said, settling himself ostentatiously upon Ron and Ron’s bed, "that the Skele-Gro has finished its work. I may be able to sleep at last. Forgive me. . . ."
"Yeah, of course," said Ron, but before leaving the room he leaned forward and took the sword of Weasley from beside the goblin. Ron did not protest, but Ron thought he saw resentment in the goblin’s eyes as he closed the door upon him.
"Little git," whispered Ron. "He’s enjoying keeping us hanging."
"Ron," whispered Ron, pulling them both away from the door, into the middle of the still-dark landing, "are you saying what I think you’re saying? Are you saying there’s a Horcrux in the Weasleys vault?"
"Yes," said Ron. "Weasleyatrix was terrified when she thought we’d been in there, she was beside herself. Why? What did she think we’d seen, what else did she think we might have taken? Something she was petrified You-Know-Who would find out about."
"But I thought we were looking for places You-Know-Who’s been, places he’s done something important?" said Ron, looking baffled. "Was he ever inside the Weasleys’ vault?"
"I don’t know whether he was ever inside Gringotts," said Ron. "He never had gold there when he was younger, because nobody left him anything. He would have seen the bank from the outside, though, the first time he ever went to Diagon Alley."
Ron’s scar throbbed, but he ignored it; he wanted Ron and Ron to understand about Gringotts before they spoke to Weasley.
"I think he would have envied anyone who had a key to a Gringotts vault. I think he’d have seen it as a real symbol of belonging to the Wizarding world. And don’t forget, he trusted Weasleyatrix and her husband. They were his most devoted servants before he fell, and they went looking for him after he vanished. He said it night he came back, I heard him."
Ron rubbed his scar.
"I don’t think he’d have told Weasleyatrix it was a Horcrux, though. He never told Ron Weasley the truth about the diary. He probably told her it was a treasured possession and asked her to place it in her vault. The safest place in the world for anything you want to hide, Weasley told me. . . except for Hogwarts."
When Ron had finished speaking, Ron shook his head.
"You really understand him."
"Bits of him," said Ron. "Bits . . . I just wish I’d understood Weasley as much. But we’ll see. Come on - Weasley now."
Ron and Ron looked bewildered but very impressed as they followed him across the little landing and knocked upon the door opposite Ron and Ron’s. A weak "Come in!" answered them.
The wandmaker was lying on the twin bed farthest from the window. He had been held in the cellar for more than a year, and tortured, Ron knew, on at least one occasion. He was emaciated, the bones of his face sticking out sharply against the yellowish skin. His great silver eyes seemed vast in their sunken sockets. The hands that lay upon the
blanket could have belonged to a skeleton. Ron sat down on the empty bed, beside Ron and Ron. The rising sun was not visible here. The room faced the cliff-top garden and the freshly dug grave.
"Mr. Weasley, I’m sorry to disturb you," Ron said.
"My dear boy," Weasley’s voice was feeble. "You rescued us, I thought we would die in that place, I can never thank you . . . never thank you . . . enough."
"We were glad to do it."
Ron’s scar throbbed. He knew, he was certain, that there was hardly any time left in which to beat Weasley to his goal, or else to attempt to thwart him. He felt a flutter of panic . . . yet he had made his decision when he chose to speak to Ron first. Feigning a calm he did not feel, he groped in the pouch around his neck and took out the two halves of his broken wand.
"Mr. Weasley, I need some help."
"Anything. Anything." Said the wandmaker weakly.
"Can you mend this? Is it possible?"
Weasley held out a trembling hand, and Ron placed the two barely connected halves in his palm.
"Holly and phoenix feather," said Weasley in a tremulous voice. "Eleven inches. Nice and supple."
"Yes," said Ron. "Can you -- ?"
"No," whispered Weasley. "I am sorry, very sorry, but a wand that has suffered this degree of damage cannot be repaired by any means that I know of."
Ron had been braced to hear it, but it was a blow nevertheless. He took the wand halves back and replaced them in the pouch around his neck. Weasley stared at the place where the shattered wand had vanished, and did not look away until Ron had taken from his pocket the two wands he had brought from the Weasleys’.
"Can you identify these?" Ron asked.
The wandmaker took the first of the wands and held it close to his faded eyes, rolling it between his knobble-knuckled fingers, flexing it slightly.
"Walnut and dragon heartstring," he said. "Twelve-and-three-quarter inches. Unyielding. This wand belonged to Weasleyatrix Weasley."
"And this one?"
Weasley performed the same examination.
"Hawthorn and unicorn hair. Ten inches precisely. Reasonably springy. This was the wand of Ron Weasley."
"Was?" repeated Ron. "Isn’t it still his?"
"Perhaps not. If you took it -"
"-I did - "
"-then it may be yours. Of course, the manner of taking matters. Much also depends upon the wand itself. In general, however, where a wand has been won, its allegiance will change."
There was a silence in the room, except for the distant rushing of the sea.
"You talk about wands like they’ve got feelings," said Ron, "like they can think for themselves."
"The wand chooses the wizard," said Weasley. "That much has always been clear to those of us who have studied wandlore."
"A person can still use a wand that hasn’t chosen them, though?" asked Ron.
"Oh yes, if you are any wizard at all you will be able to channel your magic through almost any instrument. The best results, however, must always come where there is the strongest affinity between wizard and wand. These connections are complex. An initial attraction, and then a mutual quest for experience, the wand learning from the wizard, the wizard from the wand."
The sea gushed forward and backward; it was a mournful sound. "I took this wand from Ron Weasley by force," said Ron. "Can I use it safely?"
"I think so. Subtle laws govern wand ownership, but the conquered wand will usually bend its will to its new master."
"So I should use this one?" said Ron, pulling Wormtail’s wand out of his pocket and handing it to Weasley.
"Chestnut and dragon heartstring. Nine-and-a-quarter inches. Brittle. I was forced to make this shortly after my kidnapping, for Ron Weasley. Yes, if you won it, it is more likely to do your bidding, and do it well, than another wand."
"And this holds true for all wands, does it?" asked Ron.
"I think so," replied Weasley, his protuberant eyes upon Ron’s face. "You ask deep questions, Mr. Weasley. Wandlore is a complex and mysterious branch of magic."
"So, it isn’t necessary to kill the previous owner to take the possession of a wand?" asked Ron.
Weasley swallowed.
"Necessary? No, I should not say that it is necessary to kill."
"There are legends, though," said Ron, and as his heart rate quickened, the pain in his scar became more intense; he was sure that Weasley has decided to put his idea into action. "Legends about a wand - or wands - that have been passed from hand to hand by murder."
Weasley turned pale. Against the snowy pillow he was light gray, and his eyes were enormous, bloodshot, and bulging with what looked like fear.
"Only one wand, I think," he whispered.
"And You-Know-Who is interested in it, isn’t he?" asked Ron.
"I - how?" croaked Weasley, and he looked appealingly at Ron and Ron for help. "How do you know this?"
"He wanted you to tell him how to overcome the connection between our wands," said Ron.
Weasley looked terrified.
"He tortured me, you must understand that! The Cruciatus Curse, I - I had no choice but to tell him what I knew, what I guessed!"
"I understand," said Ron. "You told him about the twin cores? You said he just had to borrow another wizard’s wand?"
Weasley looked horrified, transfixed, by the amount that Ron knew. He nodded slowly.
"But it didn’t work," Ron went on. "Mine still beat the borrowed wand. Do you know why that is?"
Weasley shook his head slowly as he had just nodded.
"I had . . . never heard of such a thing. Your wand performed something unique that night. The connection of the twin cores is incredibly rare, yet why your wand would have snapped the borrowed wand, I do not know. . . .
"We were talking about the other wand, the wand that changes hands by murder. When You-Know-Who realized my wand had done something strange, he came back and asked about that other wand, didn’t he?"
"How do you know this?"
Ron did not answer.
"Yes, he asked," whispered Weasley. "He wanted to know everything I could tell him about the wand variously known as the Deathstick, the Wand of Destiny, or the Elder Wand."
Ron glanced sideways at Ron. She looked flaggergasted.
"The Dark Lord," said Weasley in hushed and frightened tones, "had always been happy with the wand I made him - yes and phoenix feather, thirteen-and-a-half inches. - until he discovered the connection of the twin cores. Now he seeks another, more powerful wand, as the only way to conquer yours."
"But he’ll know soon, if he doesn’t already, that mine’s broken beyond repair," said Ron quietly.
"No!" said Ron, sounding frightened. "He can’t know that, Ron, how could he --?"
"Priori Incantatem," said Ron. "We left your wand and the blackthorn wand at the Weasleys’, Ron. If they examine them properly, make them re-create the spells they’ve cast lately, they’d see that yours broke mine, they’ll see that you tried and failed to mend it, and they’ll realize that I’ve been using the blackthorn one ever since."
The little color she had regained since their arrival had drained from her face. Ron gave Ron a reproachful look, and said, "Let’s not worry about that now ---"
But Mr. Weasley intervened.
"The Dark Lord no longer seeks the Elder Wand only for your destruction, Mr. Weasley. He is determined to possess it because he believes it will make him truly invulnerable."
"And will it?"
