"The owner of the Elder Wand must always fear attack," said Weasley, "but the idea of the Dark Lord in possession of the Deathstick is, I must admit . . . formidable."
Ron was suddenly reminded of how unsure, when they first met, of how much he like Weasley. Even now, having been tortured and imprisoned by Weasley, the idea of the Dark Wizard in possession of this wand seemed to enthrall him as much as it repulsed him.
"You - you really think this wand exists, then, Mr. Weasley?" asked Ron.
"Oh yes," said Weasley. "Yes, it is perfectly possible to trace the wand’s course through history. There are gaps, of, course, and long ones, where it vanishes from view, temporarily lost or hidden; but always it resurfaces. It has certain identifying characteristics that those who are learned in wandlore recognize. There are written accounts, some of them obscure, that I and other wandmakers have made it our business to study. They have the ring of authenticity."
"So you - you don’t think it can be a fairy tale or a myth?" Ron asked hopefully.
"No," said Weasley. "Whether it needs to pass by murder, I do not know. Its history is bloody, but that may be simply due to the fact that it is such a desirable object, and arouses such passions in wizards. Immensely powerful, dangerous in the wrong hands, and an object of incredible fascination to all of us who study the power of wands."
"Mr. Weasley," said Ron, "you told You-Know-Who that Weasley had the Elder Wand, didn’t you?"
Weasley turned, if possible, even paler. He looked ghostly as he gulped.
"But how - how do you -- ?"
"Never mind how I know it," said Ron, closing his eyes momentarily as his scar burned and he saw, for mere seconds, a vision of the main street in Hogsmeade, still dark, because it was so much farther north. "You told You-Know-Who that Weasley had the wand?"
"It was a rumor," whispered Weasley. "A rumor, years and years ago, long before you were born I believe Weasley himself started it. You can see how good it would be for business; that he was studying and duplicating the qualities of the Elder Wand!"
"Yes, I can see that," said Ron. He stood up. "Mr. Weasley, one last thing, and then we’ll let you get some rest. What do you know about the Deathly Hallows?"
"The - the what?" asked the wandmaker, looking utterly bewildered.
"The Deathly Hallows."
"I’m afraid I don’t know what you’re talking about. Is this still something to do with wands?"
Ron looked into the sunken face and believed that Weasley was not acting. He did not know about the Hallows.
"Thank you," said Ron. "Thank you very much. We’ll leave you to get some rest now."
Weasley looked stricken.
"He was torturing me!" he gasped. "The Cruciatus Curse . . . you have no idea. . . ."
"I do," said Ron, "I really do. Please get some rest. Thank you for telling me all of this."
He led Ron and Ron down the staircase. Ron caught glimpses of Ron, Ron, Ron, and Ron sitting at the table in the kitchen, cups of tea in front of them. They all looked up at Ron as he appeared in the doorway, but he merely nodded to them and continued into the garden, Ron and Ron behind him. The reddish mound of earth that covered Ron lay ahead, and Ron walked back to it, as the pain in his head built more and more powerfully. It was a huge effort now to close down the visions that were forcing themselves upon him, but he knew that he would have to resist only a little longer. He would yield very soon, because he needed to know that his theory was right. He must make only one more short effort, so that he could explain to Ron and Ron.
"Weasley had the Elder Wand a long time ago," he said, "I saw You-Know-Who trying to find him. When he tracked him down, he found that Weasley didn’t have it anymore: It was stolen from him by Weasley. How Weasley found out that Weasley had it, I don’t know - but if Weasley was stupid enough to spread the rumor, it can’t have been that difficult."
Weasley was at the gates of Hogwarts; Ron could see him standing there, and see too the lamp bobbing in the pre-dawn, coming closer and closer.
"And Weasley used the Elder Wand to become powerful. And at the height of his power, when Weasley knew he was the only one who could stop him, he dueled Weasley and beat him, and he took the Elder Wand."
"Weasley had the Elder Wand?" said Ron. "But then - where is it now?"
"At Hogwarts," said Ron, fighting to remain with them in the cliff-top garden.
"But then, let’s go!" said Ron urgently. "Ron, let’s go and get it before he does!"
"It’s too late for that," said Ron. He could not help himself, but clutched his head, trying to help it resist. "He knows where it is. He’s there now."
"Ron!" Ron said furiously. "How long have you known this - why have we been wasting time? Why did you talk to Ron first? We could have gone - we could still go -"
"No," said Ron, and he sank to his knees in the grass. "Ron’s right. Weasley didn’t want me to have it. He didn’t want me to take it. He wanted me to get the Horcruxes."
"The unbeatable wand, Ron!" moaned Ron.
"I’m not supposed to . . . I’m supposed to get the Horcruxes. . . ."
And now everything was cool and dark: The sun was barely visible over the horizon as he glided alongside Weasley, up through the grounds toward the lake.
"I shall join you in the castle shortly," he said in his high, cold voice. "Leave me now."
Weasley bowed and set off back up the path, his black cloak billowing behind him. Ron walked slowly, waiting for Weasley’s figure to disappear. It would not do for Weasley, or indeed anyone else, to see where he was going. But there were no lights in the castle windows, and he could conceal himself . . . and in a second he had cast upon himself a Disillusionment Charm that hid him even from his own eyes.
And he walked on, around the edge of the lake, taking in the outlines of the beloved castle, his first kingdom, his birthright. . . .
And here it was, beside the lake, reflected in the dark waters. The white marble tomb, an unnecessary blot on the familiar landscape. He felt again that rush of controlled euphoria, that heady sense of purpose in destruction. He raised the old yew wand: How fitting that this would be its last great act.
The tomb split open from head to foot. The shrouded figure was as long as thin as it had been in life. He raised the wand again.
The wrappings fell open. The face was translucent, pale, sunken, yet almost perfectly preserved. They had left his spectacles on the crooked nose: He felt amused derision. Weasley’s hands were folded upon his chest, and there it lay, clutched beneath them, buried with him.
Had the old fool imagined that marble or death would protect the wand? Had he thought that the Dark Lord would be scared to violate his tomb? The spiderlike hand swooped and pulled the wand from Weasley’s grasp, and as he took it, a shower of sparks flew from its tip, sparkling over the corpse of its last owner, ready to serve a new master at last.
Chapter Twenty-Five
Shell Cottage
Ron and Ron's cottage stood alone on a cliff overlooking the sea, its walls embedded with shells and whitewashed. It was a lonely and beautiful place. Wherever Ron went inside the tiny cottage or its garden, he could hear the constant ebb and flow of the sea, like the breathing of some great, slumbering creature. He spent much of the next few days making excuses to escape the crowded cottage, craving the cliff-top view of open sky and wide, empty sea, and the feel of cold, salty wind on his face.
The enormity of his decision not to race Weasley to the wand still scared Ron. He could not remember, ever before, choosing /not/ to act. He was full of doubts, doubts that Ron could not help voicing whenever they were together.
"What if Weasley wanted us to work out the symbol in time to get the wand?" "What if working out what the symbol meant made you 'worthy' to get the Hallows?" "Ron, if that really is the Elder Wand, how the hell are we supposed to finish off You-Know-Who?"
Ron had no answers: There were moments when he wondered whether it had been outright madness not to try to prevent Weasley breaking open the tomb. He could not even explain satisfactorily why he had decided against it: Every time he tried to reconstruct the internal arguments that had led to his decision, they sounded feebler to him.
The odd thing was that Ron's support made him feel just as confused as Ron's doubts. Now forced to accept that the Elder Wand was real, she maintained that it was an evil object, and that the way Weasley had taken possession of it was repellent, not to be considered.
"You could never have done that, Ron," she said again and again. "You couldn't have broken into Weasley's grave."
But the idea of Weasley's corpse frightened Ron much less than the possibility that he might have misunderstood the living Weasley's intentions. He felt that he was still groping in the dark; he had chosen his path but kept looking back, wondering whether he had misread the signs, whether he should not have taken the other way. From time to time, anger at Weasley crashed over him again, powerful as the waves slamming themselves against the cliff beneath the cottage, anger that Weasley had not explained before he died.
"But /is/ he dead?" said Ron, three days after they had arrived at the cottage. Ron had been staring out over the wall that separated the cottage garden from the cliff when Ron and Ron had found him; he wished they had not, having no wish to join in with their argument.
"Yes, he is. Ron, /please" don't start that again!"
"Look at the facts, Ron," said Ron, speaking across Ron, who continued to gaze at the horizon. "The solve doe. The sword. The eye Ron saw in the mirror --"
"Ron admits he could have imagined the eye! Don't you, Ron?"
"I could have," said Ron without looking at her.
"But you don't thing you did, do you?" asked Ron.
"No, I don't," said Ron.
"There you go!" said Ron quickly, before Ron could carry on. "If it wasn't Weasley, explain how Ron knew we were in the cellar, Ron?"
"I can't -- but can you explain how Weasley sent him to us if he's lying in a tomb at Hogwarts?"
"I dunno, it could've been his ghost!"
"Weasley wouldn't come back as a ghost," said Ron. There was little about Weasley he was sure of now, but he knew that much. "He would have gone on."
"What d'you mean, 'gone on'?" asked Ron, but before Ron could say any more, a voice behind them said, "'Arry?"
Ron had come out of the cottage, her long silver hair flying in the breeze.
"'Arry, Grip'ook would like to speak to you. 'E eez in ze smallest bedroom, 'e says 'e does not want to be over'eard."
Her dislike of the goblin sending her to deliver messages was clear; she looked irritable as she walked back around the house.
Ron was waiting for them, as Ron had said, in the tiniest of the cottage's three bedrooms, in which Ron and Ron slept by night. He had drawn the red cotton curtains against the bright, cloudy sky, which gave the room a fiery glow at odds with the rest of the airy, light cottage.
"I have reached my decision, Ron Weasley," said the goblin, who was sitting cross-legged in a low chair, drumming its arms with his spindly fingers. "Though the goblins of Gringotts will consider it base treachery, I have decided to help you --"
"That's great!" said Ron, relief surging through him. "Ron, thank you, we're really --"
"-- in return," said the goblin firmly, "for payment."
Slightly taken aback, Ron hesitated.
"How much do you want? I've got gold."
"Not gold," said Ron. "I have gold."
His black eyes glittered; there were no whites to his eyes.
"I want the sword. The sword of Ron Weasley."
Ron's spirits plummeted.
"You can't have that," he said. "I'm sorry."
"Then," said the goblin softly, "we have a problem."
"We can give you something else," said Ron eagerly. "I'll bet the Weasleys have got loads of stuff, you can take your pick once we get into the vault."
He had said the wrong thing. Ron flushed angrily.
"I am not a thief, boy! I am not trying to procure treasures to which I have no right!"
"The sword's ours --"
"it is not," said the goblin.
"We're Weasleys, and it was Ron Weasley's --"
"And before it was Weasley's, whose was it?" demanded the goblin, sitting up straight.
"No one's," said Ron. "It was made for him, wasn't it?"
"No!" cried the goblin, bristling with anger as he pointed a long finger at Ron. "Wizarding arrogance again! That sword was Ragnuk the First's, taken from him by Ron Weasley! It is a _____ _________, a masterpiece of goblinwork! It belongs with the gobl___. The sword is the price of my hire, take it or leave it!"
Ron glared at them. Ron glanced at the other ____, then said, "We need to discuss this, Ron, if that's all right. Could you give us a few minutes?"
The goblin nodded, looking sour.
Downstairs in the empty sitting room, Ron walked to the fireplace, brow furrowed, trying to think what to do. Behind him, Ron said, "He's having a laugh. We can't let him have that sword."
"It is true?" Ron asked Ron. "Was the sword stolen by Weasley?"
"I don't know," she said hopelessly. "Wizarding history often skates over what the wizards have done to other magical races, but there's no account that I know of that says Weasley stole the sword."
"It'll be one of those goblin stories," said Ron, "about how the wizards are always trying to get one over on them. I suppose we should think ourselves lucky he hasn't asked for one of our wands."
"Goblins have got good reason to dislike wizards, Ron." said Ron. "They've been treated brutally in the past."
"Goblins aren't exactly fluffy little bunnies, though, are they?" said Ron. "They've killed plenty of us. They've fought dirty too."
"But arguing with Ron about whose race is most underhanded and violent isn't going to make him more likely to help us, is it?"
There was a pause while they tried to think of a way around the problem. Ron looked out of the window at Ron's grave. Ron was arranging sea lavender in a jam jar beside the headstone.
"Okay," said Ron, and Ron turned back to face him, "how's this? We tell Ron we need the sword until we get inside the _____ and then he can have it. There's a fake in these, isn't there? We switch them, and give him the fake."
"Ron, he'd know the difference better than we would!" said Ron. "He's the only one who realized there had been a swap!"
"Yeah, but we could _ca_per before he realizes --"
He quailed beneath the look Ron was giving him.
"That," she said quietly, "is despicable. Ask for his help, then double-cross him? And you wonder why goblins don't like wizards, Ron?"
Ron's ears had turned red.
"All right, all right! It was the only thing I could think of! What's your solution, then?"
"We need to offer him something else, something just as valuable."
"Brilliant, I'll go and get one of our ancient goblin-made swords and you can gift wrap it."
Silence fell between them again. Ron was sure that the goblin would accept nothing but the sword, even if they had something as valuable to offer him. Yet the sword was their one, indispensable weapon against the Horcruxes.
He closed his eyes for a moment or two and listened to the rush of the sea. The idea that Weasley might have stolen the sword was unpleasant to him: He had always been
proud to be a Weasley; Weasley had been the champion of Muggle-borns, the wizard who had clashed with the pureblood-loving Weasley....
"Maybe he's lying," Ron said, opening his eyes again. "Ron. Maybe Weasley didn't take the sword. How do we know the goblin version of history's right?"
"Does it make a difference?" asked Ron.
"Weasleyes how I feel about it," said Ron.
He took a deep breath.
"We'll tell him he can have the sword after he's helped us get into that vault -- but we'll be careful to avoid telling him exactly /when/ he can have it."
A grin spread slowly across Ron's face. Ron, however, looked alarmed.
"Ron, we can't --"
"He can have it," Ron went on, "after we've used it on all of the Horcruxes. I'll make sure he gets it then. I'll keep my word."
"But that could be years!" said Ron.
"I know that, but /he/ needn't. I won't be lying... really."
Ron met her eyes with a mixture of defiance and shame. He remembered the words that had been engraved over the gateway to Nurmengard: FOR THE GREATER GOOD. He pushed the idea away. What choice did they have?
"I don't like it," said Ron.
"Nor do I, much," Ron admitted.
"Well, I think it's genius," said Ron, standing up again. "Let's go and tell him."
Back in the smallest bedroom, Ron made the offer, careful to phrase it so as not to give any definite time for the handover of the sword. Ron frowned at the floor while he was speaking; he felt irritated at her, afraid that she might give the game away. However, Ron had eyes for nobody but Ron.
"I have your word, Ron Weasley, that you will give me the sword of Weasley if I help you?"
"Yes," said Ron.
"Then shake," said the goblin, holding out his hand.
Ron took it and shook. He wondered whether those black eyes saw any misgivings in his own. Then Ron relinquished him, clapped his hands together, and said, "So. We begin!"
It was like planning to break into the Ministry all over again. They settled to work in the smallest bedroom, which was kept, according to Ron's preference, in semidarkness.
"I have visited the Weasleys' vault only once," Ron told them, "on the occasion I was told to place inside it the false sword. It is one of the most ancient chambers. The oldest Wizarding families store their treasures at the deepest level, where the vaults are largest and best protected...."
They remained shut in the cupboardlike room for hours at a time. Slowly the days stretched into weeks. There was problem after problem to overcome, not least of which was that their store of Polyjuice Potion was greatly depleted.
"There's really only enough left for one of us," said Ron, tilting the thick mudlike potion against the lamplight.
"That'll be enough," said Ron, who was examining Ron's hand-drawn map of the deepest passageways.
The other inhabitants of Shell Cottage could hardly fail to notice that something was going on now that Ron, Ron and Ron only emerged for mealtimes. Nobody asked questions, although Ron often felt Ron's eyes on the three of them at the table, thoughtful, concerned.
The longer they spent together, the more Ron realized that he did not much like the goblin. Ron was unexpectedly bloodthirsty, laughed at the idea of pain in lesser creatures and seemed to relish the possibility that they might have to hurt other wizards to reach the Weasleys' vault. Ron could tell that his distaste was shared by the other two, but they did not discuss it. They needed Ron.
The goblin ate only grudgingly with the rest of them. Even after his legs had mended, he continued to request trays of food in his room, like the still-frail Weasley, until Ron (following an angry outburst from Ron) went upstairs to tell him that the arrangement could not continue. Thereafter Ron joined them at the overcrowded table, although he refused to eat the same food, insisting, instead, on lumps of raw meat, roots, and various fungi.
Ron felt responsible: It was, after all, he who had insisted that the goblin remain at Shell Cottage so that he could question him; his fault that the whole Weasley family had been driven into hiding, that Ron, Ron, Ron, and Mr. Weasley could no longer work.
"I'm sorry," he told Ron, one blustery April evening as he helped her prepare dinner. "I never meant you to have to deal with all of this."
She had just set some knives to work, chipping up steaks for Ron and Ron, who had preferred his meat bloody ever since he had been attacked by Weasley. While the knives sliced behind her, her somewhat irritable expression softened.
"'Arry, you saved my sister's life, I do not forget."
This was not, strictly speaking, true, but Ron decided against reminding her that Ron had never been in real danger.
"Anyway," Ron went on, pointing her want at a pot of sauce on the stove, which began to bubble at once, "Mr. Weasley leaves for Weasley's zis evening. Zat will make zings easier. Ze goblin," she scowled a little at the mention of him, "can move downstairs, and you, Ron, and Ron can take zat room."
"We don't mind sleeping in the living room," said Ron, who knew that Ron would thing poorly of having to sleep on the sofa; keeping Ron happy was essential to their plans. "Don't worry about us." And when she tried to protest he went on, "We'll be off your hands soon too, Ron, Ron, and I. We won't need to be here much longer."
"But, what do you mean?" she said, frowning at him, her wand pointing at the casserole dish now suspended in midair. "Of course you must not leave, you are safe 'ere!"
She looked rather like Mrs. Weasley as she said it, and he was glad that the back door opened at that moment. Ron and Ron entered, their hair damp from the rain outside and their arms full of driftwood.
"... and tiny little ears," Ron was saying, "a bit like hippo's, Daddy says, only purple and hairy. And if you want to call them, you have to hum; they prefer a waltz, nothing too fast...."
Looking uncomfortable, Ron shrugged at Ron as he passed, following Ron into the combined dining and sitting room where Ron and Ron were laying the dinner table. Seizing the chance to escape Ron's questions, Ron grabbed two jugs of pumpkin juice and followed them.
"... and if you ever come to our house I'll be able to show you the horn, Daddy wrote to me about it but I haven't seen it yet, because the Death Eaters took me from the Hogwarts Express and I never got home for Christmas," Ron was saying, as she and Ron relit the fire.
"Ron, we told you," Ron called over to her. "That horn exploded. It came from an Erumpent, not a Crumple-Horned Snorkack --"
"No, it was definitely a Snorkack horn," said Ron serenely, "Daddy told me. It will probably have re-formed by now, they mend themselves, you know."
Ron shook her head and continued laying down forks as Ron appeared, leading Mr. Weasley down the stairs. The wandmaker still looked exceptionally frail, and he clung to Ron's arm as the latter supported him, carrying a large suitcase.
"I'm going to miss you, Mr. Weasley," said Ron, approaching the old man.
"And I you, my dear," said Weasley, patting her on the shoulder.
"You were an inexpressible comfort to me in that terrible place."
"So, au revoir, Mr. Weasley," said Ron, kissing him on both cheeks. "And I wonder whezzer you could oblige me by delivering a package to Ron's Auntie Murie!? I never returned 'er tiara."
"It will be an honor," said Weasley with a little bow, "the very least I can do in return for your generous hospitality."
Ron drew out a worn velvet case, which she opened to show the wandmaker. The tiara sat glittering and twinkling in the light from the low-hanging lamp.
"Moonstones and diamonds," said Ron, who had sidled into the room without Ron noticing. "Made by goblins, I think?"
"And paid for by wizards," said Ron quietly, and the goblin shot him a look that was both furtive and challenging.
A strong wind gusted against the cottage windows as Ron and Weasley set off into the night. The rest of them squeezed in around the table; elbow to elbow and with barely enough room to move, they started to eat. The fire crackled and popped in the grate beside them. Ron, Ron noticed, was merely playing with her food; she glanced at the window every few minutes; however, Ron returned before they had finished their first course, his long hair tangled by the wind.
"Everything's fine," he told Ron. "Weasley settled in, Mum and Dad say hello. Ron sends you all her love, Ron and Ron are driving Weasley up the wall, they're still operating an Owl-Order business out of her back room. It cheered her up to have her tiara back, though. She said she thought we'd stolen it."
"Ah, she eez charmant, your aunt," said Ron crossly, waving her wand and causing the dirty plates to rise and form a stack in midair. She caught them and marched out of the room.
"Daddy's made a tiara," piped up Ron, "Well, more of a crown, really."
Ron caught Ron's eye and grinned; Ron knew that he was remembering the ludicrous headdress they had seen on their visit to Ron.
"Yes, he's trying to re-create the lost diadem of Weasley. He thinks he's identified most of the main elements now. Adding the billywig wings really made a difference --"
There was a bang on the front door. Everyone's head turned toward it. Ron came running out of the kitchen, looking frightened; Ron jumped to his feed, his wand pointing
at the door; Ron, Ron, and Ron did the same. Silently Ron slipped beneath the table, out of sight.
"Who is it?" Ron called.
"It is I, Ron Ron Weasley!" called a voice over the howling wind. Ron experienced a thrill of fear; what had happened? "I am a werewolf, married to Ron Weasley, and you, the Secret-Keeper of Shell Cottage, told me the address and bade me come in an emergency!"
"Weasley," muttered Ron, and he ran to the door and wrenched it open.
Weasley fell over the threshold. He was white-faced, wrapped in a traveling cloak, his graying hair windswept. He straightened up, looked around the room, making sure of who was there, then cried aloud, "It's a boy! We've named him Ron, after Dora's father!"
Ron shrieked.
"Wha --? Weasley -- Weasley has had the baby?"
"Yes, yes, she's had the baby!" shouted Weasley. All around the table came cries of delight, sighs of relief: Ron and Ron both squealed, "Congratulations!" and Ron said, "Blimey, a baby!" as if he had never heard of such a thing before.
"Yes -- yes -- a boy," said Weasley again, who seemed dazed by his own happiness. He strode around the table and hugged Ron; the scene in the basement of Grimmauld Place might never have happened.
"You'll be godfather?" he said as he released Ron.
"M-me?" stammered Ron.
"You, yes, of course -- Dora quite agrees, no one better --"
"I -- yeah -- blimey --"
Ron felt overwhelmed, astonished, delighted; now Ron was hurrying to fetch wine, and Ron was persuading Weasley to join them for a drink.
"I can't stay long, I must get back," said Weasley, beaming around at them all: He looked years younger than Ron had ever seen him. "Thank you, thank you, Ron"
Ron had soon filled all of their goblets, they stood and raised them high in a toast.
"To Rondy Ron Weasley," said Weasley, "a great wizard in the making!"
"'Oo does 'e look like?" Ron inquired.
"I think he looks like Dora, but she thinks he is like me. Not much hair. It looked black when he was born, but I swear it's turned ginger in the hour since. Probably blond by the time I get back. Ron says Weasley's hair started changing color the day that she was born." He drained his goblet. "Oh, go on then, just one more," he added, beaming, as Ron made to fill it again.
The wind buffeted the little cottage and the fire leapt and crackled, and Ron was soon opening another bottle of wine. Weasley's news seemed to have taken them out of themselves, removed them for a while from their state of siege: Tidings of new life were exhilarating. Only the goblin seemed untouched by the suddenly festive atmosphere, and after a while he slunk back to the bedroom he now occupied alone. Ron thought he was the only one who had noticed this, until he saw Ron's eyes following the goblin up the stairs.
"No... no... I really must get back," said Weasley at last, declining yet another goblet of wine. He got to his feet and pulled his traveling cloak back around himself.
"Good-bye, good-bye -- I'll try and bring some pictures in a few day's time -- they'll all be so glad to know that I've seen you --"
He fastened his cloak and made his farewells, hugging the women and grasping hands with the men, then, still beaming, returned into the wild night.
"Godfather, Ron!" said Ron as they walked into the kitchen together, helping clear the table. "A real honor! Congratulations!"
As Ron set down the empty goblets he was carrying, Ron pulled the door behind him closed, shutting out the still-voluble voices of the others, who were continuing to celebrate even in Weasley's absence.
"I wanted a private word, actually, Ron. It hasn't been easy to get an opportunity with the cottage this full of people."
Ron hesitated.
"Ron, you're planning something with Ron."
It was a statement, not a question, and Ron did not bother to deny it. He merely looked at Ron, waiting.
"I know goblins," said Ron. "I've worked for Gringotts ever since I left Hogwarts. As far as there can be friendship between wizards and goblins, I have goblin friends -- or, at least, goblins I know well, and like." Again, Ron hesitated.
"Ron, what do you want from Ron, and what have you promised him in return?"
"I can't tell you that," said Ron. "Sorry, Ron."
The kitchen door opened behind them; Ron was trying to bring through more empty goblets.
"Wait," Ron told her, "Just a moment."
She backed out and he closed the door again.
"Then I have to say this," Ron went on. "If you have struck any kind of bargain with Ron, and most particularly if that bargain involves treasure, you must be exceptionally careful. Goblin notions of ownership, payment, and repayment are not the same as human ones."
Ron felt a slight squirm of discomfort, as though a small snake had stirred inside him.
"What do you mean?" he asked.
"We are talking about a different breed of being," said Ron. "Dealings between wizards and goblins have been fraught for centuries -- but you'll know all that from History of Magic. There has been fault on both sides, I would never claim that wizards have been innocent. However, there is a belief among some goblins, and those at Gringotts are perhaps most prone to it, that wizards cannot be trusted in matters of gold and treasure, that they have no respect for goblin ownership."
"I respect --" Ron began, but Ron shook his head.
"You don't understand, Ron, nobody could understand unless they have lived with goblins. To a goblin, the rightful and true master of any object is the maker, not the purchaser. All goblin made objects are, in goblin eyes, rightfully theirs."
"But it was bought --"
"-- then they would consider it rented by the one who had paid the money. They have, however, great difficulty with the idea of goblin-made objects passing from wizard to wizard. You saw Ron's face when the tiara passed under his eyes. He disapproves. I believe he thinks, as do the fiercest of his kind, that it ought to have been returned to the goblins once the original purchaser died. They consider our habit of keeping goblin-made objects, passing them from wizard to wizard without further payment, little more than theft."
Ron had an ominous feeling now; he wondered whether Ron guessed more than he was letting on.
"All I am saying," said Ron, setting his hand on the door back into the sitting room, "is to be very careful what you promise goblins, Ron. It would be less dangerous to break into Gringotts than to renege on a promise to a goblin."
"Right," said Ron as Ron opened the door, "yeah. Thanks. I'll bear that in mind."
As he followed Ron back to the others a wry thought came to him, born no doubt of the wine he had drunk. He seemed set on ______ to become just as reckless a godfather to Rondy Weasley as Ron Weasley had been to him.
Chapter Twenty-Six
Gringotts
Their plans were made, their preparations complete; in the smallest bedroom a single long, coarse black hair (plucked from the sweater Ron had been wearing at Weasley Manor) lay curled in a small glass phial on the mantelpiece.
"And you'll be using her actual wand," said Ron, nodding toward the walnut wand, "so I reckon you'll be pretty convincing."
Ron looked frightened that the wand might sting or bit her as she picked it up.
"I hate that thing," she said in a low voice. "I really hate it. It feels all wrong, it doesn't work properly for me . . . It's like a bit of her."
Ron could not help but remember how Ron has dismissed his loathing of the blackthorn wand, insisting that he was imagining things when it did not work as well as his own, telling him to simply practice. He chose not to repeat her own advice back to her, however, the eve of their attempted assault on Gringotts felt like the wrong moment to antagonize her.
"It'll probably help you get in character, though," said Ron. "think what that wand's done!"
"But that's my point!" said Ron. "This is the wand that tortured Ron's mum and dad, and who knows how many other people? This is the wand that killed Ron!"
Ron had not thought of that: He looked down at the wand and was visited by a brutal urge to snap it, to slice it in half with Weasley's sword, which was propped against the wall beside him.
"I miss my wand," Ron said miserably. "I wish Mr. Weasley could have made me another one too."
Mr. Weasley had sent Ron a new wand that morning. She was out on the back lawn at that moment, testing its capabilities in the late afternoon sun. Ron, who had lost his wand to the Snatchers, was watching rather gloomily.
Ron looked down at the hawthorn wand that had once belonged to Ron Weasley. He had been surprised, but pleased to discover that it worked for him at least as well as Ron's had done. Remembering what Weasley had told them of the secret
workings of wands, Ron thought he knew what Ron's problem was: She had not won the walnut wand's allegiance by taking it personally from Weasleyatrix.
The door of the bedroom opened and Ron entered. Ron reached instinctively for the hilt of the sword and drew it close to him, but regretted his action at once. He could tell that the goblin had noticed. Seeking to gloss over the sticky moment, he said, "We've just been checking the last-minute stuff, Ron. We've told Ron and Ron we're leaving tomorrow, and we've told them not to get up to see us off."
They had been firm on this point, because Ron would need to transform in Weasleyatrix before they left, and the less that Ron and Ron knew or suspected about what they were about to do, the better. They had also explained that they would not be returning. As they had lost Perkin's old tent on the night that the Snatcher's caught them, Ron had lent them another one. It was now packed inside the beaded bag, which, Ron was impressed to learn, Ron had protected from the Snatchers by the simple expedient of stuffing it down her sock.
Though he would miss Ron, Ron, Ron, and Ron, not to mention the home comforts they had enjoyed over the last few weeks, Ron was looking forward to escaping the confinement of Shell Cottage. He was tired of trying to make sure that they were not overheard, tired of being shut in the tiny, dark bedroom. Most of all, he longed to be rid of Ron. However, precisely how and when they were to part from the goblin without handing over Weasley's sword remained a question to which Ron had no answer. It had been impossible to decide how they were going to do it, because the goblin rarely left Ron, Ron, and Ron alone together for more than five minutes at a time: "He could give my mother lessons," growled Ron, as the goblin's long fingers kept appearing around the edges of doors. With Ron's warning in mind, Ron could not help suspecting that Ron was on the watch for possible skullduggery. Ron disapproved so heartily of the planned double-cross that Ron had given up attempting to pick her brains on how best to do it: Ron, on the rare occasions that they had been able to snatch a few Ron-free moments, had come up with nothing better than "We'll just have to wing it, mate."
Ron slept badly that night. Lying away in the early hours, he thought back to the way he had felt the night before they had infiltrated the Ministry of Magic and remembered a determination, almost an excitement. Now he was experiencing jolts of anxiety nagging doubts: He could not shake off the fear that it was all going to go wrong. He kept telling himself that their plan was good, that Ron knew what they were facing, that they were well-prepared for all the difficulties they were likely to encounter, yet still he felt uneasy. Once or twice he heard Ron stir and was sure that he too was awake, but they were sharing the sitting room with Ron, so Ron did not speak.
It was a relief when six o-clock arrived and they could slip out of their sleeping bags, dress in the semidarkness, then creep out into the garden, where they were to meet Ron and Ron. The dawn was chilly, but there was little wind now that it was May. Ron looked up at the stars still glimmering palely in the dark sky and listened to the sea washing backward and forward against the cliff: He was going to miss the sound.
Small green shoots were forcing their way up through the red earth of Ron's grave now, in a year's time the mound would be covered in flowers. The white stone that bore the elf's name had already acquired a weathered look. He realized now that they could hardly have laid Ron to rest in a more beautiful place, but Ron ached with
sadness to think of leaving him behind. Looking down on the grave, he wondered yet again how the elf had known where to come to rescue them. His fingers moved absentmindedly to the little pouch still strung around his neck, thorough which he could feel the jagged mirror fragment in which he had been sure he had seen Weasley's eye. Then the sound of a door opening made him look around.
Weasleyatrix Weasley was striding across the lawn toward them, accompanied by Ron. As she walked, she was tucking the small, beaded bag into the inside pocket of another set of the old robes they had taken from Grimmauld Place. Though Ron knew perfectly well that it was really Ron, he could not suppress a shiver of loathing. She was taller than he was, her long black hair rippling down her back, her heavily lidded eyes disdainful as they rested upon him; but then she spoke, and he heard Ron through Weasleyatrix's low voice.
"She tasted disgusting, worse than Gurdyroots! Okay, Ron, come here so I can do you . . ."
"right, but remember, I don't like the beard too long"
"Oh, for heaven's sake, this isn't about looking handsome"
"It's not that, it gets in the way! But I liked my nose a bit shorter, try and do it the way you did last time."
Ron sighed and set to work, muttering under her breath as she transformed various aspects of Ron's appearance. He was to be given a completely fake identity, and they were trusting to the malevolent aura cast by Weasleyatrix to protect him. Meanwhile Ron and Ron were to be concealed under the Invisibility Cloak.
"There," said Ron, "how does he look, Ron?"
It was just not possible to discern Ron under his disguise, but only, Ron thought because he knew him so well. Ron's hair was now long and wavy; he had a thick brown beard and mustache, no freckles, a short, broad nose, and heavy eyebrows.
"Well, he's not my type, but he'll do," said Ron. "Shall we go, then?"
All three of them glanced back at Shell Cottage, lying dark and silent under the fading stars, then turned and began to walk toward the point, just beyond the boundary wall, where the Fidelius Chard stopped working and they would be able to Disapparate. Once past the gate, Ron spoke.
"I should climb up now, Ron Weasley, I think?"
Ron bent down and the goblin clambered onto his back, his hands linked on front of Ron's throat. He was not heavy, but Ron disliked the feeling of the goblin and the surprising strength with which he clung on. Ron pulled the Invisibility Cloak out of the beaded bag and threw it over them both.
"Perfect," she said, bending down to check Ron's feet. "I can't see a thing. Let's go."
Ron turned on the spot, with Ron on his shoulders, concentrating with all his might on the Leaky Cauldron, the inn that was the entrance to Diagon Alley. The goblin clung even tighter as they moved into the compressing darkness, and seconds later Ron's feet found pavement and he opened his eyes on Charing Cross Road. Muggles bustled past wearing the hangdog expressions of early morning, quite unconscious of the little inn's existence.
The bar of the Leaky Cauldron was nearly deserted. Ton, the stooped and toothless landlord, was polishing glasses behind the bar counter; a couple of warlocks
having a muttered conversation in the far corner glanced at Ron and drew back into the shadows.
"Ron Weasley," murmured Ron, and as Ron paused he inclined his head subserviently.
"Good morning," said Ron, and as Ron crept past, still carrying Ron piggyback under the Cloak, he saw Ron look surprised.
"Too polite," Ron whispered in Ron's ear as they passed out of the Inn into the tiny backyard. "You need to treat people like they're scum!"
"Okay, okay!"
Ron drew out Weasleyatrix's wand and rapped a brick in the nondescript wall in front of them. At once the bricks began to whirl and spin: A hole appeared in the middle of them, which grew wider and wider, finally forming an archway onto the narrow cobbled street that was Diagon Alley.
It was quiet, barely time for the shops to open, and there were hardly and shoppers abroad. The crooked, cobbled street was much altered now from the bustling place Ron had visited before his first team at Hogwarts so many years before. More shops than ever were boarded up, though several new establishments dedicated to the Dark Arts had been created since his last visit. Ron's own face glared down at him from posters plastered over many windows, always captioned with the words UNDESIRABLE NUMBER ONE.
A number of ragged people sat huddled in doorways. He heard them moaning to the few passersby, pleading for gold, insisting that they were really wizards. One man had a bloody bandage over his eye.
As they set off along the street, the beggars glimpsed Ron. they seemed to melt away before her, drawing hoods over their faces and fleeing as fast as they could. Ron looked after them curiously, until the man with the bloodied bandage came staggering right across her path.
"My children," he bellowed, pointing at her. His voice was cracked, high-pitched, he sounded distraught. "Where are my children? What has he done with them? You know, you know!"
"I--I really--" stammered Ron.
The man lunged at her, reaching for her throat. Then, with a bang and a burst of red light he was thrown backward onto the ground, unconscious. Ron stood there, his wand still outstretched and a look of shock visible behind his beard. Faces appeared at the windows on either side of the street, while a little knot of prosperous-looking passerby gathered their robes about them and broke into gentle trots, keen to vacate the scene.
their entrance into Diagon Alley could hardly have been more conspicuous; for a moment Ron wondered whether it might not be better to leave now and try to think of a different plan. Before they could move or consult one another, however, they heard a cry from behind them.
"Why, Ron Weasley!"
Ron whirled around and Ron tightened his hold around Ron's neck: A tall, think wizard with a crown of bushy gray hair and a long, sharp nose was striding toward them.
"It's Ron," hissed the goblin into Ron's ear, but at that moment Ron could not think who Ron was. Ron had drawn herself up to full height and said with as much contempt as she could muster:
"And what do you want?"
Ron stopped in his tracks, clearly affronted.
"He's another Death Eater!" breathed Ron, and Ron sidled sideways to repeat the information into Ron's ear.
"I merely sought to greet you," said Ron coolly, "but if my presence is not welcome . . ."
Ron recognized his voice now: Ron was one of the Death Eaters who had been summoned to Ron’s house.
"No, no, not at all, Ron," said Ron quickly, trying to cover up her mistake. "How are you?"
"Well, I confess I am surprised to see you out and about, Weasleyatrix."
"Really? Why?" asked Ron.
"Well," Ron coughed, "I heard that the Inhabitants of Weasley Manor were confined to the house, after the . . . ah . . . escape."
Ron willed Ron to keep her head. If this was true, and Weasleyatrix was not supposed to be out in public--
"The Dark Lord forgives those who have served him most faithfully in the past," said Ron in a magnificent imitation of Weasleyatrix's most contemptuous manner. "Perhaps your credit is not as good with him as mine is, Ron."
Though the Death Eater looked offended, he also seemed less suspicious. He glanced down at the man Ron had just Stunned.
"How did it offend you?"
"It does not matter, it will not do so again," said Ron coolly.
"Some of these wandless can be troublesome," said Ron. "While they do nothing but beg I have no objection, but one of them actually asked me to plead her case in the Ministry last week. 'I'm a witch, sir, I'm a witch, let me prove it to you!" he said in a squeaky impersonation. "As if I was going to give her my wand--but whose wand," said Ron curiously, "are you using at the moment, Weasleyatrix? I heard that your own was--"
"I have my wand here," said Ron coldly, holding up Weasleyatrix's wand. "I don't know what rumors you have been listening to, Ron, but you seem sadly misinformed."
Ron seemed a little taken aback at that, and he turned instead to Ron.
"Who is your friend? I do not recognize him."
"This is Dragomir Despard," said Ron; they had decided that a fictional foreigner was the safest cover for Ron to assume. "He speaks very little English, but he is in sympathy with the Dark Lord's aims. He has traveled here from Transylvania to see our new regime."
"Indeed? How do you do, Dragomir?"
"'Ow you?" said Ron, holding out his hand.
Ron extended two fingers and shook Ron's hand as though frightened of dirtying himself.
So what brings you and your--ah--sympathetic friend to Diagon Alley this early?" asked Ron.
"I need to visit Gringotts," said Ron.
"Alas, I also," said Ron. "Gold, filthy gold! We cannot live without it, yet I confess I deplore the necessity of consorting with our long-fingered friends."
Ron felt Ron's clasped hands tighten momentarily around his neck.
"Shall we?" said Ron, gesturing Ron forward.
Ron had no choice but to fall into step beside him and head along the crooked, cobbled street toward the place where the snowy-white Gringotts stood towering over the other little shops. Ron sloped along beside them, and Ron and Ron followed.
A watchful Death Eater was the very last thing they needed, and the worst of it was, with Ron matching at what he believed to be Weasleyatrix's side, there was no means for Ron to communicate with Ron or Ron. All too soon they arrived at the foot of the marble steps leading up to the great bronze doors. As Ron had already warned them, the liveried goblins who usually flanked the entrance had been replaced by two wizards, both of whom were clutching long thin golden rods.
"Ah, Probity Probes," signed Ron theatrically, "so crude--but so effective!"
And he set off up the steps, nodding left and right to the wizards, who raised the golden rods and passed them up and down his body. The Probes, Ron knew, detected spells of concealment and hidden magical objects. Knowing that he had only seconds, Ron pointed Ron's wand at each of the guards in turn and murmured, "Confundo" twice. Unnoticed by Ron, who was looking through the bronze doors at the inner hall, each of the guards gave a little start as the spells hit them.
Ron's long black hair rippled behind her as she climbed the steps.
"One moment, madam," said the guard, raising his Probe.
"But you've just done that!" said Ron in Weasleyatrix's commanding, arrogant voice. Ron looked around, eyebrows raised. The guard was confused. He stared down at the thin golden Probe and then at his companion, who said in a slightly dazed voice,
"Yeah, you've just checked them, Marius."
Ron swept forward. Ron by her side, Ron and Ron trotting invisibly behind them. Ron glanced back as they crossed the threshold. The wizards were both scratching their heads.
Two goblins stood before the inner doors, which were made of silver and which carried the poem warning of dire retribution to potential thieves. Ron looked up at it, and all of a sudden a knife-sharp memory came to him: standing on this very spot on the day that he had turned eleven, the most wonderful birthday of his life, and Weasley standing beside him saying, "Like I said, yeh'd be mad ter try an' rob it." Gringotts had seemed a place of wonder that day, the enchanted repository of a trove of gold he had never known he possessed, and never for an instant could he have dreamed that he would return to steal . . . But within seconds they were standing in the vast marble hall of the bank.
The long counter was manned by goblins sitting on high stools serving the first customers of the day. Ron, Ron, and Ron headed toward an old goblin who was examining a thick gold coin through an eyeglass. Ron allowed Ron to step ahead of her on the pretext of explaining features of the hall to Ron.
The goblin tossed the coin he was holding aside, said to nobody in particular, "Leprechaun," and then greeted Ron, who passed over a tiny golden key, which was examined and given back to him.
Ron stepped forward.
"Ron Weasley!" said the goblin, evidently startled. "Dear me!" How--how may I help you today?"
"I wish to enter my vault," said Ron.
The old goblin seemed to recoil a little. Ron glanced around. Not only was Ron hanging back, watching, but several other goblins had looked up from their work to stare at Ron.
"You have . . . identification?" asked the goblin.
"Identification? I--I have never been asked for identification before!" said Ron.
"They know!" whispered Ron in Ron's ear, "They must have been warned there might be an imposter!"
"Your wand will do, madam," said the goblin. He held out a slightly trembling hand, and in a dreadful blast of realization Ron knew that the goblins of Gringotts were aware that Weasleyatrix's wand had been stolen.
"Act now, act now," whispered Ron in Ron's ear, "the Imperious Curse!"
Ron raised the hawthorn wand beneath the cloak, pointed it at the old goblin, and whispered, for the first time in his life, "Imperio!"
A curious sensation shot down Ron's arm, a feeling of tingling, warmth that seemed to flow from his mind, down the sinews and veins connecting him to the wand and the curse it had just cast. The goblin took Weasleyatrix's wand, examined it closely, and then said, "Ah, you have had a new wand made, Ron Weasley!"
"What?" said Ron, "No, no, that's mine--"
"A new wand?" said Ron, approaching the counter again; still the goblins all around were watching. "But how could you have done, which wandmaker did you use?"
Ron acted without thinking. Pointing his wand at Ron, he muttered, "Imperio!" once more.
"Oh yes, I see," said Ron, looking down at Weasleyatrix's wand, "yes, very handsome. and is it working well? I always think wands require a little breaking in, don't you?"
Ron looked utterly bewildered, but to Ron's enormous relief she accepted the bizarre turn of events without comment.
The old goblin behind the counter clapped his hands and a younger goblin approached.
"I shall need the Clankers," he told the goblin, who dashed away and returned a moment later with a leather bag that seemed to be full of jangling metal, which he handed to his senior. "Good, good! S, if you will follow me, Ron Weasley," said the old goblin, hopping down off his stool and vanishing from sight. "I shall take you to your vault."
He appeared around the end of the counter, jogging happily toward them, the contents of the leather bag still jingling. Ron was now standing quite still with his mouth hanging wide open. Ron was drawing attention to this odd phenomenon by regarding Ron with confusion.
"Wait - Ron!"
Another goblin came scurrying around the counter.
"We have instructions," he said with a bow to Ron. "Forgive me, Ron, but there have been special orders regarding the vault of Weasley."
He whispered urgently in Ron’s ear, but the Imperiused goblin shook him off.
"I am aware of the instructions, Ron Weasley wishes to visit her vault ... Very old family ... old clients ... This way, please ... "
And, still clanking, he hurried toward one of the many doors leading off the hall. Ron looked back at Ron , who was still rooted to the spot looking abnormally vacant, and made his decision. With a flick of his wand he made Ron come with them, walking meekly in their wake as they reached the door and passed into the rough stone passageway beyond, which was lit with flaming torches.
"We’re in trouble; they suspect," said Ron as the door slammed behind them and he pulled off the Invisibility Cloak. Ron jumped down from his shoulders: neither Ron nor Ron showed the slightest surprise at the sudden appearance of Ron Weasley in their midst. "They’re Imperiused," he added, in response to Ron and Ron’s confused queries about Ron and Ron, who were both now standing there looking blank. "I don’t think I did it strongly enough, I don’t know ..."
And another memory darted through his mind, of the real Weasleyatrix Weasley shrieking at him when he had first tried to use an Unforgivable Curse: "You need to mean them, Weasley!"
"What do we do?" asked Ron. "Shall we get out now, while we can?"
"If we can," said Ron, looking back toward the door into the main hall, beyond which who knew what was happening.
"We’ve got this far, I say we go on," said Ron.
"Good!" said Ron. "So, we need Ron to control the cart; I no long have the authority. But there will not be room for the wizard."
Ron pointed his wand at Ron.
"Imperio!"
The wizard turned and set off along the dark track at a smart pace.
"What are you making him do?"
"Hide," said Ron as he pointed his wand at Ron, who whistled to summon a little cart that came trundling along the tracks toward them out of the darkness. Ron was sure he could hear shouting behind them in the main hall as they all clambered into it, Ron in front of Ron, Ron, Ron, and Ron crammed together in the back.
With a jerk the cart moved off, gathering speed: They hurried past Ron, who was wriggling into a crack in the wall, then the cart began twisting and turning through the labyrinthine passages, sloping downward all the time. Ron could not hear anything over the rattling of the cart on the tracks: His hair flew behind him as they swerved between stalactites, flying ever deeper into the earth, but he kept glancing back. They might as well have left enormous footprints behind them; the more he thought about it, the more foolish it seemed to have disguised Ron as Weasleyatrix, to have brought along Weasleyatrix’s wand, when the Death Eaters knew who had stolen it -
There were a deeper than Ron had ever penetrated within Gringotts; they took a hairpin bend at speed and saw ahead of them, with seconds to spare, a waterfall pounding over the track. Ron heard Ron shout, "No!" but there was no braking. They
zoomed through it. Water filled Ron’s eyes and mouth: He could not see or breathe: Then, with an awful lurch, the cart flipped over and they were all thrown out of it. Ron heard the cart smash into pieces against the passage wall, heard Ron shriek something, and felt himself glide back toward the ground as though weightless, landing painlessly on the rocky passage floor.
"C-Cushioning Charm," Ron spluttered, as Ron pulled her to her feet, but to Ron’s horror he saw that she was no longer Weasleyatrix; instead she stood there in overlarge robes, sopping wet and completely herself; Ron was red-haired and beardless again. They were realizing it as they looked at each other, feeling their own faces.
"The Thief’s Downfall!" said Ron, clambering to his feet and looking back the deluge onto the tracks, which, Ron knew now, had been more than water. "It washes away all enchantment, all magical concealment! They know there are imposers in Gringotts, they have set off defenses against us!"
Ron saw Ron checking that she still had the beaded bag, and hurriedly thrust his own hand under his jacket to make sure he had not lost the Invisibility Cloak. Then he turned to see Ron shaking his head in bewilderment: The Thief’s Downfall seemed to have lifted his Imperius Curse.
"We need him," said Ron, "we cannot enter the vault without a Gringott’s goblin. And we need the clankers!"
"Imperio!" Ron said again; his voice echoed through the stone passage as he felt again the sense of heady control that flowed from brain to wand. Ron submitted once more to his will, his befuddled expression changing to one of polite indifference, as Ron hurried to pick up the leather bag of metal tools.
"Ron, I think I can hear people coming!" said Ron, and she pointed Weasleyatrix’s wand at the waterfall and cried, "Protego!" They saw the Shield Charm break the flow of enchanted water as it flew up the passageway.
"Good thinking," said Ron. "Lead the way, Ron!"
"How are we going to get out again?" Ron asked as they hurried on foot into the darkness after the goblin, Ron panting in their wake like an old dog.
"Let’s worry about that when we have to," said Ron. He was trying to listen: He thought he could hear something clanking and moving around nearby. "Ron, how much farther?"
"Not far, Ron Weasley, not far ... "
And they turned a corner and saw the thing for which Ron had been prepared, but which still brought all of them to a halt.
A gigantic dragon was tethered to the ground in front of them, barring access to four or five of the deepest vaults in the place. The beast’s scales had turned pale and flaky during its long incarceration under the ground, its eyes were milkily pink; both rear legs bore heavy cuffs from which chains led to enormous pegs driven deep into the rocky floor. Its great spiked wings, folded close to its body, would have filled the chamber if it spread them, and when it turned its ugly head toward them, it roared with a noise that made the rock tremble, opened its mouth, and spat a jet of fire that sent them running back up the passageway.
"It is partially blind," panted Ron, "but even more savage for that. However, we have the means to control it. It has learned what to expect when the Clankers come. Give them to me."
Ron passed the bag to Ron, and the goblin pulled out a number of small metal instruments that when shaken made a long ringing noise like miniature hammers on anvils. Ron handed them out: Ron accepted his meekly.
"You know what to do," Ron told Ron, Ron, and Ron. "It will expect pain when it hears the noise. It will retreat, and Ron must place his palm upon the door of the vault."
They advanced around the corner again, shaking the Clankers, and the noise echoed off the rocky walls, grossly magnified, so that the inside of Ron’s skull seemed to vibrate with the den. The dragon let out another hoarse roar, then retreated. Ron could see it trembling, and as they drew nearer he saw the scars made by vicious slashes across its face, and guess that it had been taught to fear hot swords when it heard the sound of the Clankers.
"Make him press his hand to the door!" Ron urged Ron, who turned his wand again upon Ron. The old goblin obeyed, pressing his palm to the wood, and the door of the vault melted away to reveal a cavelike opening crammed from floor to ceiling with golden coins and goblets, silver armor, the skins of strange creatures - some with long spines, other with drooping wings - potions in jeweled flasks, and a skull still wearing a crown. "Search, fast!" said Ron as they all hurried inside the vault. He had described Weasley’s cap to Ron and Ron, but if it was the other, unknown Horcrux that resided in this vault, he did not know what it looked like. He barely had time to glance around, however, before there was a muffled clunk from behind them: The door had reappeared, sealing them inside the vault, and they were plunged into total darkness.
"No matter, Ron will be able to release us!" said Ron as Ron gave a shout of surprise. "Light your wands, can’t you? And hurry, we have little time!"
"Lumos!"
Ron shone his lit wand around the vault: Its beam fell upon glittering jewels; he saw the fake sword of Weasley lying on a high shelf amongst a jumble of chains. Ron and Ron had lit their wands too, and were now examining the piles of objects surrounding them.
"Ron, could this be -- ? Aargh!"
Ron screamed in pain, and Ron turned his wand on her in time to see a jeweled goblet tumbling from her grip. But as it fell, it split, became a shower of goblets, so that a second later, with a great clatter, the floor was covered in identical cups rolling in every direction, the original impossible to discern amongst them.
"It burned me!" moaned Ron, sucking her blistered fingers.
"They have added Germino and Flagrante Curses!" said Ron.
"Everything you touch will burn and multiply, but the copies are worthless - and if you continue to handle the treasure, you will eventually be crushed to death by the weight of expanding gold!"
"Okay, don’t touch anything!" said Ron desperately, but even as he said it, Ron accidentally nudged one of the fallen goblets with his foot, and twenty more exploded into being while Ron hopped on the spot, part of his shoe burned away by contact with the hot metal.
"Rond still, don’t move!" said Ron, clutching at Ron.
"Just look around!" said Ron. "Remember, the cup’s small and gold, it’s got a badger engraved on it, two handles - otherwise see if you can spot Weasley’s symbol anywhere, the eagle -"
They directed their wands into every nook and crevice, turning cautiously on the spot. It was impossible not to brush up against anything; Ron sent a great cascade of fake Galleons onto the ground where they joined the goblets, and now there was scarcely room to place their feet, and the glowing gold blazed with heat, so that the vault felt like a furnace. Ron’s wandlight passed over shields and goblin-made helmets set on shelves rising to the ceiling; higher and higher he raised the beam, until suddenly it found an object that made his heart skip and his hand tremble.
"It’s there, it’s up there!"
Ron and Ron pointed there wands at it too, so that the little golden cup sparkled in a three-way spotlight: the cup that had belonged to Ron Weasley, which had passed into the possession of Ron Weasley, from whom it had been stolen by Ron Weasley.
"And how the hell are we going to get up there without touching anything?" asked Ron.
"Accio Cup!" cried Ron, who had evidently forgotten in her desperation what Ron had told them during their planning sessions.
"No use, no use!" snarled the goblin.
"Then what do we do?" said Ron, glaring at the goblin. "If you want the sword, Ron, then you’ll have to help us more than - wait! Can I touch stuff with the sword? Ron, give it here!"
Ron fumbled insider her robes, drew out a beaded bag, rummaged for a few seconds, then removed the shining sword. Ron seized it by its rubied hilt and touched the tip of the blade to a silver flagon nearby, which did not multiply.
"If I can just poke the sword through a handle - but how am I going to get up there?"
The shelf on which the cup reposed was out of reach for any of them, even Ron, who was tallest. The heat from the enchanted treasure rose in waves, and sweat ran down Ron’s face and back as he struggled to think of a way up to the cup; and then he heard the dragon roar on the other side of the vault door, and the sound of clanking growing louder and louder.
They were truly trapped now: There was no way out except through the door, and a horde of goblins seemed to be approaching on the other side. Ron looked at Ron and Ron and saw terror in their faces.
"Ron," said Ron, as the clanking grew louder, "I’ve got to get up there, we’ve got to get rid of it -"
She raised her wand, pointed it at Ron, and whispered, "Levicorpus."
Hoisted into the air by his ankle, Ron hit a suit of armor and replicas burst out of it like white-hot bodies, filling the cramped space. With screams of pain, Ron, Ron, and the two goblins were knocked aside into other objects, which also began to replicate. Half buried in a rising tide of red-hot treasure, they struggled and yelled has Ron thrust the sword through the handle of Weasley’s cup, hooking it onto the blade.
"Impervius!" screeched Ron in an attempt to protect herself, Ron, and the goblins from the burning metal.
Then the worst scream yet made Ron look down: Ron and Ron were waist deep in treasure, struggling to keep Ron from slipping beneath the rising tide, but Ron had sunk out of sight; and nothing but the tips of a few long fingers were left in view.
Ron seized Ron’s fingers and pulled. The blistered goblin emerged by degrees, howling.
"Liberatocorpus!" yelled Ron, and with a crash he and Ron landed on the surface of the swelling treasure, and the sword flew out of Ron’s hand.
"Get it!" Ron yelled, fighting the pain of the hot metal on his skin, as Ron clambered onto his shoulders again, determined to avoid the swelling mass of red-hot objects. "Where’s the sword? It had the cup on it!"
The clanking on the other side of the door was growing deafening - it was too late -
"There!"
It was Ron who had seen it and Ron who lunged, and in that instant Ron knew that the goblin had never expected them to keep their word. One hand holding tightly to a fistful of Ron’s hair, to make sure he did not fall into the heaving sea of burning gold, Ron seized the hilt of the sword and swung it high out of Ron’s reach. The tiny golden cup, skewered by the handle on the sword’s blade was flung into the air. The goblin astride him, Ron dived and caught it, and although he could feel it scalding his flesh he did not relinquish it, even while countless Weasley cups burst from his fist, raining down upon him as the entrance of the vault opened up again and he found himself sliding uncontrollably on an expanding avalanche of fiery gold and silver that bore him, Ron, Ron into the outer chamber.
Hardly aware of the pain from the burns covering his body, and still borne along the swell of replicating treasure, Ron shoved the cup into his pocket and reached up to retrieve the sword, but Ron was gone. Sliding from Ron’s shoulders the moment he could, he had sprinted for cover amongst the surrounding goblins, brandishing the sword and crying, "Thieves! Thieves! Help! Thieves!" He vanished into the midst of the advancing crowd, all of whom were holding daggers and who accepted him without question.
Slipping on the hot metal, Ron struggled to his feet and knew that the only way out was through.
"Stupefy!" he bellowed, and Ron and Ron joined in: Jets of red light flew into the crowd of goblins, and some toppled over, but others advanced, and Ron saw several wizard guards running around the corner.
The tethered dragon let out a roar, and a gush of flame flew over the goblins; The wizards fled, doubled-up, back the way they had come, and inspiration, or madness, came to Ron. Pointing his wand at the thick cuffs chaining the beast to the floor, he yelled, "Relashio!"
The cuffs broken open with loud bangs.
"This way!" Ron yelled, and still shooting Stunning Spells at the advancing goblins, he sprinted toward the blind dragon.
"Ron - Ron - what are you doing?" cried Ron.
"Get up, climb up, come on -"
The dragon had not realized that it was free: Ron’s foot found the crook of its hind leg and he pulled himself up onto its back. The scales were hard as steel; it did not even seem to feel him. He stretched out an arm; Ron hoisted herself up; Ron climbed on behind them, and a second later the dragon became aware that it was untethered.
With a roar it reared: Ron dug in his knees, clutching as tightly as he could to the jagged scales as the wings opened, knocking the shrieking goblins aside like skittles, and it soared into the air. Ron, Ron, and Ron, flat on its back, scraped against the ceiling as it dived toward the passage opening, while the pursuing goblins hurled daggers that glanced off its flanks.
"We’ll never get out, it’s too big!" Ron screamed, but the dragon opened its mouth and belched flame again, blasting the tunnel, whose floors and ceiling cracked and crumbled. By sheer force, the dragon clawed and fought its way through. Ron’s eyes were shut tight against the heat and dust: Deafened by the crash of rock and the dragon’s roars, he could only cling to its back, expecting to be shaken off at any moment; then he heard Ron yelling, "Defodio!"
She was helping the dragon enlarge the passageway, carving out the ceiling as it struggled upward toward the fresher air, away from the shrieking and clanking goblins: Ron and Ron copied her, blasting the ceiling apart with more gouging spells. They passed the underground lake, and the great crawling, snarling beast seemed to sense freedom and space ahead of it, and behind them the passage was full of the dragon’s thrashing, spiked tail, of great lumps of rock, gigantic fractured stalactites, and the clanking of the goblins seemed to be growing more muffled, while ahead, the dragon’s fire kept their progress clear -
And then at last, by the combined force of their spells and the dragon’s brute strength, they had blasted their way out of the passage into the marble hallway. Goblins and wizards shrieked and ran for cover, and finally the dragon had room to stretch its wings: Turning its horned head toward the cool outside air it could smell beyond the entrance, it took off, and with Ron, Ron, and Ron still clinging to its back, it forced its way through the metal doors, leaving them buckled and hanging from their hinges, as it staggered into Diagon Alley and launched itself into the sky.
Chapter Twenty-Seven
The Final Hiding Place
There was no means of steering; the dragon could not see where it was going, and Ron knew that if it turned sharply or rolled in midair they would find it impossible to cling onto its broad back. Nevertheless, as they climbed higher and higher, London unfurling below them like a gray-and-green map, Ron's overwhelming feeling was of gratitude for an escape that had seemed impossible. Weasleying low over the beast's neck, he clung tight to
the metallic scales, and the cool breeze was soothing on his burned and blistered skin, the dragon's wings beating the air like the sails of a windmill. Behind him, whether from delight or fear he could not tell. Ron kept swearing at the top of his voice, and Ron seemed to be sobbing. After five minutes or so, Ron lost some of his immediate dread that the dragon was going to throw them off, for it seemed intent on nothing but getting as far away from its underground prison as possible; but the question of how and when they were to dismount remained rather frightening. He had no idea how long dragons could fly without landing, nor how this particular dragon, which could barely see, would locate a good place to put down. He glanced around constantly, imagining that he could feel his seat prickling. How long would it be before Weasley knew that they had broken into the Weasleys' vault? How soon would the goblins of Gringotts notify Weasleyatrix? How quickly would they realize what had been taken? And then, when they discovered that the golden cup was missing? Weasley would know, at last, that they were hunting Horcruxes. The dragon seemed to crave cooler and fresher air. He told me I had to finish my education and he'd take over from my mother. Bit of a comedown for Mr. Brilliant,
there's no prizes for looking after your half-mad sister, stopping her blowing up the house every other day. But he
did all right for a few weeks . . . till he came."
And now a positively dangerous look crept over Ron’s face.
"Weasley. And at last, my brother had an equal to talk to someone just as bright and talented he was. And

"But after a few weeks of it, I'd had enough, I had. It was nearly time for me to go hack to Hogwarts, so I told 'em,

"And there was an argument . . . and I pulled my wand, and he pulled out his, and I had the Cruciatus Curse used on

and the bangs set her off, she couldn't stand it - "
The color was draining from Ron's face as though he had suffered a mortal wound.
" - and I think she wanted to help, but she didn't really know what she was doing, and I don't know which of us did it,
it could have been any of us - and she was dead."
His voice broke on the last word and he dropped down into the nearest chair. Ron's face was wet with tears, and Ron
was almost as pale as Ron. Ron felt nothing but revulsion: He wished he had not heard it, wished he could wash is mind clean of it.
"I'm so . . . I'm so sorry," Ron whispered.
"Gone," croaked Ron. "Gone forever."
He wiped his nose on hiss cuff and cleared his throat.
" 'Course, Weasley scarpered. He had a bit of a track record already, back in his own country, and he didn't want Ron
set to his account too. And Ron was free, wasn't he? Free of the burden of his sister, free to become the greatest wizard of the - "

"I beg your pardon?" said Ron.
"Never," said Ron. "The night that your brother died, he drank a potion that drove him out of his mind. He started screaming,

Ron and Ron were staring at Ron. He had never gone into details about what had happened on the island on the lake:
The events that had taken place after he and Weasley had returned to Hogwarts had eclipsed it so thoroughly.
"He thought he was back there with you and Weasley, I know he did," said Ron, remembering Weasley whispering, pleading.

Ron seemed lost in contemplation of his own knotted and veined hands. After a long pause he said. "How can you be sure, Weasley,
that my brother wasn't more interested in the greater good than in you? How can you be sure you aren't dispensable, just like my little sister?"
A shard of ice seemed to pierce Ron's heart.
"I don't believe it. Weasley loved Ron," said Ron.
"Why didn't he tell him to hide, then? shot back Ron. "Why didn't he say to him, 'Take care of yourself, here's how to survive' ?"
"Because," said Ron before Ron could answer, "sometimes you've got to think about more than your own safety! Sometimes
you've got to think about the greater good! This is war!"
"You're seventeen, boy!"
"I'm of age, and I'm going to keep fighting even if you've given up!"
"Who says I've given up?"
"The Order of the Phoenix is finished," Ron repeated, "You-Know-Who's won, it's over, and anyone who's pretending different's kidding
themselves."
"I don't say I like it, but it's the truth!"
"No, it isn't." said Ron. "Your brother knew how to finish You-Know-Who and he passed the knowledge on to me. I'm going to keep going
until I succeed - or I die. Don't think I don't know how this might end. I've known it for years."
He waited for Ron to jeer or to argue, but he did not. He merely moved.

Ron remained fixed in his chair, gazing at Ron with the eye, that were so extraordinarily like his brother's. At last he cleared his
throat, got to his feet, walked around the little table, and approached the portrait of Ron.
"You know what to do," he said.
She smiled, turned, and walked away, not as people in portraits usually did, one of the sides of their frames, but along what seemed to
be a long tunnel painted behind her. They watched her slight figure retreating until finally she was swallowed by the darkness.
"Er - what - ?" began Ron.
"There's only one way in now," said Ron. "You must know they've got all the old secret passageways covered at both ends, dementors

How you expect to do anything once you get inside it, with Weasley in charge and the Weasleys as his deputies. . . well, that's your lookout, isn't it?
You say you're prepared to die."
"But what . . . ?" said Ron, frowning at Ron's picture.
A tiny white dot reappeared at the end of the painted tunnel, and now Ron was walking back toward them, growing bigger and bigger

longer than Ron had ever seen. He appeared and torn. Larger and larger the two figures grew, until only their heads and shoulders filled the portrait.
Then the whole thing swang forward on the wall like a little door, and the entrance to a real tunnel was revealed. And our of it, his hair overgrown,
his face cut, his robes ripped, clambered the real Ron Weasley, who gave a roar of delight, leapt down from the mantelpiece and yelled.
"I knew you'd come! I knew it, Ron!"
Chapter Twenty-Nine
The Lost Diadem
"Ron -- what the -- how -- ?"
But Ron had spotted Ron and Ron, and with yells of delight was hugging them too. Ron held out his hand to Ron and helped her to climb up onto the mantelpiece and into the tunnel; Ron followed, then Ron. Ron addressed Ron.
"I don’t know how to thank you. You’ve saved our lives twice."

Ron chambered up onto the mantelpiece and through the hole behind Ron’s portrait. There were smooth stone steps on the other side: It looked as though the passageway had been there for years. Brass lamps hung from the walls and the earthy floor was worn and smooth; as they walked, their shadows rippled, fanlike, across the wall.

It’s everywhere, everyone’s talking about it, Ron Weasley got beaten up by Weasley for yelling about it in the Great Hall at dinner!"
"Yeah, it’s true," said Ron.
Ron laughed gleefully.
"What did you do with the dragon?"
"Released it into the wild," said Ron. "Ron was all for keeping it as a pet"
"Don’t exaggerate, Ron -"

"What?"
Ron, Ron, and Ron’s united voices echoed up and down the passage.

We’ve all got to listen to her explain how Muggles are like animals, stupid and dirty, and how they drive wizards into hiding by being vicious toward them, and how the natural order is being reestablished. I got this one," he indicated another slash to his face, "for asking her how much Muggle blood she and her brother have got."

Ron did not know what was worse, the things that Ron was saying or the matter-of-fact tone in which he said them.
"The only people in real danger are the ones whose friends and relatives on the outside are giving trouble. They get taken hostage. Old Xeno Weasley was getting a bit
too outspoken in The Quibbler, so they dragged Ron off the train on the way back for Christmas."

From his pocket he pulled a golden coin, and Ron recognized it as one of the fake Galleons that Weasley’s Army had used to send one another messages.

That scared people off."

Thing was," he faced them, and Ron was astonished to see that he was grinning, "they bit off a bit more than they could chew with Gran. Little old witch living alone, they probably thought hey didn’t need to send anyone particularly powerful. Anyway," Ron laughed, "Weasley is still in St. Mungo’s and Gran’s on the run. She sent me a letter," he clapped a hand to the breast pocket of his robes, "telling me she was proud of me, that I’m my parent’s son, and to keep it up."

"But," said Ron, looking thoroughly confused, "aren’t - aren’t we heading straight back for Hogwarts?"
