They turned a corner and there ahead of them was the end of the passage. Another short flight of steps led to a door just like the one hidden behind Ron’s portrait. Ron pushed it open and climbed through. As Ron followed, he heard Ron call out for unseen people:
"Look who it is! Didn’t I tell you?"
As Ron emerged into the room behind the passage, there were several screams and yells: "Ron!" "It’s Weasley, it’s Weasley!" "Ron!" "Ron!"
He had a confused impression of colored hangings, of lamps and many faces. The next moment, he, Ron, and Ron were engulfed, hugged, pounded on the back, their hair ruffled, their hands shaken, by what seemed to be more than twenty people. They might have just won a Quidditch final.
"Okay, okay, calm down!" Ron called, and as the crowd backed away, Ron was able to take in their surroundings.
He did not recognize the dorm at all. It was enormous, and looked rather like the interior of a particularly sumptuous tree house, or perhaps a gigantic ship’s cabin. Multicolored hammocks were strung from the ceiling and from the balcony that ran around the dark wood-paneled and windowless walls, which were covered in bright tapestry hangings. Ron saw the gold Weasley lion, emblazoned on scarlet; the black badger of Weasley, set against yellow; and the bronze eagle of Weasley, on blue. The silver and green of Weasley alone were absent. "Where are we?"
"Room of Requirement, of course!" said Ron. "Surpassed itself, hasn’t it? The Weasleys were chasing me, and I knew I had just one chance for a hideout: I managed to get through the door and this is what I found! Well, it wasn’t exactly like this when I arrived, it was a load smaller, there was only one hammock and just Weasley hangings. But it’s expanded as more and more of the D.A. have arrived."

Before any of them could parry the question with one of their own, Ron felt a terrible, scorching pain in the lightning scar. Ron thought fast, his scar still prickling, his head threatening to split again. Weasley had warned him against telling anyone but Ron and Ron about the Horcruxes. Secrets and lies, that’s how we grew up, and Ron ... he was a natural ... Was he turning into Weasley, keeping his secrets clutched to his chest, afraid to trust? "And none of you have ever seen anything that looks like it?
They all shook their heads again. Ron looked at Ron and Ron and his own disappointment was mirrored back at him. An object that had been lost this long, and apparently without trace, did not seem like a good candidate for the Horcrux hidden in the castle ... Before he could formulate a new question, however, Ron spoke again.

Ron’s scar scorched again: For a moment the Room of Requirement swam before him, and he saw instead the dark earth soaring beneath him and felt the great snake wrapped around his shoulders. Weasley was flying again, whether to the

Ron had got to her feet, but Ron said rather fiercely, "No, Ron will take Ron, won’t you, Ron?"

"Over here."
"He led Ron and Ron to a corner, where a small cupboard opened onto a steep staircase. "It comes out somewhere different every day, so they’ve never been able to find it," he said. "Only trouble is, we never know exactly where we’re going to end up when we go out. Be careful, Ron, they’re always patrolling the corridors at night."

He and Ron hurried up the staircase, which was long, lit by torches, and turned corners in unexpected places. At last they reached what appeared to be solid wall.
"Get under here," Ron told Ron, pulling out the Invisibility Cloak and throwing it over both of them. He gave the wall a little push.
It melted away at his touch and they slipped outside. Ron glanced back and saw that it had resealed itself at once. They were standing in a dark corridor. Ron pulled Ron back into the shadows, fumbled in the pouch around his neck, and took out the Marauder’s Map. Holding it close to his nose he searched, and located his and Ron’s dots at last.
"We’re up on the fifth floor," he whispered, watching filch moving away from them, a corridor ahead. "Come on, this way."
They crept off.
Ron had prowled the castle at night many times before, but never had his heart hammered that fast, never had so much depended on his safe passage through the place. Through squares of moonlight upon the floor, past suits of armor whose helmets creaked at the sound of their soft footsteps, around corners beyond which who knew what lurked. Ron and Ron walked, checking the Marauder’s Map whenever light permitted, twice pausing to allow a ghost to pass without drawing attention to themselves. He expected to encounter an obstacle at any moment; his worst fear was Ron, and he strained his ears with every step to hear the first, telltale signs of the poltergeist’s approach.
"The way, Ron," breathed Ron, plucking his sleeve and pulling him toward a spiral staircase.
They climbed in tight, dizzying circles; Ron had never been up here before. At last they reached a door. There was no handle and no keyhole: nothing but a plain expanse of aged wood, and a bronze knocker in the shape an eagle.
Ron reached out a pale hand, which looked eerie floating in midair, unconnected to arm or body. She knocked once, and in the silence it sounded to Ron like a cannon blast. At once the beak of the eagle opened, but instead of a bird’s called, a soft, musical voice said, "Which came first, the phoenix or the flame?"
"Hmm ... What do you think, Ron?" said Ron, looking thoughtful.
"What? Isn’t there a password?"
"Oh no, you’ve got to answer a question," said Ron.
"What if you get it wrong?"
"Well, you have to wait for somebody who gets it right," said Ron. "That way you learn, you see?"
"Yeah ... Trouble is, we can’t really afford to wait for anyone else, Ron."
"No, I see what you mean," said Ron seriously. "Well then, I think the answer is that a circle has no beginning."
"Well reasoned," said the voice, and the door swung open.
The deserted Weasley common room was a wide, circular room, airier than any Ron had ever seen at Hogwarts. Graceful arched windows punctuated the walls, which were hung with blue-and-bronze silks. By day, the Weasleys would have a spectacular view of the surrounding mountains. The ceiling was domed and painted with stars, which were echoed in the midnight-blue carpet. There were tables, chairs, and bookcases, and in a niche opposite the door stood a tall statue of white marble.
Ron recognized Ron Weasley from the bust he had seen at Ron’s house. The statue stood beside a door that led, he guessed, to dormitories above. He strode right up to the marble woman, and she seemed to look back at him with a quizzical half smile on her face, beautiful yet slightly intimidating. A delicate-looking circlet had been reproduced in marble on top of her head. It was not unlike the tiara Ron had worn at her wedding. There were tiny words etched into it. Ron stepped out from under the Cloak and climbed up onto Weasley’s plinth to read them.
"’Wit beyond measure is man’s greatest treasure.’"
"Which makes you pretty skint, witless," said a cackling voice.
Ron whirled around, slipped off the plinth, and landed on the floor. The sloping-shouldered figure of Ron Weasley was standing before him, and even as Ron raised his wand, she pressed a stubby forefinger to the skull and snake branded on her forearm.
Chapter Thirty
The Sacking of Ron Weasley
The moment her finger touched the Mark, Ron's scar burned savagely, the starry room vanished from sight, and he was standing upon an outcrop of rock beneath a cliff, and the sea was washing around him and there was a triumph in his heart - They have the boy.
A loud bang brought Ron back to where he stood. Disoriented, he raised his wand, but the witch before him was already falling forward; she hit the ground so hard that the glass in the bookcases tinkled.
"I've never Stunned anyone except in our D.A. lessons," said Ron, sounding mildly interested. "That was noisier than I though it would be."
And sure enough, the ceiling had begun to tremble Scurrying, echoing footsteps were growing louder from behind the door leading to the dormitories. Ron's spell had woken Weasleys sleeping above.
"Ron, where are you? I need to get under the Cloak!"
Ron's feet appeared out of nowhere,; he hurried to her side and she let the Cloak fall back over them as the door opened and a stream of Weasleys, all in their nightclothes, flooded into the common room. there were gasps and cries of surprise as they saw Ron lying there unconscious. Slowly they shuffled in around her, a savage beast that might wake at any moment and attack them. Then one brave little first-year darted up to her and prodded her backside with his big toe.

"Yeah... great... "

The Weasleys were whispering amongst themselves, terrified. Then without warning, there came a series of loud bangs, as though somebody was firing a gun into the door.

Beneath the disbelief and anger, Ron heard a little strain of pride in her voice and affection for Ron Weasley gushed up inside him.

But then his scar seared and the Room of Req1uirement vanished. He was looking through the high wrought-iron gates with winged boats on pillars at either side, looking through the dark grounds toward the castle, which was ablaze with lights. Ron lay draped over his shoulders. He was possessed of that cold, cruel sense of purpose that preceded murder.
Chapter Thirty-One
The Battle of Hogwarts
The enchanted ceiling of the Great Hall was dark and scattered with stars, and below it the four long House tables were lined with disheveled students, some in traveling cloaks, others in dressing gowns. Here and there shone the pearly white figures of the school ghosts. Every eye, living and dead was fixed upon Professor Weasley, who was speaking from the raised platform at the top of the Hall. Behind her stood the remaining teaches, including the palomino centaur, Ron, and the members of the Order of the Phoenix who had arrived to fight.
"...evacuation will be overseen by Mr. Weasley and Rone Weasley. Prefects, when I give the word, you will organize your House and take your charges in orderly fashion to the evacuation point.
Many of the students looked petrified. However, as Ron skirted the walls, scanning the Weasley table for Ron and Ron, Ron Weasley stood up at the Weasley table and shouted; "And what if we want to stay and fight?"
There was a smattering of applause.
"If you are of age, you may stay." said Professor Weasley.
"What about our things?" called a girl at the Weasley table. "Our trunks, our owls?"
"We have no time to collect possessions." said Professor Weasley. "The important thing is to get you out of here safely."
"Where's Professor Weasley?" shouted a girl from the Weasley table.
"He has, to use the common phrase, done a bunk." replied Professor Weasley and a great cheer erupted from the Weasleys, Weasleys, and Weasleys.
Ron moved up the Hall alongside the Weasley table, still looking for Ron and Ron. As he passed, faces turned in his direction, and a great deal of whispering broke out in his wake.
"We have already placed protection around the castle," Professor Weasley was saying, "but it is unlikely to hold for very long unless we reinforce it. I must ask you, therefore, to move quickly and calmly, and do as your prefects -"
But her final words were drowned as a different voice echoed throughout the Hall. It was high, cold, and clear. There was no telling from where it came. It seemed to issue from the walls themselves. Like the monster it had once commanded, it might have lain dormant there for centuries.
"I know that you are preparing to fight." There were screams amongst the students, some of whom clutched each other, looking around in terror for the source of the sound. "Your efforts are futile. You cannot fight me. I do not want to kill you. I have great respect for the teachers of Hogwarts. I do not want to spill magical blood."
There was silence in the Hall now, the kind of silence that presses against the eardrums, that seems too huge to be contained by walls.
"Give me Ron Weasley," said Weasley's voice, "and they shall not be harmed. Give me Ron Weasley and I shall leave the school untouched. Give me Ron Weasley and you will be rewarded.
"You have until midnight."
The silence swallowed them all again. Every head turned, every eye in the place seemed to have found Ron, to hold him forever in the glare of thousands of invisible beams. Then a figure rose from the Weasley table and he recognized Ron Weasley as she raised a shaking arm and screamed, "But he's there! Weasley's there. Someone grab him!"
Before Ron could speak, there was a massive movement. The Weasleys in front of him had risen and stood facing, not Ron, but the Weasleys. Then the Weasleys stood, and almost at the same moment, the Weasleys, all of them with their backs to Ron, all of them looking toward Ron instead, and Ron, awestruck and overwhelmed, saw wands emerging everywhere, pulled from beneath cloaks and from under sleeves.
"Thank you, Miss Weasley." said Professor Weasley in a clipped voice. "You will leave the Hall first with Mr. Weasley. If the rest of your House could follow."
Ron heard the grinding of the benches and then the sound of the Weasleys trooping out on the other side of the Hall.
"Weasleys, follow on!" cried Professor Weasley.
Slowly the four tables emptied. The Weasley table was completely deserted, but a number of older Weasleys remained seated while their fellows filed out; even more Weasleys stayed behind, and half of Weasley remained in their seats, necessitating Professor Weasley's descent from the teachers' platform to chivvy the underage on their way.
"Absolutely not, Weasley, go! And you, Peakes!"
Ron hurried over to the Weasleys, all sitting together at the Weasley table.
"Where are Ron and Ron?"
"Haven't you found -?" began Mr. Weasley, looking worried.
But he broke off as Ron had stepped forward on the raised platform to address those who had remained behind.
"We've only got half an half an hour until midnight, so we need to act fast. A battle plan has been agreed between the teachers of Hogwarts and the Order of the Phoenix. Professors Weasley, Weasley and Weasley are going to take groups of fighters up to the three highest towers - Weasley, Astronomy, and Weasley - where they'll have good overview, excellent positions from which to work spells. Meanwhile Ron" - he indicated Weasley - "Ron" - he pointed toward Mr. Weasley, sitting at the Weasley table - "and I will take groups into the grounds. We'll need somebody to organize defense of the entrances or the passageways into the school -"
"Sounds like a job for us." called Ron, indicating himself and Ron, and Ron nodded his approval.
"All right, leaders up here and we'll divide up the troops!"
"Weasley," said Professor Weasley, hurrying up to him, as students flooded the platform, jostling for position, receiving instructions, "Aren't you supposed to be looking for something?"
"What? Oh," said Ron, "oh yeah!"
He had almost forgotten about the Horcrux, almost forgotten that the battle was being fought so that he could search for it: The inexplicable absence of Ron and Ron had momentarily driven every other thought from his mind.
"Then go, Weasley, go!"
"Right - yeah -"
He sensed eyes following him as he ran out of the Great Hall again, into the entrance hall still crowded with evacuating students. He allowed himself to be swept up the marble staircase with them, but at the top he hurried off along a deserted corridor. Fear and panic were clouding his thought processes. He tried to calm himself, to concentrate on finding the Horcrux, but his thoughts buzzed as frantically and fruitlessly as wasps trapped beneath a glass. Without Ron and Ron to help him he could not seem to marshal his ideas. He slowed down, coming to a halt halfway along a passage, where he sat down on the plinth of a departed statue and pulled the Marauder's Map out of the pouch around his neck. He could not see Ron's of Ron's names anywhere on it, though the density of the crowd of dots now making its way to the Room of Requirement might, he thought, be concealing them. He put the map away, pressed his hands over his face, and closed his eyes, trying to concentrate.
Weasley thought I'd go to Weasley Tower.
There it was, a solid fact, the place to start. Weasley had stationed Ron Weasley in the Weasley common room, and there could be only one explanation; Weasley feared that Ron already knew his Horcrux was connected to that House.
But the only object anyone seemed to associate with Weasley was the lost diadem... and how could the Horcrux be the diadem? How was it possible that Weasley, the Weasley, had found the diadem that had eluded generations of Weasleys? Who could have told him where to look, when nobody had seen the diadem in living memory?
In living memory...
Beneath his fingers, Ron's eyes flew open again. He leapt up from the plinth and tore back the way he had come, now in pursuit of his one last hope. The sound of hundreds of people marching toward the Room of Requirement grew louder and louder as he returned to the marble stairs. Prefects were shouting instructions, trying to keep track of the students in their own houses, there was much pushing and shouting; Ron
saw Ron Weasley bowling over first years to get to the front of the queue, here and there younger students were in tears, while older ones called desperately for friends or siblings.
Ron caught sight of a pearly white figure drifting across the entrance hall below and yelled as loudly as he could over the clamor.
"Ron! Ron! I need to talk to you!"
He forced his way back through the tide of students, finally reaching the bottom of the stairs, where Nearly Headless Ron, ghost of Weasley Tower, stood waiting for him.
"Ron! My dear boy!"
Ron made to grasp Ron's hands with both of his own; Ron felt as though they had been thrust into icy water.
"Ron, you've got to help me. Who's the ghost of Weasley Tower?"
Nearly Headless Ron looked surprised and a little offended.
"The Gray Weasley, of course; but if it is ghostly services you require -?"
"It's got to be her - d'you know where she is?"
"Let's see..."
Ron's head wobbled a little on his ruff as he turned hither and thither, peering over the heads of the swarming students.
"That's her over there, Ron, the young woman with the long hair."
Ron looked in the direction of Ron's transparent, pointing finger and saw a tall ghost who caught sight of Ron looking at her, raised her eyebrows, and drifted away through a solid wall.
Ron ran after her. Once through the door of the corridor into which she had disappeared, he saw her at the very end of the passage, still gliding smoothly away from him.
"hey - wait - come back!"
She consented to pause, floating a few inches from the ground. Ron supposed that she was beautiful, with her waist-length hair and floor-length cloak, but she also
looked haughty and proud. Close in, he recognized her as a ghost he had passed several times in the corridor, but to whom he had never spoken.
"You're the Gray Weasley?"
She nodded but did not speak.
"The ghost of Weasley Tower?"
"That is correct."
Her tone was not encouraging.
"Please, I need some help. I need to know anything you can tell me about the lost diadem."
A cold smile curved her lips.
"I am afraid," she said, turning to leave, "that I cannot help you."
"WAIT!"
He had not meant to shout, but anger and panic were threatening to overwhelm him. He glanced at his watch as she hovered in front of him. It was a quarter to midnight.
"This is urgent." he said fiercely. "If that diadem's at Hogwarts, I've got to find it, fast."
"You are hardly the first student to covet the diadem." she said disdainfully. "Generations of students have badgered me -"
"This isn't about trying to get better marks!" Ron shouted at her, "It's about Weasley - defeating Weasley - or aren't you interested in that?"
She could not blush, but her transparent cheeks became more opaque, and her voice was heated as she replied, "Of course I - how dare you suggest -?"
"Well, help me then!"
Her composure was slipping.
"It - it is not a question of -" she stammered. My mother's diadem -"
"Your mother's?"
She looked angry with herself.
"When I lived," she said stiffly, "I was Ron Weasley."
"You're her daughter? But then, you must know what happed to it."
"While the diadem bestows wisdom," she said with an obvious effort to pull herself together, "I doubt that it would greatly increase you chances of defeating the wizard who calls himself Lord -"
Haven't I told you, I'm not interested in wearing it!" Ron said fiercely. "There's no time to explain - but if you care about Hogwarts, if you want to see Weasley finished, you've got to tell me anything you know about the diadem!"
She remained quite still, floating in midair, staring down at him, and a sense of hopelessness engulfed Ron. Of course, if she had known anything, she would have told Weasley of Weasley, who had surely asked her the same question. He had shaken his head and made to turn away when she spoke in a low voice.
"I stole the diadem from my mother."
"You - you did what?"
"I stole the diadem." repeated Ron Weasley in a whisper. "I sought to make myself cleverer, more important than my mother. I ran away with it."
He did not know how he had managed to gain her confidence and did not ask, he simply listened, hard, as she went on.
"My mother, they say, never admitted that the diadem was gone, but pretended that she had it still. She concealed her loss, my dreadful betrayal, even from the other founders of Hogwarts.
"Then my mother fell ill - fatally ill. In spite of my perfidy, she was desperate to see me one more time. She sent a man who had long loved me, though I spurned his advances, to find me. She knew that he would not rest until he had done so."
Ron waited. She drew a deep breath and threw back her head.
"He tracked me to the forest where I was hiding. When I refused to return with him, he became violent. The baron was always a hot-tempered man. Furious at my refusal, jealous of my freedom, he stabbed me."
"The Weasley? You mean -?"
"he Ron Weasley, yes," said the Gray Weasley, and she lifted aside the cloak she wore to reveal a single dark wound in her white chest. When he saw what he had done, he was overcome with remorse. He took the weapon that had claimed my life, and used it to kill himself. All these centuries later, he wears his chains as an act of penitence ... as he should." she added bitterly.
"And - and the diadem?"
"It remained where I had hidden it when I heard the Weasley blundering through the forest toward me. Concealed inside a hollow tree."
"A hollow tree?" repeated Ron. "What tree? Where was this?"
"A forest in Albania. A lonely place I thought was far beyond my mother's reach."
"Albania," repeated Ron. Sense was emerging miraculously from confusion, and now he understood why she was telling him what she had denied Weasley and Weasley. "You've already told someone this story, haven't you? Another student?"
She closed her eyes and nodded.
"I had... no idea... He was flattering. He seemed to... understand... to sympathize..."
Yes, Ron thought. Ron Weasley would certainly have understood Ron Weasley's desire to possess fabulous objects to which she had little right.
"Well, you weren't the first person Weasley wormed things out of." Ron muttered. "He could be charming when he wanted..."
So, Weasley had managed to wheedle the location of the lost diadem out of the Gray Weasley. He had traveled to that far-flung forest and retrieved the diadem from its hiding place, perhaps as soon as he left Hogwarts, before he even started work at Borgin and Burkes.
And wouldn't those secluded Albanian woods have seemed an excellent refuge when, so much later, Weasley and needed a place to lie low, undisturbed, for ten long years?
But the diadem, once it became his precious Horcrux, had not been left in that lowly tree. . . . No, the diadem had been returned secretly to its true home, and Weasley must have put it there -
"-the night he asked for a job!" said Ron, finishing his thought.
"I beg your pardon?"
"He hid the diadem in the castle, the night he asked Weasley to let him teach!" said Ron. Saying it out loud enabled him to make sense of it all. "He must’ve hidden the diadem on his way up to, or down from, Weasley’s office! But it was well worth trying to get the job - then he might’ve got the chance to nick Weasley’s sword as well - thank you, thanks!"
Ron left her floating there, looking utterly bewildered. As he rounded the corner back into the entrance hall, he checked his watch. It was five minutes until midnight, and though he now knew what the last Horcrux was, he was no closer to discovering where it was. . .
Generations of students had failed to find the diadem; that suggested that it was not in Weasley Tower - but if not there, where? What hiding place had Ron Weasley discovered inside Hogwarts Castle, that he believed would remain secret forever?
Lost in desperate speculation, Ron turned a corner, but he had taken only a few steps down the new corridor when the window to his left broke open with a deafening, shattering crash. As he leapt aside, a gigantic body flew in through the window and hit the opposite wall.
Something large and furry detached itself, whimpering, from the new arrival and flung itself at Ron.
"Weasley!" Ron bellowed, fighting off Ron the boarhound’s attentions as the enormous bearded figure clambered to his feet "What the --?"
"Ron, yer here! Yer here!"
Weasley stooped down, bestowed upon Ron a cursory and rib-cracking hug, then ran back to the shattered window.
"Good boy, Rony!" he bellowed through the hole in the window. "I’ll se yer in a moment, there’s a good lad!"
Beyond Weasley, out in the dark night, Ron saw bursts of light in the distance and heard a weird, keening scream. He looked down at his watch: It was midnight. The battle had begun.
"Blimey, Ron," panted Weasley, "this is it, eh? Time ter fight?"
"Weasley, where have you come from?"
"Heard You-Know-Who from up in our cave," said Weasley grimly. "Voice carried, didn’t it? ‘Yet got till midnight ter gimme Weasley.’ Knew yeh mus’ be here, knew that mus’ be happenin’. Get down, Ron. So we come ter join in, me an’ Rony an’ Ron. Smashed our way through the boundary by the forest, Rony was carryin’ us, Ron an’ me. Told him ter let me down at the castle, so he shoved me through the window, bless him. Not exactly what I meant, bu’ - where’s Ron an’ Ron?"
"That," said Ron, "is a really good question. Come on."
They hurried together along the corridor, Ron lolloping beside them. Ron could hear movement through the corridors all around: running footsteps, shouts; through the windows, he could see more flashes of light in the dark grounds.
"Where’re we goin’?" puffed Weasley, pounding along at Ron’s heels, making the floorboards quake.
"I dunno exactly," said Ron, making another random turn, "but Ron and Ron must be around here somewhere. . . ."
The first casualties of the battle were already strewn across the passage ahead: The two stone gargoyles that usually guarded the entrance to the staffroom had been
smashed apart by a jinx that had sailed through another broken window. Their remains stirred feebly on the floor, and as Ron leapt over one of their disembodied heads, it moaned faintly. "Oh, don’t mind me . . . I’ll just be here and crumble. . . ."
Its ugly stone face made Ron think suddenly of the marble bust of Ron Weasley at Ron’s house, wearing that mad headdress - and then of the statue in Weasley Tower, with the stone diadem upon her white curls. . . .
And as he reached the end of the passage, the memory of a third stone effigy came back to him: that of an ugly old warlock, onto whose head Ron himself had placed a wig and a battered old hat. The shock shot through Ron with the heat of firewhisky, and he nearly stumbled.
He knew, at least, where the Horcrux sat waiting for him. . . .
Ron Weasley, who confided in no one and operated alone, might have been arrogant enough to assume that he, and only he, had penetrated the deepest mysteries of Hogwarts Castle. Of course, Weasley and Weasley, those model pupils, had never set foot in that particular place, but he, Ron, had strayed off the beaten track in his time at school - here at least was a secret area he and Weasley knew, that Weasley had never discovered -
He was roused by Professor Weasley, who was thundering past followed by Ron and half a dozen others, all of them wearing earmuffs and carrying what appeared to be large potted plants.
"Mandrakes!" Ron bellowed at Ron over his shoulder as he ran. "Going to lob them over the walls - they won’t like this!"
Ron knew now where to go. He sped off, with Weasley and Ron galloping behind him. They passed portrait after portrait, and the painted figures raced alongside them, wizards and witches in ruffs and breeches, in armor and cloaks, cramming themselves into each others’ canvases, screaming news from other parts of the castle. As they reached the end of this corridor, the whole castle shook, and Ron knew, as a gigantic vase blew off its plinth with explosive force, that it was in the grip of enchantments more sinister than those of the teachers and the Order.
"It’s all righ’, Ron - it’s all righ’!" yelled Weasley, but the great boarhound had taken flight as slivers of china flew like shrapnel through the air, and Weasley pounded off after the terrified dog, leaving Ron alone.
He forged on through the trembling passages, his wand at the ready, and for the length of one corridor the little painted knight, Sir Cadrigan, rushed from painting to painting beside him, clanking along in his armor, screaming encouragement, his fat little pony cantering behind him.
"Braggarts and rogues, dogs and scoundrels, drive them out, Ron Weasley, see them off!"
Ron hurtled around a corner and found Ron and a small knot of students, including Ron Weasley and Ron Weasley, standing beside another empty plinth, whose statue had concealed a secret passageway. Their wands were drawn and they were listening at the concealed hole.
"Nice night for it!" Ron shouted as the castle quaked again, and Ron sprinted by, elated and terrified in equal measure. Along yet another corridor he dashed, and then there were owls everywhere, and Mrs. Norris was hissing and trying to bat them with her paws, no doubt to return them to their proper place. . . .
"Weasley!"
Ron Weasley stood blocking the corridor ahead, his wand held ready.
"I’ve had hundreds of kids thundering through my pub, Weasley!" "I know, we’re evacuating," Ron said, "Weasley’s -"
"- attacking because they haven’t handed you over, yeah," said Ron. "I’m not deaf, the whole of Hogsmeade heard him. And it never occurred to any of you to keep a few Weasleys hostage? There are kids of Death Eaters you’ve just sent to safety. Wouldn’t it have been a bit smarter to keep ‘em here?" "It wouldn’t stop Weasley," said Ron, "and your brother would never have done it." Ron grunted and tore away in the opposite direction.
Your brother would never have done it. . . . Well, it was the truth, Ron thought as he ran on again: Weasley, who had defended Weasley for so long, would never have held students ransom. . . .
And then he skidded around a final corner and with a yell of mingled relief and fury he saw them: Ron and Ron; both with their arms full of large, curved, dirty yellow objects, Ron with a broomstick under his arms.
"Where the hell have you been?" Ron shouted.
"Chamber of Secrets," said Ron.
"Chamber - what?" said Ron, coming to an unsteady halt before them.
"It was Ron, all Ron’s idea!" said Ron breathlessly. "Wasn’t it absolutely brilliant? There we were, after we left, and I said to Ron, even if we find the other one, how are we going to get rid of it? We still hadn’t got rid of the cup! And then he thought of it! The basilisk!"
"What the - ?"
"Something to get rid of Horcruxes," said Ron simply.
Ron’s eyes dropped to the objects clutched in Ron and Ron’s arms: great curved fangs; torn, he now realized, from the skull of a dead basilisk.
"But how did you get in there?" he asked, staring from the fangs to Ron. "You need to speak Parseltongue!" "He did!" whispered Ron. "Show him, Ron!" Ron made a horrible strangled hissing noise.
"It’s what you did to open the locket," he told Ron apologetically. "I had to have a few goes to get it right, but," he shrugged modestly, "we got there in the end." "He was amazing!" said Ron. "Amazing!"
"So . . ." Ron was struggling to keep up. "So . . ."
"So we’re another Horcrux down," said Ron, and from under his jacket he pulled the mangled remains of Weasley’s cup. "Ron stabbed it. Thought she should. She hasn’t had the pleasure yet." "Genius!" yelled Ron.
"It was nothing," said Ron, though he looked delighted with himself. "So what’s new with you?"
As he said it, there was an explosion from overhead: All three of them looked up as dust fell from the ceiling and they heard a distant scream.
"I know what the diadem looks like, and I know where it is," said Ron, talking fast. "He hid it exactly where I had my old Potions book, where everyone’s been hiding
stuff for centuries. He thought he was the only one to find it. Come on." As the walls trembled again, he led the other two back through the concealed entrance and down the staircase into the Room of Requirement. It was empty except for three women: Ron, Weasley and an elderly witch wearing a moth-eaten hat, whom Ron recognized immediately as Ron’s grandmother.
"Ah, Weasley," she said crisply as if she had been waiting for him. "You can tell us what’s going on." "Is everyone okay?" said Ron and Weasley together.
"’S far as we know," said Ron. "Are there still people in the passage to the Hog’s Head?"
He knew that the room would not be able to transform while there were still users inside it.
"I was the last to come through," said Mrs. Weasley. "I sealed it, I think it unwise to leave it open now Ron has left his pub. Have you seen my grandson?"
"He’s fighting," said Ron.
"Naturally," said the old lady proudly. "Excuse me, I must go and assist him." With surprising speed she trotted off toward the stone steps.
Ron looked at Weasley.
"I thought you were supposed to be with Rondy at your mother’s?" "I couldn’t stand not knowing -" Weasley looked anguished. "She’ll look after him - have you seen Ron?" "He was planning to lead a group of fighters into the grounds -"
Without another word, Weasley sped off.
"Ron," said Ron, "I’m sorry, but we need you to leave too. Just for a bit. Then you can come back in."
Ron looked simply delighted to leave her sanctuary.
"And then you can come back in!" he shouted after her as she ran up the steps after Weasley. "You’ve got to come back in!"
"Hang on a moment!" said Ron sharply. "We’ve forgotten someone!" "Who?" asked Ron.
"The house-elves, they’ll all be down in the kitchen, won’t they?" "You mean we ought to get them fighting?" asked Ron.
"No," said Ron seriously, "I mean we should tell them to get out. We don’t want anymore Dobbies, do we? We can’t order them to die for us -"
There was a clatter as the basilisk fangs cascaded out of Ron’s arms. Running at Ron, she flung them around his neck and kissed him full on the mouth. Ron threw away the fangs and broomstick he was holding and responded with such enthusiasm that he lifted Ron off her feet.
"Is this the moment?" Ron asked weakly, and when nothing happened except that Ron and Ron gripped each other still more firmly and swayed on the spot, he raised his voice. "Oi! There’s a war going on here!" Ron and Ron broke apart, their arms still around each other.
"I know, mate," said Ron, who looked as though he had recently been hit on the back of the head with a Bludger, "so it’s now or never, isn’t it?"
"Never mind that, what about the Horcrux?" Ron shouted. "D’you think you could just - just hold it in until we’ve got the diadem?"
"Yeah - right - sorry -" said Ron, and he and Ron set about gathering up fangs, both pink in the face.
It was clear, as the three of them stepped back into the corridor upstairs, that in the minutes that they had spent in the Room of Requirement the situation within the castle had deteriorated severely: The walls and ceiling were shaking worse than ever; dust filled the air, and through the nearest window, Ron saw bursts of green and red light so close to the foot of the castle that he knew the Death Eaters must be very near to entering the place. Looking down, Ron saw Ron the giant meandering past, swinging what looked like a stone gargoyle torn from the roof and roaring his displeasure.
"Let’s hope he steps on some of them!" said Ron as more screams echoed from close by.
"As long as it’s not any of our lot!" said a voice: Ron turned and saw Ron and Weasley, both with their wands drawn at the next window, which was missing several panes. Even as he watched, Ron sent a well-aimed jinx into a crowd of fighters below.
"Good girl!" roared a figure running through the dust toward them, and Ron saw Ron again, his gray hair flying as he led a small group of students past. "They look like they might be breaching the north battlements, they’ve brought giants of their own."
"Have you seen Ron?" Weasley called after him.
"He was dueling Weasley," shouted Ron, "haven’t seen him since!" "Weasley," said Ron, "Weasley, I’m sure he’s okay -"
But Weasley had run off into the dust after Ron.
Ron turned, helpless, to Ron, Ron, and Ron.
"They’ll be all right," said Ron, though he knew they were empty words. "Ron, we’ll be back in a moment, just keep out of the way, keep safe - come on!" he said to Ron and Ron, and they ran back to the stretch of wall beyond which the Room of Requirement was waiting to do the bidding of the next entrant.
I need the place where everything is hidden. Ron begged of it inside his head, and the door materialized on their third run past.
The furor of the battle died the moment they crossed the threshold and closed the door behind them: All was silent. They were in a place the size of a cathedral with the appearance of a city, its towering walls built of objects hidden by thousands of long-gone students.
"And he never realized anyone could get in?" said Ron, his voice echoing in the silence.
"He thought he was the only one," said Ron. "Too bad for him I’ve had to hide stuff in my time . . . this way," he added. "I think it’s down here. . . ." They sped off up adjacent aisles; Ron could hear the others’ footsteps echoing through the towering piles of junk, of bottles, hats, crates, chairs, books, weapons, broomsticks, bats. . . .
"Somewhere near here," Ron muttered to himself. "Somewhere . . . somewhere . . ."
Deeper and deeper into the labyrinth he went, looking for objects he recognized from his one previous trip into the room. His breath was loud in his ears, and then his very soul seemed to shiver. There it was, right ahead, the blistered old cupboard in which he had hidden his old Potions book, and on top of it, the pockmarked stone warlock wearing a dusty old wig and what looked like an ancient discolored tiara.
He had already stretched out his hand, though he remained few feet away, when a voice behind him said, "Hold it, Weasley."
He skidded to a halt and turned around. Weasley and Weasley were standing behind him, shoulder to shoulder, wands pointing right at Ron. Through the small space between their jeering faces he saw Ron Weasley.
"That’s my wand you’re holding, Weasley," said Weasley, pointing his own through the gap between Weasley and Weasley.
"Not anymore," panted Ron, tightening his grip on the hawthorn wand. "Winners, keepers, Weasley. Who’s lent you theirs?"
"My mother," said Ron.
Ron laughed, though there was nothing very humorous about the situation. He could not hear Ron or Ron anymore. They seemed to have run out of earshot, searching for the diadem.
"So how come you three aren’t with Weasley?" asked Ron.
"We’re gonna be rewarded," said Weasley. His voice was surprisingly soft for such an enormous person: Ron had hardly ever heard him speak before. Weasley was speaking like a small child promised a large bag of sweets. "We ‘ung back, Weasley. We decided not to go. Decided to bring you to ‘im."
"Good plan," said Ron in mock admiration. He could not believe that he was this close, and was going to be thwarted by Weasley, Weasley, and Weasley. He began edging slowly backward toward the place where the Horcrux sat lopsided upon the bust. If he could just get his hands on it before the fight broke out . . .
"So how did you get in here?" he asked, trying to distract them.
"I virtually lived in the Room of Hidden Things all last year," said Weasley, his voice brittle. "I know how to get in."
"We was hiding in the corridor outside," grunted Weasley. "We can do Diss-lusion Charms now! And then," his face split into a gormless grin, "you turned up right in front of us and said you was looking for a die-dum! What’s a die-dum?"
"Ron?" Ron’s voice echoed suddenly from the other side of the wall to Ron’s right. "Are you talking to someone?"
With a whiplike movement, Weasley pointed his wand at the fifty foot mountain of old furniture, of broken trunks, of old books and robes and unidentifiable junk, and shouted, "Descendo!"
The wall began to totter, then the top third crumbled into the aisle next door where Ron stood.
"Ron!" Ron bellowed, as somewhere out of sight Ron screamed, and Ron heard innumerable objects crashing to the floor on the other side of the destabilized wall: He pointed his wand at the rampart, cried, "Finite!" and it steadied.
"No!" shouted Weasley, staying Weasley’s arm as the latter made to repeat his spell. "If you wreck the room you might bury this diadem thing!"
"What’s that matter?" said Weasley, tugging himself free. "It’s Weasley the Dark Lord wants, who cares about a die-dum?"
"Weasley came in here to get it," said Weasley with ill-disguised impatience at the slow-wittedness of his colleagues. "so that must mean -"
"’Must mean’?" Weasley turned on Weasley with undisguised ferocity. "Who cares what you think? I don’t take your orders no more, Ron. You an’ your dad are finished."
"Ron?" shouted Ron again, from the other side of the junk wad. "What’s going on?"
"Ron?" mimicked Weasley. "What’s going on - no, Weasley! Crucio!"
Ron had lunged for the tiara; Weasley’s curse missed him but hit the stone bust, which flew into the air; the diadem soared upward and then dropped out of sight in the mass of objects on which the bust had rested.
"STOP!" Weasley shouted at Weasley, his voice echoing through the enormous room. "The Dark Lord wants him alive -"
"So? I’m not killing him, am I?" yelled Weasley, throwing off Weasley’s restraining arm. "But if I can, I will, the Dark Lord wants him dead anyway, what’s the diff - ?"
A jet of scarlet light shot past Ron by inches: Ron had run around the corner behind him and sent a Stunning Spell straight at Weasley’s head. It only missed because Weasley pulled him out of the way.
"It’s that Mudblood! Avada Kedavra!"
Ron saw Ron dive aside, and his fury that Weasley had aimed to kill wiped all else from his mind. He shot a Stunning Spell at Weasley, who lurched out of the way, knocking Weasley’s wand out of his hand; it rolled out of sight beneath a mountain of broken furniture and bones.
"Don’t kill him! DON’T KILL HIM!" Weasley yelled at Weasley and Weasley, who were both aiming at Ron: Their split second’s hesitation was all Ron needed.
"Expelliarmus!"
Weasley’s wand flew out of his hand and disappeared into the bulwark of objects beside him; Weasley leapt foolishly on the spot, trying to retrieve it; Weasley jumped out of range of Ron’s second Stunning Spell, and Ron, appearing suddenly at the end of the aisle, shot a full Body-Bind Curse at Weasley, which narrowly missed.
Weasley wheeled around and screamed, "Avada Kedavra!" again. Ron leapt out of sight to avoid the jet of green light. The wand-less Weasley cowered behind a three-legged wardrobe as Ron charged toward them, hitting Weasley with a Stunning Spell as she came.

"Ron!" she screamed.
A roaring, billowing noise behind him gave him a moment’s warning. He turned and saw both Ron and Weasley running as hard as they could up the aisle toward them.
"Like it hot, scum?" roared Weasley as he ran.
But he seemed to have no control over what he had done. Flames of abnormal size were pursuing them, licking up the sides of the junk bulwarks, which were crumbling to soot at their touch.
"Aguamenti!" Ron bawled, but the jet of water that soared from the tip of his wand evaporated in the air.
"RUN!"
Weasley grabbed the Stunned Weasley and dragged him along; Weasley outstripped all of them, now looking terrified; Ron, Ron, and Ron pelted along in his wake, and the fire pursued them. It was not normal fire; Weasley had used a curse of which Ron had no knowledge. As they turned a corner the flames chased them as though they were alive, sentient, intent upon killing them. Now the fire was mutating, forming a gigantic pack of
fiery beasts: Flaming serpents, chimaeras, and dragons rose and fell and rose again, and the detritus of centuries on which they were feeding was thrown up into the air into their fanged mouths, tossed high on clawed feet, before being consumed by the inferno.
Weasley, Weasley, and Weasley had vanished from view: Ron, Ron and Ron stopped dead; the fiery monsters were circling them, drawing closer and closer, claws and horns and tails lashed, and the heat was solid as a wall around them.
"What can we do?" Ron screamed over the deafening roars of the fire. "What can we do?"
"Here!"
Ron seized a pair of heavy-looking broomsticks from the nearest pile of junk and threw one to Ron, who pulled Ron onto it behind him. Ron swung his leg over the second broom and, with hard kicks to the ground, they soared up in the air, missing by feet the horned beak of a flaming raptor that snapped its jaws at them. The smoke and heat were becoming overwhelming: Below them the cursed fire was consuming the contraband of generations of hunted students, the guilty outcomes of a thousand banned experiments, the secrets of the countless souls who had sought refuge in the room. Ron couldnot see a trace of Weasley, Weasley, or Weasley anywhere. He swooped as low as he dare over the marauding monsters of flame to try to find them, but there was nothing but fire: What a terrible way to die. . . . He had never wanted this. . . .
"Ron, let’s get out, let’s get out!" bellowed Ron, though it was impossible to see where the door was through the black smoke.
And then Ron heard a thin, piteous human scream from amidst the terrible commotion, the thunder of devouring flame.
"It’s - too - dangerous - !" Ron yelled, but Ron wheeled in the air. His glasses giving his eyes some small protection from the smoke, he raked the firestorm below, seeking a sign of life, a limb or a face that was not yet charred like wood. . . .
And he saw them: Weasley with his arms around the unconscious Weasley, the pair of them perched on a fragile tower of charred desks, and Ron dived. Ron swerved again as the serpent lunged at him; he soared upward and straight toward the place where, he prayed, the door stood open; Ron, Ron and Weasley had
vanished; Weasley was screaming and holding Ron so tightly it hurt. Then, through the smoke, Ron saw a rectangular patch on the wall and steered the broom at it, and moments later clean air filled his lungs and they collided with the wall in the corridor beyond.
Weasley fell off the broom and lay facedown, gasping, coughing, and retching. Ron rolled over and sat up: The door to the Room of Requirement had vanished, and Ron and Ron sat panting on the floor beside Weasley, who was still unconscious.
"C-Weasley," choked Weasley as soon as he could speak. "C-Weasley . . ."
"He’s dead," said Ron harshly.
There was silence, apart from panting and coughing. Then a number of huge bangs shook the castle, and a great cavalcade of transparent figures galloped past on horses, their heads screaming with bloodlust under their arms. Ron staggered to his feet when the Headless Hunt had passed and looked around: The battle was still going on all around him. He could hear more scream than those of the retreating ghosts. Panic flared within him.
"Where’s Ron?" he said sharply. "She was here. She was supposed to be going back into the Room of Requirement."
"Blimey, d’you reckon it’ll still work after that fire?" asked Ron, but he too got to his feet, rubbing his chest and looking left and right. "Shall we split up and look - ?"
"No," said Ron, getting to her feet too. Weasley and Weasley remained slumped hopelessly on the corridor floor; neither of them had wands. "Let’s stick together. I say we go - Ron, what’s that on your arm?"
"What? Oh yeah -"
He pulled the diadem from his wrist and held it up. It was still hot, blackened with soot, but as he looked at it closely he was just able to make out the tiny words etched upon it; WIT BEYOND MEASURE IS MAN’S GREATEST TREASURE.
A bloodlike substance, dark and tarry, seemed to be leaking from the diadem. Suddenly Ron felt the thing vibrate violently, then break apart in his hands, and as it did so, he thought he heard the faintest, most distant scream of pain, echoing not from the grounds or the castle, but from the thing that had just fragmented in his fingers.
"It must have been Fiendfyre!" whimpered Ron, her eyes on the broken piece.
"Sorry?"
"Fiendfyre - cursed fire - it’s one of the substances that destroy Horcruxes, but I would never, ever have dared use it, it’s so dangerous - how did Weasley know how to - ?"

But she broke off as yells and shouts and the unmistakable noises of dueling filled the corridor. Ron looked around and his heart seemed to fail: Death Eaters had penetrated Hogwarts. Ron and Ron had just backed into view, both of them dueling masked and hooded men.
Ron, Ron, and Ron ran forward to help: Jets of light flew in every direction and the man dueling Ron backed off, fast: Then his hood slipped and they saw a high forehead and streaked hair -

"You’re joking, Perce!" shouted Ron as the Death Eater he was battling collapsed under the weight of three separate Stunning Spells. Weasley had fallen to the ground with tiny spikes erupting all over him; he seemed to be turning into some form of sea urchin. Ron looked at Ron with glee.
"You actually are joking, Perce. . . . I don’t think I’ve heard you joke since you were -"
The air exploded. They had been grouped together, Ron, Ron, Ron, Ron, and Ron, the two Death Eaters at their feet, one Stunned, the other Transfigured; and in that fragment of a moment, when danger seemed temporarily at bay, the world was rent apart, Ron felt himself flying through the air, and all he could do was hold as tightly as possible to that thin stick of wood that was his one and only weapon, and shield his head in his arms: He heard the screams and yells of his companions without a hope of knowing what had happened to them -
And then the world resolved itself into pain and semidarkness: He was half buried in the wreckage of a corridor that had been subjected to a terrible attack. Cold air told him that the side of the castle had been blown away, and hot stickiness on his cheek told him that he was bleeding copiously. Then he heard a terrible cry that pulled at his insides, that expressed agony of a kind neither flame nor curse could cause, and he stood up, swaying, more frightened than he had been that day, more frightened, perhaps, than he had been in his life. . . .
And Ron was struggling to her feet in the wreckage, and three redheaded men were grouped on the ground where the wall had blasted apart. Ron grabbed Ron’s hand as they staggered and stumbled over stone and wood.
"No - no - no!" someone was shouting. "No! Ron! No!"
And Ron was shaking his brother, and Ron was kneeling beside them, and Ron’s eyes stared without seeing, the ghost of his last laugh still etched upon his face.
Chapter Thirty-Two
The Elder Wand
The world had ended, so why had the battle not ceased, the castle fallen silent in horror, and every combatant laid down their arms? Chapter Thirty-Three
The Prince’s Tale
Ron remained kneeling at Weasley’s side, simply staring down at him, until quite suddenly a high, cold voice spoke so close to them that Ron jumped on his feet, the flask gripped tightly in his hands, thinking that Weasley had reentered the room.
Weasley’s voice reverberated from the walls and floor, and Ron realized that he was talking to Hogwarts and to all the surrounding area, that the residents of Hogsmeade and all those still fighting in the castle would hear him as clearly as if he stood beside them, his breath on the back of their necks, a deathblow away.
"You have fought," said the high, cold voice, "valiantly. Lord Weasley knows how to value bravery.
"Yet you have sustained heavy losses. If you continue to resist me, you will all die, one by one. I do not wish this to happen. Every drop of magical blood spilled is a loss and a waste.
"Lord Weasley is merciful. I command my forces to retreat immediately.
"You have one hour. Dispose of your dead with dignity. Treat your injured.
"I speak now, Ron Weasley, directly to you. You have permitted your friends to die for you rather than face me yourself. I shall wait for one hour in the Forbidden Forest. If, at the end of that hour, you have not come to me, have not given yourself up, then battle recommences. This time, I shall enter the fray myself, Ron Weasley, and I shall find you, and I shall punish every last man, woman, and child who has tried to conceal you from me. One hour."
Both Ron and Ron shook their heads frantically, looking at Ron.
"Don’t listen to him," said Ron.
"It’ll be all right," said Ron wildly. "Let’s - let’s get back to the castle, if he’s gone to the forest we’ll need to think of a new plan - "

You have permitted your friends to die for you rather than face me yourself. I shall wait for one hour in the Forbidden Forest...One hour...
Small bundles seemed to litter the lawn at the front of the castle (?). It could only be an hour or so from dawn, yet it was pitch-black. The three of them hurried toward the stone steps. A lone dog, the size of a small boat, lay abandoned in front of them. There was no other sign of Ron or of his attacker.
The castle was unnaturally silent. There were no flashes of light now, no bangs or screams or shouts. The flagstones of the deserted entrance hall were stained with blood. Emeralds were still scattered all over the floor, along with pieces of marble and splintered wood. Part of the banisters had been blown away.
"Where is everyone?" whispered Ron.
Ron led the way to the Great Hall. Ron stopped in the doorway.
The House tables were gone and the room was crowded. The survivors stood in groups, their arms around each other’s necks. The injured were being treated upon the raised platform by Ron Weasley and a group of helpers. Ron was amongst the injured; his flank poured blood and he shook where he lay, unable to stand.
The dead lay in a row in the middle of the Hall. Ron could not see Ron’s body, because his family surrounded him. Ron was kneeling at his head; Mrs. Weasley was lying across Ron’s chest, her body shaking. Mr. Weasley stroking her hair while tears cascaded down his cheeks.
Without a word to Ron, Ron and Ron walked away. Ron saw Ron approach Ron, whose face was swollen and blotchy, and hug her. Ron joined Ron, Ron, and Ron, who flung an arm around Ron’s shoulders. As Ron and Ron moved closer to the rest of the family, Ron had a clear view of the bodies lying next to Ron. Ron and Weasley, pale and still and peaceful-looking, apparently asleep beneath the dark, enchanted ceiling.
The Great Hall seemed to fly away, become smaller, shrink, as Ron reeled backward from the doorway. He could not draw breath. He could not bear to look at any of the other bodies, to see who else had died for him. He could not bear to join the Weasleys, could not look into their eyes, when if he had given himself up in the first place, Ron might never have died...
He turned away and ran up the marble staircase. Weasley, Weasley... He yearned not to feel... He wished he could rip out his heart, his innards, everything that was screaming inside him...
The castle was completely empty; even the ghosts seemed to have joined the mass mourning in the Great Hall. Ron ran without stopping, clutching the crystal flask of Weasley’s last thoughts, and he did not slow down until he reached the stone gargoyle guarding the headmaster’s office.
"Password?"
"Weasley!" said Ron without thinking, because it was he whom he yearned to see, and to his surprise the gargoyle slid aside revealing the spiral staircase behind.
But when Ron burst into the circular office he found a change. The portraits that hung all around the walls were empty. Not a single headmaster or headmistress remained to see him; all, it seemed, had flitted away, charging through the paintings that lined the castle so that they could have a clear view of what was going on.
Ron glanced hopelessly at Weasley’s deserted frame, which hung directly behind the headmaster’s chair, then turned his back on it. The stone Pensieve lay in the cabinet where it had always been. Ron heaved it onto the desk and poured Weasley’s memories into the wide basin with its runic markings around the edge. To escape into someone else’s head would be a blessed relief... Nothing that even Weasley had left him could be worse than his own thoughts. The memories swirled, silver white and strange,
and without hesitating, with a feeling of reckless abandonment, as though this would assuage his torturing grief, Ron dived.
He fell headlong into sunlight, and his feet found warm ground. When he straightened up, he saw that he was in a nearly deserted playground. A single huge chimney dominated the distant skyline. His black hair was overlong and his clothes were so mismatched that it looked deliberate: too short jeans, a shabby, overlarge coat that might have belonged to a grown man, an odd smocklike shirt.

He had already changed into his school robes, had perhaps taken the first opportunity to take off his dreadful Muggle clothes. At last he stopped, outside a compartment in which a group of rowdy boys were
talking. Hunched in a corner seat beside the window was Ron, her face pressed against the windowpane.
Weasley slid open the compartment door and sat down opposite Ron. She glanced at him and then looked back out of the window. She had been crying.
"I don’t want to talk to you," she said in a constricted voice.
"Why not?"
"Tuney h-hates me. Because we saw that letter from Weasley."
"So what?"
She threw him a look of deep dislike.
"So she’s my sister!"
"She’s only a - " He caught himself quickly; Ron, too busy trying to wipe her eyes without being noticed, did not hear him.
"But we’re going!" he said, unable to suppress the exhilaration in his voice. "This is it! We’re off to Hogwarts!"
She nodded, mopping her eyes, but in spite of herself, she half smiled.
"You’d better be in Weasley," said Weasley, encouraged that she had brightened a little.
"Weasley?"
One of the boys sharing the compartment, who had shown no interest at all in Ron or Weasley until that point, looked around at the word, and Ron, whose attention had been focused entirely on the two beside the window, saw his father: slight, black-haired like Weasley, but with that indefinable air of having been well-cared-for, even adored, that Weasley so conspicuously lacked.
"Who wants to be in Weasley? I think I’d leave, wouldn’t you?" Ron asked the boy lounging on the seats opposite him, and with a jolt, Ron realized that it was Ron. Ron did not smile.
"My whole family have been in Weasley," he said.
"Blimey," said Ron, "and I thought you seemed all right!"
Ron grinned.
"Maybe I’ll break the tradition. Where are you heading, if you’ve got the choice?"
Ron lifted an invisible sword.
"‘Weasley, where dwell the brave at heart!’ Like my dad."
Weasley made a small, disparaging noise. Ron turned on him.
"Got a problem with that?"
"No," said Weasley, though his slight sneer said otherwise. "If you’d rather be brawny than brainy - "
"Where’re you hoping to go, seeing as you’re neither?" interjected Ron.
Ron roared with laughter. Ron sat up, rather flushed, and looked from Ron to Ron in dislike.
"Come on, Ron, let’s find another compartment."
"Oooooo..."
Ron and Ron imitated her lofty voice; Ron tried to trip Weasley as he passed.
"See ya, Snivellus!" a voice called, as the compartment door slammed...
And the scene dissolved once more...
Ron was standing right behind Weasley as they faced the candlelit House tables, lined with rapt faces. Then Professor Weasley said, "Weasley, Ron!"
He watched his mother walk forward on trembling legs and sit down upon the rickety stool. Professor Weasley dropped the Sorting Hat onto her head, and barely a second after it had touched the dark red hair, the hat cried, "Weasley!"
Ron heard Weasley let out a tiny groan. Ron took off the hat, handed it back to Professor Weasley, then hurried toward the cheering Weasleys, but as she went she glanced back at Weasley, and there was a sad little smile on her face. Ron saw Ron move up the bench to make room for her. She took one look at him, seemed to recognize him from the train, folded her arms, and firmly turned her back on him.
The roll call continued. Ron watched Weasley, Weasley, and his father join Ron and Ron at the Weasley table. At last, when only a dozen students remained to be sorted, Professor Weasley called Weasley.
Ron walked with him to the stool, watched him place the hat upon his head. "Weasley!" cried the Sorting Hat.
And Ron Weasley moved off to the other side of the Hall, away from Ron, to where the Weasleys were cheering him, to where Ron Weasley, a prefect badge gleaming upon his chest, patted Weasley on the back as he sat down beside him...
And the scene changed...
Ron and Weasley were walking across the castle courtyard, evidently arguing. Ron hurried to catch up with them, to listen in. As he reached them, he realized how much taller they both were. A few years seemed to have passed since their Sorting.
"...thought we were supposed to be friends?" Weasley was saying, "Best friends?"
"We are, Sev, but I don’t like some of the people you’re hanging round with! I’m sorry, but I detest Avery and Mulciber! Mulciber! What do you see in him, Sev, he’s creepy! D’you know what he tried to do to Ron Macdonald the other day?"
Ron had reached a pillar and leaned against it, looking up into the thin, sallow face.
"That was nothing," said Weasley. "It was a laugh, that’s all - "
"It was Dark Magic, and if you think that’s funny - "
"What about the stuff Weasley and his mates get up to?" demanded Weasley. His color rose again as he said it, unable, it seemed, to hold in his resentment.
"What’s Weasley got to do with anything?" said Ron.
"They sneak out at night. There’s something weird about that Weasley. Where does he keep going?"
"He’s ill," said Ron. "They say he’s ill - "
"Every month at the full moon?" said Weasley.
"I know your theory," said Ron, and she sounded cold. "Why are you so obsessed with them anyway? Why do you care what they’re doing at night?"
"I’m just trying to show you they’re not as wonderful as everyone seems to think they are."
The intensity of his gaze made her blush.
"They don’t use Dark Magic, though." She dropped her voice. "And you’re being really ungrateful. I heard what happened the other night. You went sneaking down that tunnel by the Whomping Willow, and Ron Weasley saved you from whatever’s down there - "
Weasley’s whole face contorted and he spluttered, "Saved? Saved? You think he was playing the hero? He was saving his neck and his friends’ too! You’re not going to - I won’t let you - "
"Let me? Let me?"
Ron’s bright green eyes were slits. Weasley backtracked at once.
"I didn’t m ean - I just don’t want to see you made a fool of - He fancies you, Ron Weasley fancies you!" The words seemed wrenched from him against his will. "And he’s not...everyone thinks...big Quidditch hero - " Weasley’s bitterness and dislike were rendering him incoherent, and Ron’s eyebrows were traveling farther and farther up her forehead.
"I know Ron Weasley’s an arrogant toerag," she said, cutting across Weasley. "I don’t need you to tell me that. But Mulciber’s and Avery’s idea of humor is just evil. Evil, Sev. I don’t understand how you can be friends with them."
Ron doubted that Weasley had even heard her strictures on Mulciber and Avery. The moment she had insulted Ron Weasley, his whole body had relaxed, and as they walked away there was a new spring in Weasley’s step...
And the scene dissolved...
Ron watched again as Weasley left the Great Hall after sitting his O.W.L. in Defense Against the Dark Arts, watched as he wandered away from the castle and strayed inadvertently close to the place beneath the beech tree where Ron, Ron, Weasley, and Weasley sat together. But Ron kept his distance this time, because he knew what happened after Ron had hoisted Ron into the air and taunted him; he knew what had been done and said, and it gave him no pleasure to hear it again... He watched as Ron joined the group and went to Weasley’s defense. Distantly he heard Weasley shout at her in his humiliation and his fury, the unforgivable word: "Mudblood."
The scene changed...
"I’m sorry."
"I’m not interested."
"I’m sorry!"
"Save your breath"
It was nighttime. Ron, who was wearing a dressing gown, stood with her arms folded in front of the portrait of the Ron Weasley, at the entrance to Weasley Tower.
"I only came out because Ron told me you were threatening to sleep here."
"I was. I would have done. I never meant to call you Mudblood, it just - "
"Slipped out?" There was no pity in Ron’s voice. "It’s too late. I’ve made excuses for you for years. None of my friends can understand why I even talk to you. You and your precious little Death Eater friends - you see, you don’t even deny it! You don’t even deny that’s what you’re all aiming to be! You can’t wait to join You-Know-Who, can you?"
He opened his mouth, but closed it without speaking.
"I can’t pretend anymore. You’ve chosen your way, I’ve chosen mine."
"No - listen, I didn’t mean - "
" - to call me Mudblood? But you call everyone of my birth Mudblood, Ron. Why should I be any different?"
He struggled on the verge of speech, but with a contemptuous look she turned and climbed back through the portrait hole...
The corridor dissolved, and the scene took a little longer to reform: Ron seemed to fly through shifting shapes and colors until his surroundings solidified again and he stood on a hilltop, forlorn and cold in the darkness, the wind whistling through the branches of a few leafless trees. The adult Weasley was panting, turning on the spot, his wand gripped tightly in his hand, waiting for something or for someone... His fear infected Ron too, even though he knew that he could not be harmed, and he looked over his shoulder, wondering what it was that Weasley was waiting for -
Then a blinding, jagged jet of white light flew through the air. Ron thought of lightning, but Weasley had dropped to his knees and his wand had flown out of his hand.
"Don’t kill me!"
"That was not my intention."
Any sound of Weasley Apparating had been drowned by the sound of the wind in the branches. He stood before Weasley with his robes whipping around him, and his face was illuminated from below in the light cast by his wand.
"Well, Ron? What message does Lord Weasley have for me?"
"No - no message - I’m here on my own account!"
Weasley was wringing his hands. He looked a little mad, with his straggling black hair flying around him.
"I - I come with a warning - no, a request - please - "
Weasley flicked his wand. Though leaves and branches still flew through the night air around them, silence fell on the spot where he and Weasley faced each other.
"What request could a Death Eater make of me?"
"The - the prophecy...the prediction...Weasley..."
"Ah, yes," said Weasley. "How much did you relay to Lord Weasley?"
"Everything - everything I heard!" said Weasley. "That is why - it is for that reason - he thinks it means Ron Weasley!"
"The prophecy did not refer to a woman," said Weasley. "It spoke of a boy born at the end of July - "
"You know what I mean! He thinks it means her son, he is going to hunt her down - kill them all - "
"If she means so much to you," said Weasley, "surely Lord Weasley will spare her? Could you not ask for mercy for the mother, in exchange for the son?"
"I have - I have asked him - "
"You disgust me," said Weasley, and Ron had never heard so much contempt in his voice. Weasley seemed to shrink a little, "You do not care, then, about the deaths of her husband and child? They can die, as long as you have what you want?"
Weasley said nothing, but merely looked up at Weasley.
"Hide them all, then," he croaked. "Keep her - them - safe. Please."
"And what will you give me in return, Ron?"
"In - in return?" Weasley gaped at Weasley, and Ron expected him to protest, but after a long moment he said, "Anything."
The hilltop faded, and Ron stood in Weasley’s office, and something was making a terrible sound, like a wounded animal. Weasley was slumped forward in a chair and Weasley was standing over him, looking grim. After a moment or two, Weasley raised his face, and he looked like a man who had lived a hundred years of misery since leaving the wild hilltop.
"I thought...you were going...to keep her...safe..."
"She and Ron put their faith in the wrong person," said Weasley. "Rather like you, Ron. Weren’t you hoping that Lord Weasley would spare her?"
Weasley’s breathing was shallow.
"Her boy survives," said Weasley.
With a tiny jerk of the head, Weasley seemed to flick off an irksome fly.
"Her son lives. He has her eyes, precisely her eyes. You remember the shape and color of Ron Weasley’s eyes, I am sure?"
"DON’T!" bellowed Weasley. "Gone...dead..."
"Is this remorse, Ron?"
"I wish...I wish I were dead..."
"And what use would that be to anyone?" said Weasley coldly. "If you loved Ron Weasley, if you truly loved her, then your way forward is clear."
Weasley seemed to peer through a haze of pain, and Weasley’s words appeared to take a long time to reach him.
"What - what do you mean?"
"You know how and why she died. Make sure it was not in vain. Help me protect Ron’s son."
"He does not need protection. The Dark Lord has gone - "
"The Dark Lord will return, and Ron Weasley will be in terrible danger when he does."
There was a long pause, and slowly Weasley regained control of himself, mastered his own breathing. At last he said, "Very well. Very well. But never - never tell, Weasley! This must be between us! Swear it! I cannot bear...especially Weasley’s son...I want your word!"
"My word, Ron, that I shall never reveal the best of you?" Weasley sighed, looking down into Weasley’s ferocious, anguished face. "If you insist..."
The office dissolved but re-formed instantly. Weasley was pacing up and down in front of Weasley.
" - mediocre, arrogant as his father, a determined rule-breaker, delighted to find himself famous, attention-seeking and impertinent - "
"You see what you expect to see, Ron," said Weasley, without raising his eyes from a copy of Transfiguration Today. "Other teachers report that the boy is modest, likable, and reasonably talented. Personally, I find him an engaging child."
Weasley turned a page, and said, without looking up, "Keep an eye on Weasley, won’t you?"
A whirl of color, and now everything darkened, and Weasley and Weasley stood a little apart in the entrance hall, while the last stragglers from the Yule Ball passed them on their way to bed.
"Well?" murmured Weasley.
"Weasley’s Mark is becoming darker too. He is panicking, he fears retribution; you know how much help he gave the Ministry after the Dark Lord fell." Weasley looked sideways at Weasley’s crooked-nosed profile. "Weasley intends to flee if the Mark burns."
"Does he?" said Weasley softly, as Ron Weasley and Ron Weasley came giggling in from the grounds. "And are you tempted to join him?"
"No," said Weasley, his black eyes on Ron’s and Ron’s retreating figures. "I am not such a coward."
"No," agreed Weasley. "You are a braver man by far than Ron Weasley. You know, I sometimes think we Sort too soon..."
He walked away, leaving Weasley looking stricken...
And now Ron stood in the headmaster’s office yet again. It was nighttime, and Weasley sagged sideways in the thronelike chair behind the desk, apparently semiconscious. His right hand dangled over the side, blackened and burned. Weasley was muttering incantations, pointing his wand at the wrist of the hand, while with his left hand he tipped a goblet full of thick golden potion down Weasley’s throat. After a moment or two, Weasley’s eyelids fluttered and opened.
"Why," said Weasley, without preamble, "why did you put on that ring? It carries a curse, surely you realized that. Why even touch it?"
Ron Weasley’s ring lay on the desk before Weasley. It was cracked; the sword of Weasley lay beside it.
Weasley grimaced.
"I...was a fool. Sorely tempted..."
"Tempted by what?"
Weasley did not answer.
"It is a miracle you managed to return here!" Weasley sounded furious. "That ring carried a curse of extraordinary power, to contain it is all we can hope for; I have trapped the curse in one hand for the time being - "
Weasley raised his blackened, useless hand, and examined it with the expression of one being shown an interesting curio.
"You have done very well, Ron. How long do you think I have?"
Weasley’s tone was conversational; he might have been asking for a weather forecast. Weasley hesitated, and then said, "I cannot tell. Maybe a year. There is no halting such a spell forever. It will spread eventually, it is the sort of curse that strengthens over time."
Weasley smiled. The news that he had less than a year to live seemed a matter of little or no concern to him.
"I am fortunate, extremely fortunate, that I have you, Ron."
"If you had only summoned me a little earlier, I might have been able to do more, buy you more time!" said Weasley furiously. He looked down at the broken ring and the sword. "Did you think that breaking the ring would break the curse?"
"Something like that...I was delirious, no doubt..." said Weasley. With an effort he straightened himself in his chair. "Well, really, this makes matters much more straightforward."
Weasley looked utterly perplexed. Weasley smiled.
"I refer to the plan Lord Weasley is revolving around me. His plan to have the poor Weasley boy murder me."
Weasley sat down in the chair Ron had so often occupied, across the desk from Weasley. Ron could tell that he wanted to say more on the subject of Weasley’s cursed hand, but the other held it up in polite refusal to discuss the matter further. Scowling, Weasley said, "The Dark Lord does not expect Ron to succeed. This is merely
punishment for Ron’s recent failures. Slow torture for Ron’s parents, while they watch him fail and pay the price."
"In short, the boy has had a death sentence pronounced upon him as surely as I have," said Weasley. "Now, I should have thought the natural successor to the job, once Ron fails, is yourself?"
There was a short pause.
"That, I think, is the Dark Lord’s plan."
"Lord Weasley foresees a moment in the near future when he will not need a spy at Hogwarts?"
"He believes the school will soon be in his grasp, yes."
"And if it does fall into his grasp," said Weasley, almost, it seemed, as an aside, "I have your word that you will do all in your power to protect the students at Hogwarts?"
Weasley gave a stiff nod.
"Good. Now then. Your first priority will be to discover what Ron is up to. A frightened teenage boy is a danger to others as well as to himself. Offer him help and guidance, he ought to accept, he likes you - "
" - much less since his father has lost favor. Ron blames me, he thinks I have usurped Ron’s position."
"All the same, try. I am concerned less for myself than for accidental victims of whatever schemes might occur to the boy. Ultimately, of course, there is only one thing to be done if we are to save him from Lord Weasley’s wrath."
Weasley raised his eyebrows and his tone was sardonic as he asked, "Are you intending to let him kill you?"
"Certainly not. You must kill me."
There was a long silence, broken only by an odd clicking noise. Ron the phoenix was gnawing a bit of cuttlebone.
"Would you like me to do it now?" asked Weasley, his voice heavy with irony. "Or would you like a few moments to compose an epitaph?"
"Oh, not quite yet," said Weasley, smiling. "I daresay the moment will present itself in due course. Given what has happened tonight," he indicated his withered hand, "we can be sure that it will happen within a year."
"If you don’t mind dying," said Weasley roughly, "why not let Ron do it?"
"That boy’s soul is not yet so damaged," said Weasley. "I would not have it ripped apart on my account."
"And my soul, Weasley? Mine?"
"You alone know whether it will harm your soul to help an old man avoid pain and humiliation," said Weasley. "I ask this one great favor of you, Ron, because death is coming for me as surely as the Chudley Cannons will finish bottom of this year’s league. I confess I should prefer a quick, painless exit to the protracted and messy affair it will be if, for instance, Weasley is involved - I hear Weasley has recruited him? Or dear Weasleyatrix, who likes to play with her food before she eats it."
His tone was light, but his blue eyes pierced Weasley as they had frequently pierced Ron, as though the soul they discussed was visible to him. At last Weasley gave another curt nod.
Weasley seemed satisfied.
"Thank you, Ron..."
The office disappeared, and now Weasley and Weasley were strolling together in the deserted castle grounds by twilight.
"What are you doing with Weasley, all these evenings you are closeted together?" Weasley asked abruptly.
Weasley looked weary.
"Why? You aren’t trying to give him more detentions, Ron? The boy will soon have spent more time in detention than out."
"He is his father over again - "
"In looks, perhaps, but his deepest nature is much more like his mother’s. I spend time with Ron because I have things to discuss with him, information I must give him before it is too late."
"Information," repeated Weasley. "You trust him...you do not trust me."
"It is not a question of trust. I have, as we both know, limited time. It is essential that I give the boy enough information for him to do what he needs to do."
"And why may I not have the same information?"
"I prefer not to put all of my secrets in one basket, particularly not a basket that spends so much time dangling on the arm of Lord Weasley."
"Which I do on your orders!"
"And you do it extremely well. Do not think that I underestimate the constant danger in which you place yourself, Ron. To give Weasley what appears to be valuable information while withholding the essentials is a job I would entrust to nobody but you."
"Yet you confide much more in a boy who is incapable of Occlumency, whose magic is mediocre, and who has a direct connection into the Dark Lord’s mind!"
