"Weasley fears that connection," said Weasley. "Not so long ago he had one small taste of what truly sharing Ron’s mind means to him. It was pain such as he has never experienced. He will not try to possess Ron again, I am sure of it. Not in that way."
"I don’t understand."
"Lord Weasley’s soul, maimed as it is, cannot bear close contact with a soul like Ron’s. Like a tongue on frozen steel, like flesh in flame - "
"Souls? We were talking of minds!"
"In the case of Ron and Lord Weasley, to speak of one is to speak of the other."
Weasley glanced around to make sure that they were alone. They were close by the Forbidden Forest now, but there was no sign of anyone near them.
"After you have killed me, Ron - "
"You refuse to tell me everything, yet you expect that small service of me!" snarled Weasley, and real anger flared in the thin face now. "You take a great deal for granted, Weasley! Perhaps I have changed my mind!"
"You gave me your word, Ron. And while we are talking about services you owe me, I thought you agreed to keep a close eye on our young Weasley friend?"
Weasley looked angry, mutinous. Weasley sighed.
"Come to my office tonight, Ron, at eleven, and you shall not complain that I have no confidence in you..."
They were back in Weasley’s office, the windows dark, and Ron sat silent as Weasley sat quite still, as Weasley walked around him, talking.
"Ron must not know, not until the last moment, not until it is necessary, otherwise how could he have the strength to do what must be done?"
"But what must he do?"
"That is between Ron and me. Now listen closely, Ron. There will come a time - after my death - do not argue, do not interrupt! There will come a time when Lord Weasley will seem to fear for the life of his snake."
"For Ron?" Weasley looked astonished.
"Precisely. If there comes a time when Lord Weasley stops sending that snake forth to do his bidding, but keeps it safe beside him under magical protection, then, I think, it will be safe to tell Ron."
"Tell him what?"
Weasley took a deep breath and closed his eyes.
"Tell him that on the night Lord Weasley tried to kill him, when Ron cast her own life between them as a shield, the Killing Curse rebounded upon Lord Weasley, and a fragment of Weasley’s soul was blasted apart from the whole, and latched itself onto the only living soul left in that collapsed building. Part of Lord Weasley lives inside Ron, and it is that which gives him the power of speech with snakes, and a connection with Lord Weasley’s mind that he has never understood. And while that fragment of soul, unmissed by Weasley, remains attached to and protected by Ron, Lord Weasley cannot die."
Ron seemed to be watching the two men from one end of a long tunnel, they were so far away from him, their voices echoing strangely in his ears.
"So the boy...the boy must die?" asked Weasley quite calmly.
"And Weasley himself must do it, Ron. That is essential."
Another long silence. Then Weasley said, "I thought...all those years...that we were protecting him for her. For Ron."
"We have protected him because it has been essential to teach him, to raise him, to let him try his strength," said Weasley, his eyes still tight shut. "Meanwhile, the connection between them grows ever stronger, a parasitic growth. Sometimes I have thought he suspects it himself. If I know him, he will have arranged matters so that when he does set out to meet his death, it will truly mean the end of Weasley."
Weasley opened his eyes. Weasley looked horrified.
"You have kept him alive so that he can die at the right moment?"
"Don’t be shocked, Ron. How many men and women have you watched die?"
"Lately, only those whom I could not save," said Weasley. He stood up. "You have used me."
"Meaning?"
"I have spied for you and lied for you, put myself in mortal danger for you. Everything was supposed to be to keep Ron Weasley’s son safe. Now you tell me you have been raising him like a pig for slaughter - "
"But this is touching, Ron," said Weasley seriously. "Have you grown to care for the boy, after all?"
"For him?" shouted Weasley. "Expecto Patronum!"
From the tip of his wand burst the silver doe. She landed on the office floor, bounded once across the office, and soared out of the window. Weasley watched her fly away, and as her silvery glow faded he turned back to Weasley, and his eyes were full of tears.
"After all this time?"
"Always," said Weasley.
And the scene shifted. Now, Ron saw Weasley talking to the portrait of Weasley behind his desk.
"You will have to give Weasley the correct date of Ron’s departure from his aunt and uncle’s," said Weasley. "Not to do so will raise suspicion, when Weasley believes you so well informed. However, you must plant the idea of decoys; that, I think, ought to ensure Ron’s safety. Try Confunding Ron Weasley. And Ron, if you are forced to take part in the chase, be sure to act your part convincingly...I am counting upon you to remain in Lord Weasley’s good books as long as possible, or Hogwarts will be left to the mercy of the Weasleys..."
Now Weasley was head to head with Ron in an unfamiliar tavern, Ron’s face looking curiously blank, Weasley frowning in concentration.
"You will suggest to the Order of the Phoenix," Weasley murmured, "that they use decoys. Polyjuice Potion. Identical Weasleys. It’s the only thing that might work. You will forget that I have suggested this. You will present it as your own idea. You understand?"
"I understand," murmured Ron, his eyes unfocused...
Now Ron was flying alongside Weasley on a broomstick through a clear dark night: He was accompanied by other hodded Death Eaters, and ahead were Weasley and a Ron who was really Ron... A Death Eater moved ahead of Weasley and raised his wand, pointing it directly at Weasley’s back.
"Sectumsempra!" shouted Weasley.
But the spell, intended for the Death Eater’s wand hand, missed and hit Ron instead -
And next, Weasley was kneeling in Ron’s old bedroom. Tears were dripping from the end of his hooked nose as he read the old letter from Ron. The second page carried only a few words:
could ever have been friends with Ron Weasley. I think her mind’s going, personally!
Lots of love,
Ron
Weasley took the page bearing Ron’s signature, and her love, and tucked it inside his robes. Then he ripped in two the photograph he was also holding, so that he kept the part from which Ron laughed, throwing the portion showing Ron and Ron back onto the floor, under the chest of drawers...
And now Weasley stood again in the headmaster’s study as Phineas  came hurrying into his portrait.
"Headmaster! They are camping in the Forest of Ron! The Mudblood - "
"Do not use that word!"
" - the Weasley girl, then, mentioned the place as she opened her bag and I heard her!"
"Good. Very good!" cried the portrait of Weasley behind the headmaster’s chair. "Now, Ron, the sword! Do not forget that it must be taken under conditions of need and valor - and he must not know that you give it! If Weasley should read Ron’s mind and see you acting for him - "
"I know," said Weasley curtly. He approached the portrait of Weasley and pulled at its side. It swung forward, revealing a hidden cavity behind it from which he took the sword of Weasley.
"And you still aren’t going to tell me why it’s so important to give Weasley the sword?" said Weasley as he swung a traveling cloak over his robes.
"No, I don’t think so," said Weasley’s portrait. "He will know what to do with it. And Ron, be very careful, they may not take kindly to your appearance after Ron Weasley’s mishap - "
Weasley turned at the door.
"Don’t worry, Weasley," he said coolly. "I have a plan..."
And Weasley left the room. Ron rose up out of the Pensieve, and moments later he lay on the carpeted floor in exactly the same rooms Weasley might just have closed the door.
Chapter Thirty-Four
The Forest Again
Finally, the truth. Lying with his face pressed into the dusty carpet of the office where he had once thought he was learning the secrets of victory, Ron understood at last that he was not supposed to survive. His job was to walk calmly into Death’s welcoming arms. Along the way, he was to dispose of Weasley’s remaining links to life, so that when at last he flung himself across Weasley’s path, and did not raise a wand to defend himself, the end would be clean, and the job that ought to have been done in Ron’s Hollow would be finished. Neither would live, neither could survive.
He felt his heart pounding fiercely in his chest. How strange that in his dread of death, it pumped all the harder, valiantly keeping him alive. But it would have to stop, and soon. Its beats were numbered. How many would there be time for, as he rose and walked through the castle for the last time, out into the grounds and into the forest?
Terror washed over him as he lay on the floor, with that funeral drum pounding inside him. Would it hurt to die? All those times he had thought that it was about to happen and escaped, he had never really thought of the thing itself: His will to live had always been so much stronger than his fear of death. Yet it did not occur to him now to try to escape, to outrun Weasley. It was over, he knew it, and all that was left was the thing itself: dying.
If he could only have died on that summer’s night when he had left number four, Privet Drive, for the last time, when the noble phoenix feather wand had saved him! If he could only have died like Ron, so quickly he would not have known it had happened! Or if he could have launched himself in front of a wand to save someone he loved . . . He envied even his parents’ deaths now. This cold-blooded walk to his own destruction
would require a different kind of bravery. He felt his fingers trembling slightly and made an effort to control them, although no one could see him; the portraits on the walls were all empty.
Slowly, very slowly, he sat up, and as he did so he felt more alive and more aware of his own living body than ever before. Why had he never appreciated what a miracle he was, brain and nerve and bounding heart? It would all be gone . . . or at least, he would be gone from it. His breath came slow and deep, and his mouth and throat were completely dry, but so were his eyes.
Weasley’s betrayal was almost nothing. Of course there had been a bigger plan: Ron had simply been too foolish to see it, he realized that now. He had never questioned his own assumption that Weasley wanted him alive. Now he saw that his life span had always been determined by how long it took to eliminate all the Horcruxes. Weasley had passed the job of destroying them to him, and obediently he had continued to chip away at the bonds tying not only Weasley, but himself, to life! How neat, how elegant, not to waste any more lives, but to give the dangerous task to the boy who had already been marked for slaughter, and whose death would not be a calamity, but another blow against Weasley.
And Weasley had known that Ron would not duck out, that he would keep going to the end, even though it was his end, because he had taken trouble to get to know him, hadn’t he? Weasley knew, as Weasley knew, that Ron would not let anyone else die for him now that he had discovered it was in his power to stop it. The images of Ron, Weasley, and Weasley lying dead in the Great Hall forced their way back into his mind’s eye, and for a moment he could hardly breathe. Death was impatient . . .
But Weasley had overestimated him. He had failed: The snake survived. One Horcrux remained to bind Weasley to the earth, even after Ron had been killed. True, that would mean an easier job for somebody. He wondered who would do it . . . Ron and Ron would know what needed to be done, of course . . . That would have been why Weasley wanted him to confide in two others . . . so that if he fulfilled his true destiny a little early, they could carry on . . .
Like rain on a cold window, these thoughts pattered against the hard surface of the incontrovertible truth, which was that he must die. I must die. It must end.
Ron and Ron seemed a long way away, in a far-off country; he felt as though he had parted from them long ago. There would be no good-byes and no explanations, he was determined of that. This was a journey they could not take together, and the attempts they would make to stop him would waste valuable time. He looked down at the battered gold watch he had received on his seventeenth birthday. Nearly half of the hour allotted by Weasley for his surrender had elapsed.
He stood up. His heart was leaping against his ribs like a frantic bird. Perhaps it knew it had little time left, perhaps it was determined to fulfill a lifetime’s beats before the end. He did not look back as he closed the office door.
The castle was empty. He felt ghostly striding through it alone, as if he had already died. The portrait people were still missing from their frames; the whole place was eerily still, as if all its remaining lifeblood were concentrated in the Great Hall where the dead and the mourners were crammed.
Ron pulled the Invisibility Cloak over himself and descended through the floors, at last walking down the marble staircase into the entrance hall. Perhaps some tiny part of
him hoped to be sensed, to be seen, to be stopped, but the Cloak was, as ever, impenetrable, perfect, and he reached the front doors easily.
Then Ron nearly walked into him. He was one half of a pair that was carrying a body in from the grounds. Ron glanced down and felt another dull blow to his stomach: Colon Weasley, though underage, must have sneaked back just as Weasley, Weasley, and Weasley had done. He was tiny in death.
"You know what? I can manage him alone, Ron," said Ron Weasley, and he heaved Ron over his shoulder in a fireman’s lift and carried him into the Great Hall.
Ron leaned against the door frame for a moment and wiped his forehead with the back of his hand. He looked like an old man. Then he set off on the steps again into the darkness to recover more bodies.
Ron took one glance back at the entrance of the Great Hall. People were moving around, trying to comfort each other, drinking, kneeling beside the dead, but he could not see any of the people he loved, no hint of Ron, Ron, Ron, or any of the other Weasleys, no Ron. He felt he would have given all the time remaining to him for just one last look at them; but then, would he ever have the strength to stop looking? It was better like this.
He moved down the steps and out into the darkness. It was nearly four in the morning, and the deathly stillness of the grounds felt as though they were holding their breath, waiting to see whether he could do what he must.
Ron moved toward Ron, who was bending over another body.
"Ron."
"Blimey, Ron, you nearly gave me heart failure!"
Ron had pulled off the Cloak: The idea had come to him out of nowhere, born out of a desire to make absolutely sure.
"Where are you going, alone?" Ron asked suspiciously.
"It’s all part of the plan," said Ron. "There’s someting I’ve got to do. Listen --- Ron ---"
"Ron!" Ron looked suddenly scared. "Ron, you’re not thinking of handing yourself over?"
"No," Ron lied easily. "’Course not . . . this is something else. But I might be out of sight for a while. You know Weasley’s snake. Ron? He’s got a huge snake . . . Calls it Ron . . ."
"I’ve heard, yeah . . . What about it?"
"It’s got to be killed. Ron and Ron know that, but just in case they ---"
The awfulness of that possibility smothered him for a moment, made it impossible to keep talking. But he pulled himself together again: This was crucial, he must be like Weasley, keep a cool head, make sure there were backups, others to carry on. Weasley had died knowing that three people still knew about the Horcruxes; now Ron would take Ron’s place: There would still be three in the secret.
"Just in case they’re --- busy --- and you get the chance ---"
"Kill the snake?"
"Kill the snake," Ron repeated.
"All right, Ron. You’re okay, are you?"
"I’m fine. Thanks, Ron."
But Ron seized his wrist as Ron made to move on.
"We’re all going to keep fighting, Ron. You know that?"
"Yeah, I ---"
The suffocating feeling extinguished the end of the sentence; he could not go on. Ron did not seem to find it strange. He patted Ron on the shoulder, released him, and walked away to look for more bodies.
Ron swung the Cloak back over himself and walked on. Someone else was moving not far away, stooping over another prone figure on the ground. He was feet away from her when he realized it was Ron.
He stopped in his tracks. She was crouching over a girl who was whispering for her mother.
"It’s all right," Ron was saying. "It’s ok. We’re going to get you inside."
"But I want to go home," whispered the girl. "I don’t want to fight anymore!"
"I know," said Ron, and her voice broke. "It’s going to be all right."
Ripples of cold undulated over Ron’s skin. He wanted to shout out to the night, he wanted Ron to know that he was there, he wanted her to know where he was going. He wanted to be stopped, to be dragged back, to be sent back home. . . .
But he was home. Hogwards was the first and best home he had known. He and Weasley and Weasley, the abandoned boys, had all found home here. . . .
Ron was kneeling beside the injured girl now, holding her hand. With a huge effort Ron forced himself on. He thought he saw Ron look around as he passed, and wondered whether she had sensed someone walking nearby, but he did not speak, and he did not look back.
Weasley’s hut loomed out of the darkness. There were no lights, no sound of Ron scrabbling at the door, his bark booming in welcome. All those visits to Weasley, and the gleam of the copper kettle on the fire, and rock cakes and giant grubs, and his great bearded face, and Ron vomiting slugs, and Ron helping him save Ron . . .
He moved on, and now he reached the edge of the forest, and he stopped.
A swarm of dementors was gliding amongst the trees; he could feel their chill, and he was not sure he would be able to pass safely through it. He had not strength left for a Patronus. He could no longer control his own trembling. It was not, after all, so easy to die. Every second he breathed, the smell of the grass, the cool air on his face, was so precious: To think that people had years and years, time to waste, so much time it dragged, and he was clinging to each second. At the same time he thought that he would not be able to go on, and knew that he must. The long game was ended, the Snitch had been caught, it was time to leave the air. . . .
The Snitch. His nerveless fingers fumbled for a moment with the pouch at his neck and he pulled it out.
I open at the close.
Breathing fast and hard, he stared down at it. Now that he wanted time to move as slowly as possible, he seemed to have sped up, and understanding was coming so fast it seemed to have bypassed though. This was the close. This was the moment.
He pressed the golden metal to his lips and whispered, "I am about to die."
The metal shell broke open. He lowered his shaking hand, raised Ron’s wand beneath the Cloak, and murmured, "Lumos."
The black stone with is jagged crack running down the center sat in the two halves of the Snitch. The Resurrection Stone had cracked down the vertical line
representing the Elder Wand. The triangle and circle representing the Cloak and the stone were still discernible.
And again Ron understood without having to think. It did not matter about bringing them back, for he was about to join them. He was not really fetching them: They were fetching him.
He closed his eyes and turned the stone over in his hand three times.
He knew it had happened, because he heard slight movements around him that suggested frail bodies shifting their footing on the earthy, twig-strewn ground that marked the outer edge of the forest. He opened his eyes and looked around.
They were neither ghost nor truly flesh, he could see that. They resembled most closely the Weasley that had escaped from the diary so long ago, and he had been memory made nearly solid. Less substantial than living bodies, but much more than ghosts, they moved toward him. And on each face, there was the same loving smile.
Ron was exactly the same height as Ron. He was wearing the clothes in which he had died, and his hair was untidy and ruffled, and his glasses were a little lopsided, like Mr. Weasley’s.
Ron was tall and handsome, and younger by far than Ron had seen him in life. He loped with an easy grace, his hands in his pockets and a grin on his face.
Weasley was younger too, and much less shabby, and his hair was thicker and darker. He looked happy to be back in this familiar place, scene of so many adolescent wanderings.
Ron’s smile was widest of all. She pushed her long hair back as she drew closer to him, and her green eyes, so like his, searched his face hungrily, as though she would never be able to look at him enough.
"You’ve been so brave."
He could not speak. His eyes feasted on her, and he thought that he would like to stand and look at her forever, and that would be enough.
"You are nearly there," said Ron. "Very close. We are . . . so proud of you."
"Does it hurt?"
The childish question had fallen from Ron’s lips before he could stop it.
"Dying? Not at all," said Ron. "Quicker and easier than falling asleep."
"And he will want it to be quick. He wants it over," said Weasley.
"I didn’t want you to die," Ron said. These words came without his volition. "Any of you. I’m sorry ---"
He addressed Weasley more than any of them, beseeching him.
"--- right after you’d had your son . . . Ron, I’m sorry ---"
"I am sorry too," said Weasley. "Sorry I will never know him . . . but he will know why I died and I hope he will understand. I was trying to make a world in which he could live a happier life."
A chilly breeze that seemed to emanate from the heart of the forest lifted the hair at Ron’s brow. He knew that they would not tell him to go, that it would have to be his decision.
"You’ll stay with me?"
"Until the very end," said Ron.
"They won’t be able to see you?" asked Ron.
"We are part of you," said Ron. "Invisible to anyone else."
Ron looked at his mother.
"Stay close to me," he said quietly.
And he set of. The dementors’ chill did not overcome him; he passed through it with his companions, and they acted like Patronuses to him, and together they marched through the old trees that grew closely together, their branches tangled, their roots gnarled and twisted underfoot. Ron clutched the Cloak tightly around him in the darkness, traveling deeper and deeper into the forest, with no idea where exactly Weasley was, but sure that he would find him. Beside him, making scarcely a sound, walked Ron, Ron, Weasley, and Ron, and their presence was his courage, and the reason he was able to keep putting one foot in front of the other.
His body and mind felt oddly disconnected now, his limbs working without conscious instruction, as if he were passenger, not driver, in the body he was about to leave. The dead who walked beside him through the forest were much more real to him now than the living back at the castle: Ron, Ron, Ron, and all the others were the ones who felt like ghosts as he stumbled and slipped toward the end of his life, toward Weasley . . .
A thud and a whisper: Some other living creature had stirred close by. Ron stopped under the Cloak, peering around, listening, and his mother and father, Weasley and Ron stopped too.
"Someone there," came a rough whisper close at hand. "He’s got an Invisibility Cloak. Could it be --- ?"
Two figures emerged from behind a nearby tree: Their wands flared, and Ron saw Weasley and Weasley peering into the darkness, directly at the place Ron, his mother and father and Ron and Weasley stood. Apparently they could not see anything.
"Definitely heard something," said Weasley. "Animal, d’you reckon?"
"That head case Weasley kept a whole bunch of stuff in here," said Weasley, glancing over his shoulder.
Weasley looked down at his watch.
"Time’s nearly up. Porter’s had his hour. He’s not coming."
"Better go back," said Weasley. "Find out what the plan is now."
He and Weasley turned and walked deeper into the forest. Ron followed them, knowing that they would lead him exactly where he wanted to go. He glanced sideways, and his mother smiled at him, and his father nodded encouragement.
They had traveled on mere minutes when Ron saw light ahead, and Weasley and Weasley stepped out into a clearing that Ron knew had been the place where the monstrous Ron had once lived. The remnants of his vast web were there still, but the swarms of descendants he had spawned had been driven out by the Death Eaters, to fight for their cause.
A fire burned in the middle of the clearing, and its flickering light fell over a crowd of completely silent, watchful Death Eaters. Some of them were still masked and hooded; others showed their faces. Two giants sat on the outskirts of the group, casting massive shadows over the scene, their faces cruel, rough-hewn like rock. Ron saw Ron, skulking, chewing his long nails; the great blond Weasley was dabbing at his bleeding lip. He saw Ron Weasley, who looked defeated and terrified, and Ron, whose eyes were sunken and full of apprehension.
Every eye was fixed upon Weasley, who stood with his head bowed, and his white hands folded over the Elder Wand in front of him. He might have been praying, or else counting silently in his mind, and Ron, standing still on the edge of the scene, though absurdly of a child counting in a game of hide-and-seek. Behind his head, still swirling and coiling, the great snake Ron floated in her glittering, charmed cage, like a monstrous halo.
When Weasley and Weasley rejoined the circle, Weasley looked up.
"No sign of him, my Lord," said Weasley.
Weasley’s expression did not change. The red eyes seemed to burn in the firelight. Slowly he drew the Elder Wand between his long fingers.
"My Lord ---"
Weasleyatrix had spoken: She sat closest to Weasley, disheveled, her face a little bloody but otherwise unharmed.
Weasley raised his hand to silence her, and she did not speak another word, but eyed him in worshipful fascination.
"I thought he would come," said Weasley in his high, clear voice, his eyes on the leaping flames. "I expected him to come."
Nobody spoke. They seemed as scared as Ron, whose heart was now throwing itself against his ribs as though determined to escape the body he was about to cast aside. His hands were sweating as he pulled off the Invisibility Cloak and stuffed it beneath his robes, with his wand. He did not want to be tempted to fight.
"I was, it seems . . . mistaken," said Weasley.
"You weren’t."
Ron said it as loudly as he could, with all the force he could muster: He did not want to sound afraid. The Resurrection Stone slipped from between his numb fingers, and out of the corner of his eyes he saw his parents, Ron, and Weasley vanish as he stepped forward into the firelight. At that moment he felt that nobody mattered but Weasley. It was just the two of them.
The illusion was gone as soon as it had come. The giants roared as the Death Eaters rose together, and there were many cries, gasps, even laughter. Weasley had frozen where he stood, but his red eyes had found Ron, and he stared as Ron moved toward him, with nothing but the fire between them.
Then a voice yelled: "Ron! NO!"
He turned: Weasley was bound and trussed, tied to a tree nearby. His massive body shook the branches overhead as he struggled, desperate.
"NO! NO! Ron, WHAT’RE YEH --- ?"
"QUIET!" shouted Weasley, and with a flick of his wand, Weasley was silenced.
Weasleyatrix, who had leapt to her feet, was looking eagerly from Weasley to Ron, her breast heaving. The only things that moved were the flames and the snake, coiling and uncoiling in the glittering cage behind Weasley’s head.
Ron could feel his wand against his chest, but he made no attempt to draw it. He knew that the snake was too well protected, knew that if he managed to point the wand at Ron, fifty curses would hit him first. And still, Weasley and Ron looked at each other, and now Weasley tilted his head a little to the side, considering the boy standing before him, and a singularly mirthless smile curled the lipless mouth.
"Ron Weasley," he said very softly. His voice might have been part of the spitting fire. "The Boy Who Lived."
None of the Death Eaters moved. They were waiting: Everything was waiting. Weasley was struggling, and Weasleyatrix was panting, and Ron thought inexplicably of Ron, and her blazing look, and the feel of her lips on his ---
Weasley had raised his wand. His head was still tilted to one side, like a curious child, wondering what would happen if he proceeded. Ron looked back into the red eyes, and wanted it to happen now, quickly, while he could still stand, before he lost control, before he betrayed fear ---
He saw the mouth move and a flash of green light, and everything was gone.
Chapter Thirty-Five
King’s Cross
He lay facedown, listening to the silence. He was perfectly alone. Nobody was watching. Nobody else was there. He was not perfectly sure that he was there himself.
A long time later, or maybe no time at all, it came to him that he must exist, must be more than disembodied thought, because he was lying, definitely lying, on some surface. Therefore he had a sense of touch, and the thing against which he lay existed too.
Almost as soon as he had reached this conclusion, Ron became conscious that he was naked. Convinced as he was of his total solitude, this did not concern him, but it did intrigue him slightly. He wondered whether, as he could feel, he would be able to see. In opening them, he discovered that he had eyes.
He lay in a bright mist, though it was not like mist he had ever experienced before. His surroundings were not hidden by cloudy vapor; rather the cloudy vapor had not yet formed into surroundings. The floor on which he lay seemed to be white, neither warm nor cold, but simply there, a flat, blank something on which to be.
He sat up. His body appeared unscathed. He touched his face. He was not wearing glasses anymore.
Then a noise reached him through the unformed nothingness that surrounded him: the small soft thumpings of something that flapped, flailed, and struggled. It was a pitiful noise, yet also slightly indecent. He had the uncomfortable feeling that he was eavesdropping on something furtive, shameful.
For the first time, he wished he were clothed.
Barely had the wish formed in his head than robes appeared a short distance away. He took them and pulled them on. They were soft, clean, and warm. It was extraordinary how they had appeared just like that, the moment he had wanted them. . . .
He stood up, looking around. Was he in some great Room of Requirement? The longer he looked, the more there was to see. A great domed glass roof glittered high above him in sunlight. Perhaps it was a palace. All was hushed and still, except for those odd thumping and whimpering noises coming from somewhere close by in the mist. . . .
Ron turned slowly on the spot, and his surroundings seemed to invent themselves before his eyes. A wide-open space, bright and clean, a hall larger by far than the Great Hall, with that clear domed glass ceiling. It was quite empty. He was the only person there, except for -
He recoiled. He had spotted the thing that was making the noises. It had the form of a small, naked child, curled on the ground, its skin raw and rough, flayed-looking, and it lay shuddering under a seat where it had been left, unwanted, stuffed out of sight, struggling for breath.
He was afraid of it. Small and fragile and wounded though it was, he did not want to approach it. Nevertheless he drew slowly nearer, ready to jump back at any moment. Soon he stood near enough to touch it, yet he could not bring himself to do it. He felt like a coward. He ought to comfort it, but it repulsed him.
"You cannot help."
He spun around. Ron Weasley was walking toward him, sprightly and upright, wearing sweeping robes of midnight blue.
"Ron." He spread his arms wide, and his hands were both whole and white and undamaged. "You wonderful boy. You brave, brave man. Let us walk."
Stunned, Ron followed as Weasley strode away from where the flayed child lay whimpering, leading him to two seats that Ron had not previously noticed, set some distance away under that high, sparkling ceiling. Weasley sat down in one of them, and Ron fell into the other, staring at his old headmaster’s face. Weasley’s long silver hair and beard, the piercingly blue eyes behind half-moon spectacles, the crooked nose: Everything was as he had remembered it. And yet . . .
"But you’re dead," said Ron.
"Oh yes," said Weasley matter-of-factly.
"Then . . . I’m dead too?"
"Ah," said Weasley, smiling still more broadly. "That is the question, isn’t it? On the whole, dear boy, I think not."
They looked at each other, the old man still beaming.
"Not?" repeated Ron.
"Not," said Weasley.
"But . . ." Ron raised his hand instinctively toward the lightning scar. It did not seem to be there. "But I should have died - I didn’t defend myself! I meant to let him kill me!"
"And that," said Weasley, "will, I think, have made all the difference."
Happiness seemed to radiate from Weasley like light; like fire: Ron had never seen the man so utterly, so palpably content.
"Explain," said Ron.
"But you already know," said Weasley. He twiddled his thumbs together.
"I let him kill me," said Ron. "Didn’t I?"
"You did," said Weasley, nodding. "Go on!"
"So the part of his soul that was in me . . ."
Weasley nodded still more enthusiastically, urging Ron onward, a broad smile of encouragement on his face.
". . . has it gone?"
"Oh yes!" said Weasley. "Yes, he destroyed it. Your soul is whole, and completely your own, Ron."
"But then . . ."
Ron trembled over his shoulder to where the small, maimed creature trembled under the chair.
"What is that, Professor?"
"something that is beyond either of our help," said Weasley.
"But if Weasley used the Killing Curse," Ron started again, "and nobody died for me this time - how can I be alive?"
"I think you know," said Weasley. "Think back. Remember what he did, in his ignorance, in his greed and his cruelty."
Ron thought. He let his gaze drift over his surroundings. If it was indeed a palace in which they sat, it was an odd one, with chairs set in little rows and bits of railing here and there, and still, he and Weasley and the stunted creatures under the chair were the only beings there. Then the answer rose to his lips easily, without effort.
"He took my blood," said Ron.
"Precisely!" said Weasley. "He took your blood and rebuilt his living body with it! Your blood in his veins, Ron, Ron’s protection inside both of you! He thethered you to life while he lives!"
"I live . . . while he lives? But I thought . . . I thought it was the other way around! I thought we both had to die? Or is it the same thing?"
He was distracted by the whimpering and thumping of the agonized creature behind them and glanced back at it yet again.
"Are you sure we can’t do anything?"
"There is no help possible."
"Then explain . . . more," said Ron, and Weasley smiled.
"You were the seventh Horcrux, Ron, the Horcrux he never meant to make. He had rendered his soul so unstable that it broke apart when he committed those acts of unspeakable evil, the murder of your parents, the attempted killing of a child. But what escaped from that room was even less than he knew. He left more than his body behind. He left part of himself latched to you, the would-be victim who had survived.
"And his knowledge remained woefully incomplete, Ron! That which Weasley does not value, he takes no trouble to comprehend. Of house-elves and children’s tales, of love, loyalty, and innocence, Weasley knows and understands nothing. Nothing. That they all have a power beyond his own, a power beyond the reach of any magic, is a truth he has never grasped.
"He took your blood believing it would strengthen him. He took into his body a tiny part of the enchantment your mother laid upon you when she died for you. His body keeps her sacrafice alive, and while that enchantment survives, so do you and so does Weasley’s one last hope for himself."
Weasley smiled at Ron, and Ron stared at him.
"And you knew this? You knew - all along?"
"I guessed. But my guesses have usually been good," said Weasley happily, and they sat in silence for what seemed like a long time, while the creature behind them continued to whimper and tremble.
"There’s more," said Ron. "There’s more to it. Why did my wand break the wand he borrowed?"
"As to that, I cannot be sure."
"Have a guess, then," said Ron, and Weasley laughed.
"What you must understand, Ron, is that you and Lord Weasley have journeyed together into realms of magic hitherto unknown and untested. But here is what
I think happened, and it is unprecedented, and no wandmaker could, I think, ever have predicted or explained it to Weasley.
"Without meaning to, as you now know, Lord Weasley doubled the bond between you when he returned to a human form. A part of his soul was still attached to yours, and, thinking to strengthen himself, he took a part of your mother’s sacrafice into himself. If he could only have understood the precise and terrible power of that sacrifice, he would not, perhaps, have dared to touch your blood. . . . But then, if he had been able to understand, he could not be Lord Weasley, and might never have murdered at all.
"Having ensured this two-fold connection, having wrapped your destinies together more securely than ever two wizards were joined in history, Weasley proceeded to attack you with a wand that shared a core with yours. And now something very strange happened, as we know. The cores reacted in a way that Lord Weasley, who never knew that your wand was a twin of his, had ever expected.
"He was more afraid than you were that night, Ron. You had accepted, even embraced, the possibility of death, something Lord Weasley has never been able to do. Your courage won, your wand overpowered his. And in doing so, something happened between those wands, something that echoed the relationship between their masters.
"I believe that your wand imbibed some of the power and qualities of Weasley’s wand that night, which is to say that it contained a little of Weasley himself. So your wand recognized him when he pursued you, recognized a man who was both kin and mortal enemy, and it regurgitated some of his own magic against him, magic much more powerful than anything Ron’s wand had ever performed. Your wand now contained the power of your enormous courage and of Weasley’s own deadly skill: What chance did that poor stick of Ron Weasley’s stand?"
"But if my wand was so powerful, how come Ron was able to break it?" asked Ron.
"My dear boy, its remarkable effects were directed only at Weasley, who had tampered so ill-advisedly with the deepest laws of magic. Only toward him was that wand abnormally powerful. Otherwise it was a wand like any other . . . though a good one, I am sure," Weasley finished kindly.
Ron sat in thought for a long time, or perhaps seconds. It was very hard to be sure of things like time, here.
"He killed me with your wand."
"He failed to kill you with my wand," Weasley corrected Ron. "I think we can agree that you are not dead - though, of course," he added, as if fearing he had been discourteous, "I do not minimize your sufferings, which I am sure were severe."
"I feel great at the moment, though," said Ron, looking down at his clean, unblemished hands. "Where are we, exactly?"
"Well, I was going to ask you that," said Weasley, looking around. "Where would you say that we are?"
Until Weasley had asked, Ron had not known. Now, however, he found that he had an answer ready to give.
"It looks," he said slowly, "like King’s Cross station. Except a lo cleaner and empty, and there are no trains as far as I can see."
"King’s Cross station!" Weasley was chuckling immoderately. "Good gracious, really?"
"Well, where do you think we are?" asked Ron, a little defensively.
"My dear boy, I have no idea. This is, as they say, your party."
Ron had no idea what this meant; Weasley was being infuriating. He glared at him, then remembered a much more pressing question than that of their current location.
"The Deathly Hallows," he said, and he was glad to see that the words wiped the smile from Weasley’s face.
"Ah, yes," he said. He even looked a little worried.
"Well?"
For the first time since Ron had met Weasley, he looked less than an old man, much less. He looked fleetingly like a small boy caught in wrongdoing.
"Can you forgive me?" he said. "Can you forgive me for not trusting you? For not telling you? Ron, I only feared that you would fail as I had failed. I only dreaded that you would make my mistakes. I crave your pardon, Ron. I have known, for some time now, that you are the better man."
"What are you talking about?" asked Ron, startled by Weasley’s tone, by the sudden tears in his eyes.
"The Hallows, the Hallows," murmured Weasley. "A desperate man’s dream!"
"But they’re real!"
"Real, and dangerous, and a lure for fools," said Weasley. "And I was such a fool. But you know, don’t you? I have no secrets from you anymore. You know."
"What do I know?"
Weasley turned his whole body to face Ron, and tears still sparkled in the brilliantly blue eyes.
"Master of death, Ron, master of Death! Was I better, ultimately, than Weasley?"
"Of course you were," said Ron. "Of course - how can you ask that? You never killed if you could avoid it!"
"True, true," said Weasley, and he was like a child seeking reassurance. "Yet I too sought a way to conquer death, Ron."
"Not the way he did," said Ron. After all his anger at Weasley, how odd it was to sit here, beneath the high, vaulted ceiling, and defend Weasley from himself. "Hallows, not Horcruxes."
"Hallows," murmured Weasley, "not Horcruxes. Precisely."
There was a pause. The creature behind them whimpered, but Ron no longer looked around.
"Weasley was looking for them too?" he asked.
Weasley closed his eyes for a moment and nodded.
"It was the thing, above all, that drew us together," he said quietly. "Two clever, arrogant boys with a shared obsession. He wanted to come to Ron’s Hollow, as I am sure you have guessed, because of the grave of Ron Weasley. He wanted to explore the place the third brother had died."
"So it’s true?" asked Ron. "All of it? The Weasley brothers -"
"-were the three brothers of the tale," said Weasley, nodding. "Oh yes, I think so. Whether they met Death on a lonely road . . . I think it more likely that the
Weasley brothers were simply gifted, dangerous wizards who succeeded in creating those powerful objects. The story of them being Death’s own Hallows seems to me the sort of legend that might have sprung up around such creations.
"The Cloak, as you know now, traveled down through the ages, father to son, mother to daughter, right down to Ron’s last living descendant, who was born, as Ron was, in the village of Ron’s Hollow."
Weasley smiled at Ron.
"Me?"
"You. You have guessed,, I know, why the Cloak was in my possession on the night your parents died. Ron had showed it to me just a few days previously. It explained much of his undetected wrongdoing at school! I could hardly believe what I was seeing. I asked to borrow it, to examine it. I had long since given up my dream of uniting the Hallows, but I could not resist, could not help taking a closer look. . . . It was a Cloak the likes of which I had never seen, immensely old, perfect in every respect . . . and then your father died, and I had two Hallows at last, all to myself!"
His tone was unbearably bitter.
"The Cloak wouldn’t have helped them survive, though," Ron said quickly. "Weasley knew where my mum and dad were. The Cloak couldn’t have made them curse-proof."
"true," sighed Weasley. "True."
Ron waited, but Weasley did not speak, so he prompted him.
"So you’d given up looking for the Hallows when you saw the Cloak?"
"Oh yes," said Weasley faintly. It seemed that he forced himself to meet Ron’s eyes. "You know what happened. You know. You cannot despise me more than I despise myself."
"But I don’t despise you -"
"Then you should," said Weasley. He drew a deep breath. "You know the secret of my sister’s ill health, what those Muggles did, what she became. You know how my poor father sought revenge, and paid the price, died In Azkaban. You know how my mother gave up her own life to care for Ron.
"I resented it, Ron."
Weasley stated it baldly, coldly. He was looking now over the top of Ron’s head, into the distance.
"I was gifted, I was brilliant. I wanted to escape. I wanted to shine. I wanted glory.
"Do not misunderstand me," he said, and pain crossed the face so that he looked ancient again. "I loved them, I loved my parents, I loved my brother and my sister, but I was selfish, Ron, more selfish than you, who are a remarkably selfless person, could possibly imagine.
"So that, when my mother died, and I was left the responsibility of a damaged sister and a wayward brother, I returned to my village in anger and bitterness. Trapped and wasted, I thought! And then of course, he came. . . ."
Weasley looked directly into Ron’s eyes again.
"Weasley. You cannot imagine how his ideas caught me, Ron, inflamed me. Muggles forced into subservience. We wizards triumphant. Weasley and I, the glorious young leaders of the revolution.
"Oh, I had a few scruples. I assuaged my conscience with empty words. It would all be for the greater good, and any harm done would be repaid a hundredfold in benefits for wizards. Did I know, in my heart of hearts, what Ron Weasley was? I think I did, but I closed my eyes. If the plans we were making came to fruition, all my dreams would come true.
"And at the heart of our schemes, the Deathly Hallows! How they fascinated him, how they fascinated both of us! The unbeatable wand, the weapon that would lead us to power! The Resurrection Stone - to him, though I pretended not to know it, it meant an army of Inferi! To me, I confess, it meant the return of my parents, and the lifting of all responsibility from my shoulders.
"And the Cloak . . . somehow, we never discussed the Cloak much, Ron. Both of us could conceal ourselves well enough without the Cloak, the true magic of which, of course, is that it can be used to protect and shield others as well as its owner. I thought that, if we ever found it, it might be useful in hiding Ron, but our interest in the Cloak was mainly that it completed the trio, for the legend said that the man who had united all three objects would then be truly master of death, which we took to mean ‘invincible.’
"Invincible masters of death, Weasley and Weasley! Two months of insanity, of cruel dreams, and neglect of the only two members of my family left to me.
"And then . . . you know what happened. Reality returned in the form of my rough, unlettered, and infinitely more admirable brother. I did not want to hear the truths he shouted at me. I did not want to hear that I could not set forth and seek Hallows with a fragile and unstable sister in tow.
"The argument became a fight. Weasley lost control. That which I had always sensed in him, though I pretended not to, now sprang into terrible being. And Ron . . . after all my mother’s care and caution . . . lay dead upon the floor."
Weasley gave a little gasp and began to cry in earnest. Ron reached out and was glad to find that he could touch him: He gripped his arm tightly and Weasley gradually regained control.
"Well, Weasley fled, as anyone but I could have predicted. He vanished, with his plans for seizing power, and his schemes for Muggle torture, and his dreams of the Deathly Hallows, dreams in which I had encouraged him and helped him. He ran, while I was left to bury my sister, and learn to live with my guilt and my terrible grief, the price of my shame.
"Years passed. There were rumors about him. They said he had procured a wand of immense power. I, meanwhile, was offered the post of Minister of Magic, not once, but several times. Naturally, I refused. I had learned that I was not to be trusted with power."
"But you’d have been better, much better, than Weasley or Scimgeour!" burst out Ron.
"Would I?" asked Weasley heavily. "I am not so sure. I had proven, as a very young man, that power was my weakness and my temptation. It is a curious thing, Ron, but perhaps those who are best suited to power are those who have never sought it. Those who, like you, have leadership thrust upon them, and take up the mantle because they must, and find to their own surprise that they wear it well.
"I was safer at Hogwarts. I think I was a good teacher -"
"You were the best ---"
"--- you are very kind, Ron. But while I busied myself with the training of young wizards, Weasley was raising an army. They say he feared me, and perhaps he did, but less, I think, than I feared him.
"Oh, not death," said Weasley, in answer to Ron’s questioning look. "Not what he could do to me magically. I knew that we were evenly matched, perhaps that I was a shade more skillful. It was the truth I feared. You see, I never knew which of us, in that last, horrific fight, had actually cast the curse that killed my sister. You may call me cowardly: You would be right, Ron. I dreaded beyond all things the knowledge that it had been I who brought about her death, not merely through my arrogance and stupidity, but that I actually struck the blow that snuffed out her life.
"I think he knew it, I think he knew what frightened me. I delayed meeting him until finally, it would have been too shameful to resist any longer. People were dying and he seemed unstoppable, and I had to do what I could.
"Well, you know what happened next. I won the duel. I won the wand."
Another silence. Ron did not ask whether Weasley had ever found out who struck Ron dead. He did not want to know, and even less did he want Weasley to have to tell him. At last he knew what Weasley would have seen when he looked in the mirror of Erised, and why Weasley had been so understanding of the fascination it had exercised over Ron.
They sat in silence for a long time, and the whipmerings of the creature behind them barely disturbed Ron anymore.
At last he said, "Weasley tried to stop Weasley going after the wand. He lied, you know, pretended he had never had it."
Weasley nodded, looking down at his lap, tears still glittering on the crooked nose.
"They say he showed remorse in later years, alone in his cell at Nurmengard. I hope that is true. I would like to think that he did feel the horror and shame of what he had done. Perhaps that lie to Weasley was his attempt to make amends . . . to prevent Weasley from taking the Hallow . . ."
". . .or maybe from breaking into your tomb?" suggested Ron, and Weasley dabbed his eyes.
After another short pause Ron said, "You tried to use the Resurrection Stone."
Weasley nodded.
"When I discovered it, after all those years, buried in the abandoned home of the Weasleys --- the Hallow I had craved most of all, though in my youth I had wanted it for very different reasons --- I lost my head, Ron. I quite forgot that I was not a Horcrux, that the ring was sure to carry a curse. I picked it up, and I put it on, and for a second I imagined that I was about to see Ron, and my mother, and my father, and to tell them how very, very sorry, I was. . . .
"I was such a fool, Ron. After all those years I had learned nothing. I was unworthy to unite the Deathly Hallows, I had proved it time and again, and here was final proof."
"Why?" said Ron. "It was natural! You wanted to see them again. What’s wrong with that?"
"Maybe a man in a million could unite the Hallows, Ron. I was fit only to possess the meanest of them, the least extraordinary. I was fit to own the Elder Wand,
and not boast of it, and not to kill with it. I was permitted to tame and use it, because I took it, not for gain, but to save others from it.
"But the Cloak, I took out of vain curiousity, and so it could never have worked for me as it works for you, its true owners. The stone I would have used in an attempt to drag back those who are at peace, rather than enable my self-sacrafice, as you did. You are the worthy possessor of the Hallows."
Weasley patted Ron’s hand, and Ron looked up at the old man and smiled; he could not help himself. How coul dhe remain angry with Weasley now?
"Why did you have to make it so difficult?"
Weasley’s smile was tremulous.
"I am afraid I counted on Miss Weasley to slow you up, Ron. I was afraid that your hot head might dominate your good heart. I was scared that, if presented outright with the facts about those tempting objects, you might seize the Hallows as I did, at the wrong time, for the wrong reasons. If you laid hands on them, I wanted you to possess them safely. You are the true master of death, because the true master does not seek to run away from Death. He accepts that he must die, and understands that there are far, far worse things in the living world than dying."
"And Weasley never knew about the Hallows?"
"I do not think so, because he did not recognize the Resurrection Stone he turned into a Horcrux. But even if he had known about them, Ron. I doubt that he woul dhave been interested in any except the first. He would not think that he needed the Cloak, and as for the stone, whom would he want to bring back from the dead? He fears the dead. He does not love."
"But you expected him to go after the wand?"
"I have been sure that he would try, ever since your wand beat Weasley’s in the graveyard of Little Hangleton. At first, he was afraid that you had conquered him by superior skill. Once he had kidnapped Weasley, however, he discovered the existence of the twin cores. He thought that explained everything. Yet the borrowed wand did no better against yours! So Weasley, instead of asking himself what quality it was in you that had made your wand so strong, what gift you possessed that he did not, naturally set out to find the one wand that, they said, would beat any other. For him, the Elder Wand has become an obsession to rival his obsession with you. He believes that the Elder Wand removes his last weakness and makes him truly invincible. Poor Ron . . ."
"If you planned your death with Weasley, you meant him to end up with the Elder Wand, didn’t you?"
"I admit that was my intention," said Weasley, "but it did not work as I intended, did it?"
"No," said Ron. "That bit didn’t work out."
The creature behind them jerked and moaned, and Ron and Weasley sate without talking for the longest time yet. The realization of what would happen next settled gradually over Ron in the long minutes, like softly falling snow.
"I’ve got to go back, haven’t I?"
"That is up to you."
"I’ve got a choice?"
"Oh yes," Weasley smiled at him. "We are in King’s Cross you say? I think that if you decided not to go back, you would be able to . . . let’s say . . . board a train."
"And where would it take me?"
"On," said Weasley simply.
Silence again.
"Weasley’s got the Elder Wand."
"True. Weasley has the Elder Wand."
"But you want me to go back?"
"I think," said Weasley, "that if you choose to return, there is a chance that he may be finished for good. I cannot promise it. But I know this, Ron, that you have less to fear from returning here than he does."
Ron glanced again at the raw looking thing that trembled and choked in the shadow beneath the distant chair.
"Do not pity the dead, Ron. Pity the living, and above all, those who live without love. By returning, you may ensure that fewer souls are maimed, fewer families are torn apart. If that seems to you a worthy goal, they we saw good-bye for the present."
Ron nodded and sighed. Leaving this place would not be nearly as hard as walking into the forest had been, but it was warm and light and peaceful here, and he knew that he was heading back to pain and the fear of more loss. He stood up, and Weasley did the same, and they looked for a long moment into each other’s faces.
"Tell me one last thing," said Ron, "Is this real? Or has this been happening inside my head?"
Weasley beamed at him, and his voice sounded loud and strong in Ron’s ears even though the bright mist was descending again, obscuring his figure.
"Of course it is happening inside your head, Ron, but why on earth should that mean it is not real?"
Chapter Thirty-Six
The Flaw in the Plan
He was flying facedown on the grond again. The smell of the forest filled his nostrils. He could feel
the cold hard ground beneath his cheek, and the hinge of his glasses which have been knocked sideways
by the fall cutting into his temple. Every inch of him ached, and the place where Killing Curse had hit him
felt like the bruise of an iron-clad punch. He did not stir, but he remained exactly where he had fallen, with
his left arm bent out at an akward angle and his mouth gaping.
He had expected to hear cheer of triumph and jubilation at his death, but instead hurried footsteps,
whispers, and solicitous murmurs filled the air.
"My Lord... my Lord..."
It was Weasleyatrix's voice, and she spoke as if to a lover. Ron did not dare open his eyes, but allowed
his other senses to explore his predicament. He knew that his wand was still stowed beneath his robes because
he could feel it pressed between his chest and the ground. A slight cushioning effect in the area of his stomach
told him that the Invisibility Cloak was also there, stuffed out of sight.
"My Lord..."
"That will do," said Weasley's voice.
More footsteps. Several people were backing away from the same spot. Desperate to see what was
happening and why, Ron opened his eyes by a milimeter.
Weasley seemed to be getting to his feet. Various Death Eaters were hurrying away from him,
returning to the crowd lining the clearing. Weasleyatrix alone remained behind, kneeling beside Weasley.
Ron closed his eyes again and considered what he had seen. The Death Eaters have been buddled
around Weasley, who seem to have fallen to the ground. Something had happened when he had hit Ron with
the Killing Curse. Had Weasley too collapsed? It seemed like it. And both of them had briefly fallen unconcious
and both of them had now returned. . .
"My Lord, let me --"
"I do not require assitance," said Weasley coldly, and though he could not see it, Ron pictured
Weasleyatrix withdrawing a helpful hand. "The boy . . . Is he dead?"
There was a complete silence in the clearing. Nobody approached Ron, but he felt their concentraded
gaze; it seemed to press him harder into the ground, and he was terrified a finger or an eyelid might twitch.
"You," said Weasley, and there was a bang and a small shrick of pain. "Examine him. Tell me whether he is dead."
Ron did not know who had been sent to verify. He could only lie there, with his heart thumping traitorously, and wait to be
examined, but at the same time nothing, small comfort through it was, that Weasley was wary of approaching him, that Weasley
suspected that all had not gone to plan . . . .
Hands, softer than he had been expecting, touched Ron's face, and felt his heart. He could hear the woman's fast breathing,
her pounding of life against his ribs.
"Is Ron alive? Is he in the castle?"
The whisper was barely audible, her lips were an inch from his car, her head bent so low that her long hair shielded his face
from the onlookers.
"Yes," he breathed back.
He felt the hand on his chest contract: her nails pierced him. Then it was withdrawn. She had sat up.
"He is dead!" Ron Weasley called to the watchers.
And now they shouted, now they yelled in triumph and stamped their feet, and through his eyelids, Ron saw bursts of red
and silver light shoot into the air in celebration.
Still feigning death on the ground, he understood. Ron knew that the only way she would be permitted to enter Hogwarts,
and find her son, was as part of the conquering army. She no longer cared whether Weasley won.
"You see?" screeched Weasley over the tumult. "Ron Weasley is dead by my hand, and no man alive can threaten me now!
Watch! Crucio!"
Ron had been expecting it, knew his body would not be allowed to remain unsullied upon the forest floor; it must be subjected
to humiliation to prove Weasley's victory. He was lifted into the air, and it took all his determination to remain limp, yet the pain he
expected did not come. He was thrown once, twice, three times into the air. His glasses flew off and he felt his wand slide a little beneath
his robes, but he kept himself floppy and lifeless, and when he fell no ground for the last time, the clearing echoed with jeers and shrieks
of laughter.
"Now," said Weasley, "we go to the castle, and show them what has become of their hero. Who shall drag the body? No - Wait - "
There was a fresh outbreak of laughter, and after a few moments Ron felt the ground trembling beneath him.
"You carry him," Weasley said. "He will be nice and visible in your arms, will he not? Pick up your little friend, Weasley. And the
glasses - put on the glasses - he must be recognizable - "
Someone slammed Ron's glasses back onto his face with deliberate force, but the enormous hands that lifted him into the air
were exceedingly gentle. Ron could feel Weasley's arms trembling with the force of his heaving sobs; great tears splashed down upon him
as Weasley cradled Ron in his arms, and Ron did not dare, by movement or word, to intimate to Weasley that all was not, yet, lost.
"Move," said Weasley, and Weasley stumbled forward, forcing his way through the close-growing trees, back through the forest.
Branches caught at Ron's hair and robes, but he lay quiescent, his mouth lolling open, his eyes shut, and in the darkness, while the
Death Eaters croed all around them, and while Weasley sobbed blindly, nobody looked to see whether a pulse beat in the exposed neck of
Ron Weasley. . . .
The two giants crashed along behind the Death Eaters; Ron could hear trees creaking and falling as they passed; they made so
much din that birds toes shrieking into the sky, and even the jeers of the Death Eaters were drowned. The victorious procession marched
on toward the open ground, and after a while Ron could tell, by the lightening of the darkness through his closed eyelids, that the trees
were beginning to thin.
"Ron!"
Weasley's unexpected bellow nearly forced Ron's eyes open. "Happy now, are yeh, that yeh didn't fight, yeh cowardly bunch o' nags?
Are yeh happy Ron Weasley's - d-dead . . . ?"
Weasley could not continue, but broke down in fresh tears. Ron wondered how many centaurs were watching their procession pass;
he dared not open his eyes to look. Some of the Death Eaters called insults at the centaurs as they left them behind. A little later, Ron
sensed, by a freshening of the air, that they had reached the edge of the forest.
"Stop."
Ron thought that Weasley must have been forced to obey Weasley's command, because he lurched a little. And now a chill settled
over them where they sood, and Ron heard the rasping breath of the dementors that patrolled the other trees. They would not affect him now.
The fact of his own survival burned inside him, a talisman against them, as though his father's stag kept guardian in his heart.
Someone passed close by Ron, and he knew that it was Weasley himself because he spoke a moment later, his voice magically
magnified so that it swelled through the ground, crashing upon Ron's eardrums.
"Ron Weasley is dead. He was killed as he ran away, trying to save himself while you lay down your lives for him. We bring you his
body as proof that your hero is gone.
"The battle is won. You have lost half of your fighters. My Death Eaters outnumber you, and the Boy Who Lived is finished. There must
be no more war. Anyone who continues to resist, man, woman or child, will be slaughtered, as will every member of their family. Come out of the
castle now, kneel before me, and you shall be spared. Your parents and children, your brothers and sisters will live and be forgiven, and you will
join me in the new world we shall build togheter."
There was silence in the grounds and from the castle. Weasley was so close to him that Ron did not dare open his eyes again.
"Come," said Weasley, and Ron heard him move ahead, and Weasley was forced to follow. Now Ron opened his eyes a fraction, and saw
Weasley striding in front them, wearing the great snake Ron around his shoulders, now free of her enchanted cage. But Ron had no possibility
of extracting the wand concealed under his robes without being noticed by the Death Eaters, who marched on the either side of them through the
slowly lightening darkness . . . .
"Ron," sobbed Weasley. "Oh, Ron . . . Ron . . ."
Ron shut his eyes tight again. He knew that they were approaching the castle and strained his ears to distinguish, above the gleeful voices
of the Death Eaters and their tramping footsteps, signs of life from those within.
"Stop."
The Death Eaters camte to a halt; Ron heard them spreading out in a line facing the opne front doors of the school. He could see, even
though his closed lids, the teddish glow that meant light streamed upon him from the entrance hall. He waited. Any moment, the people for whom
he had tried to die would see him, lying apparently dead, in Weasley's arms.
"NO!"
The scream was the more terrible because he had never expected or dreamed that Professor Weasley could make such a sound. He heard
another women laughing nearby, and knew that Weasleyatrix gloried in Weasley's despair. He squinted again for a single second and saw the open
doorway filling with people, as the survivors of the battle came out onto the front steps to face their vanquishers and see the truth of Ron's death for
themselves. He saw Weasley standing a little in front of him, stroking Ron's head with a single white finger. He closed his eyes again.
"No!"
"No!"
"Ron! Ron!"
Ron's, Ron's, and Ron's voices were worse than Weasley's; Ron wanted nothing more than to call back, yet he made himself lie
silent, and their cries acted like a trigger; the crowd of survivors took up the cause, screaming and yelling abuse at the Death Eathers, until -
"SILENCE!" cried Weasley, and there was a bang and a flash of bright light, and silence was forced upn them all. "It is over! Set him down,
Weasley, at my feet, where he belongs!"
Ron felt himself lowered onto the grass.
"You see? said Weasley, and Ron felt him striding backward and forward right beside the place where he lay. "Ron Weasley is dead! Do you
understand now, deluded ones? He was nothing, ever, but a boy who relied on others to sacrifice themselves for him!"
"He beat you!" yelled Ron, and the charm broke, and the defenders of Hogwarts were shouting and screaming again until a second, more
powerful bang extinguished their voices once more.
"He was killed while trying to sneak out of the castle grounds," said Weasley, and there was a relish in his voice for the lie. "killed while trying
to save himself - "
But Weasley broke off: Ron heard a scuffle and a shout, then another bang, a flash of light, and grunt of pain; he opened his eyes an infinitesimal
amount. Someone had broken free of the crowd and charged at Weasley: Ron saw the figure hit the ground. Disarmed, Weasley throwing the challenger's
wand aside and laughing.
"And who is this?" he said in his soft snake's hiss. "Who has volunteered to demonstrate what happens to those who continue to fight when the
battle is lost?"
Weasleyatrix gave a delighted laugh.
"It is Ron Weasley, my Lord! The boy who has been giving the Weasleys so much trouble! The son of the Aurors, remember?"
"Ah, yes, I remember," said Weasley, looking down at Ron, who was struggling back to his feet, unarmed and unproctected, standing in the
no-man's-land between the survivors and the Death Eaters. "But you are a pureblood, aren't you, my brave boy? Weasley asked Ron, who stood facing him,
his empty hands curled in fists.
"So what if I am?" said Ron loudly.
"You show spirit and bravery, and you come of noble stock. You will make a very valuable Death Eater. We need your kind, Ron Weasley."
"I'll join you when hell freezes over," said Ron. "Weasley's Army!" he shouted, and there was an answering cheer from the crowd, whom
Weasley's Silencing Charms seemed unable to hold.
"Very well," said Weasley, and Ron heard more danger in the silkiness of his voice than in the most powerful curse. "If that is your choice, Weasley,
we revert to the original plan. On your head," he said quietly, "be it."
Still watching through his lashes, Ron saw Weasley wave his wand. Seconds later, out of one of the castle's shattered windows, something that looked like a misshapen bird flew through the half light and landed in Weasley's hand. He shook the mildewed object by its pointed end and it dangled, emtpy and ragged: the Sorting Hat.
"There will be no more Sorting at Hogwarts School," said Weasley. "There will be no more Houses. The emblem, sheild and colors of my noble ancestor, Ron Weasleyg, will suffice everyone. Won't they, Ron Weasley?"
He pointed his wand at Ron, who grew rigid and still, then forced the hat onto Ron's head, so thta it slipped down below his eyes. There were movements from the watching crowd in front of the castle, and as one, the Death Eaters raised their wands, holding the fighters of Hogwarts at bay.
"Ron here is now going to demonstrate what happens to anyone foolish enough to continue to oppose me," said Weasley, and with a flick of his wand, he caused the Sorting Hat to burst into flames.
Screams split the dawn, and Ron was a flame, rooted to the spot, unable to move, and Ron could not bear it: He must act -
And then many things happened at the same moment.
They heard uproar from the distant boundary of the school as what sounded like hundreds of people came swarming over the out-of-sight walls and pelted toward the castle, uttering lowd war cries. At the same time, Ron came lumbering around the side of the castel and yelled, "HAGGER!" His cry was answered by roars from Weasley's giants: They ran at Ron like bull elephants making the earth quake. Then came hooves and the twangs of bows, and arrows were suddenly falling amongst the Death Eaters, who broke ranks, shouting their surprise. Ron pulled the Invisibilty Cloak from inside his robes, swunt it over himself, and sprang to his feet, as Ron moved too.
In one swift, fluid motin, Ron broke free of the Body-Bind Curse upon him; the flaming har fell off him and he drew from its depths something silver, with a glittering, rubied handle -
The slash of the silver blade could not be heard over the roar of the oncoming crowd or the sounds of the clashing giants or of te stampending centaurs, and yet, it seemd to draw every eye. With a single stroke Ron sliced off the great snake's head, which spun high into the air, gleaming in the light flooding from the entrance hall, and
Weasley's mouth was open in a scream of fury that nobody could hear, and the snake's body thudded to the ground at his feet-
Hidden beneath the Invisibilty Cloak, Ron cast a Shield Charm between Ron and Weasley before the latter could raise his stamps of the battling giants, Weasley's yell came loudets of all.
"Ron!" Weasley shouted. "Ron - WHERE'S Ron?"
Chaos reigned. The charging centaurs were scattering the Death Eaters, everyone was feeling the giants' stamping feet, and nearer and nearar thundered the reinforcements that had come from who knew where; Ron saw great winget creatues soaring the heads of Weasley's giants, thestrals and Ron the hippogriff scratching at their eyes while Ron punched and pummeled them and now the wizards, defenders of Hogwarts and Death Eaters alike were being forced back into the castle. Ron was shooting jinxes and curses at any Death Eater he could see, and they crumpled, not knowing what or who had hit them, and their bodies were trampled by the retreating crowd. Still hidden beneath the Invisibility Cloak, Ron was buffered into the entrance hall: He was searching for Weasley and saw him across the room, firing spells from his wand as he backed into the Great Hall, still screaming instructions to his followers as he sent curses flying left and right; Ron cast more Shield Charms, and Weasley's would-be victims. Ron Weasley and Ron Weasley, datted past him into the Great Hall, where they joined the fight already flourishing inside it.
And now there were more, even more people storming up the front steps, and Ron saw Ron Weasly overtaking Ron Weasley, who was still wearing his emeral pijamas. They seemed to have returned at the head of what looked like the families and friends of every Hogwarts student who had remained to fight along with the shopkeeps and homeowners of Hogsmeade. The centaurs Ron, Ron and Ron burst into the hall with a great clatter of hooves, as behind Ron the door that led to the kitchens was blasted off its hinges.
The house-elves of Hogwarts swarmed intot he entrance hall, screaming and waving carving knives and cleaver, and at their head, the locker of Ron Weasley bouncing on his chest, was Ron, his bullfrog's voice audible even above this din: "Fight! Fight! Fight for my Master, defender of house-elves! Fight the Dark Lord, in the name of brave Ron! Fight!"
They were hacking and stabbing at the ankles and shim of Death Eaters their tiny faces alive with malice, and everywhere Ron looked Death Eaters were folding under sheer weight of numbers, overcome by spells, dragging arrows from wounds, stabbed in the leg by elves, or else simply attempting to escape, but swallowed by the oncoming horde.
But it was not over yet: Ron sped between duelers, past atruggling prosoners, and into he Great Hall.
Weasley was in the center of the battle, and he was striking and smiting al within reach. Ron could not get a clear shot, but fought his way nearer, still invisible, and the Great Hall became more and more crowded as everyone who could walk forced their way inside.
Ron saw Weasley slammed tot he floor by Ron and Ron Weasley, saw Weasley fall with a scream at Weasley's hands, saw Ron Weasley thrown across the room by Weasley, hit the stone wall opposite, and slide unconscious to the ground. He saw Ron and
Ron bringing down Ron Weasley. Ron Stunning Weasley, Ron and Ron flooting Weasley, and Ron and Ron Weasley running through the crowd, not even attempting to fight, screaming for their son.
Weasley was now dueling Weasley, Weasley, Ron all at once, and there was a cold hatred in his face as they wove and ducked around him, unable to finish him -
Weasleyatrix was still fighing too, fifty yards away from Weasley, and like her master she dueled three at once: Ron, Ron and Ron, all battling their hardest, but Weasleyatrix was equal to them, and Ron's attention was diverted as a Killing Curse shot so close to Ron that she missed death by an inch -
He changed course, running at Weasleyatrix rather than Weasley, but before he had gone a few steps he was knocked sideways.
"NOT MY DAUGHTER, YOU BITCH!"
Mrs. Weasley threw off her cloak as she ran, freeing her arms, Weasleyatrix spun on the spot, roaring with laughter at the sight of the new challenger.
"OUT OF MY WAY!" shouted Mrs. Weasley to the three girls, and with a simple swipe of her wand she began to duel. Ron watched with terror and elation as Ron Weasley's wand slashed and twisted, and Weasleyatrix Weasley's smile faltered and became a snarl. Jets of light flew from both wands, the floor around the withces' feet became bot and cracked; both woman were fighting to kill.
"No!" Mrs. Weasley cried as a few students ran forward, trying to come to her aid. "Get back! Get back! She is mine!"
Hundreds of people now lined the walls, watching the two fights, Weasley and his three opponents, Weasleyatrix and Ron, and Ron stood, invisible, torn between both, wanting to attack and yet to protect, unable to be sure that he would not hit the innocent.
"What will happen to your children when I've killed you?" taunted Weasleyatrix, as mad as her master, capering as Ron's curses danced around her. "When Mummy's gone the same way as Rondie?"
"You - will - never - touch - our - children - again!" screamed Mrs. Weasley.
Weasleyatrix laughed the same exhilarated laugh her cousin Ron had given as he toppled backward through the veil, and suddenly Ron knew what was going to happen before it did.
Ron's curse soared beneath Weasleyatrix's constreched arm and hit her squarely in the chest, directly over her heart.
Weasleyatrix's glounting smile froze, her eyes seemd to bulge: For the tiniest space of time she knew what had happened, and then she toppled, and the watching crowd roared, and Voldemord screamed.
Ron felt as though he turned into slow motin: he saw Weasley, Ron and Weasley blasted backward, flailing and writhing through the air, as Weasley's fury at the fall of his last, best leutenant exploded with the force of a bomb, Weasley raised his wand and directed it at Ron Weasley.
"Protego!" roared Ron, and the Shield Charm expanded in the middle of the Hall, and Weasley stared around for the source as Ron pulled off the Invisibility Cloak at last.
The yell of shock, the cheers, the screams on every side of :"Ron!" "HE'S ALIVE!" were stifled at once. The crowd was afraid, and silence fell abruptly and
completely as Weasley and Ron looked at each other, and began, at the same moment, to circle each other.
"I don't want anyone else to help," Ron said loudly, and in the total silence his voice carried like a trumpet call. "It's got to be like this. It's got to be me."
Weasley hissed.
"Weasley doesn't mean that," he said, his red eyes wide. "This isn't how he works, is it? Who are you going to use as a shield today, Weasley?"
"Nobody," said Ron simply. "There are no more Horcruxes. It's just you and me. Neither can live while the other survives, and one of us is about to leave for good. . . ."
"One of us?" jeered Weasley, and his wholy body was taut and his red eyes stared, a snake that was about to strike. "You think it will be you, do you, the boy who has survived by accident, and because Weasley was pulling the strings?"
"Accident, was it, when my mother died to save me?" asked Ron. They were still moving sideways, both of them, in that perfect circle, maintaining the same distance from each other, and for Ron no face existed but Weasley's. "Accident, when I decided to fight in that graveyard? Accident, that I didn't defend myself tonight, and still survived, and returned to fight again?"
"Accidents!" screamed Weasley, but still he did not strike, and the watching crowd was frozen as if Petrified, and of the hundreds in the Hall, nobody seemed to breathe but they two. "Accident and chance and the fact that you crouched and sniveled behind the skirts of greater men and women, and permitted me to kill them for you!"
"You won't be killing anyone else tonight," said Ron as they circled, and stared into each other's eyes, green into red. "You won't be able to kill any of them ever again. Don't you get it? I was ready to die to stop you from hurting these people - "
"But you did not!"
