" - I meant to, and that's what did it. I've done what my mother did. They're protected from you. Haven't you noticed how none of the spells you put on them are binding? You can't torture them. You can't touch them. You don't learn from your mistakes, Weasley, do you?"
"You dare -"
"Yes, I dare," said Ron. "I know things you don't know, Ron Weasley. I know lots of important things that you don't. Want to hear some, before you make another big mistake?"
Weasley did not speak, but powled in a circle, and Ron knew that he kept him temporarily mesmerized at bay, held back by the faintest possibility that Ron might indeed know a final secret. . . .
"Is it love again?" said Weasley, his snake's face jeering. "Weasley favorite solution, love, which he claimed conqered death, though love did not stop him falling from the tower and breaking like and old waxwork? Love, which did not prevent me stamping out your Modblood mother like a cockroack, Weasley - and nobody seems to love you enough to run forward this time and take my curse. So what will stop you dying now when I strike?"
"Just one thing," said Ron, and still they circled each other, wrapped in each other, held apart by nothing but the last secret.
"If it is not love that will save you this time," said Weasley, "you must believe that you have magic that i do not, or else a weapon more powerful than mine?"
"I believe both," said Ron, and he saw shock flit across the snakelike face, though it was instantly dispelled; Weasley began to laugh, and the sound was more frightening than his screams; humorles and insane, it echoed around the silent Hall.
"You think you know more magic than I do?" he said. "Than I, than Lord Weasley, who has performed magic that Weasley himself never dreamed of?"
"Oh he dreamed of it," said Ron, "but he knew more than you, knew enough not to do what you've done."
"You mean he was weak!" screamed Weasley. "Too weak to dare, too weak to take what might have been his, what will be mine!"
"No, he was cleverer than you," said Ron, "a better wizard, a better man."
"I brought about the death of Ron Weasley!"
"You thought you did," said Ron, "but you were wrong."
For the frist time, the watching crowd stirred as the hundreds of people around the walls drew breath as one.
"Weasley is dead!" Weasley hurled the words at Ron as in the marble tomb in the grounds of this castle, I have seen it, Weasley, and he will not return!"
"Yes, Weasley is dead," said Ron calmly, "but you didn't have him killed. He chose his own manner of dying, chose it months before he died, arranged the whole thing with the man you thought was your servant."
"What chldish dream is this?" said Weasley, but still he did not strike, and his red eyes did not waver from Ron's.
"Ron Weasley wasn't yours," said Ron. "Weasley was Weasley's. Weasley's from the moment you starting hunting down my mother. And you never realized it, because of the thing you can't understand. You never saw Weasley cast a Patronus, did you, Weasley?"
Weasley did not answer. They continued to circle each other like wolves about to tear each other apart.
"Weasley's Patronus was a doe," said Ron, "the same as my mother's, because he loved her for nearly all of his life, from the time when they were children. You should have realized," he said as he saw Weasley's nostrils flare, "he asked you to spare her life, didn't he?" "He desired her, that was all," sneered Weasley, "but when she had gone, he agreed that there were other women, and of purer blood, worhier of him - "
"Of course he told you that," said Ron, "but he was Weasley's spy from the moment you threatened her, and he's been working against you ever since! Weasley was already dying when Weasley finished him!"
"It matters not!" shrieked Weasley, who had followed every word with rapt attention, but now let out a cackle of mad laughter. "It matters not whether Weasley was mine or Weasley's, or what petty obstacles they tried to put in my path! I crushed them as I crushed your mother, Weasley's supposed great love! Oh, but it all makes sense, Weasley, and in ways that you do not understand!
"Weasley was trying to keep the Elder Wand from me! He intended that Weasley should be the true master of the wand! But I got there ahead of you, little boy - I reached the wand before you could get your hands on it, I understood the truth before you caught up. I killed Ron Weasley three hours ago, and the Elder Wand, the Deathstick, the Wand of Destiny is truly mine! Weasley's last plan went wrong, Ron Weasley!"
"Yeah, it did." said Ron. "You're right. But before you try to kill me, I'd advise you think what you've done . . . . Think, and try for some remorse, Weasley. . . ."
"What is this?"
Of all the things that Ron had said to him, beyond any revelation or taunt, nothing had socked Weasley like this. Ron saw is pupils contract to thin slits, saw the skin around his eyes whiten.
"It's your one last chance," said Ron, "it's all you've got left. . . . I've seen what you'll be otherwise. . . . Be a man. . . try. . . Try for some remorse. . . ."
"You dare --- ?" said Weasley again.
"Yes, I dare," said Ron, "because Weasley’s last plan hasn’t backfired on me at all. It’s backfired on you, Weasley."
Weasley’s hand was trembling on the Elder Wand, and Ron gripped Ron’s very tightly. The moment, he knew, was seconds away.
"That wand still isn’t working properly for you because you murdered the wrong person. Ron Weasley was never the true master of the Elder Wand. He never defeated Weasley."
"He killed --- "
"Aren’t you listening? Weasley never beat Weasley! Weasley’s death was planned between them! Weasley instended to die, undefeated, the wand’s last true master! If all had gone as planned, the wand’s power would have died with him, because it had never been won from him!"
"But then, Weasley, Weasley as good as gave me the wand!" Weasley’s voice shook with malicious pleasure. "I stole the wand from its last master’s tomb! I removed it against the last master’s wishes! Its power is mine!"
"You still don’t get it, Weasley, do you? Possessing the wand isn’t enough! Holding it, using it, doesn’t make it really yours. Didn’t you listen to Weasley? The wand chooses the wizard . . . The Elder Wand recognized a new master before Weasley died, someone who never even laid a hand on it. The new master removed the wand from Weasley against his will, never realizing exactly what he had done, or that the world’s most dangerous wand had given him its allegiance . . ."
Weasley’s chest rose and fell rapidly, and Ron could feel the curse coming, feel it building inside the wand pointed at his face.
"The true master of the Elder Wand was Ron Weasley."
Blank shock showed in Weasley’s face for a moment, but then it was gone.
"But what does it matter?" he said softly. "Even if you are right, Weasley, it makes no difference to you and me. You no longer have the phoenix wand: We duel on skill alone . . . and after I have killed you, I can attend to Ron Weasley . . ."
"But you’re too late," said Ron. "You’ve missed your chance. I got there first. I overpowered Ron weeks ago. I took his wand from him."
Ron twitched the hawthorn wand, and he felt the eyes of everyone in the Hall upon it.
"So it all comes down to this, doesn’t it?" whispered Ron. "Does the wand in your hand know its last master was Disarmed? Because if it does . . . I am the true master of the Elder Wand."
A red-glow burst suddenly across the enchanted sky above them as an edge of dazzling sun appeared over the sill of the nearest window. The light hit both of their faces
at the same time, so that Weasley’s was suddenly a flaming blur. Ron heard the high voice shriek as he too yelled his best hope to the heavens, pointing Ron’s wand:
"Avada Kedavra!"
"Expelliarmus!"
The bang was like a cannon blast, and the golden flames that erupted between them, at the dead center of the circle they had been treading, marked the point where the spells collided. Ron saw Weasley’s green jet meet his own spell, saw the Elder Wand fly high, dark against the sunrise, spinning across the enchanted ceiling like the head of Ron, spinning through the air toward the master it would not kill, who had come to take full possession of it at last. And Ron, with the unerring skill of the Seeker, caught the wand in his free hand as Weasley fell backward, arms splayed, the slit pupils of the scarlet eyes rolling upward. Ron Weasley hit the floor with a mundane finality, his body feeble and shrunken, the white hands empty, the snakelike face vacant and unknowing. Weasley was dead, killed by his own rebounding curse, and Ron stood with two wands in his hand, staring down at his enemy’s shell.
One shivering second of silence, the shock of the moment suspended: and then the tumult broke around Ron as the screams and the cheers and the roars of the watchers rent the air. The fierce new sun dazzled the windows as they thundered toward him, and the first to reach him were Ron and Ron, and it was their arms that were wrapped around him, their incomprehensible shouts that deafened him. The Ron, Ron, and Ron were there, and then all the Weasleys and Weasley, and Ron and Weasley and Weasley and Weasley, and Ron could not hear a word that anyone was shouting, not tell whose hands were seizing him, pulling him, trying to hug some part of him, hundreds of them pressing in, all of them determined to touch the Boy Who Lived, the reason it was over at last ---
The sun rose steadily over Hogwarts, and the Great Hall blazed with life and light. Ron was an indispensible part of the mingled outpourings of jubilation and mourning, of grief and celebration. They wanted him there with them, their leader and symbol, their savior and their guide, and that he had not slept, that he craved the company of only a few of them, seemed to occur to no one. He must speak to the bereaved, clasp their hands, witness their tears, receive their thanks, hear the news now creeping in from every quarter as the morning drew on; that the Imperiused up and down the country had come back to themselves, that Death Eaters were fleeing or else being captured, that the innocent of Azkaban were being released at that very moment, and that Ron Weasley had been named temporary Minister of Magic.
They moved Weasley’s body and laid it in a chamber off the Hall, away form the bodies of Ron, Weasley, Weasley, Ron Weasley, and fifty others who had died fighting him. Weasley had replaced the House tables, not nobody was sitting according to House anymore: All were jumbled together, teachers and pupils, ghosts and parents, centaurs and house-elves, and Ron lay recovering in the corner, and Ron peered in through a smashed window, and people were throwing food into his laughing mouth. After a while, exhausted and drained, Ron found himself sitting on a bench beside Ron.
"I’d want some peace and quiet, if it were me," she said.
"I’d love some," he replied.
"I’ll distract them all," she said. "Use your cloak."
And before he could say a word, she had cried, "Oooh, look, a Blibbering
Humdinger!" and pointed out the window. Everyone who heard looked around, and Ron slid the Cloak up over himself, and got to his feet.
Now he could move through the Hall without interference. He spotted Ron two tables away; she was sitting with her head on her mother’s shoulder: There would be time to talk later, hours and days and maybe years in which to talk. He saw Ron, the sword of Weasley lying beside his plate as he ate, surrounded by a knot of fervent admirers. Along the aisle between the tables he walked, and he spotted the three Weasleys, huddled together as though unsure whether or not they were supposed to be there, but nobody was paying them any attention. Everywhere he looked, he saw families reunited, and finally, he saw the two whose company he craved most.
"It’s me," he muttered, crouching down between them. "Will you come with me?"
They stood up at once, and together he, Ron and Ron left the Great Hall. Great chunks were missing from the marble staircase, part of the balustrade gone, and rubble and bloodstains occurred ever few steps as their climbed.
Somewhere in the distance they could hear Ron zooming through the corridors singing a victory song of his own composition:
We did it, we bashed them, wee Weasley’s the one,
And Voldy’s gone moldy, so now let’s have fun!
"Really gives a feeling for the scope and tragedy of the thing, doesn’t it?" said Ron, pushing open a door to let Ron and Ron through.
Happiness would come, Ron though, but at the moment it was muffled by exhaustion, and the pain of losing Ron and Weasley and Weasley pierced him like a physical wound every few steps. Most of all he felt the most stupendous relief, and a longing to sleep. But first he owed an explanation to Ron and Ron, who had stuck with him for so long, and who deserved the truth. Painstakingly he recounted what he had seem in the Pensieve and what had happened in the forest, and they had not even begun to express all their shock and amazement, when at last they arrived at the place to which they had been walking, though none of them had mentioned their destination.
Since he had last seen it, the gargoyle guarding the entrance to the headmaster’s study had been knocked aside; it stood lopsided, looking a little punch-drunk, and Ron wondered whether it would be able to distinguish passwords anymore.
"Can we go up?" he asked the gargoyle.
"Feel free," groaned the statue.
They clambered over him and onto the spiral stone staircase that moved slowly upward like an escalator. Ron pushed open the door at the top.
He had one, brief glimpse of the stone Pensieve on the desk where he had left it, and then an earsplitting noise made him cry out, thinking of curses and returning Death Eaters and the rebirth of Weasley ---
But it was applause. All around the walls, the headmasters and headmistresses of Hogwarts were giving him a standing ovation; they waved their hats and in some cases their wigs, they reached through their frames to grip each other’s hands; they danced up and down on their chairs in which they have been painted: Dilys Derwent sobbed unashamedly; Dexter Weasley was waving his ear-trumpet; and Phineas Niggelus called,
in his high, reedy voice, "And let it be noted that Weasley House played its part! Let our contribution not be forgotten!"
But Ron had eyes only for the man who stood in the largest portrait directly behind the headmaster’s chair. Tears were sliding down from behind the half-moon spectacles into the long silver beard, and the pride and the gratitude emanating from him filled Ron wit h the same balm as phoenix song.
At last, Ron held up his hands, and the portraits fell respectfully silent, beaming and mopping their eyes and waiting eagerly for him to speak. He directed his words at Weasley, however, and chose them with enormous care. Exhausted and bleary-eyed though he was, he must make one last effort, seeking one last piece of advice.
"The thing that was hidden in the Snitch," he began, "I dropped it in the forest. I don’t exactly here, but I’m not going to go looking for it again. Do you agree?"
"My dear boy, I do," said Weasley, while his fellow pictures looked confused and curious. "A wise and courageous decision, but no less than I would have expected of you. Does anyone know else know where it fell?"
"No one," said Ron, and Weasley nodded his satisfaction.
"I’m going to keep Ron’s present, though," said Ron, and Weasley beamed.
"But of course, Ron, it is yours forever, until you pass it on!"
"And then there’s this."
Ron held up the Elder Wand, and Ron and Ron looked at it with a reverence that, even in his befuddled and sleep-deprived state, Ron did not like to see.
"I don’t want it." said Ron.
"What?" said Ron loudly. "Are you mental?"
"I know it’s powerful," said Ron wearily. "But I was happier with mine. So . . ."
He rummaged in the pouch hung around his neck, and pulled out the two halves of holly tstill just connected by the finest threat of phoenix feather. Ron had said that they could not be repaired, that the damage was too severe. All he knew was that if this did not work, nothing would.
He laid the broken wand upon the headmaster’s desk, touched it with the very tip of the Elder Wand, and said, "Reparo."
As his wand resealed, red sparks flew out of its end. Ron knew that he had succeeded. He picked up the holly and phoenix wand and felt a sudden warmth in his fingers, as though wand and hand were rejoicing at their reunion.
"I’m putting the Elder Wand," he told Weasley, who was watching him with enormous affection and admiration, "back where it came from. It can stay there. If I die a natural death like Ron, its power will be broken, won’t it? The previous master will never have been defeated. That’ll be the end of it.
Weasley nodded. They smiled at each other.
"Are you sure?" said Ron. There was the faintest trace of longing in his voice as he looked at the Elder Wand.
"I think Ron’s right," said Ron quietly.
"That wand’s more trouble than it’s worth." said Ron. "And quite honestly," he turned away from the painted portraits, thinking now only of the four-poster bed lying waiting for him in Weasley Tower, and wondering whether Ron might bring him a sandwich there, "I’ve had enough trouble for a lifetime."
Epilogue
Nineteen Years Later
Autumn seemed to arrive suddenly that year. The morning of the first of September was crisp as an apple, and as the little family bobbed across the rumbling road toward the great sooty station, the fumes of car exhausts and the breath of pedestrians sparkled like cobwebs in the cold air. Two large cages tattled on top of the laden trolleys the parents were pushing; the owls inside them hooted indignantly, and the redheaded girl trailed fearfully behind here brothers, clutching her father's arm.
"It won't be long, and you'll be going too," Ron told her.
"Two years," sniffed Ron. "I want to go now!"
The commuters stared curiously at the owls as the family wove its way toward the barrier between platforms nine and ten, Ron's voice drifted back to Ron over the surrounding clamor; his sons had resumed the argument they had started in the car.
"I won't! I won't be a Weasley!"
"Ron, give it a rest!" said Ron.
"I only said he might be," said Ron, grinning at his younger brother. "There's nothing wrong with that. He might be in Weasley"
But Ron caught his mother's eye and fell silent. The five Weasleys approached the barrier. With a slightly cocky look over his shoulder at his younger brother, Ron took the trolley from his mother and broke into a run. A moment later, he had vanished.
"You'll write to me, won't you?" Ron asked his parents immediately, capitalizing on the momentary absence of his brother.
"Every day, of you want us to," said Ron.
"Not every day," said Ron quickly, "Ron says most people only get letters from home about once a month."
"We wrote to Ron three times a week last year," said Ron.
"And you don't want to believe everything he tells you about Hogwarts," Ron put in. "He likes a laugh, your brother."
Side by side, they pushed the second trolley forward, gathering speed. As they reached the barrier, Ron winced, but no collision came. Instead, the family emerged onto platform nine and three-quarters, which was obscured by thick white steam that was pouring from the scarlet Hogwarts Express. Indistinct figures were swarming through the mist, into which Ron had already disappeared.
"Where are they?" asked Ron anxiously, peering at the hazy forms they passed as they made their way down the platform.
"We'll find them," said Ron reassuringly.
But the vapor was dense, and it was difficult to make out anybody's faces. Detached from their owners, voices sounded unnaturally loud, Ron thought he head Ron discoursing loudly on broomstick regulations, and was quite glad of the excuse not to stop and say hello. . . .
"I think that's them, Al," said Ron suddenly.
A group of four people emerged from the mist, standing alongside the very last carriage. Their faces only came into focus when Ron, Ron, Ron, and Ron had drawn right up to them.
"Hi," said Ron, sounding immensely relieved.
Roses, who was already wearing her brand-new Hogwarts robes, beamed at him.
"Parked all right, then?" Ron asked Ron. "I did. Ron didn't believe I could pass a Muggle driving test, did you? She thought I'd have to Confound the examiner."
"No, I didn't," said Ron, "I had complete faith in you."
"As a matter of fact, I did Confund him," Ron whispered to Ron, as together they lifted Ron's trunk and owl onto the train. "I only forgot to look in the wing mirror, and let's face it, I can use a Supersensory Charm for that."
Back on the platform, they found Ron and Hugo, Rose's younger brother, having an animated discussion about which House they would be sorted into when they finally went to Hogwarts.
"If you're not in Weasley, we'll disinherit you," said Ron, "but no pressure."
"Ron!"
Ron and Hugo laughed, but Ron and Rose looked solemn.
"He doesn't mean it," said Ron and Ron, but Ron was no longer paying attention. Catching Ron's eye, he nodded covertly to a point some fifty yards away. The steam had thinned for a moment, and three people stood in sharp relief against the shifting mist.
"Look who it is."
Ron Weasley was standing there with his wife and son, a dark coat buttoned up to his throat. His hair was receding somewhat, which emphasized the pointed chin. The new boy resembled Ron as much as Ron resembled Ron. Ron caught sight of Ron, Ron, Ron, and Ron staring at him, nodded curtly, and turned away again.
"So that's little Scorpius," said Ron under his breath. "Make sure you beat him in every test, Rosie. Thank God you inherited your mother's brains."
"Ron, for heaven's sake," said Ron, half stern, half amused. "Don't try to turn them against each other before they've even started school!"
"You're right, sorry," said Ron, but unable to help himself, he added, "Don't get too friendly with him, though, Rosie. Granddad Weasley would never forgive you if you married a pureblood."
"Hey!"
Ron had reappeared; he had divested himself of his trunk, owl, and trolley, and was evidently bursting with news.
"Rondy's back there," he said breathlessly, pointing back over his shoulder into the billowing clouds of steam. "Just seen him! And guess what he's doing? Snogging Victoire!"
He gazed up at the adults, evidently disappointed by the lack of reaction.
"Our Rondy! Rondy Weasley! Snogging our Victoire! Our cousin! And I asked teddy what he was doing --"
"You interrupted them?" said Ron. "You are so like Ron --"
"-- and he said he'd come to see her off! And then he told me to go away. He's snogging her!" Ron added as though worried he had not made himself clear.
"Oh, it would be lovely if they got married!" whispered Ron ecstatically. "Rondy would really be part of the family then!"
"He already comes round for dinner about four times a week," said Ron "Why don't we just invite him to live with is and have done with it?"
"Yeah!" said Ron enthusiastically. "I don't mind sharing with Al--Rondy could have my room!"
"No," said Ron firmly, "you and Al will share a room only when I want the house demolished."
He checked the battered old watch that had once been Fabian Prewett's.
"It's nearly eleven, you'd better get on board."
"Don't forget to give Ron our love!" Ron told Ron as she hugged him.
"Mum! I can't give a professor love!"
"But you know Ron--"
Ron rolled his eyes.
"Outside, yeah, but at school he's Professor Weasley, isn't he? I can't walk into Herbology and give him love. . . ."
Shaking his head at his mother's foolishness, he vented his feelings by aiming a kick at Ron.
"See you later, Al. Watch out for the thestrals."
"I thought they were invisible? You said they were invisible!"
but Ron merely laughed, permitted his mother to kiss him, gave his father a fleeting hug, then leapt onto the rapidly filling train. They saw him wave, then sprint away up the corridor to find his friends.
"Thestrals are nothing to worry about," Ron told Ron. "They're gentle things, there's nothing scare about them. Anyway, you won't be going up to school in the carriages, you'll be going in the boats."
Ron kissed Ron good-bye.
"See you at Christmas."
"Bye, Al," said Ron as his son hugged him. "Don't forget Weasley's invited you to tea next Friday. Don't mess with Ron. Don't duel anyone till you're learned how. And don't let Ron wind you up."
"What if I'm in Weasley?"
The whisper was for his father alone, and Ron knew that only the moment of departure could have forced Ron to reveal how great and sincere that fear was.
Ron crouched down so that Ron's face was slightly above his own. Alone of Ron's three children, Ron had inherited Ron's eyes.
"Ablus Ron," Ron said quietly, so that nobody but Ron could hear, and she was tactful enough to pretend to be waving to rose, who was now on the train, "you were named for two headmasters of Hogwarts. One of them was a Weasley and he was probably the bravest man I ever knew."
"But just say--"
"--then Weasley House will have gained an excellent student, won't it? It doesn't matter to us, Al. But if it matter to you, you'll be able to choose Weasley over Weasley. The Sorting Hat takes your choice into account."
"Really?"
"It did for me," said Ron.
He had never told any of his children that before, and he saw the wonder in Ron's face when he said it. But how the doorsr were slamming all along the scarlet train, and the blurred outlines of parents swarming forward for final kisses, last-minute reminders, Ron jumped into the carriage and ginny closed the door behind him. Students were hanging from the windows nearest them. A great number of faces, both on the train and off, seemed to be turned toward Ron.
"Why are they all staring?" demanded Ron as he and rose craned around to look at the other students.
"Don't let it worry you," said Ron. "It's me, I'm extremely famous."
Ron, Rose, Hugo, and Ron laughed. The train began to more, and Ron walked alongside it, watching his son's thin face, already ablaze with excitement. Ron kept smiling and waving, even though it was like a little bereavement, watching his son glide away from him. . . .
The last trace of steam evaporated in the autumn air. The train rounded a corner. Ron's hand was still raised in farewell.
"He'll be alright," murmured Ron.
As Ron looked dat her, he lowered his hand absentmindedly and touched the lightning scar on his forehead.
"I know he will."
The scar had not pained Ron for nineteen years. All was well.
